Th mechanics are actually engaging, and the game does not limit you in your "magic" usage. The graphics and the whole atmosphere are really good, exceedign any expectations. The enemies vary slightly, and the game difficulty progresses very smoothly.

Now, unfortunately, this game has a story. A very convoluted, insane plot that somehow leads (without any spoilers here) to a conclusion you do not expect... understand or like even. Why does it happen? Elizabeth answers a similar question with "It just does". For me it means that whoever wrote it did not understand it either. Rather, they understood what needs to happen in the end, but did not entirely understand how to lead to it and explain it.

BioShock Infinite, developed by Irrational Games and published by 2K Games, is a tour de force that elevates the first-person shooter genre to new heights, both literally and metaphorically. Released in 2013, this installment in the BioShock series is a breathtaking journey that seamlessly weaves an intricate narrative, stunning visuals, and innovative gameplay into a masterpiece that leaves a lasting impression. The game introduces players to Booker DeWitt, a former Pinkerton agent with a troubled past, who is tasked with rescuing a mysterious young woman named Elizabeth from the floating city of Columbia. Set against the backdrop of an alternate-reality America in the early 20th century, Columbia is a marvel of design, a city suspended in the clouds that feels both fantastical and eerily plausible. The narrative of BioShock Infinite is a gripping tale that explores complex themes such as American exceptionalism, racism, and the consequences of unchecked power. The relationship between Booker and Elizabeth is central to the story, and it unfolds in a way that is both emotionally resonant and thought-provoking. The game's plot is filled with twists and turns, keeping players on the edge of their seats until the final, mind-bending conclusion. The world-building in BioShock Infinite is nothing short of extraordinary. Columbia is a living, breathing city with a vibrant atmosphere, diverse locales, and a rich history that players can unravel through various audio logs and environmental storytelling. The attention to detail is remarkable, creating a world that feels both fantastical and deeply rooted in its own lore. Gameplay in BioShock Infinite is a dynamic mix of traditional first-person shooter mechanics and unique elements that set it apart from its peers. The introduction of the skyhook, a grappling hook that allows players to traverse the city's skyline, adds a vertical dimension to combat that is exhilarating and fluid. The combination of gunplay, vigors (special powers), and Elizabeth's AI companion abilities results in a combat system that is both strategic and satisfying. The audio and visual elements of BioShock Infinite contribute significantly to its immersive experience. The music, composed by Garry Schyman, complements the period setting while enhancing the emotional impact of key moments. The art direction, with its blend of steampunk aesthetics and American nostalgia, creates a visual spectacle that is both beautiful and haunting. While some may argue that the gameplay can be occasionally repetitive, the strength of BioShock Infinite lies in its ability to seamlessly merge storytelling and gameplay into a cohesive and unforgettable experience. The game's thought-provoking narrative, combined with its stunning design and innovative gameplay, cements its status as a modern classic.

In conclusion, BioShock Infinite is a triumph of storytelling and game design, offering a captivating experience that transcends the boundaries of the medium. Its exploration of complex themes, coupled with its breathtaking world and gameplay innovations, make it a must-play for anyone seeking a truly memorable gaming experience. BioShock Infinite is not just a game; it's a work of art that will leave a lasting imprint on those fortunate enough to embark on its sky-high journey.

Bioshock Infinite as a game is a complete package of what a first person shooter should be . Set in the early 1950s with the backdrop of Rapture on land and at sea, this game oozes a lot of scenic beauty blended in with the retro 50s music which suits its style.The game has a lot going for it with its unique artstyle , intriguing storyline with plots and twists and slick gameplay. 

The story is what makes Bioshock different with Ken Levine's direction really adding a lot of meat to it. I wouldn't get into much of the story, but I would say that if you play it a couple of times you will know what I am talking. Further, there are YouTube videos which dive deep into the  story tying out certain loose ends. I, for one, am going to watch these videos to understand Bioshock Infinite, not just in a nutshell, but as a complete storybook.

The music is quite good with the enervating feeling of birds chirping, stalls selling stuff and the pristine beaches with waves slapping against the sand to the nervy unsettling and eerie music being in Rapture City infested with splicers and psychopaths. Yes, these psychopaths are more in the story and in the DLCs, so please be warned . I would suggest stocking up on medkits and tranquilizer darts with your very own tried and trusted guns. 

The gameplay , as discussed before , is quite good and it continues with the subsequent DLCs. To me, DLC 1 was great as it gives you innovative ways of playing the game. You can go guns blazing or sneak in like an assassin just like in the Dishonored or Thief series. This , to me , does justice  to the main game which incorporates the same. 

However, DLC 2 doesnt do the game justice as its focussed solely on stealth which brought its downfall. I would only hope they brought in the same gameplay elements of DLC 1 which could have sped the progress of DLC 2. This DLC is a slow one (i.e anaemic)  as you sneak past enemies and ahem, the Big Daddy , as well to try to complete tasks. I ama person who likes to go guns blazing and I had to replay levels just for the simple reason that I was caught with my pants down by one of the splicers . :)

The challenge missions are a pallette cleanser as they test your skills with a number of weapons and challenges to sink your teeth in. Overall, I could see why there was no sequel to the Bioshock franchise solely because of DLC 2 which didnt stick to the basics of what Bioshock has and will always be. The lack of innovative mechanisms, paucity of choices and the short story took a number of hardcore gamers away. 

Do not mistake me while you read this post. Its a great game  as a whole. But this DLC gets a 6/10 as the story was short with no twists coupled with a sneakfest of a gameplay. However, Bioshock Infinite gets a 9/10 as it really is so good to play even today and forever. We do need a sequel to Bioshock Infinite which I hope it sees the light of day.

TL;DR - This game was a solid, average game. In this respect it fell far short of its designers' reputation and abilities.

A note on timing: I played this game in April 2015, two years after it was first released. I put it down for five months and returned to it in Sept. 2015 to see if the passage of time had given me any new insights, and still disliked it. Finally I loaded it up in Feb. 2024 and completed it after watching Youtube guides to get me past the bits I couldn't do.

My final verdict is that this game is far weaker than its two precursors and features lazy "quantum physics did it!" handwaving to explain its creaky plot holes. Having finally completed it with a fair bit of resentment, I believe it is not worth completing another time and I'm on the fence about whether it was even worth completing the first time. The sort of game that might be worth watching through on Youtube before putting down the money to buy it.

Below are the issues I had:

1. Weapon selection is limited. Or more specifically, you're limited to carrying around two weapons at any one time. This is still okay with the standard mooks, but the boss fights can be frustrating if you brought the wrong tools for the job.

2. If mook fights are too easy (which I found they are), boss fights are too hard. It's sort of all right, because the game gives you a respawn auto option. This sort of compensates for the obligatory deaths from damage while you're still figuring out the level geometry, but there isn't really much chance to investigate much into the mechanics. Some funky effects do happen, but I had to look them up in walkthroughs because standard combat is so frenetic that you don't get much chance to really think about what happened.

3. Level design merely appears to be open. In actuality, once you look beyond the open-air backdrops, the actual walkable areas are still linear. There's some gymnastic potential with some of the boss battles, but as I mentioned above, I found I was dying too often to really enjoy exploring them.

4. The scope of philosophical inquiry in this game seemed much more subdued than SS2 or the BS1/2 games. Instead of thought-provoking questions about collectivism vs. individuality, Irrational Games gave us some alt-history, some speculative fiction, and a passing look at religious zealotry and a vague mystery of the holy uterus. This is probably unavoidable with the change in focus of the game - there are very few non-combat challenges in the game when you're not shooting or hurting something.

5. After programming in hard-coded fanservice cleavage that literally follows you around the entire game, it struck me as a bit disingenuous of Irrational to scold its fans for making Rule 34 artwork. They were sort of asking for it.

Not a terrible game, but not as inspiring as its predecessors. I'm not sure why. Irrational used to make great games.

BioShock Infinite was a game I genuinely wanted to enjoy, drawn in by its captivating style and setting, which are undoubtedly the highlights. Despite this, I found myself unable to finish it. Beyond the initial allure, the game didn't manage to hold my attention. Its scale felt lacking, and I struggled to feel connected to the characters. While the gameplay was smooth, it didn't offer anything novel, leaving me feeling underwhelmed amidst the anticipation for a return to the BioShock universe. The surrounding hype raised my expectations, only to leave me wanting more from the experience. Given these points, I find it hard to recommend BioShock Infinite to others now, as it didn't live up to the expectations set by its predecessors or its initial presentation.

The gameplay and atmosphere are great, both are way better than the previous two titles. The writing is... just, no. If you just wanna turn your brain off and mindlessly shoot it's a perfectly fine game but this story is atrocious compared to the previous two games.

Bioshock Infinite: where you go for a lovely sky-high jaunt in a floating city and end up in a twisted sci-fi version of American history class gone wrong. This game is like taking a rollercoaster through a steampunk fever dream with a side of existential crisis.

You play as Booker DeWitt, a guy with such a murky past he could give a soap opera character a run for their money. Booker's mission? Find a girl named Elizabeth who can open tears in reality. Yeah, it's as bonkers as it sounds. She's basically a human Swiss Army knife of spacetime. Need a weapon? Boom, she tears one in. Need cover? Bam, she tears in a wall. Accidentally tear in a 1980s rock band during a firefight? Oops, but also, kinda cool?

The city of Columbia is a floating paradise filled with Americana turned up to 11, where the locals are about as friendly as a hornet's nest and twice as chatty. You'll be floating around on sky-lines, which is basically like riding the world's most dangerous rollercoaster while people shoot at you. Fun times!

And let's not forget the big daddy of this game (pun intended), the story. It's like a philosophy book and a conspiracy theory had a love child. Just when you think you've got it all figured out, the game hits you with a plot twist so wild, you'll need a moment to just sit there and question your entire existence.

In summary, Bioshock Infinite is a wild, mind-bending adventure that's part shooter, part existential road trip. It's a game that doesn't just break the mould; it throws the mould out of a floating city and watches it plummet to the earth below. 10/10 would question reality again.

Likes:
Columbia
Set pieces
Lutece Twins


dislikes:
weapons:
-can only carry two guns meaning much less choice
-only worth upgrading guns you use and only really worth going for damage upgrades
-no alternate ammo types so even less choice
-a lot of guns suck so why bother with them
-much less niche to guns, choice comes down to what damage type do you like the most?/what is your play style?

vigors (this games plasmids):
-a lot of the vigors are functionally very similar
-don't get to choose what vigors are equipped, they just are all at once

management aspects:
-now there is only one currency which you have to buy both vigor and weapon upgrades with
-lock picks are the only new management aspect and by the end of the game you will have well over what you need.
-Elizabeth, the npc that follows you around, will just toss coins and lock picks at you making the discovery of these resources less satisfying.
-never bought ammo in my play through from a vendor because enemies either dropped a lot of my ammo type or I would just switch guns for a short period
-can't carry health or salt so you don't have to spend money stocking up and just have to dig around for supplies.

Exploration:
-everything is so linear so there isn't much exploration to do other than unlock doors with lock picks
-no more free weapon upgrade machines
-only thing really worth finding are more lock picks, money, and health/shield/salt upgrades (which only the salt upgrade felt like it made a difference both functionally and visually)

Combat:
-enemies are no where near as interesting as first two games, only exception would probably be mechanized patriot
-why have a shield? why? it's a step backwards to having to manage health packs and just feels like another stat they wanted to throw in. Really just there to make bioshock more like Halo.
-no camera or item to research enemies, meaning less strategy to encounters
-rarely passive enemies and even then, the game is so linear that you are just going to fight them soon anyways.
-One of the bossfights really sucks.
-ending fight wasn't impressive, didn't even realize it was the final fight till a little while later.

Story(all of this can be considered spoilers):
[spoiler]
-While I love the Luteces and can see some charm in Elizabeth, both Elizabeth and Booker are idiots.
-How Columbia functions all seems half baked, it is made out to be a society filled with cultists following their prophet Comstock, but everyone just seems like regular people, living their lives. Edit: I forgot about the one part in the beginning in the game where there is a racist cult thing going on, but it was so short and nothing really happened here so I forgot about it.
-Bioshock infinite... has rascism? it doesn't make much sense. Irish and black people are lower class workers doing all the dirty jobs, but they still get the choice to move to Columbia. Why would any of them move? Ah yes, we will go from an America where racism and segregation is mainly going on in half of the country to Columbia where racism and segregation is throughout all of it AND it's also led by a giant nutcase cult leader.
-Not to mention all of the discriminated people live in shantytown, a run down part of Columbia. How did this happen? This obviously wasn't the intention because the sign was painted over. If this part of Columbia was initially a more beautiful part, why would they move people here that couldn't take care of the property? Why didn't they put them in barracks or smaller houses so that everything doesn't look rundown and the workers are at least living in a clean space, maybe if they did this they wouldn't have had a revolution against them.
-Gives no idea of how leadership actually works in Columbia, does Colmstock actually run everything? What are the laws? If it is all one big cult why isn't it more authoritarian? If it was democracy were the black and Irish people hoping for civil rights?
-Why did America even fund this project if the whole thing was to be controlled by a cult leader that said he was a prophet within Christianity? While America might have been more Christian back then, they would have denounced Comstock because Jesus literally said there will be no more prophets.
-Why did they introduce timeline hopping? It literally destroyed all stakes. Why didn't they just hop into a timeline where Columbia was just a nice place with no cultists, no racism, and no fighting? How is the audience supposed to care about what happens in every single timeline? Human minds can't comprehend or emphasize with concepts that big. 
-What was the purpose of killing Booker at his baptism? To kill Comstock? what about any timeline where something different happened before the baptism? There would literally be an infinite amount of things that could have been different. Yet the creators decided to explain it away with "constants and variables". The spiderverse did something similar with its "canon events" but this worked way better because it was similarities across multiverses, not branching timelines. Not to mention the whole "Killing your parent kills yourself" trope is stupid, this doesn't make you disappear because if you were the one to kill your parent but this also means you don't exist, then you could have never killed your parent. This wouldn't make you disappear, this would make all of time freeze or implode on itself.
[/spoiler]

I'm perfectly fine with disregarding this entry from the Bioshock series. It has stripped itself of fun mechanics to appeal to a different audience; it has plenty of questionable design choices; and the story is made for midwits who think that you have to be smart to understand the story when really if you think harder the entire story falls apart and seems like they made it up as they were going.

On a STEEP discount sure get the game otherwise don't bother.

-Besides graphics the game is a downgrade in every possible way compared to Bioshock 1&2,the weapons are meh, the powers are meh, and the story is absolute piss.
-Say goodbye to having you weapons CHANGE as you upgrade them. I cannot stress enough how BORING this makes upgrading everything. Now it's just numbers you don't notice and nothing changes.
-The lack of a sodding manual save infuriates me. And on top of that the auto save doesn't occur at set times but happens at the beginning of each level so you either have to finish it or suffer an RESET OF THE ENTIRE LEVEL! What idiot though that was a good idea?
-I just cannot impress enough just how shit the auto save in this game is. I can't even sodding tell WHEN the game is saving!
-There are SO MANY WEAPONS and 1/2 of them are the SAME GUNS BUT RED.
-This game went from alt history psyco first person shooter that explored some really interesting concepts, to "industrial era America but in the sky and more racist and with time travel"....... To the surprise of no one this  story is NOT unique, compelling or interesting at all, and to top it off all the characters are nothing more than extreme caricatures. 
-The potential ramifications of traveling through the rips and opening them at all is MOOT because you are REQUIRED to use them to progress the game.... You don't get a choice and the characters become EXTREMELY flippant with just doing it all the time without a second thought. 
-The first 2 games are about CHOICE and the ABILITY to make your own choices and live with the different paths those choices will take you. This game just shits all over that and just says "JK actually you don't have a choice and you never did. You were always set on this path and we won't let you make any choices that matter unless they take you down the path we want"

To say I was disappointed with how the 3rd game turned out is beyond an understatement.

Boasting stunning graphics that still hold up over a decade later, BioShock Infinite serves up an enthralling adventure in a short but sweet game with fun combat and movement mechanics. However, it has to be stated that the story it tells might seem convoluted to some, with an ending that might confuse players more than it ties up loose ends. In addition, it appears that there might be some bugs that remain in the game even now that could force players to restart certain areas if encountered. Altogether, in spite of a few nitpicks here and there, I still believe that BioShock Infinite remains a worthy addition to both the BioShock family and your steam library.

Bioshock Infinite: Head or tails?

There's something mildly damning about Bioshock Infinite and the whole franchise when its cultural legacy for the last few years has been either revisiting Bioshock 1 or Burial at Sea's kickstarting of the entire micro-industry of SFM porn with model rips of Elizabeth. A decade ago, this game was part of a pillar erected by gaming journalists trying to vie for the idea that games were art, and always leaning on A or AA games for it. Because they're hacks. This, Spec Ops: The Line and Life Is Strange were the easy hits for some literal-who article writer to say were challenging the gaming paradigm. Just as GamerGate picked up steam, Irrational leaned on Bioshock: Infinite and pumped out as many DLC's as it could to ride that wave. That and also purging most of the staff outside of Levine and a core group of devs who haven't done much in a decade. Thank you Take-Two, you really are the worst.

With the recent revival of interest in System Shock, it's painted Bioshock as a franchise and Infinite especially in a odd light. Bioshock has always felt like Irrational Games trying to recapture that same lightning in a bottle, and with varying results. And Infinite feels like the game that's trying to break the bottle and move on, and fails to do so. The game tries its best to reinvent every basic mechanic you've come to expect from a Bioshock game and spin it on its head, and instead ends up muting what you do like and replacing it with things you don't. 

The combat is neat until you realize that it's basically just Bioshock 1 with less punchy weapons and a movement mechanic the game barely uses. Sky-Lines were this game's bread and butter for advertising back then but you rarely get to use them for anything beyond bipping out of combat encounters, dragging yourself to the next combat arena or the odd enemy takedown. Once you're on the ground, it's the same shoot/spam vigors you've come to expect. And the game pallidly shrugging its shoulders with that makes it worse. Vigors being glorified plasmids from Bioshock 1 is one thing, but it nullifies what made plasmids and Bioshock 1's plot work. It's a plasmid except with no consequences. Which is the best short hand statement for what Bioshock: Infinite as a game is.

It's Bioshock 1 without consequences or proper pacing. It's spinning the formula enough that you don't notice the wizard behind the curtain, because the second you do, you're screwed. You're in fact Andrew Ryan from this dimension fighting against Andrew Ryan from ANOTHER dimension and the Little Sister you've been saving has been the Little Sister you sold years ago. And in the end you have to brain yourself with a golf club. The fact this game's positive reviews always to a tee mention "wanting to replay this game with no memory" tells you all you need to know. The twist of Infinite is not that deep, and the second you get the faintest hint of it, you're done. You know every punch this game is going to pull and nothing will solve that. All the while the game is leaning on the worst possible trope to pull that off. 

Dimensional chicanery and time travel would be neat if it wasn't in service of trying to make some greater Bioshock mythos. But this game forces it to try and tie Columbia to Rapture and in doing so, take them both down to the bottom of the sea. A stretched metaphor? Absolutely, Irrational knew that when they made two DLC's out of it.

In boiling down Bioshock's tropes to the basics, Irrational made a Bioshock game that feels the least like a Bioshock game. Crawl from arena to arena to open world-ish area and buy non-descript upgrades to your peashooters while using any of the game's features a whole five times. Enjoy the ever present fun of combat with the only interesting bit of it being using Elizabeth as an ammo generator and casting Testicular Torsion on random enemies. Read random audio logs that spoon feed you the twist 12 hours before it's supposed to happen and try to resist eating wallpaper paste for the better experience that'd be. Good work Mr. Levine, I can tell why you weren't lead writer for all of the good Looking Glass and Irrational Games. Because if you were, Thief would've ended with Garrett letting Victoria drown him for defeating the Trickster God.
Great game. Super easy to pick back up and its long enough to enjoy the story but short enough that replaying the story does not feel like a chore.

This game is extremly aware of human history and how it all depends on perspective, history is always written by the victors.

(SMALL SPOILER AHEAD)

Playing in a superficial utopia which soon turns out to be a flatout dystopia, heavily reminding me of germany around the second world war or america before the civil war but also unfortunately reminding me of more recent events around the world, which makes it appear like we aren't able to learn out of our history. This game is unbelievable close to reality and tells alot about human behaviour, especially the century long dispute about "us" vs. "them", "bread & games" and "divide & conquer". 

The first person shooter mechanics are nothing new, you've got basically the same array of weapons you've got in other games of that type, but playing on hard difficulty makes it less of a repetitive task. What really pissed me off though was the back tracking, I really don't want to backtrack for some more or less useful equipment, where the majority of it is not beneficial for the play-through, so I stopped backtracking and just finished with the story and it was worth it, but the backtracking really killed the flow of it a couple of times, if you're playing on lower difficulty I really recommend you not to backtrack to open some kind of chest, most of the times it's really not worth it and the navigation help system is garbage, way too often it just makes you keep going circles.

The game is great and the story is amazing, for being released more than 10 years ago now, it hasn't really aged at all, if you're late to the party just like me, I'd definitely recommend you to play this, it's worth even just for the story, especially when it's on discount and atleast usually all bioshock games are on discount whenever there are steam sales.

I am still wondering if the main character is somewhat an homage to shutter island.

Edit: The ending was incredible and deeper than you'll ever think, I'm mind blown and in love, aswell as extremly intrigued by the bioshock universe! Great job, amazing game! Gunplay and game mechanics get quite repetitive at mid-end game but after watching a behind the scenes it's understandable, the devs were ahead of their time and just didn't have the recources and developing time they needed. Buy it whenever it's on sale, for 10-20€ it's definitely worth playing for the story alone. (9.2/10)

This is not just a game; first and foremost, it's a work of art, a masterpiece. Even the most elaborate words fall short in describing this piece. From its intricate graphic design to the seamless flow of the linear shooter, and above all, its captivating narrative, it's like a love story that woos, engulfs, and consumes you. This game, including its two predecessors, is an unparalleled experience that everyone must undergo.

From a storytelling perspective, it possesses the most unconventional and non-cliché narrative, even surpassing AAA games. It stands out as a rare gem that brought tears to my eyes in the end. Like a life story that forcefully slaps you with the harsh consequences of the decisions we make, it's a flawless 10/10 experience without any shortcomings. This is a journey that every individual must encounter, a narrative that transcends language barriers and deserves to be felt by all.

[h1]“Sky-High Expectations with a Side of Vertigo”[/h1]

[h2]Intro: Soaring High but Hitting Some Turbulence[/h2]

Bioshock Infinite is like going on a rollercoaster that's supposed to take you through history, but halfway through, you realize it's just a fancy merry-go-round. The game is a visual feast set in the floating city of Columbia, where the buildings are more uplifting than the storyline. Get ready for a sky-high adventure that occasionally forgets it's not tethered to the ground.

[h2]“Eye Candy in the Sky: A Graphics Gala”[/h2]

Graphically, Bioshock Infinite is like attending a Gatsby party in the sky – everything is dazzling and over-the-top. Columbia is a place where you'll spend half your time gawking at the scenery and the other half wondering if you accidentally walked onto a movie set. Astounding design? Check. Reality? Questionable.

[h2]“A Story That Almost Sticks the Landing”[/h2]

The plot is as compelling as a soap opera set in an alternate universe. It's got twists, drama, and a mind-blowing ending that will leave you more confused than trying to solve a Rubik's cube in the dark. The characters are well-fleshed out, forging relationships that feel about as real as your chances of actually visiting a floating city. 

[h2]“Shoot, Fly, Repeat: Gameplay in the Clouds”[/h2]

Shooting in Bioshock Infinite is sharper than a tack – if the tack was attached to a semi-automatic weapon. Combat is so engaging it almost makes you forget you're essentially on a very violent sightseeing tour. And don't worry about combat fatigue; the game keeps it as fresh as Columbia's apparently limitless supply of ammunition.

[h2]“Sounds Like Heaven, Quirks Like Hell”[/h2]

The sound design is an auditory delight, perfectly blending gunfire with a soundtrack that's more immersive than a 4D movie. But watch out for those occasional quirks and contrivances that disrupt the immersion like an out-of-place tourist in your perfect vacation photo.

[h2]Verdict[/h2]

[b]Graphics: 8/10[/b]
Columbia is a visual spectacle that might make you wish you lived in a postcard.

[b]Sound: 8/10[/b]
A soundscape so good, you'd swear you were actually soaring through the clouds.

[b]Gameplay: 6.5/10[/b]
Razor-sharp shooting in a world that's sometimes too sharp for its own good.

[b]Story: 6/10[/b]
A compelling tale that tries to juggle too much and ends up dropping a few balls.

[b]Overall: 7.1/10[/b]

[h2]Closing Thoughts: “A Flight of Fancy That Sometimes Forgets to Fly”[/h2]

Bioshock Infinite is like that dream where you're flying – exhilarating at first, but then you start to wonder why everyone's speaking in riddles. It's a journey that's both awe-inspiring and slightly puzzling, like finding a hidden gem that turns out to be cubic zirconia. Remember, even in the most beautiful of skies, sometimes you have to come down for a reality check.

[h1] TLDR: 8.5/10 An amazing yet flawed end to one of the most iconic and award-worthy franchises of all time. [/h1]

[h3] Actual Review (No Spoilers) [/h3]
A modern twist on what made Bioshock 1&2 special. Infinite is definitely more of an action shooter than BS1&2, but thanks to a streamlined gameplay system and a stellar story, Infinite continues to stand the test of time a decade later - even for a new player like me.

[h3] Story [/h3]
The story (while majorly confusing) ties up the series pretty nicely and will keep you thinking about it long after you stop playing. I can't really say much about it because everything major is heavy spoiler territory, but just know that you will most likely be more emotionally moved on your second playthrough once you understand what's actually going on beneath the surface. I think the game is carried a little by the story, as I find the gameplay having some missed potential. Even still, the setting allows for some really creative ways to play the game. BS1 still manages to be the better game overall, gameplay wise I'd say they're on par, however they are two different types of gunplay so you can't really compare them directly. BS2 still reigns supreme in that department however.

[h3] Gameplay [/h3]
And speaking of gameplay, Infinite also is pretty refined and is even more streamlined and boiled down to it's core elements with very little bloat, almost to the detriment of the game however. There is definitely places where it lacks and there's also areas that feel like they have missed potential. Weapons for example have defined rolls but the amount of them kinda muddies the water and there is a lot of bleed over. There's also a couple weapons that are just bad and have better options (something that BS2 avoids) Infinite also adopts the two weapon system other action games have - which works for how the game is balanced, but I feel like they could have kept a version of the previous games' weapon system, it breaks away from the Bioshock mold too much IMO and just stifles a lot of the sandbox-style combat. The plasmids however (vigors in this game) are all still fairly unique, while admittedly holding less power for experimenting compared to BS1&2. A lot of them are just an attack and then being able to set it as a trap. There are a few different combos you can pull off but most of them aren't that useful or have a unique effect. There is also thankfully NO researching of enemies anymore and you just upgrade weapons and vigors to keep up with the increasing difficulty.

There are also four different difficulties and honestly, none of them were truly difficult. My first playthrough was on medium and there were some really tough sections because of my lack of knowledge, but on my second playthrough I cranked it up all the way and had an easier time than before thanks to prior knowledge. Enemies are tankier and do more damage and that's about it. The AI isn't particularly hard and the only really hard fights are the ones with either little cover (which rarely happen), or you happen to have weapons that aren't effective for that situation.

[h3] DLC & Achievements [/h3]
Now to talk about the DLCs, I know they are very divisive story wise, but I've kinda learned to look past the shortcomings because what we got is an incredibly interesting and emotionally climactic story that ties into the first game and offers different toys to play with than the base game. Clash in the Clouds however? Here's where I have some issues.

CitC is an arena DLC with a nice progression system that spans all 4 arenas. It's great.....if you aren't trying to achievement hunt. Every achievement in the game is not hard to do, you just have to put in the time and it will take a maximum of two playthroughs per campaign. The one and only stupid and grindy achievement is getting all 60 blue ribbons in CitC. The biggest reason why? Aside from some of them relying basically on RNG, There is NO WAY to replay specific rounds out of the 15 per arena. Meaning if you're stuck on getting a ribbon from a later round, sucks for you because you have to replay the entire arena up to that point every single time. This achievement is truly awful and there is a reason its the rarest one in the whole game.

[h3] Conclusion [/h3]
But putting CitC aside, the overall package of Bioshock Infinite is one of amazing quality, worth full price and then some. It's an excellent way to wrap up a revolutionary trilogy that I have no doubt will be one of those games that you'll remember fondly for years to come. 8.5/10

* Pros
+ Elizabeth is very good companion and very likable character
+ Art direction is great
+ City in the Sky is cool mirror to Rapture from the previous titles
+ Sky line riding is a neat spectacle

* Cons
- Story thinks it is profound and it just isn't
- Booker's character is as flat as a plank until the end
- Combat isn't very satisfying
- You can only carry two weapons
- Plasmids don't really help much in combat (I honestly only used three of them)
- The whole game had so much potential in so many aspects
- The game can be very easy in some parts or insanely hard in others
- A boss that kept spawning enemies, can move around very fast, and is all around annoying
- Dying has no real penalty (you only lose a little money and gain health back)
- Did not need to be a Bioshock game, it would of been a little better if it was its own IP

Overall: 5/10 Average

I am a 45 -year -old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father raising my son, who is now 14 years old. My son won this game from his uncle, so we installed him on his computer and he started playing. Until the end of the week he had 24 hours in this game. This was horrible for me, because it was hard to find ways to spend time with my son, because he is always with friends or just watching Youtube. So I decided to do a Steam account and get this game to see if I could play beside him. I bought the game, chose my skin and world and started playing, but I was stuck in what you should do. I asked my son for help and he organized a game for me to participate. I loved it, because it was the best time I spent with my son since my wife died. Since then, this game has approached me and my son again and now we spend time together away from home as well. This game reminded me that there is fun in everything, and I brought many happy memories to me and my son.

While i wasn't looking forward to this game at the start, the more and more i played, the more and more i enjoyed my time with it. 

The Story is well told with little pieces of information being spread out through the runtime which allows the played to fit the pieces together at a well paced rate. The characters are decent with Booker and Elizabeth being a pretty good duo. I also really like the themes of religion and time travel being integral parts of the story; really fitting in with the whole Bioshock aesthetic.

The Setting of Columbia is just incredible. I don't know what it is about this development team but they really know how to make a creative and lived in world full of wonder. There were moments where i just stood there and took in the atmosphere of this 1920's sky world that was in front of me.

Visually, its a stunning game and it goes to show how a great art direction can carry a game for years. Performance was a bit janky to say the least. There would be moments where areas would be laggy, npc's clothing would just boomerang and there would be points where i would be stopped in my tracks while moving. Apart from that, there wasn't any bugs or crashes that ruined the game. Art Direction as i just said is fantastic and everything was just a cite to see, even for a game that came out from 2013.

Sound and Audio are also fantastic with the soundtrack containing may tense pieces as well as 20's music to even stuff like barber quartets adding to the atmosphere. Audio is perfect for guns, enemies etc.

In terms of gameplay, it might look simple but it can get fun real quick. There's a variety of guns to choose one with each being as fun to use as the other. The abilities are probably some of my favourite parts of the combat with each one having its own effect and allows the player to mix and match with new way to take down enemies. Speaking of enemies, there are your normal classes such as melee, shooter and heavy foes, but there are some nice additions such as the crow men (i don'y know their official name) and the mechanical presidents (yeah you heard me) that spice up the fights quite nicely. Elizabeth's tears are also quite useful with each one giving the player an advantage to take on the hordes of enemies. The vendors for upgrade and buying items are also pretty nice to use and fit the environments quite nicely. Debt. Debt is the main focus of the narrative of this game both financial and metaphorical, but I won't go into spoilers, but I hope those who have played the game agree with what I mean!

The game is quite beautiful visually and holds up really well even these days from the real damn hard work that they've done when making this game. However, much like rapture, it too has it's own problems revealed later on with the corruption and revolution not far away.

The concept was certainly very different, being a far more religious-based situation with regards to how Comstock and his followers deify the founding fathers. Buying into the worst of their bigotry and classism. They game has Vigors instead of Plasmids, but often act the same, but have some new abilities too like releasing crows and such. You play as a PI, down on his luck and owing money to the point that he's been offered this one job to get rid of his debts. "Bring us the girl and the debt will be paid" which gets repeated often due to the aforementioned fact it's the focus of the narrative.

The levels are all huge and part of that is due to the skyhook that gives you a hell of a distance to travel by hanging on these wires and giving a whole new angles to the combat. Not to mention using it as a melee weapon when needed too. It's a really great game with not just great mechanics, but a great narrative and a beautiful ending and a wonderful character in Elizabeth.

Despite being such a different and simpler game from the first two Bioshocks, I tried my best to nevertheless give this a fair shake, and for the most part, I feel like this game can be a heck of a spectacle: a real rollercoaster that keeps things flashy and interesting, and has some promising combat design!

Unfortunately, as it went on, it keep getting worse: my favorite part, the combat, became an awkward slog due to spongy enemies and limited weaponry/salts, and the story just became an overcomplicated, pretentious and dumb mess that juggles too much, doesn't give anything time to breathe, and ends with a heck of an ending that, despite technically being a twist, lacks any of the interesting and satisfying punch that the first Bioshock had.

In a way, if you turn your brain off, turn it to easy and just grab some popcorn, it can be a fun ride...but I wouldn't say it's worth it.

Bioshock Infinite is one of those games that the less you know about before you start, the better.

[h1]The clouds of heaven[/h1]

Who doesn't recommend this game for its art, remarkable themes related to politics and philosophy, and its rich story. This time it happens in a heaven, where man being exceptional escapes to the heights, achieving to conquer the decadent morals above the mountains. All created by the brilliant mind of Ken Levine.

This is the story of Booker DeWitt, who arrives at the floating city of Columbia in 1912. His mission is to find Elizabeth. In some of his nebulous remembrances, he assumes that he must pay his debts without recognizing the reason why it took him there. But the task won’t be easy, as he’s identified by the city's security led by Zachary Hale Comstock, who presaged them about the advent of the false shepherd.

The protagonist carries an anathematized AD stigma in his hand. With that the crowd and security identify him. So they try to stop him, nevertheless he’ll do everything possible to reach Elizabeth and at the same time realize more of the world (a civil rebellion is starting) like his past.

[h1]The quantum of possible worlds[/h1]

Without a doubt, the world of [i]BioShock[/i] captures the eye through its art. Thus it’s conspicuous the influences (books, music, science, paintings or films) that the game has been inspired. The idea of an aerial city is fascinating, the technological steampunk type is fused with late romantic art from the United States. Quantum knowledge is bonded with an excessively patriotic atmosphere. Since the world is a paradise, it was achieved from superb lighting with vibrant and vivid colours. Everything is detailed to halt for a moment to contemplate the architecture and its vertiginous design. As well, notwithstanding the years, its appearance doesn’t age. The characters are expressive and the places are perennial to their existence.

The ear is also enchanted by its soundtrack composed by Garry Schyman. At some moments we’ll perceive pop music from the 60's. But the monumental work is found in the orchestral pieces that narratively comprise the game. The theme immerses itself in Comstock's utopia, consisting of musical pieces about his vision of paradise. But also this immediately proposes music from a parallel world, occasioning the music gradually lose its lustre (from utopia to rebellion). The musical effort is formidable, as it expresses through atonality (as diverse musical vibrations) and film score with elements of US folklore. The soundtrack reveals the context of the past and present of a possible world.

The narrative develops a sober theme but without losing dramatic impetus at any time. The theme focuses on the exceptionalism of man, but whose glimpse of the future makes it fear and, therefore, it looks for a way to elude it through immoral actions for society in general. It turns to messianic, religious and political themes, issues that haven’t changed in the US. The parallel possible worlds or Many-worlds interpretation is the narrative core. Since everything is interwoven and overlapping, the narrative thread isn’t misplaced in the multiplicity of contexts and the memory game plays with the protagonist. It tells the past of father and daughter, but at the end it glints at knowing whom he and she’s. The interesting story always invites us to realize more about the world where DeWitt tries to be.

[h1]Disturbing the shepherd's flock[/h1]

If you've played the previous stories, [i]BioShock Infinite[/i] makes some noticeable changes. The familiar: first-person shooter that combines powers and their upgrades, the use of currency, looting as basic actions of the character's movement. Although it changed a little, this is the new thing. You can now only take and use two weapons. Depending on the difficulty you find weapons and ammo frequently. In addition, melees is effective, so it can be combined with Vigors. These powers are similar to plasmids, although their effects are new and different. You can combine them (almost two at a time); they have two effects and require salts to activate such skills.

Some of these powers allow you to take control of enemies, turrets or Heavy Hitters. Since everything takes place in the air, there’ll be no shortage of airship combat as well as being able to use the environment during combat, such as hooks or air rails. For better performance in the role of the character, it contains gear as clothing parts to get various advantages. He has a shield automatically regenerates. However, if you die, you’ll lose some cash. So be careful when you die and have no money. Currency is important, because it’s for the retries, enhance weapons and Vigors. While the character improves his health bar, salts and shield with Infusions.

He doesn’t travel the adventure alone. On many occasions Elizabeth will assist us. It makes the game feel somewhat cooperative. She takes care of herself —an self-sufficient and independent character who doesn't even seek to be protected. But she has skills: will open temporal tears to bring us allied machines, environmental support, money or supplies. All the time she’ll be in interaction, she’ll offer us clues and support us in combat by giving us what we need. We’ll find closed doors or places with cryptic texts (small side quests), in which she’ll use lock picks we find and notebooks for her to decipher. Elizabeth is someone with personality and helps a lot.

[h1]The windows to other realities or the best possible world[/h1]

The narrative is outstanding, with a logical heuristic and rhetorical scheme, its air of sci-fi through quantum, provides an unforgettable style of how much theme and game are developed. The political air within the game gives those “if and then” in a persuasive tone but simultaneously discreet way for the sharp mind who will be uncomfortable with the fact. I like to listen to them, but I don’t agree with such “reasoning”, it moved me to think and feel, it achieves its immersion well.

Its art is gorgeous compared to previous games; but its story, the first game still convinces me. The colour palette, ruled by pink and blue tones bear a resemblance to the divine kaleidoscopic rainbow, emphasizes very well what Comstock's utopia promotes through a distorted faith. Since the ending is an opening to possible worlds —Elizabeth's wonder consists of using the analogy of the stars being lighthouses whose doors lead to other worlds— it allows to be replayed to appreciate the story and the game in detail.

At this time the game is too cheap, so it’s better to buy the bundle where some interesting things like weapons and gears contains (its season pass). There are also two expansions that give an “end” to Elizabeth's story from another universe. This evokes nostalgia when contemplating the marine architecture of Rapture. Or, its difficulty can be a good challenge. If there’re games that persist in eternity, this is one of them.

I've changed my mind on Infinite. I originally recommended it but, all things considered, this game, for all it's worth, is a pain in the butt. I think that the bad here outweighs the good. And it doesn't matter what amount of crap I have been able to tolerate from it up until now, the game just doesn't make for a good recommendation in my eyes.

The last straw for me was when I was recently trying to collect things in Burial at Sea, and explore completely all the areas (specifically the optional area where Shock Jockey is found, which you can miss).

Life being life, I had to close the game at some point, then I reloaded later, and the checkpoint system decided that I had no more access to the area I still wasn't finished exploring, and that I had to move forward on this metaphorical theme park ride (I even found an easily reproductible softlock bug while trying to go back to the area I wanted to be in, because the game apparently couldn't cope with what I wanted to do and had to break, and I effectively got stuck in a room).

In terms of my options, I couldn't complete the task I had chosen for myself, since the proper savegame for me to go back to didn't exist. So, all I could still theoretically do was start over from the beginning, not shut down the game at any moments the game would judge inconvenient, and be very mindful of each and every checkpoint (by looking at the icon on the upper right corner that's signaling that the game is saving). What do I think of all that? "No, thanks".

That was effectively the last straw, and what made me change my mind. Okay, guess what. On top of every other differences I mentioned in my original review, BioShock 2007 had a proper saving system. While Infinite has console check points. Now, what is so bad about check points, you ask, and how does that system compare to a traditional save system? Simple. The latter leaves you with complete control over your experience with the game and with your own computer, leaves the choices and decisions to you, the player; while the former is controling your experience, and is controlling you the entire time.

Infinite, on PC, needed to have a traditional save system with multiple save slots. Period.

--------------[Original review bellow]--------------

BioShock Infinite is a lesser game than BioShock (2007) in every respect, except for a couple of details and the graphics.

Its story, not only is a mess, but makes no sense past a certain point. In a way even a child would understand right away that it is making no sense. They had to make the characters be very stupid, to the point of mental retardation, in order for the story to progress (ie. to get to the next level, and the next, etc).

The game feels like a theme park ride, and has only as much depth as one.

All of this ultimately stems from the fact that BioShock Infinite had a very troubled development cycle. There is no real way to tell if Irrational Games would have been able to ever release this game, had the publisher not sent their own man to try and patch the various elements of the game together and salvage this mess, but all signs points to "no".

[strike]In spite of this, I would still recommend this game, though not at full price.[/strike] It can be an okay virtual adventure when playing through once, and the production value is obviously high and is looking like it, even ten years later.

BioShock Infinite is what Irrational came up with when they had, effectively, infinite time and money (no pun intended, but I'll take it). While BioShock (2007) was what they produced, whence they had to work within stricter boundaries and constraints. Let that also be an educational lesson. Today, on one side we have a timeless classic (BioShock) and on the other a mere curiosity (Infinite).

There you go. BioShock Infinite is a game that was saved by its publisher, and that would have been even worse or would not have existed at all, had its developpers been left to their own devices and, some could argue, their insanity. It's a bit of a Frankenstein monster, but it's a finished product with some endearing aspects.

I actually like the personal story of Booker and Elizabeth, and I also really like how open certain levels are - so much so that they don't really feel like "levels" in a video game.

I heavily dislike the fact that the player can only carry two firearms/weapons. This [b]takes away options[/b] from the player, choices, and makes for a more homogeneous and uniform gameplay experience, which is to say a more [b]boring[/b] one. This also feels very [b]controlling[/b], in the same way the checkpoint system instead of actual saves is controlling.

I also dislike the fact that Elizabeth's whole purpose during combat is to be your imaginary friend (she's invisible to ennemies and can't get hurt) who throws at you ammo and salts. The animation for that is also too long/slow, so you can fully expect to get really tired of it after a while - I think it can even make people feel dizzy, since it's in first person view and [b]takes control away[/b] (once again) from the player for a moment.

Finally on the subject of Elizabeth as an NPC, I strongly suspect that the whole reason why, as the player, you are so often frustratingly low on ammo, salts and weapons is because Elizabeth exists, and because they had to give her purpose in terms of gameplay. But this is, and feels, backwards. It was a backward way to go at things. And in my opinion it is making for a worst game overall.

BioShock Infinite is a semi-satisfying game with its fun game mechanics, artistic graphics, yet boring plot. It's unfortunate that the scenario of the game is inspired by the American Civil War, indeed a boring topic that nobody but US citizens care about. While the first game takes you to Rapture which is a city inspired by Atlantis, this game introduces you Columbia which has a nice atmosphere but an uninteresting theme and history. At least the secondary plot, "parallel universes" become more important later in the game.

Oh well, I also did not like the relationship between you and Elizabeth. I will not give more details in order to not spoil the game scenario for you, but while it is obvious that the relationship created between the player and the little sisters in the first two games cannot be established here in this game with Elizabeth, who is obviously and adult woman, therefore the game is (probably unwittingly) promoting incest which is really annoying.

About game mechanics, the vigors are not more interesting than the ones in the previous games, but Elizabeth is one of the most useful NPC's ever. She gives you ammo, health, weapon, unlocks doors and safe boxes (but she opens them in 1 sec which makes the game unrealistic also), advises and she doesn't stop you shooting enemies by standing in front of your gun, she runs away from it.

In short, BioShock Infinite is not good as the previous games of the franchise, yet if you liked the previous games, just play it because with the two DLCs (Burial at Sea 1 & 2), the scenario of the this game connects with the first game. BTW, the scenario of the DLCs are better than the main game, so if you are gonna play the game, be sure to play the DLCs also.

I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand—the hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed—the hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

There is no singular vision here - it feels very clear that there were too many cooks in the kitchen imposing their disparate ideas. The quality starts out consistent and is wildly oscillating by the end.

The setting and premise are very strong, in my opinion. Quippy gunplay, really cool environments, etc...

I know many people like to point to Elizabeth as the gold standard for video game companions - I cannot disagree more strongly. Not only does she tipify the "Manic Pixey Dream Girl" male fantasy, but she consistently makes nonsensical decisions that go against the story's internal logic. So many legitimately excellent, intelligent female characters in modern games - it's time to stop giving Elizabeth your roses.

It's like a tear to the past. The whole world may be against you - politics, wars, diseases, cultural decline, society filled with hatred and disbelief, friends who turn out to be your enemies. No one will stay by your side, and no one will care, because caring isn't cool anymore

Then you boot up this old masterpiece, and voila - you are back in the warm summer of 2013, when life seemed like a fairy tale, when love and friendship were still things, and there is still so much hope ahead, so much time that you can spend wherever you want, because you are young and damn you can

A beautiful lady says “Booker, catch” and gives you some ammo, so you know there is a world to save. You won't be stopping for the next 12 hours, you will live this story, you will be a hero and you will be needed.

I originally got this game for the Xbox 360 when it first came out. Preordered it even. This is one of my favorite games of all time. I was a big fan of the first Bioshock and the less said about the second one, the better. When Infinite was announced, I wasn't sure if they'd be able to capture the magic of the first while being fresh. Especially considering how much they stumbled in the second game and how the studio drama seemed to be reaching a breaking point. It did reach a breaking point (thanks 2K...), but from that break came this wonderful game. I already see some folks talking about how "it's not a particularly good Bioshock game" but let me tell you that this is just as good, if not better Bioshock game. It's just that it does things differently than Rapture and that's OK.

[b]THE AESTHETICS[/b] are the biggest reason I replay this game every year. It's a huge departure from the first Bioshock. Columbia as a setting is set in the 1910s America, the height of Nationalism and patriotic pride. There's a lot to love here as they get so much of it right: the iconography, the music on the radios, the speech, everything. That also means we get the same ugliness that the 1910s America brought with it: racism, bigotry, and those looking to exploit both for political gain. It's a tale as old as time. But it works great as a Bioshock setting. What really is different though, is how [i]alive[/i] the world is compared to Rapture. In Rapture, you arrive there after the fall. Everyone is dead or spliced out of their minds. In Columbia, you're there as it begins to fall so it's still relatively bright and sunny. It's an interesting trip because you get to see what once was and it's hard not to fall in love with the old shops, Independence day celebrations, and simple times. But so long as you're... you know... white. That's the ugly truth under Columbia that begins to fester an boil over. 

The game is set about 40 years before the time in Rapture so folks looking for a big connection to the other Bioshock should stop. Folks worried about needing to play all the Bioshocks before don't have too as you can jump into this one without missing a beat.

[b]THE COMBAT[/b] is pretty similar to the first Bioshock. You consume plasmids instead of inject them and they're all old timey sounding like "Shock Jockey" or "Bucking Bronco." This again, fits the theme as the 1910s was such a transition age of wild west adventures and the mechanical war that would soon take over the globe. You can see that in how the weapons are laid out. You have your sniper rifle, shot gun, and machine guns, but they're all either held together with tape or look like prototypes of better guns. When playing the game, your ability to mix and match your guns to your plasmids is what makes this game fun. Upgrading your favorites makes you more effective at combat and even the weaker plasmids become competent enough to handle most situations so long as your playstyle fits it. 

Added to this Bioshock is the use of rails to traverse battlefields and find caches. There's a lot to like here, but the game doesn't utilize it enough for it to really feel more than a gimmick. There's just not enough railings to feel like you absolutely need it to explore. Sure there are some hard to reach areas that you can grab with them and you do get some combat bonuses when you jump from them, but it ultimately just isn't as prevalent as I'd like. This isn't a huge complaint because you don't really notice this unless you play this game 19 something times like I have. But the rail system feels like something that would work well in an open world version of this game but it just feels a bit restricted in this more linear version. 

Finally, there's Elizabeth. This game is one giant escort mission. DON'T WALK AWAY YET! It's not a babysitting escort mission like in Resident Evil or in any James Bond mission or what not. Elizabeth is wonderful. They set out to make a good AI companion and they succeeded. She can handle herself and will throw you weapons, coins, potions, whatever. It's great to not have to worry about her but to see her as an asset instead. She's also incredibly charming and witty, but I'll save that for the character section.

[b]THE STORY[/b] is where this game starts to get wiggy and great. It's a simple prompt: Save the girl, wipe away your debt. You play Booker DeWitt, a very 1910s American private investigator who through immense debt, has been hired to get this girl. This takes a turn as you find out just how corrupt Colombia is and how crazed some of its devoted citizens are to it. No spoilers, but in this game you deal with a egotistical leader with a God complex, a race war where no one is the good guy by the end, time shenanigans, and your own demons that threatens your very mission. It's a great trip. 

Now... the ending. I feel like a lot of people just don't get it. It's a fantastic ending and it requires a bit of thought and knowledge of how paradoxes work in time traveling. Throughout this game there's this theme "Will the circle be unbroken." That's kind of your clue to latch onto and start looking at things in a different way. This is a game that you might have to play more than once to see how it all fits. Does that make the ending good? I thought so and still do today. But it isn't a perfectly executed ending because you start to getting into the weeds of relativity, and space and time parallel universe shenanigans. Which is just a complex topic that takes more than a 30 minute ending to help explain without having [i]some[/i] base for or some clue to how this would end like that. Just bear with it and enjoy the ride.

[b]THE CHARACTERS[/b] are the star of the show for most people. The team of Booker and Elizabeth is fun, challenging, dramatic, worrying, encouraging, and adorable at times. Voiced by Troy Baker and Courtnee Draper, this is a duo you will fall in love with immediately. Booker being the straight man that just wants to get this job over with and will do literally whatever he has to to get it done is a great foil to Elizabeth's naive, wonderlust personality. That doesn't mean they stay that way. Booker softens through the game, mostly thanks to Elizabeth. And Elizabeth learns some hard lessons in this game. Sometimes people who fight so hard to be free, become the very evil they were trying to rid. It's a profound moment that if Elizabeth was any other character or acted by anyone else other than Courtnee would have been lost or watered down. This game doesn't pull punches with it's main protagonists. 

Now, the other characters are a different story. You have four other big characters: Comstock, Daisy Fitzroy, Jeremiah Fink, and the duo twins: Robert and Rosalind Lutece. In terms of Comstock and Fink, they just don't get enough screen time. They get some good rumors and voxophones, but until their climaxes, you don't face them directly often. Daisy on the other hand, has such a unique arc. It's controversial though, but I thin it's one of those cautionary tales of how to far you'll go to achieve your goals and freedom. The Lutece twins steal the show for me. Every scene they're in is hilarious and thought provoking. 

[b]VERDICT[/b] I give this game a 9/10 easily. It's one of my favorites and is just such a joy to play through and explore this world as it tears itself apart. For anyone a fan of the first Bioshock, but want something fresh this is a game to play. For anyone that loves this era in time, you'll feel like you got transported into the Edwardian period. For anyone looking for a good first person shooter with some RPG elements, this is a game to try. And finally, for anyone that likes princesses in towers set in a modern time where maybe the princess is the one doing the saving at the end, this game will be a delight.

Synopsis: it's a magic world filled with a great deal of drama.

It would be hard and unfair to describe the game just telling it's perfect in all possible aspects, the game (DLCs are included) is a quintessence of all Bioshock series. Yet I can't say that it's the best as all of Bioshock games are unique in its perfection.

Binfinite is a masterpiece that's for sure. I'm not going to describe common features like top notch graphics etc. I just want to say that the game, if played correctly (no haste, plz), will tear you apart and drain emotionally as the plot is so deep and heart-touching. The game has perfect balance between action and story-telling, yet I would advice to replay it in a while to understand the plot deeply.

It was a long journey for me to Bioshock series, and Binfinite was the pioneer for me, the successful pioneer. Thx [b]Irrational Games[/b], thx [b]Ken Levine[/b], thx to all the devs. It's a pleasure to play games like this: beautiful, story-deep and perfect in everything.

PS. @future players: would you kindly watch the cast till the end?

PPS: "Clash in the Clouds" (arcade non-story DLC) is one hell of pain in the ass!!! I ate my shoes until I was able to beat it for all the achievements :)

What a ride! Probably my coolest and most fascinating adventure in video games. The colourful airborne city Columbia, the cute and lifelike sidekick Elizabeth, the music, the cinematography, the story… all got me hooked from the start to the end. I wholeheartedly endorse this game.

But, if you are a picky gamer, you might need to be warned that Bioshock Infinite is far from an impeccable masterpiece. As a matter of fact, many elements don't feel right, when I finally have time to ruminate on the gameplay after my breathless journey in Columbia (more details can be found in this well-written review from [url=https://www.rockpapershotgun.com/bioshock-infinite-pc-review]Rock Paper Shotgun[/url]):
- The architecture of the city is so majestic, yet its denizens are mostly glassy-eyed automatons, and there are so few things to interact with.
- The game is extremely linear, to the point that it doesn't even have an in-game map, since you barely need one.
- No manual save. The game autosaves at checkpoints, which sometimes are half an hour apart. Hence, this game is not suitable for gamers who cannot play a few hours straight at a time.
- Most characters are too shallow, and their raison d'être remains unclear.
- Bare-bones combat system, which would probably disappoint FPS players.

And some mechanics break immersion:
- Unlike in previous titles of Bioshock, you can only carry two weapons at a time. Ironically, you always carry the ammos for each weapon with you! Luckily, this design is fixed in the DLCs.
- Stories are mainly told by audio logs scattered around the map as collectibles.
- The scavenge system is nonsensical. You find ammos, food, or drink in unlikely places. Occasionally, you might even find a pineapple in a little chocolate box! Not that I do not love pineapple, though.

Other downsides:
- Apparently, some locations only support 30 fps graphics output: every time I go near certain places, the frame rate drops from 60 to 30, and when I stay away from these places the frame rate returns to 60 fps.
- The game has been through some development hell of its studio. As a consequence, many contents have been cut and the released game is much less ambitious than it ought to be, such as showcased in the early trailer https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=p5it-pAYmKY
- Some small bugs have not been fixed after all these years. Even worse, 2K has recently added a 2K launcher and refers to it as a “quality of life update”. How outrageous!

All that being said, playing through Bioshock Infinite is still an amazingly intriguing and smooth journey. It almost feels like an interactive film where the interactive part is you explore the beautiful fictive city Columbia and shoot some guys. Its task system, guiding, and difficulty setting allow casual gamers who just want to enjoy the story to breeze through. Hence, I highly recommend Bioshock Infinite. Just don't expect too much depth from its gameplay or story!

Relation to previous Bioshock titles:
The main game of Bioshock Infinite can be played without previous exposure to Bioshock 1 or 2. The DLC Burial at Sea, however, will bring you back to Rapture, the city in which the stories of Bioshock 1 and 2 take place. To fully grasp the story of Burial at Sea, it is highly recommended to play Bioshock 1 first, especially because Burial at Sea contains major spoilers of the plot of Bioshock 1.

Bioshock Infinity gave me the creeps and had me on the edge of my seat. It was a thriller all through out. The story and visuals were respectively mindblowing and breathtaking, and I had a brief crisis as I finished the game. I did not expect that ending.

The combat was great on its own right, but my favorite part was sliding through skylines. Initially I thought the abilities were simple, but shortly found that the devil's in the details. I got to say, it was satisfying to experience new Tear interactions with Elizabeth as you progressed through the story.

Bioshock Infinite is a game with a particular identity, and it's a pleasure seeing how much creativity was poured into it.

You're not in Rapture anymore, Dorothy!  Instead, you play as Booker DeWitt on mission to rescue Elizabeth from Columbia, a city in the clouds.  In contrast to the dark and somewhat scary environments of Rapture, most of Columbia feels light and airy, with amazing early 20th century-inspired architecture and characters.  Booker and Elizabeth are a memorable duo that have some great interactions as they escape the city together.

Vigors replace Plasmids as the way to gain powers to help you on your quest, but the idea is pretty much the same.  Vigors, used in combination with your arsenal of weapons, provide varied and interesting ways of dealing with your enemies.  As you progress through the game you will find Voxophones, audio logs that provide more of the back story of the city and the people that created it.

What a masterpiece! What is the meaning of time and universe? It is a question numerous directors, game designers, etc. have sought and/or are seeking answers. In this piece of art (in the form of a game), Ken Levine tried to answer it with that you cannot just fix what you want to fix, but you have to find its origin and restart from there. Sometimes, this means you will experience a completely different timeline and universe. It is a price you have to pay. When I (Booker) first arrived at sea of doors, I could not wait to kill Comstock once and for all. When Elizabeth asked me, "Are you sure?" I was annoyed by her riddles and did not hesitate for a second. But when I replayed this part, looking at Elizabeth's sorrow expression, I suddenly felt powerless, fateful, and dutiful. I stared at her for a moment and still went through the door. There is no other choice I could make. [b]Do not do anything you will regret. And do not regret.[/b]

No wonder [i]Bioshock Infinite[/i] has an excellent plot, since Ken Levine was a playwright. Playing for the first time, I was confused by the shifting of scenes and scattering of evidence throughout the game, but when looking back, I realized how they are connected in a meaningful way. What once I thought was decorative is actually essential to the story. Salute to the team.

[h1][u] A Tale of Two Experiences[/u][/h1]

My first journey through Colombia in Bioshock Infinite was awe-inspiring, captivated by the intricate time-travel narrative. However, a second playthrough revealed some disappointing aspects.

[b][u]Pro:[/u][/b]
+ Colombia is beautifully crafted, showcasing incredible detail and ambiance.
+ The time-travel storyline is exceptionally well done, ranking as one of the best in gaming.
+ Initially, the game felt like a masterpiece, mesmerizing in its storytelling and world-building.

[b][u]Neutral:[/u][/b]
~ Powers that added depth in the first game are less impactful

[b][u]Contra:[/u][/b]
- Limitation to carrying only two weapons, a step back from the freedom in Bioshock 1 & 2.
- Audio logs and looting mechanics feel out of place in the lively setting of Colombia.
- Many shooting sections are dull and overly linear.
- Lack of real exploration opportunities, with a heavy reliance on following quest markers.

[b][u]Conclusion:[/u][/b]
Bioshock Infinite's [u]STUNNING[/u] story and world-building are unfortunately coupled with [u]AVERAGE[/u] gameplay. This dichotomy left me feeling a sense of disappointment, wondering why the game regressed in certain gameplay aspects from its predecessors. It's a game of contrasting experiences – breathtaking in narrative but lacking in the explorative and combat freedom that defined the earlier titles.

I should say first that I wanted to LOVE this game, the story and setting that it has are both amazing, unique, and interesting. But I can't base a review on what's seen without talking about what's experienced. The gameplay is so grueling, not in a way that is particularly hard, but that it is extremely repetitive and an annoyance to get through. There were several memorable points, but the whole of it blends together into one premise - go to this open area, clear the enemies, then repeat and repeat and repeat without a difference in your method or the overall layout of the areas. There were multiple points where I got stuck and had to restart because I simply ran out of ammo and there wasn't a way to get more. After watching some gameplay clips, I stopped playing just before Comstock's House near the end of the game, because I honestly couldn't keep dragging myself along without any desire to keep going.
The way the story and gameplay conflict for me is a bit hard to understand but all in all, I LIKE this game, I just can't enjoy playing it. I recommend looking into it and learning about the story and lore, but I do not recommend playing it.
