This game is excellent, and easily the best of the Bioshock game series.

I played Infinite when it came out and recently decided to play it again after 10 years plus the original Bioshock 1, 2 and all DLC that I never played before. So, this time I had way more context to the game and being 10 years older also helps understanding the story better. Replaying this also made me understand why I loved this game so much back then. It was entirely justified.

The story is smart with some really cool twists that you can figure out and puzzle together before the game tells you directly, but still leaves enough for you to think and put the pieces together afterwards. Listening to all the voice recordings you can find throughout the game (called voxophones) also give additional context and details about what actually happened.

The main gameplay loop feels really good and definitely made me explore a lot more powers (vigors) compared to the powers (plasmids) in the first two games despite there being fewer of them. The gun play feels great (though ADS is a bit awkward but you’re not supposed to use it that much anyways) and has enough variation. The game also forces you to switch weapons due to ammo at a rate that felt well balanced. It made me want to use all types of guns, but maybe that is also because the guns just feel really good.

The atmosphere of the game is definitely different compared to the first two, which were near identical in that regard. It feels fresh, nice and warm and features the type of music I started enjoying thanks to Fallout 4. It’s kind of like Rapture but not at the same time, which is a big theme in the game.

Elizabeth is probably the best companion of any game I’ve ever tried. She is useful, doesn’t take damage and has plenty of reactions and dialog to keep it interesting. It also helps that the voice actors are really good for both Booker and Elizabeth and that they both have a lot of character.

The story DLC is also really good. The first part felt a bit cheap-ish, kind of like Bioshock 2’s DLC but together with part 2 it felt amazing. Really nice to be back in Rapture too.

Infinite is also infinitely buggier compared to the first two games though. I got stuck a lot and had to return to the most recent checkpoint each time. There is also the problem with the FOV which is limited to toilet paper rolls by default. You have to go into the “C:\Users\<Username>\Documents\My Games\BioShock Infinite\XGame\Config\XUserOptions.ini” and change to “MaxUserFOVOffsetPercent” to e.g. 50 for 90 degrees and then turn up the FOV in the game settings to max (the 50 means 50% higher than the default 60 degrees). I would also recommend changing the launch options to avoid the stupid 2K launcher, just follow this guide: https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3003566535

This game is a 4/10 for the following reasons:
- The checkpoint save system is terrible. You either commit to an open-ended gaming session that could last 5-20 minutes, or longer, or take the hit of not saving and having to redo parts of a level.
- There isn't much variety of enemies. It's mostly basic humanoid variations with a handful of more powerful entities.
- The game is largely on rails with enclosed areas and points of no return.
- The combat system can be annoying if you like to use longer range guns due to random, unrealistic dodging from enemies. 
- The gear is unimpressive, it's far too biased to zipline and melee operations. If you prefer using ranged weapons and plasmids over melee, there isn't much to embellish those activities.
- There isn't much variety in the weapons. Nothing close to Bioshock 1 and 2 where there were several weapons, each with three modes of fire.

This one is difficult to review for me. It's by no means a [i]bad[/i] game. But I do think it's not a particularly good Bioshock game. I think the gameplay was a considerate step down from the previous one, with no weapon customization, less interesting powers, and other downgrades. I was bored somewhat often.
What could save this game then is the story. And I have to admit, for most people, I think this will be a great aspect of the game. But for me, unfortunately, that wasn't the case. I could see the plot twists from a mile away, and that kinda killed a lot of the suspense and wonder from the game. I won't say much so I don't spoil anyone, but if you have seen stories similar to this one before, you will probably have the same experience as me. 
As for it has going on for it, the new setting is really nice, and definitely welcome after 2 just repeated stuff from 1. But that alone can't save the game for me.
If you've played the previous Bioshock games, you really need to know what you are getting yourself into here. If the gameplay was not so important to you, then this one might still be good, depends on how well the story works for you. If the gameplay was an essential part of your enjoyment of the games, then it's probably better to skip.

Although the city in the clouds setting seems like an intriguing idea, BioShock Infinite chooses to depict it in a time period which I find particularly uninteresting. The combat is fast-paced and fun, offering plenty of vertical mobility and a damn excellent AI companion.

Despite this, I find the characters to be exaggerated cartoon people living in a cartoon world that lacks the dark realism or horror that defined the first two BioShock games. But then, there's the story.

In my personal opinion, BioShock Infinite's story is a travesty, dealing with time travel and alternate dimensions, which are ideas that feel wildly out of place and otherwise overused. The final scene, which explains the whole story as if Hercule Poirot himself was narrating it, is a painful slap in the place which makes no sense, sullies the BioShock name and tries to establish some kind of unwarranted connection to Rapture. Just... no.

BioShock Infinite is the third and final entry in the classic yet ground-breaking FPS trilogy 'Bioshock' and is a massive and incredibly ambitious step-up creatively from the previous two entries in the series and, from what i understand, was a massive technical undertaking for Illusion Studios at the time. While being completely opposite to the dark, dreary hellscape that was Rapture, Columbia is an utterly gorgeous, utopian steampunk paradise. I could spend hours just walking the streets of Columbia just to appreciate the beautiful neo-colonial aesthetic running on steampunk architecture floating thousands of feet in the sky; it's truly one of the best settings I have experienced in any game in recent memory. I really liked the designs of the wonderous tonics of Columbia known as 'Vigors' in the game. They are similar enough to the 'Plasmids' from Rapture, but are drank by the user instead of injected directly into the bloodstream. Effects range from the ability to conjure fireballs, lift heavy loads, befriend machinery, harness water, and other supernatural capabilities as well as my personal favorite 'Shock Jockey'. The gunplay is thrilling and tense, with all manner of automatic, double barrel, and sharpshooting firepower at Booker Dewitts disposal along with great, visceral melee executions using your trusty Sky-Hook that doubles as a deadly weapon in close quarters and thrilling high-velocity skyrail transportation around Columbia. Elizabeth is a charming and iconic sidekick and is always there to patch you up when you fall, as well as carrying the burden of the ability to harness 'tears' in space/time making her a necessary and tragic case as you come to learn more about yourself and your real purpose in Columbia. BioShock Infinite is a masterpiece in its innovations in gameplay and storytelling, that pushed the entire first-person shooter genre forward into what it is today and is my absolute favorite game in the 'BioShock' trilogy aswell as being one of the best first-person shooters of all time.

[h1] Bioshock Infinite [/h1] 

Graphics: ★★★★★
BioShock Infinite features stunning visuals that combine intricate level design with breathtaking artistic direction. The attention to detail in the city of Columbia is simply awe-inspiring. The game's graphics create an immersive and believable environment that truly brings the world to life.

Gameplay: ★★★★☆
The gameplay in BioShock Infinite offers a refreshing blend of first-person shooting and supernatural abilities. The combat mechanics are smooth, allowing players to seamlessly switch between different weapons and powers. The variety of weapons, as well as the ability to upgrade them, adds depth to the gameplay experience. However, at times, the AI can be slightly unpredictable and may take away from the overall challenge.

Story: ★★★★★
The narrative in BioShock Infinite is one of its strongest aspects. The game delivers a thought-provoking and gripping story that keeps players engaged from start to finish. The characters are well-developed, and the plot twists and turns will leave you eagerly wanting to uncover more secrets about the fascinating city of Columbia.

Sound Design: ★★★★☆
The sound design in BioShock Infinite is exceptional, contributing to the game's immersion. The voice acting is excellent, and the atmospheric sound effects help create a sense of tension and unease as players explore the city. The music perfectly captures the time period and adds another layer of depth to the gaming experience.

Replay Value: ★★★★☆
BioShock Infinite offers decent replay value for those who wish to revisit its breathtaking world. The multiple choices and outcomes, as well as collectibles and hidden areas, encourage players to dive back in and discover new details they may have missed. However, the linear nature of the game may limit the desire for repeated playthroughs for some players.

Overall: ★★★★★
BioShock Infinite is a mesmerizing game that combines stunning visuals, a captivating story, and engaging gameplay. It provides a unique and unforgettable experience that transcends typical first-person shooters. Despite a few minor flaws, its exceptional storytelling and breathtaking visuals make it a must-play for any gaming enthusiast.

BioShock Infinite is still one of the best FPS campaigns. It combines a unique atmospheric art style with refreshing FPS mechanics while a mysterious and evil plot plays in the background. I played through the game and watched a play through and both times I was slightly confused about the story, but not so confused that I felt lost or uninterested in the dialog. In fact I think the stories ambiguity adds a little something to the mystique of Comstock. Very rarely do we get a FPS with as good of a story as this, and the art style is nothing like you will see executed in any other game still to this day. They could have left it at a beautiful atmospheric FPS with a good story, but on top of that they came up with some fun and different game mechanics(elemental power ups, and zip lines are fun) that makes BioShock a must play for anyone into FPS campaigns or action games in general.

[h3]🌁 BioShock Infinite: An Adventure in the Sky[/h3]

BioShock Infinite is an FPS (first person shooter) video game. The game takes place in 1912 in Columbia, a city that flies in the sky. Booker DeWitt, the protagonist of the game, is tasked with rescuing a mysterious girl named Elizabeth, who is being held captive in the city to get out of debt. Booker and Elizabeth struggle together to uncover the city's secrets and escape. The game's graphics, sounds, music and animations are very high quality and impressive. The story of the game tells the character development of Booker and Elizabeth, their relationship and the history of the city. The atmosphere of the game draws you in and you experience an adventure in the sky 😍

## 🌟 Pros of the game

- What I like about the game is that there are many options such as using various weapons, equipment and psychokinetic powers called Vigor, moving quickly on rails called Sky-Line, switching between different worlds, and getting Elizabeth's help. These features make the game action-packed and enjoyable. For example, I can change my weapons and equipment as I wish, attack enemies with powers such as fire, electricity, telekinesis with Vigours, perform acrobatic moves in the air with Sky-Lines, ask Elizabeth to give me things like bullets, health, money, or open space-time coins called Rips, and encounter different events in different worlds. These choices affect the outcome of the game and give me different endings. This makes the game more interesting and varied. 😎
- The game also has a lot of secret and extra content. This content enriches the game and adds new mechanics, levels, characters, and stories. For example, in each chapter I can find hidden Voxophones and listen to them to learn about the history of the city and characters, find hidden Kinetoscopes and watch them to see the culture and propaganda of the city, find hidden Infusions and use them to increase my health, shield or salt. I can also access additional packs with the game's Season Pass, returning to the city of Rapture in the two-part story Burial at Sea, engaging in challenging battles in Clash in the Clouds, and getting extra weapons, gear, and money in Columbia's Finest. This content makes the game more replayable and rewarding. 😊

## Cons of the game

- What I don't like about the game is that sometimes it is too confusing, sometimes it is too hard, and sometimes it is too easy. The fact that the game is too confusing can actually be an advantage, because it makes me think and wonder more about the game. But sometimes I might want the game to be clearer and more understandable. In this case, I might search the internet to better understand the game's story, characters and mechanics, visit the game's wiki page or forums, read interviews or commentaries by the game's creator Ken Levine, or try to find the game's hidden content. The difficulty of the game depends on your skill and preference. The difficulty levels of the game are Easy, Normal, Hard and 1999 Mode. If I find the game too hard, I can lower the difficulty level, if I find it too easy, I can increase the difficulty level. Also, the game's artificial intelligence can sometimes be too smart and sometimes too stupid. This can destabilise the game. Therefore, it is important that I follow the updates of the game and report any bugs. 😕
- Another disadvantage of the game is that it sometimes has technical problems such as freezing, crashing and crashing. These problems can spoil the enjoyment of the game and can be frustrating. The reason for these problems may be that the game requires too many system requirements or the game is not optimised. To resolve these issues, I can lower the game settings, update the game, verify the game files, or reinstall the game. I can also get help or share my problems on the game's support page or forums. 😢

## 🏆 Game Scoring

I will rate the game in five categories: graphics, sound, gameplay, story, and overall. For each category I will choose one of five stars. Here is my rating:

You need at least 2 GB RAM, 20 GB disc space and Windows Vista operating system to play the game. Have fun playing the game! 😁

While not necessarily a bad game on its own, Bioshock Infinite is bogged down by a number of nagging issues. Front and center are dubious game mechanics changes compared to its predecessors, such as regenerating shield and two weapon limit which affect combat in a profound way. But in my opinion the biggest downfall of all is the technical roughness. BioShock Infinite truly does not play well out of the box. Noticeable texture streaming, borderline unusable sensitivity settings, forced aim assist, stuttering, forced post processing effects - these are some of the most obvious nuisances. Take a look at PcGamingWiki article for this game and see for yourself - the list of troubles plaguing this game is downright impressive. And while many of them can be solved one way or another, a prospective player has got to ask oneself if it is worth it at all.

For many it was and it is. Many a player enjoy Infinite's story, atmosphere and twists despite all the technical shortcomings. Whether or not you are a kind of player that looks past the bad to see the good is up to you and only you to decide.

Not yet beaten it. I'm just writing this since I started it 9 months ago and, while better than Bioshock II, it's just way too much of a slog for me to get into. The graphics are astounding, the sky hook mechanic is genuinely some of the most fun I've had playing this franchise, but everything else about it is not very engaging. The story confuses and bores the hell out of me, though maybe that's my fault for taking so long to play this game I forget things. I was enjoying the game for a moment when they started giving you friendly NPCs, something that too my knowledge hasn't been done yet aside from security drones, but then they immediately turn those NPCs against you, and not in any interesting way, it's basically just like fighting the cops again. If this second faction was actually relevant throughout most of the game I'd like it a lot more, especially since it'd add impact to the part where you do fight against them. I think I could best sum it up as a mindless combat gauntlet. Although sky hook fights are fun, Vigors add spice to the combat, and Elizabeth's ability is occasionally interesting, I just feel like it's missing depth past that part, like interesting enemy variety or whatever. And yes I know some enemies have Vigor abilities but I found fighting them never amounted to much more than a tankier common enemy with a single extra gimmick to them. I think the only time I've seen an enemy be interesting is when they electrified the sky hook line, actively changing my play style and making me think about how to fight while they were in the field. Every other enemy though? Eh, just shoot them until they die and right click with appropriate abilities selected, and use the same props that you find in many, many other environments. Can't say I enjoyed it.

As someone who sticks around for the gameplay I was disappointed. Typically the player will be walking through a beautiful atmosphere when a wave of enemies that take too long to kill, and do hardly anything charge out. The player uses weak guns against healthy enemies, so the majority of combat time is spent reloading behind cover, or reloading while running away. There are certain interesting mechanics that allow the player to create cover, health packs, and sentries, but they are too weak to be useful. The first enemies encountered are the same enemies fought throughout the game, so after 20 minutes the combat can be almost fully explored.

You'll have to play on 1999 mode if you want a guaranteed way to play the PC port of this game without aim assist, which means either beating the game once (recommended to familiarise yourself with the games mechanics & more on an easier difficulty) or using a cheat code to unlock it right away.
Other than that, BioShock Infinite is a neat spin off title of the BioShock series, set in 1912 on the fictional floating city of Columbia, where you're given all kinds of guns, vigors (BI's plasmids) and gear for you to choose from based on your preferred play style, while the graphics & aesthetic appeal of the game still holds up ten years later.

Would be a solid 10/10 if you could hit Jeremiah Fink in the nuts with a baseball.

Cool environment, cool action and a nice mindfucky ending! 

Replaying the entire trilogy in 2023, I couldn't help but notice Infinite's more streamlined form makes the story flourish but it comes at a considerable cost: combat is fun but you never truly do anything else and the environments are more linear which makes Columbia feel less immersive than Rapture did. 

That said, the bond between Elizabeth and Booker (and by extension, you) continues to be sublime and it's regarded as a milestone in videogame history for a reason.

I played this game 1 week after bioshock 2 which decreased my expectations quite a lot. I don't as to if that was the reason but. I truly enjoyed most mechanics in this game. guns felt smooth and effective. the enemies didn't feel like rubber. the game was flowing. of course there are multiple examples as to where game was poorly paced or hid somethings very incompetently but it was rather a good experience. 

you have many weapons and have to switch between them to keep from running out of ammo as in the previous games. that does not change. what does though is you have 2 weapons that you can switch with the arsenal of around 10 in the game only if you find the next weapon on the ground. I loved this decision. the game flows way too slowly in my taste because of the tidious looting, attention requiring lore and all other reasons. this simplification still forces you to switch weapons as you can get ammo for all weapons but only switch weapons themselves. not only that headshotting feels good. mobs move their heads a lot but it is not as stupid as the animations in tomb raider games. 

graphics are not adequate in my opinion but the art design is strong so most of the time, graphics won't effect your immersion in a bad way. I don't understand what type of animations they used but seeing enemies felt harder in larger and darker areas. It is also manageable.

AFTER THIS THERE ARE SPOILERS

we gotta talk about elizabeth. she is our protagonist and has mechanical elemts such as givin you ammo, medkits, salts and even coin while exploring. she is also commentative which is basically a different sort of audio tape in the previous games. though the exception of this method is;, our character is distinguished and filled in. other games  also put lore and value into our main character but it did it in classical gameplay way of: your character never speaks. this approach gave depth to our protagonist and is a welcome change. elizabeth itself is very cute. rawr! leaving alonet the games like witcher 3 which are on their own league: I would say this is one of those games that gives the highest attention to characterization and mimics of characters. the characters you will see constantly all have unique characteristics and mimics that are natural to the enviroment and will flow with the game. 

sooooo the salt abilites were never my favorite thing in the bioshock series. in this game I again used them on occasion, didn't upgrade them, and used what I knew most of the time. I am sure very much a people will enjoy it. It is not bad or something. I don't really enjoy systems with dependable energy sources in loot focused games. 

here we come to the story. I adored this story. I loved the connection it had to bioshock universe. I loved the characters. I loved that it did not have a happy no consequence ending. to quote from alan wake: "A story is not a machine that does what you tell it. A story is a beast with a life of its own. you can create it, shape it, but as the story grows on, it starts wanting things on its own... the characters have to be true to themselves. the events to follow a logic that fits the story. a single flaw and the magic is gone. the story dies. alice dies." I can't express the way in which I relate to this quote and this game executes it beautifully. the setting is dark and realistic. major flying cities don't mean the princess will be a classical one and if you save the princess all will be same as before. the game actually makes use of this. It purposefully shows you the sequence where you were 6 months late and see new york. while you might not enjoy parallel universes concept. In this game the sequence was both impressive on its own, showed you the consequences, and had justifications for tear powers since the beginning. 

for whatever it does masterfully. there is still a huge problem with pacing especially when you are sent into that city like place which you pass 5 times. It takes away from the immersion... 

the actual story is genious in its weight of the consequences as stated before. infinite name has its weight. world-building is standart with previous games (not to say that it is bad). the story will give you joy, resentment, sadness, I would go further in depth but I really see no point. It uses many an aspect such as time travel, parallel universes theory, and what not and I can see that some people wouldn't enjoy it as much as I would even if they do enjoy it. It is quite relative and even though I wirte reviews satisfy myself. I can't bring myself to explain why I enjoyed it so much. Might be a english languages and literature fatigue XD

[h1]Pretty but Silly[/h1]
If you thought the stories for the first two games were average, I have no doubt that you'll find BioShock Infinite's plot completely nonsensical. It even goes as far as to undermine the plots of the original games for absolutely no reason other than fan service. The concepts within are simply an excuse for the writer to write blindfolded and what we end up with is the dramatic equivalent to [spoiler]"and it was all a dream."[/spoiler] There are also multiple occasions for the player to make [b]binary[/b] choices which have no impact on the plot whatsoever. 

As far as characters go, Booker and Elizabeth range from bland to melodramatic but they are not insufferable, as they have their endearing albeit forced moments occasionally. The worst part is that, because of the plot, every major character is also a [spoiler]non-character [/spoiler] (which is even hilariously referenced in [spoiler]Burial at Sea 2[/spoiler]), including and especially the Lutece twins and Songbird. There are also many instances where NPCs will feign a struggle or state of emergency. Choosing not to press the interact key just leaves them in an endless loop of grunting and moaning. If you don't interact the game will tell you to with an onscreen prompt. The game also tells you that your companion Elizabeth "can protect herself" without ever showing how exactly she manages to do that. This game does a lot of telling and little explaining (except when it comes to basic tutorials of course). 

Where BioShock Infinite shines is in its world and visuals. After all, who wouldn't find a flying city from 1912 alluring? Even then the plot partially takes this novelty away from you for NO REASON other than to sound clever. There are also many character animations during cutscenes that look really unpolished and robotic. Despite this, it is indeed at times a very pretty game with very exciting set pieces. 

Combat can be surprisingly enjoyable. The smooth, snappy weapon animations and satisfying visual effects are pleasant to the eye, and I especially appreciate the integration of musical sound effects to communicate successful kills and critical hit kills. As for the vigors, I will say that I appreciate them in lower numbers. The earlier games really bombard you with variety, and even then many of them overlapped their intended applications. However, In BioShock Infinite you aren't really prompted to be pragmatic with your vigors, especially on 1998 mode where enemies become bullet sponges. Instead you'll just end up using your most powerful offensive vigors as opposed to your utility vigors unless you make a mental note of it. 

[b]ISSUES:[/b] 
- Launching a vigor trap occasionally doesn't work. Instead the regular attack will occur even though you held the button. This has happened twice in a row before and uses three times the salts than I intended to consume.
- During Comstock House, pulling a certain lever switch halves your sprint speed and increases zoom sensitivity by tenfold or more. I genuinely do not know if this is an intended fourth wall.
- Crank gun cranks itself while on the sky-rail. 

Despite it's major flaws, BioShock Infinite will still be found largely entertaining to many people.

Addendum:

I don't know about you, but I've always wanted to visit a floating city in the clouds. And after playing Bioshock Infinite, I can safely say that I never want to leave the ground again. This game is like a rollercoaster ride through a surreal dream world, except you're shooting bad guys instead of screaming your head off.

The graphics in this game are absolutely stunning. I mean, I'm pretty sure I spent half the game just staring out into the clouds and wondering if I could jump off and survive. (Spoiler alert: you can't.) And the sound design is just as impressive. Every gunshot and explosion feels like it is right there in the room with you.

But the real star of the show is the story. I don't want to give anything away, but let's just say that things get... weird. And by "weird," I mean "mind-bendingly insane." But in a good way! The characters are all well-written and engaging, and the plot twists will have you questioning everything you thought you knew about the game.

So if you're looking for a fun, immersive, and slightly trippy gaming experience, Bioshock Infinite is definitely worth checking out. Just be prepared to get lost in the clouds for a while.
pretty good game, it doesnt have much depth to it but its still fun and nice looking

This is the first BioShock game I've ever played, so I was worried that I'd be confused about what's going on because I didn't play the other games. Luckily, this game is a perfect introduction to the series. It's a game that can stand on its own two legs even if you've never played BioShock or BioShock 2.

The characters are fantastic, the story is compelling, and there's nothing more satisfying than getting a good kill off the skylines. Overall, I'd recommend this game to anyone who's new to the franchise, as well as people who've been fans for years.

Bioshock Infinite puts you from the dark depths of the sea into the sky, where you explore a flying city that isn't as harmonic as it may seems at first. While the first two Bioshock clearly showed you straigth from the beginning that something is seriously wrong in the world you are in, Infinite takes it time to introduce you to a deeply tattered society, full of arrogance and ignorance. 

I can directly tell you that the story, world building and gameplay sadly isn't as good as in Bioshock 1&2. At least in my personal opinion. The guns feel rather weak, even when you have fully upgraded them (this time even without the visual upgrades) and the skyhooks are pretty boring and a nearly unnecessary addition to the gameplay. Playing around with vigors is the most fun part and combining them can be a quite powerful tool in your inventory. The world feels emptier and almost copy&pasted in certain spots, the art style is just not on the same level as its predecessors even though it isn't bad by any means. The developers also decided to go with just one ending this time, which really doesn't fit the narrative of the story that much. There are also two story DLC's that take you back to Rapture, which is a pretty nice thing. Sadly the story is a little bit all over the place and doesn't make that much sense in retrospective.

In my opinion the weakest Bioshock title, nonetheless i still recommend it to fans of the franchise and newcomers likewise. It is a solid game and pretty much worth playing, but definitely wait for it to go on sale and get the collection edition.

Whoever says games can't be considered "Art" probably never played any BioShock game.

BioShock Infinite brings entertainment to another level, I haven't had fun with a game for a long time. That doesn't mean all the others releases are bad but it's been a while since i had so much fun playing a game.

The plot it's one of the best i've seen in my entire gaming life, matching some Visual Novels and books i love (i kinda like a good plot and not the usual mindless action or generic shooting gallery we get most of the time). I don't think you'll find another game with a better quality plot anytime soon.

Graphics aren't realistic but that doesn't mean they are bad, they got kinda a unique style that makes everything beautiful. You could say they are the same as the older games but they certainly improved a lot. However i kinda get annoyed with the excessive "bloom" in some scenes, sometimes they are overused to the point of blinding you. Aside from that everything else is beautiful. 

There's the music, honestly it isn't great but it's not bad either, the combat music is the same for the whole game save some specific scenes and it gets repetitive after a while. It's average at best.

The gameplay is what you've already seen in BioShock 1 & 2 with some improvements. You can equip gears that gives you a few improvements like auto-casting lightning when you are struck or put your enemies on fire when you strike them with melee attacks.

There's the new "Sky-Line" mechanic that allows you to travel around the place and can even be used in your advantage during combat, your partner Elizabeth even rides with you.

And talking about Elizabeth, that's one hell of a companion. She is like Alyx in Half-Life 2: Episode One but instead of fighting she gives you support during and outside combat like finding and giving you ammo, salt, money and even warning about points of interest and some missable items like lockpicks. I love when i'm almost out of ammo and she throws me some ammo, she also plays a huge role in the plot.

Honestly i haven't cared about my companion in a single-player game since Alyx, she isn't useless like most companions who doesn't do jack aside from yelling at you all the time like 'AIM DOWN YOUR SIGHTS", " TAKE POINT", "THEY ARE KILLING US DO SOMETHING!!!". 

PC port is above average, there isn't much graphics options but at least the game runs great, without vsync the game always run above 60fps (sometimes going up to 90fps) with everything maxed out and the game has some pretty graphics.

It took me around 13 hours to beat the game.

Bioshock Infinite. This was a game. I enjoyed it. But like many others, the significance of the ending was lost to me. Somehow I don't have a lot to say now that I've completed the experience. But I will do my best to say as much as I can. 

The gameplay of Bioshock Infinite is its biggest strength. The game is incredibly fun to play. Almost every weapon feels unique and fun to use. There are a few that are pretty lame, the burst gun being my least favorite out of all of them. Otherwise they all feel natural to use and none completely outshine the others, although there are a couple that are really special. The new shield felt pretty dumb to have. Honestly, it didn't feel super necessary beyond allowing you to take a few extra hits before taking normal damage. It only really shines in harder difficulties or towards the end of the game.

The outfits are a hit or miss thing for me. On one hand you get encouragement to play in a bunch of different ways. On the other hand, most of those ways are so niche that you may seldom get benefit out of them. I found that most outfits didn't offer me benefits that were better than my current outfit. It kind of sucks because many of these are locked behind lock picking doors. So you spend however many lock picks just to get a hat that gives you 50 percent extra melee damage if someone is being affected by the crow vigor. I think these should've been a bit broader in what they do. That's all I have against them. 

The visual design of the game is a huge step up from the previous Bioshock titles. There is a big difference in what is being portrayed between Rapture and Columbia. It's nice to see designs in the series that appear cleaner and more well kept. Falling into ruin later rather than starting out that way. It felt fresh, especially after coming straight from the other two games. I really enjoy the city in the clouds look and how they portrayed it. Like Rapture, I focused more on the beauty of it rather than worry myself about how it works or how it came to be. There is a lot of care put into how everything looks and the evolution over time was something that consistently amazed me. 

Now I'm going to talk about the story and ending. So These next sections will be put in spoilers. An additional spoiler will be in my final thoughts. Look at your own risk if you wish to remain unspoiled. 

[spoiler] The story starts pretty strong. Taking things back in time from the previous Bioshock games, and also placing you in a different setting entirely. The opening is somewhat similar. Out on the ocean heading to a lighthouse, then heading inside to then be brought to a massive hidden city. Booker starts with a simple task, which is to find Elizabeth and then bring her back to whomever hired him. This quickly escalates to avoiding the entirety of Comstock's army and ducking through rifts. Where the rifts actually take you is pretty confusing and it doesn't get made any simpler after the ending. I mean it's not terribly hard to figure out, but the actual bearing it has on the story at the time is incredibly confusing. [/spoiler]

[spoiler] The ending itself is the biggest complaint I have heard about this game. While I'm not confused by it like some, I do agree that it isn't the greatest. I like the idea of everything being linked together. And I especially like how the ending essentially causes the story to never have existed in the first place. What I don't like is how the whole thing was handled. At times it feels like it's attempting to undo the significance of the first  two games by saying, "It's a different world but things are similar". Effectively turning the story of Rapture into an unimportant side adventure. It was nice to return to Rapture at the end, but the parallels being turned into a way to explain Infinite's story wasn't my favorite. The actual ending wasn't very confusing like I've heard many say. In the context of its own story it is a fine ending, though it feels rushed. I was expecting this big final battle but it never came. Instead I watched an incredibly long cut scene that tried, but failed to effectively explain itself. I figured out the dual personality of DeWitt and Comstock, but didn't really get why this particular DeWitt was the key to it all. Especially since his life path had already been decided. Killing him wouldn't realistically undo everything that had been done. Even under the game's own rules, this doesn't hold up well. Although I will say that I am limited in my own knowledge so take that with a grain of salts. The explanation of exactly who the Luteces are was lost on me. There is slight implications that they are the same person, but how they ended up that way wasn't explained much at all. I had to research that myself to figure it out. They are the most interesting part of the story other than Elizabeth herself. Yet they do not get the ending they deserve and ulitmately make the whole thing far more complicated than it needs to be. [/spoiler]

As its own thing, Bioshock Infinite isn't bad. I wish it were just that. Its own thing not tied to the Bioshock name, or at least not tied back to the other two games. [spoiler] Flowing into them rather than writing them off. [/spoiler] I recommend this game even with my criticisms. It's fun and the story it tells is interesting. I believe this game is one of those final series titles that got more flack than it deserved. After all of these years, it still holds up well. It lacks here and there, but makes up for those things in other departments. The additional content is pretty meh though. It doesn't really have a good to make up for it. At least not one that isn't the game that it ships along with. 

Check it out if it's on sale. I got it in a bundle with the other two games which is honestly the best way to get it in my opinion.

Gameplay is good. Story is interesting. But they pursue some political messages that are just awful. Now lemme clarify that NO, I do NOT have a problem with Bioshock being political. It's literally always been political. I also don't have a problem with it exploring certain topics, such as, in this specific case, racism. I DO, however, take issue with the portrayal of both sides of racism (racists vs minorities) as somehow equal, like an "everyone is right AND wrong and they're just as bad as each other!!" Like... no?????? The game tries so hard to convince you that the Vox Populi (allegory for self-freeing fugitive slaves) are just as bad as the Founders (allegory for slave owners) because of the chaos they cause. This is an insane take that they clearly knew wouldn't work, because they felt the need to insert a scene in which Populi leader Daisy Fitzroy just kinda... kills a child? Like why??? You can't just say "oh, so you think fighting racism is bad? Well what if you did a CHILD MURDER?! Checkmate libs!!!" and it really really really really really doesn't work. That's just some centrist bullshit. 

Anyways do I recommend it? If you enjoyed the first 2 games, then yeah I suppose I would. But even so, I absolutely detest the messaging of the game's bipartisan take on fighting bigotry.

The BioShock I had the most fun with out of the three. Wide variety of guns allows you to decide yourself this time how you want to approach combat, though a lot of guns don't really distinguish themselves enough to be useful, [spoiler]e.g. most of the Vox weapons.[/spoiler] But overall a very refreshing experience. Cool story, satisfying combat, fun new mechanics.

[spoiler] Especially the addition of the Skyhook makes combat significantly more dynamic. Very satisfying jumping around, riding rails, and dropkicking enemies into the void. Run n' gun kind of playstyle actually practical here.
Heavy hitting enemies are balanced way better as well, feels like you have viable counter options and more control during the fight once you figure out the mechanics. Instead of just spam dumping half your armory into a Big Daddy and still having to panic run for your life, classic BioShock 1 experience.[/spoiler]

Solid DLCs too which expand on the story, especially Burial at Sea - Episode Two did a good job of switching things up with its stealth focused approach. Even enjoyed the challenge mode again, always makes me appreciate the combat depth in BioShock games more. Has you faced with every facet of combat possibilities, and forces you to get the hang of your entire repertoire of plasmids and weapons. Which is nice because you tend to stick with what works during the main campaign. Blue ribbon bastardice.

There really aren't many games that manage to converge all the good things that make a game great and this game nailed it.
One of the best stories in a video game, worth making tv series or movies about it. Action is everywhere, you are gaming non-stop, no unnecessary cutscenes or anything that will stop the flow of the game. As for its gameplay, it has smooth controls and its a classic shooter game, but with salt powered magical skills, literally. I liked its gameplay, however, it wouldn't hurt to have some more enemy variety, and most salt skills were just a different elemental version of the other skills so, maybe some variety on that too. Music and osts are just top notch.

I really loved the idea that we have a companion to help us through the story and during gameplay. It helps to interconnect the story, action, and the gameplay all in one place, building the immersion of its world. I love Elizabeth's "here take these coins" or "here I found medkit" types of aids she gives, without them the game would have been difficult and wouldn't have the charming vibes it gives.

I played this game for the first time in 2022, 9 years after its intial release, but I honestly did not feel its age. If you had told me it had just come out, I would have believed it.

[b]Bioshock Infinite[/b]
Like the previous Bioshock games, its strongest point is atmosphere, though a very different one. This game is beautiful, all lights and greenery and clean buildings and nice people... and yet something feels off. Something feels very very wrong.
You explore several different environments and the more you progress, the stranger and crazier and darker it becomes.
The story was as satisfying and coherent as can be given the subject. Unlike previous games it's harder to understand the plot twist before it arrives, but when it does you reexamine everything and it all makes sense, so it was still very satisfying. You understand how all you are told fits together.

Gameplay-wise, combat is more dynamic than in the previous games, but has much less flexibility. You are limited to only two weapons at any given time, and you do not have any in reserve. If you want to change weapons you have to loot another one, and you never know where you're going to find what. Powers have more utility and less DPS potential, but there are still great options for combat. (Sadly, zap+bonk is no longer a viable combo...) You also loot random equipment that may not complement how you play, so there's a bit of luck involved. (But those you can keep and swap as needed.)

[b]Burial at Sea[/b]
The DLC was amazing. I loved it. That must be said before my main criticism, which is : it contradicts some fundamental explanations that were given in the base game. And that really, REALLY rubs me the wrong way, because I can't quite consider it canon. But it was SO GOOD.
[list]
[*]First : you play in Rapture. And despite my playing all the games back to  back, it still felt very nostalgic to go back there. (Btw, warning : do yourself a favour and do not play this DLC if you haven't played the first Bioshock.) It is set during Rapture's glory days so it feels like the base game : it's all lights and fun until you dig a little and realise how crazy the city really is.
[*]Second : the gameplay is very different from the base game. There are next to no way of killing enemies, you have to hide and sneak and disable. It's a refreshing change, and poses very different challenges.
[*]Finally, there are lots of relevations and story developments and plot twists, that all feel very good to learn, especially if you've played the first Bioshock.
[/list]

To conclude : it definitely feels like a Bioshock game despite the different setting so fans of the franchise can absolutely enjoy it. People who never played a Bioshock game can start with this one as it's not related to the previous two, with the exception of the DLC.

Just finished this game's achievement run and honestly I love this game. The Bioshock series have some of the best stories in gaming and Infinite does not disappoint. The vigors/plasmids along with the gun combat are extremely satisfying as well. 

If you wanna do an achievement run just beware City In the Clouds DLC. While I was able to get all of its ribbons (which are rewarded by completing challenges every wave in the wave based game mechanic) within 8 hours I have heard of people taking triple that time to do so. The other DLC content Burial at Sea Episodes 1 & 2 have super easy and quick to get achievements. The second hardest achievement will be in the base game 1999 mode which my only suggestion is to not spend all your money and keep about 500 on hand in case of deaths OR if you wanna cheese it just close the game in task manager before it can save. As for the hardest achievement to get all the ribbons in CITC, I suggest you run through all maps to get all vigors and clothes to make rerunning maps for specific challenges easier. 

I honestly love this game's story so much and think everyone should at least give this game a try. Hope you enjoy it if you decide to try it out!

The "Quality of life" update broke the game, it doesn't launch anymore. It's the end of an era, I guess. Steam support is useless for non-Valve games. The play button runs the 2K store launcher now, not the game itself. Shame on Valve for betraying their paying customers. :-(

EDIT: found a simple workaround online: if you're having the same problem, just run the game binary directly from disc instead of going through Steam. On Windows it's located here, but on other OSs should be similar:

<library>\steamapps\common\BioShock Infinite\Binaries\Win32\BioShockInfinite.exe

The game will still try to connect with 2K servers sometimes, though, but at least you can play it...

EDIT 2: To substantially reduce the time wasted by the game contacting 2K servers, I ran Windows Defender Firewall with Advanced Security and created a new firewall Outbound Rule to block all connections from Bioshock Infinite to the internet.

Also, in case I try to run the game from its Steam page by mistake, to prevent the launcher from even opening, I changed the security permissions on binary:

<library>\steamapps\common\BioShock Infinite\2KLauncher\LauncherPatcher.exe

for the Users group to "Deny" on the "Read & execute" and "Read" permissions.
No more 2K for me.

EDIT 3: Unfortunately, since an update on October 2023, if the game files are not up-to-date / cached, the 2K store always deploys, and I have to start the game from there. The only thing, for me, that actually improves the user experience starting the game (short of installing a cracked version, that is) is managing firewall rules that block outbound connections for executables both in the game directory (<library>\steamapps\common\BioShock Infinite)  and in the Take Two launcher dir (inside C:\Users\<username>\AppData\Local). After some googleing, I made a script that updates the firewall rules for all executables, recursively, in those dirs when I want to play. This way, at least, both the store and the game always start in offline mode. Let’s see how long this lasts before EDIT 4.

Bioshock Infinite is a masterpiece of the gaming world. While the game is not without its challenges, it's a rewarding experience for those who appreciate a deep narrative and an immersive world. Bioshock Infinite is a gaming gem that raises the bar for storytelling and world-building in the medium, making it a must-play for any gaming enthusiast.

[h1]BioShock Infinite: A Departure from Rapture to the Skies of Columbia[/h1]

[b]BioShock Infinite[/b] takes players out of the underwater city of Rapture and into the floating city of Columbia. In this game, you step into the shoes of Booker DeWitt, a man on a mission to pay off his debt by rescuing the enigmatic Elizabeth from Columbia's clutches. [b]BioShock Infinite[/b] offers a fresh setting, taking to the skies instead of the depths of the ocean, and boasts stunning graphics that can rival those of contemporary gaming. It provides a new experience while still retaining the essence of the previous games in the series.

In terms of storytelling, BioShock has always been known for its gripping and imaginative narrative with a hint of mystery and surprise at the end. This tradition continues in [b]BioShock Infinite[/b]. As Booker DeWitt embarks on his journey to escort Elizabeth and unravel the city's mysteries, things aren't always as they seem. The game initially presents a comprehensible story, but as you gain the ability to manipulate tears in the fabric of time and space, the narrative becomes more intricate and at times, bewildering.

The combat system in [b]BioShock Infinite[/b] sees some improvements over its predecessors. Booker can open rifts in space and time, allowing him to summon weapons or turrets seemingly out of thin air. This addition adds a strategic element to combat that was less prominent in the previous games. Columbia's skylines are also available for Booker to ride like roller coasters while engaging enemies. This dynamic use of the environment creates a more fluid and action-packed combat experience. Plasmids, which were featured in the earlier BioShock games, make a return as Vigors in [b]BioShock Infinite[/b], offering a fresh set of abilities to wield. Overall, the combat in [b]BioShock Infinite[/b] is may feels more enjoyable compared to BioShock 1 and 2 for some.

The stunning and varied scenery of the floating city of Columbia provides a fresh and immersive experience compared to the Rapture setting, which players had explored in the previous games. With grand architectural structures, beautiful skies, and hidden dangers lurking behind every corner, Columbia stands as one of the game's most outstanding elements. More importantly, the cityscape and the game's narrative are perfectly intertwined, enhancing immersion. While the downloadable content (DLC) for [b]BioShock Infinite[/b] takes players back to Rapture, it still manages to make sense within the overarching storyline.

Despite its many positive aspects, [b]BioShock Infinite[/b] does suffer from certain downgrades compared to its predecessors. The combat system has been simplified in some ways, with limitations on the number of weapons you can carry, making it more challenging to change strategies mid-combat. Additionally, you cannot hack machines and turrets as you could in the previous games. These changes were probably intentional and aimed at creating a fresh and distinct gameplay experience compared to the previous titles in the series.

The story, while initially captivating, feels somewhat weaker, especially in its final moments. Without delving into spoilers, it's safe to say that the story is engaging for a while but may leave players feels lackluster and stupid by the end. However, the DLC story is well worth experiencing.

Despite carrying the BioShock name and sharing some connections to the series, [b]BioShock Infinite[/b] is better classified as a spin-off rather than a main entry in the series. It deviates significantly from the first two games, providing a unique experience that some players may find better or worse than its predecessors. Overall, [b]BioShock Infinite[/b] offers enjoyable gameplay and an intriguing story set in the BioShock universe, making it accessible and enjoyable for a wide range of players.

After Bioshock 2 i was a little disappointed, it was basically a DLC for the first game. It's a side story set after the events of the first game but really not much has changed.

[h1] The Main Game [/h1]
Now Bioshock Infinite is a massive step up, in a whole new setting. We are no longer under water, now were in the sky on in floating islands travelling between them on airships and rail lines. I cannot stress enough how beautiful this game is with its art direction, much like the previous games before, but despite the massive change in scenery it still feels like Bioshock. The combat feels smoother, you have a AI partner that isn't a complete moron and actually helps you in combat, giving you ammo, health and salts. As well as opening tears to other realities to get more help in combat. The story is great to, with a well done twist at the end, much like the protagonist being a sleeper agent in the first game. The combat has been stripped down a bit though, now you can only get 2 weapons instead of a Doomguy arsenal in your back pocket. There also seems to be a lack of different weapons to use, the late game weapons are just a different version of the weapons you get at the beginning just instead of blue they're red.   

[h1] DLC'S [/h1] 
If your interested in the DLC's get them both or just episode 2, epesode 1 is only about an hour long and doesn't really add much. But episode 2 is much more integral and ties neatly back into the original game and being at least 3X longer. You play as Elizabeth but instead of running around shooting everyone its much more stealth focused with a silent crossbow and a stealth take-down. Now it is still first person and FPS stealth is always gunna be a bit questionable but its fine. Granted you can sort of just run past everyone in most cases and be fine as the enemy AI is too slow to cause any real damage to you.

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]
One of the best game franchises that didn't need a million sequels, it told its story and moved on. I would definitely recommend the whole series but i guess you can skip 2 if you really want.

BioShock Infinite is an absolute masterpiece that transcends the boundaries of conventional gaming. From the moment I delved into its mesmerizing world, I felt an unparalleled emotional connection that left me breathless. To assert that video games cannot be considered a form of art is to overlook the profound impact of this BioShock installment.

This extraordinary game elevates the very essence of entertainment to unparalleled heights. While I won't discredit other releases, it has been a considerable span of time since I've experienced such unadulterated joy while playing a video game.

The plot woven into BioShock Infinite is a magnum opus, rivaling the intricate narratives found in cherished visual novels and literature. It caters to those who appreciate a compelling storyline, offering a refreshing departure from the mindless action and generic shooting experiences that dominate the gaming landscape. Finding another game with a plot of this caliber seems improbable.

The game's graphics may not lean towards realism, but they boast a unique style that radiates beauty. While reminiscent of its predecessors, significant improvements in visual quality are evident. The only minor quibble is the overuse of "bloom" effects in some scenes, occasionally overwhelming the player. Nevertheless, BioShock Infinite's aesthetics remain breathtaking.

The music, a true gem in its own right, elevates the game to even greater heights. The soundtrack includes unforgettable compositions that illuminate the grandeur of Columbia and the story. The melodies seamlessly intertwine, with the standout 'Lighter Than Air' leaving an indelible mark. It effortlessly conveys the initial idyllic impression of the floating city while subtly hinting at its underlying enigma. The music in this game ranks among the best in the industry.

Gameplay in BioShock Infinite builds upon the foundations laid by its predecessors, BioShock 1 and 2, incorporating meaningful improvements. The introduction of gear that offers various enhancements, such as automatic lightning casting when struck or the ability to set enemies ablaze with melee attacks, adds depth to the experience.

The game's crowning innovation, the "Sky-Line" mechanic, transforms the way you traverse the environment, providing an exhilarating dimension to combat. Partnered with Elizabeth, you're in for a treat. She's not your run-of-the-mill companion who engages in combat. Instead, she offers invaluable support during and outside of battles, locating and providing essential resources like ammo, salt, money, and offering vital insights into points of interest and hidden items like lockpicks. Elizabeth's role in the plot is pivotal, making her one of the most engaging companions I've encountered in a single-player game.

Speaking of companions, Elizabeth stands in stark contrast to the usual, often infuriating companions who incessantly bark orders. Her usefulness is a breath of fresh air, seamlessly integrated into the gameplay and narrative.

The PC port of BioShock Infinite is a cut above the rest. While the graphics options may not be the most extensive, the game's impeccable performance, even without V-Sync, consistently delivers frame rates exceeding 60fps, often reaching an impressive 90fps with all settings maxed out. This game is an aesthetic triumph.

In conclusion, BioShock Infinite stands as a pinnacle of gaming artistry, a transformative experience that reaches unparalleled emotional depths. Its engrossing plot, stunning aesthetics, and remarkable music intertwine seamlessly with captivating gameplay and a genuinely supportive companion. If you seek a transcendent gaming experience, look no further than BioShock Infinite.

Rating: ★★★★★ (5/5)

BioShock Infinite is a breathtaking and mind-bending experience that soars above the clouds and touches the heart. With 9.3 hours spent exploring the floating city of Columbia, it's clear that this game is a masterpiece of narrative-driven gaming.

The setting of BioShock Infinite is a stark departure from the underwater world of Rapture. You find yourself in the ethereal and seemingly utopian city of Columbia, suspended high in the skies. The city is a breathtaking spectacle, a testament to the game's artistry and imagination. Its beauty is juxtaposed with underlying darkness, and the narrative is a rollercoaster of tension, intrigue, and emotion.

The narrative is the true star of BioShock Infinite. As Booker DeWitt, you are tasked with finding and rescuing a mysterious girl named Elizabeth from the clutches of Columbia's enigmatic leader, Comstock. The story weaves a complex and emotionally charged tale, delving into themes of fate, free will, and the consequences of one's actions. The character development of Booker and Elizabeth is exceptional, creating a genuine connection between the player and the game's world.

Gameplay in BioShock Infinite retains the series' signature mix of first-person shooting and supernatural abilities, known as Vigors. The combat is fast-paced and exhilarating, with an array of weapons and Vigors that allow for diverse approaches to confrontations. The introduction of the Skyline, a system that allows you to traverse the city on rails, adds a unique and thrilling dimension to battles.

Elizabeth, your companion throughout the game, is a revelation in AI design. Her presence is not merely decorative; she actively participates in combat, offers assistance, and even interacts with the environment. This AI innovation makes her one of the most memorable and endearing video game characters in recent memory.

Columbia is a living, breathing world filled with vibrant characters, engaging side stories, and thought-provoking commentary on American exceptionalism and religious fanaticism. The city's audio design, from the haunting music to the lively street chatter, is a masterclass in creating a living, immersive world.

The 9.3 hours you've spent in BioShock Infinite may have only scratched the surface of the narrative and the complex world it presents. The story's twists and turns, coupled with a stunning conclusion, ensure that this game remains in your thoughts long after the credits roll.

In conclusion, BioShock Infinite is an exceptional work of art in the gaming world. Its narrative depth, memorable characters, and emotionally charged story make it a landmark title. With the beauty of Columbia, the complexity of its characters, and the thought-provoking themes, BioShock Infinite is an unforgettable journey through the skies and an essential play for anyone who appreciates narrative-driven gaming. It's a transcendent experience that proves the power of storytelling in video games.

This masterpiece is both the first BioShock game I ever played, and really the first shooter I played outside of the Call of Duty bubble I stayed in for about three years after discovering shooters, and remains easily one of the most memorable experiences I've had in gaming. Don't let my Steam hours deceive you: I've also played this game on the PlayStation 3 for over 100 hours easily. To say that it's a great bit of fun is a definite understatement; BioShock Infinite is profoundly unique in its setting and remarkable in its fusion of gameplay mechanics with storytelling, as well as the development of its characters and ability to make the player care about them very soon after meeting them.

Columbia is a place full of genuinely unforgettable experiences: the entrance to the city through the rocket and the walk through the church to the tune of "Will the Circle Be Unbroken" (that actually brought me to tears the first time playing, no lie); the beautiful first look at the city proper, and the dynamic world you've entered playing out in front of you, including the little conversations you can listen to and other small yet notable interactions, to the fairground, to the flight across the city using the brilliant Sky-Lines. The introduction to Elizabeth was perfect, especially the section on the beach as she danced to "Rory O'More / Saddle the Pony," and watching her interact with her surroundings and develop her character, which she had enough of to fill multiple games of this caliber, was an experience simply unmatched by any other game I've ever played. I have to praise the tastefully anachronistic music you can listen to, mostly including old-timey renditions of mid-to-late 20th century classics that provide such charm that they alone can pull and immerse you in the BioShock Infinite Universe. I'll never forget "The Bonnie Blue Flag" playing as sniper rounds [i]psssh[/i]ed past my head, or "God Only Knows," Good Night Irene," and "Everybody Wants to Rule the World" as I walked around with Elizabeth and observed Columbia's horrifically racist past, bottled up and presented as a presence of American glory and strength, or "Fortunate Son" and "The Girl They Call Fitzroy" as the (based) Vox Populi's communist revolution sounded off all around the industrial areas and sweatshops of Columbia's working-class underbelly. I also want to mention the two small bits of music found in "tears" (miniaturized sections of non-local reality which can be bent by Elizabeth for a variety of purposes, such as aiding in combat or worldbuilding), "Fortunate Son" and "Girls Just Wanna Have Fun," both of which were, though a minor detail, just cool to listen to. I'll never forget the post-revolution aftermath, strolling through Columbia's remains and finding bodies and possessions in the streets, the bloody consequence of capitalist exploitation and oppression of working men and women. I'll always remember the Comstock House, the atmosphere of which was...well, it's hard to describe, but I found it both horrific and wondrous, as an alternate future played out in front of me in all its glory as you face weird and unnerving enemies unseen in any other section of Columbia.

Booker and Elizabeth are easily two of my all-time favorite characters I've encountered in any of the games I've ever played; it's extremely difficult not to enjoy their interactions and growth as the game progresses. Booker is a hardened, bitter and cold former Pinkerton agent, experienced in breaking workers' strikes and forcing Native Americans off their land, and as a result, comes across as little more than a jagoff antagonist, but by the end of the game, [spoiler]I was devastated at his death, technically by his own hand[/spoiler]. Booker is a dynamic character, and his change from grim taskmaster to genuinely empathetic is helped mostly by Elizabeth, the girl he is sent to Columbia to rescue in order to clear a debt. Elizabeth is a gem; gorgeous, knowledgeable, fun, funny, creative, curious and, most importantly, [i]positive[/i]. She is a master class in how to make a companion for an escort mission that will make a player [i]want[/i] to escort them, to hang around them and watch them learn and grow from their experiences with the world. Elizabeth comments on facets of Columbia she knows about, on its history and her understanding of it, and speaks with Columbia's citizens on some occasions, even giving a poor young boy an apple and singing "Will the Circle Be Unbroken" while Booker plays the guiter. This was just one of many striking moments that just took me out of the real world and into BioShock Infinite, one that I still remember. She and Booker made this game for me, and with other characters such as the manipulative reactionary Zachary Comstock, the badass revolutionary Daisy Fitzroy, the opportunistic and greedy Albert Fink, and the mysterious and eccentric Lutece twins, all of them solidified Infinite as a gaming experience I will never forget.

Is it for absolutely everyone? Not necessarily. Is it 100% perfect? Well...depends on who you ask, I guess. Is it damn close? [i]YES.[/i] I loved playing it for the first time back in 2015 and I love playing it now, for what it's worth. If you're interested in a story-driven, combat-heavy, good-looking and, at times, wacky and out-there experience, you'll probably like it, too!

Bioshock Infinite Review

Review is after completing the main game and the Burial at Sea DLCs. Did not play the Clash in the Clouds DLC as I have no interest in challenge gauntlets. In the past I have played BioShock 1 and Bioshock 2, so I was already familiar with gameplay, plasmids system and the lore.
[hr][/hr]


[b]Story[/b]
This game also has a story twist that all bioshock games are famous for. I found that twist satisfactory and astonishing enough. Nothing will come close to the mind blowing twist of Bioshock 1, but Bioshock Infinite's story was fascinating in its own right. There are two main characters in the game, Booker and Elizabeth supported by a multitude of side characters including the main villain. The game uses audio and video logs to expand on the story and I was able to find most of them while exploring. The setting of the game; in the sky as opposed to the bottom of the sea, is a welcome change of scenery. The game also depicts racism, inequality and the fight against this oppression. The Burial at Sea DLC story appears to be only for fans of the series as it takes players back to a past version of Rapture. The story in the DLC doesn’t gel together so well but it showcases an intriguing ending while also revealing how the story of Rapture connects to the story of Columbia.


[b]Gameplay[/b]
The game plays very similar to the previous Bioshock games. The main difference is provided by Elizabeth, as she has powers that can alter the shape of reality. Using these powers in addition to the vigors and the variety of interesting weapons the game provides produces excellent gameplay. It used to be that only enemy splicers had the ability to traverse vertically in the Bioshock games. This game now adds an element of verticality using the air-hook allowing Booker to get the drop on enemies frequently. There is an expanded enemy variety here, e.g. handyman mini-bosses and patriot robots. Elizabeth is a living companion that doesn’t get in the way and instead supports Booker in a multitude of ways e.g. tossing money, ammo and health during battles. The Burial at Sea DLCs introduced relaxed weapon restrictions and some engaging stealth gameplay. The set pieces are not as expansive as the main game but they were satisfactory to play in nevertheless.
However, the 2 weapon limit was annoying. It would have been great if we had access to the entire arsenal of weapons on demand, perhaps by using Elizabeth’s powers to store them somewhere. Therefore, the recommended weapons are a rifle and a selected heavy weapon of your choice. I found myself easing into one style of play: using a particular pair of weapons and a particular set of vigors and tonics. Therefore, this is a game that requires a 2nd playthrough to experience some other combinations. In such a manner, the game has strong replay value. It would have been great to have some puzzles to solve using the various vigors we don't use in combat. The game is also linear in its storytelling and does not have impactful choices.


[b]Graphics[/b]
The game offered a gorgeously colorful world; the sky setting of Columbia is the perfect setting for this game. An excellent choice by the game's creators! Another one of those games that I screenshot the most. 


[b]Controls[/b]
Played using mouse and keyboard on PC and the game handled mostly quite smoothly. The gunplay and use of vigors felt smooth and responsive.


[b]Side Missions[/b]
There are a few side missions in this game. But they are not very story rich as the main game but they do award some combat upgrades such as gear for Booker.


[b]Music/Soundtrack/Voice[/b]
There is one point in the game that has a wonderful singing quartet but that is an isolated and singular instance. The game has a decent soundtrack made of piano pieces but it wasn’t too noteworthy. The combat sound queues are on point. The voice acting of Booker and Elizabeth are brilliantly done. The side characters and the main villain also have excellent voice acting.


[b]Performance[/b]
Experienced no crashes and the game was not too hard on my PC (which is a mid-range PC). It did not cause undue heating of the CPU and GPU.

Bioshock Infinite took me on an unforgettable journey through the floating city of Columbia, and I must say, it left me utterly shocked. This game is an exceptional piece of storytelling and gameplay that, despite a few minor hiccups, left me thoroughly entertained and captivated.

One of the standout aspects of Bioshock Infinite is its gripping narrative. From the moment I stepped into Columbia, I was immersed in a world filled with complex characters, political intrigue, and mind-bending plot twists. The story was a rollercoaster of emotions and left me questioning my own understanding of the game's reality. The unexpected ending, in particular, completely blew my mind and left me pondering its implications long after the credits rolled. Few games manage to deliver such a thought-provoking and emotionally charged story, and Bioshock Infinite excels in this regard.

The gameplay was equally enjoyable. The combination of gunplay, vigors, and the Skylines made for dynamic and thrilling combat encounters. The ability to manipulate the environment using vigors added an extra layer of strategy to battles, making each encounter feel unique and engaging. The Skylines, on the other hand, allowed for exhilarating aerial combat and traversal, adding a new dimension to the gameplay.

However, no game is without its flaws, and Bioshock Infinite had a few. My main gripe with the game was the presence of some annoying bugs. Occasionally, I found myself stuck in the environment or facing weird glitches that disrupted my immersion. Even worse, there were two instances of broken cutscenes that forced me to restart the game to progress. These issues, while not game-breaking, were frustrating and detracted from the otherwise smooth experience.

Despite these minor setbacks, Bioshock Infinite is a solid game that I would wholeheartedly recommend to any gamer. Its compelling story, stunning visuals, and engaging gameplay overshadow the occasional technical issues. It's a testament to the power of storytelling in video games and an experience that will stay with me for a long time.

Beautiful, but :
-Girl is too perfect, physically and emotionally, while very incoherent.
-Loot tooltips can get overwhelming. Good for lore, but I'd mostly spam F around corpses and boxes for bulk ammo / health.
-Dramatic cutscenes kinda childish but that's pretty much in every big game nowadays
-Equipment complicated for nothing : lots of weapons, gear and abilities, but most of the time, I just do with whatever I find. While abilities can help, they aren't any game-changing, so quite forgettable, same for structures from other dimensions which were spoiling fights on top of that ; I basically used thunder a couple times but that's it. Also too lazy to make my gear build.
-On the other side, combat is very basic, and there's not really much more to it than taking cover.
-Melee particles take a lot of attention. When I first spammed it on rocket launchers, I didn't even realize my health was quickly going down as well.
-When dying, the player gets revived and enemies are healed a bit, which basically means you can bruteforce any fight without paying attention to staying healthy ; while it's great for people who want to focus on the story, I was playing on "normal, if you're used to FPS". And no, I'm not a crybaby (uh, depends on the game). I know dying to a fight is frustrating, but also more rewarding once I finally clear it. I rammed through the graveyard bossfight with 2 deaths and a pistol, and it just felt miserable.

Having played and loved the original Bioshock as soon as it came out, I have avoided this version for a very long time, and for good reason.
It is hard to describe what I liked in this game. Next to the story I did like the gameplay of the original Bioshock. The gameplay in Bioshock Infinite (BI) feels like a rip-off of this original gameplay... and as such I do not really appreciate it here. What the BI tries to add to the gameplay with Elizabeth's abilities is mostly useless to me and simply makes the game a bit more convoluted.
Same goes for the weapons. The fact that you can only carry two is probably supposed to add to a sort of realism, but only in a pseudo way. I find it a bit annoying. And with the limited amount of amunition, it becomes a just-take-what-weapon-is-lying-around kind of thing. And there is a huge number of different weapons and often two very similar versions of one and you can barely tell which one you carry at a time. But all this makes it pointless to be able to upgrade weapons. After all you cannot upgrade all weapons as much as you would like to, but you also cannot upgrade a few weapons as much as you like, cause you will not be able to mostly use these weapons, because you always have to use what is lying around and amunition is there for.
And when I said that BI feels like a Bioshock rip-off regarding gameplay, it is even more the case regarding the story. The story of the male and female protagonists feel like a cliche and I do not care for their story, it bores me and I feel no connection to those empty shells of people. The characters feel as believable as "Multiverse of Madness" in contrast to proper characters in "Guardians 3". The original Bioshock being based on the works of Ayn Rand, the story of BI is a western-steampunk-bad Scifi mess, and the twists and turns of the story are not all predictable, but feel like the twists and turns of any soap opera and pulp fiction.
I only finished the story to get it over with and now I am sad that this game carries the name Bioshock.

Bioshock 1 + 2 has been a love of mine for a long time however I was never able to complete infinite, it felt like something was missing... Overall gameplay was very fun and the story was much better than I anticipated.

[b] The Bad [/b]
The achievements were fun however the last ~15 were the awful clash in the clouds DLC which almost left me raging often due to the massive RNG with some of the blue ribbon challenges. For example the enemies would sometimes just jump off the map and die and void any "kill with ____" challenges... very stupid. To top it off if you fail the challenge you have to restart the entire level, you can't just restart one part.  The skyhook was sometimes buggy for me at times such as forcing my camera forward which was very annoying at times.
