2013 was the year "Bioshock Infinite" graced my computer screen. Yeah, I confess: my first taste of Columbia wasn't through a legit copy. But from the moment Booker and Elizabeth soared across the city in the clouds, the game left an indelible mark on me. If someone ever invents a gadget to wipe selective memories, this game’s the reason I'd buy it. Just to re-experience the magic, fresh and untarnished.

Infinite's a work of art. Not just in graphics or mechanics — though it shines there too — but in its narrative prowess. It weaves a tale so intricate, yet personal. It's about choice, consequence, and redemption. And while Rapture, the setting of the earlier games, was captivating in its underwater eeriness, Columbia stole my heart with its sunlit facades hiding dark secrets.

It's rare for me to look back with such affection for a game, so to make amends for my earlier piracy, I recently bought the entire Bioshock franchise. A nod to the devs for crafting worlds I could lose myself in. Just finished reliving the horror and beauty of Bioshock 1, now gearing up for the depths of Rapture again in Bioshock 2.

Bioshock Infinite, though, it stands on a pedestal of its own. It's a testament to games as more than just entertainment. They're experiences, memories, and sometimes, they're moments we wish we could live all over again. If you've not visited Columbia yet, trust me, it's a trip worth taking.

Personal words about the game: After the second game of the series, my interest in the Bioshock series increased, and the fact that the game has managed to stand the test of time and still offers contemporary visuals has given me hope. Especially the presence of a black haired, blue eyed girl who will accompany you throughout the game was quite delightful.

There is something to tell about the story: The concept of a guardian figure protecting a girl, a recurring theme throughout the series, is also present in this game. The stories in the previous games of the series were quite good, but the story and concepts in this game are much better and more comprehensive than the others. The story begins with two person we can not quite see on a boat sending us somewhere to find a girl. It looks familiar. However, we then enter a new gaming world with a very nice presentation. Our main goal is to rescue the princess trapped in the tower from a terrifying monster. Wait a minute, this is suspicious. Perhaps the main theme seems simple, but the constant diversification of the story and its unrelenting pace are very commendable. A dictator brainwashing the minds of people, minorities arming themselves for freedom, poors, and a woman traveling between parallel universes by our side. I believe these themes are well executed, but the linear progression of the game prevents a detailed exploration of these topics. I will not delve into these topics, especially the concept of parallel universes. I will leave those for you to discover on your own.

Retinal Pleasure or Art: Look, this game was released in 2013, but thanks to its design and lighting, it offers visuals that can easily rival today's games. I especially loved the outfits they chose for Elizabeth. Why did people stop wearing such stylish clothes? When you look closely at the textures, you can tell it is a bit dated, but the game itself has a mesmerizing presentation. I do not take many screenshots, but I took a ton in this game. You are in a city flying in the sky, and the buildings are amazing. You can even install mods for this, I did, and it was a visual feast for my eyes. Oh, and do not forget, you will also see the city of Rapture in the game.

Mechanics:  I am going to split this part into two and provide my comments accordingly.

1- In terms of the classic jumping, running, melee combat, and stealth aspects, there is not much to tell. When it comes to weapon variety, the series has always excelled in this regard, but this time, there were not any of the unique, power-fantasy-inducing weapons found in the previous two games. In short, there were more realistic weapons, but the variety was lacking. Additionally, you can only carry two weapons at a time, which I did not like. The Hand Cannon and Sniper Rifle were my favorites. Always aim for the head. Apart from that, the game introduces a new travel system called the Sky-Line. It allows for constant platform switching during combat and provides opportunities for tactical retreats, which is quite effective.

2- Unlike the other games in the series, this time, the special powers are called Vigors, not Plasmids. Essentially, they serve the same purpose but with some differences. For instance, there are abilities like charming, summoning crows, canceling gravity, and catching bullets mid-air to throw them back. You should see and experience these for yourself. Additionally, the rifts called Tears enhance the tactical depth of the battles.

Nomismata: I will divide the DLC section into three parts.

1- The first DLC. It was dull, with challenges similar to clearing waves and following the rules, as seen in the previous games of the series.

2- The second DLC. You start as Booker in the game, and you are in Rapture. The design of Rapture and the new Elizabeth were marvelous. There is not much mechanical diversity, but the first part sets the stage for the second part, so you complete it without getting bored of the DLC. It also has a beautiful ending.

3- The third DLC. This is where we finally get what we've been waiting for. New weapons, new powers, and the chance to play as Elizabeth. What more could you ask for? The second DLC was a setup for the third DLC, and this time, it comes with a longer gameplay duration, diversity, and story updates. Especially the ending of the DLC was excellent. To avoid spoilers, I will not say much, just play it.

Atto Finale: In summary, the game is fantastic. You will not get bored playing it. Especially after finishing the main game, be sure to dive into the DLCs; they are also excellent. The only downside I would mention is the storytelling style. Perhaps they could have used a different approach to make the story more easily understandable. In particular, ladies and gentlemen, please consider returning to the old-fashioned way of dressing. Elizabeth's outfits are superb.

[h1] A twist you work out in the first 15 minutes and spend the whole game waiting to be paid off. [/h1]

My biggest issue with the game is that nothing about it screams Bioshock. The developers have done away with Bioshock's clever story writing entirely- writing that's renown for being subverted by suspenseful horror on an almost cinematic level. This game has ONE jump scare, and worse yet does nothing to build tension. It is hard to compare Infinite to the first two games because it is nothing like them. 

Following from this point, the developers answer most our questions with mind-numbing exposition, something granted that happened in the first game. Infinite however, takes this to a whole new level. Without spoiling the story; Elizabeth might as well be the story narrator, she chirps away constantly about what's happening and even tells you what's going to happen next otherwise the story would make no narrative sense. If you made her silent, nothing would make any sense, this is bad storytelling. 

With regards to storytelling yet again, the game (unlike Bioshock 2) gives the player no free-will and treats the player like a toddler; spending hours chasing Elisabeth around, fixing her mistakes and being forced into traps and 'plot twists' without any control or say in the matter. You also cannot influence the ending, despite being given choices throughout the game so all and all nothing you do matters- it is inconsequential to the story. Which is a massive downgrade from Bioshock 2. 

[spoiler]The red-herring that kills the story, Cornelius Slate (the veteran the player fights for Shock Jockey), supposedly serves with your character Booker before Booker becomes Comstock. Which naturally throws the player off the main story. It is later revealed that the player version of Booker spent his life waiting for Anna/Elizabeth after giving her up. So the players version of Booker is a separate Booker to the one that served with Cornelius, as is the one who served with the Vox Populi. Which leads me to believe Songbird is a version of Booker. The ending also makes out that there are infinite Elizabeths and Bookers. So we have moved beyond just time-travel and are now in multiverses.  

The infinite Booker and Infinite Elizabeth arc only works if neither can influence time, which the ending reveals is not the case, as Comstock goes back to get the child. So infinite Elizabeths can go back and stop Booker from forfeiting the child. Therefor Comstock never exists and therefor Comstock can never exists. Unless for some reason [something] infinite is stopping infinite Elizabeths, which is never the case. So, why does Elizabeth kill Booker? It never occurs to her that she can travel back in time? even after seeing infinite timelines? Maybe she can't control her ability to timetravel? But if that's the case how does older Elizabeth send us back in time?

This game has been set up to feature multiple endings, it should have had multiple endings. There was so much filler content here, the developers could have easily cut out small snippets in favour of different endings. Especially after Bioshock 2. The developers have produced a game that made out as if the player had free-will and then simply taken it away. A story with infinite possibilities and the player is forced to play one of the worse possible endings. It is such a wasted opportunity. [/spoiler]


To add salt in the wound, the combat has been completely tailored to conform with the looter shooter trend that was common at the time. Slow, methodical and heavy combat has been replaced with fast-paced gunplay and Plasmids warped to match- the murder of crows ability was just down right bizarre. The plasmids have also lost their utility and are functionally no different from weapons now. This was all terribly upsetting, and burnt me out fairly quick. I will however admit that I enjoyed the skyhook and thought it was masterfully well designed. This however, is Bioshock, not Justcause or Assassin's Creed. I don't understand what prompted this design decision, beyond 'we want a fast-paced looter shooter, and why not make it a Bioshock game?'

That's my review turned rant, I really wanted to enjoy this game but am so awfully disappointed. I will give the DLC a try tonight and see if that changes my opinion somewhat. Thank you for reading, and I hope you enjoy the game more than I did at the very least.

While most of the game is in fact, really cool ascetics and soundtrack wise, the ending is probably the most unsatisfying ending I've ever seen in any story game. If you want a game to go pew pew and kill a few racists, this is your game. But don't expect a satisfying boss battle. The game will build up "Pr0phet C0mst0ck" like it is going to be the most legendary conflict ever, only for you to kill him in a cinematic in the period of five minutes, and then you will have to deal with the most frustrating wave of black ops 2 zombies god himself could possibly create, and to top it off, the final ability(which is also hyped up to high heavens) is really only useful if you save it for zepplins and patriots. And now without spoiling too much for you, let me inform you that there is no happy ending. Instead you get a bunch of wishy washy philosophy shoved down your throat and you die in the most nonsensical matter possible. How this game could have 6 immersive interesting hours of well thought out story and decent game play have the laziest ending imaginable, constantly hype up for boss fights they never deliver, and be so god damn unsatisfying is beyond me.

If you mind, I have a few tips before you get your hands on this masterpiece of a game: 

1. If you can, play BioShock 1 first. Even though the gameplay has aged terribly, it will take you "only" about 10 hours, has a great story of its own and will drastically increase your enjoyment of this game (especially the DLCs). BioShock 2 doesn't have much to do with this game storywise, but is still a solid experience if you want to immerse yourself in the world some more.

2. PAY ATTENTION to the world around you. There are countless little scraps of foreshadowing and allusions to the game itself and other BioShocks scattered all over Infinite and its DLCs. The game and its DLCs aren't terribly long to begin with, so take the time to play a little more critically and inquisitively than you usually would. You'll be rewarded with some jaw dropping / expanding-mind-meme moments.
If you haven't played this game I would highly recommend! This is a must play. If you are into interesting movement, FPS, and a weird, whacky and amazing story, fackin' play it!

Introduction:
BioShock Infinite, developed by Irrational Games and published by 2K Games, is a tour de force in the world of video games. Released in 2013, it quickly became one of the most critically acclaimed and beloved titles of its generation. Building upon the success of the original BioShock series, Infinite takes players on a mind-bending journey through the floating city of Columbia, where political ideologies, quantum physics, and morally ambiguous characters collide. In this review, we'll delve deep into the various aspects that make BioShock Infinite a true masterpiece.

Setting and Atmosphere:
Columbia, a floating city suspended in the sky, serves as the game's backdrop. From the moment you step foot in this marvel of art-deco architecture, you're immediately captivated by its beauty and eerie tranquility. The city's bright, sunlit streets and sweeping vistas juxtaposed with the underlying tension of racial and social inequality create a unique and immersive atmosphere. The attention to detail in Columbia's design is nothing short of astounding, with each district telling its own story through environmental storytelling.

Storytelling:
At the heart of BioShock Infinite is its riveting narrative. Players assume the role of Booker DeWitt, a grizzled former Pinkerton agent tasked with rescuing Elizabeth, a mysterious woman with supernatural powers, from her captivity in Columbia. As the story unfolds, layers upon layers of complexity are revealed, including themes of alternate realities, determinism, and the consequences of one's choices. The game's story is a testament to the power of interactive storytelling in video games, leaving players questioning their own choices and moral judgments long after the credits roll.

Characters:
BioShock Infinite boasts a cast of memorable and morally ambiguous characters. Booker DeWitt is a complex protagonist, haunted by his past and faced with impossible decisions. Elizabeth is a standout character, her childlike innocence contrasting sharply with her remarkable powers. The villainous Comstock, the enigmatic Lutece twins, and the rebel leader Daisy Fitzroy all contribute to a rich and dynamic cast. The relationships between these characters evolve throughout the game, adding depth to the overall narrative.

Gameplay:
While BioShock Infinite is primarily a first-person shooter, it offers a range of gameplay elements to keep things fresh and engaging. Booker wields a variety of weapons and can harness Elizabeth's abilities to manipulate the environment, summon supplies, and open tears in reality. The skyline system, allowing players to zip around the city on rollercoaster-like tracks, adds an exhilarating and unique element to combat. The mix of gunplay, powers, and environmental traversal makes for a diverse and enjoyable gameplay experience.

Visuals and Art Direction:
Visually, BioShock Infinite is a masterpiece. The game's art direction, characterized by its vibrant colors and intricate design, is nothing short of breathtaking. From the sprawling, cloud-shrouded skylines to the ornate interiors of Columbia's buildings, every aspect of the game's visual presentation is a work of art. The character design is equally impressive, with distinctive outfits and facial expressions that convey a wealth of emotion.

Soundtrack and Audio Design:
The game's soundtrack, composed by Garry Schyman, is hauntingly beautiful and perfectly complements the atmosphere of Columbia. From the stirring choral pieces to the eerie renditions of familiar songs, the music enhances the emotional impact of the story. The voice acting is top-notch, with Troy Baker's performance as Booker and Courtnee Draper's portrayal of Elizabeth standing out as particularly exceptional.

Themes and Social Commentary:
BioShock Infinite is more than just a visually stunning and mechanically satisfying game; it also delves into thought-provoking themes. It explores issues of American exceptionalism, racism, religion, and the consequences of unchecked power. These themes are woven into the narrative seamlessly, sparking introspection and discussion among players.

Conclusion:
In conclusion, BioShock Infinite is a masterpiece of storytelling and game design. Its rich narrative, unforgettable characters, stunning visuals, and thought-provoking themes make it a standout title in the world of video games. Whether you're a fan of first-person shooters, immersive narratives, or thought-provoking storytelling, BioShock Infinite is an experience that should not be missed. It is a shining example of the potential of video games as a medium for artistic expression and storytelling.

This is what a game should be; something that draws you in with a death-grip and won't let go until the very end.  A story so deep and twisted, with a truly epic plot twist in the end that will leave you breathless.  

There's a reason why Bioshock Infinite won numerous awards:  the graphics and fluid game play; the ability to upgrade weapons and attributes; the depth of the characters, their backstories and the voice acting...it's all so 'fleshed out' that you'll not only feel that you're a part of everything that's going on in Columbia but that you're also a part of each character's life, characters that you'll likely never forget until the end of your days.  The Burial At Seal episodes are a great touch as well and further the plot that unfolds in the main game, with the second and final part being so epic that it feels like a game unto itself.  

All of the Bioshock games are phenomenal achievements, not just as far as games go, but also as works of art; games that let you know the developers feel as strongly about their product as all of us gamers do. Bioshock Infinite though....is truly a masterwork that must be experienced.

P.S. Try it on 1999 mode while not using vending machines.  It's extremely challenging but to a fault - you won't regret the journey if you make it to the end in one piece :]

A Late Discovery, An Unforgettable Journey

I've just wrapped up Bioshock Infinite, a game I delved into two years later than the rest of the world. Honestly, it wasn't even on my radar, but a friend insisted it was something special. So, with a shrug, I decided to give it a whirl, and boy, am I glad I did. This game is an absolute gem, and that ending... wow.

Intriguingly, I ended up purchasing the season pass and blitzed through it all in a single day! I had initially pegged this as just another run-of-the-mill action shooter, but Bioshock Infinite surprised me on so many levels. It's not just a game; it's an enthralling narrative experience.

Now that I've reached the end, a peculiar emptiness has settled in. The last time I felt like this was after finishing The Witcher 3, and that says a lot. Although Bioshock Infinite might not boast the same vastness in terms of content, its 20 hours were enough for me to form deep connections with the characters and become utterly engrossed in its intricate lore.

To be honest, I find myself yearning to erase my memory so I can relive the journey once more. It's a melancholic feeling, knowing that it's all over, and that void it leaves is hard to shake off. Bioshock Infinite, you've left an indelible mark on me, and I'm profoundly grateful for the experience.

In conclusion, this game was a late discovery for me, but it's an unforgettable one. It's more than just entertainment; it's a captivating narrative that lingers in your thoughts long after the credits roll. I'm a little sad it's all over, but the memories will stay with me forever.

I think these days Bioshock Infinite has even more value than it did when it first came out back in 2013, what with all it's multiverse shenanigans and timeline-hopping. It's actually kinda impressive how ahead of its time it was with this trend. I mean this game was a huge deal back in the day and blew my mind because it was my first time seeing the multiverse in action. I remember finishing this game for the first time and being like "That was the best game I've ever played in my life!". Granted I was 13 at the time haha. This game was a cornerstone of gaming for me back in the day, yet I haven't touched it in a number of years so here I am in 2023 giving it a replay to see how it holds up.

The WORLD in this game, oh my god it's still crazy cool to me. This giant floating city in the sky that's run by an ultra-patriotic American society is so unique and there's not much that rivals it in the gaming space in my opinion. The game takes place in 1912 and has a cool mix of stuff from that era and more futuristic blended together. You'll be running around using old wooden carbines and rifles surrounded by tech that really shouldn't exist at that time, it works surprisingly well. 

The game is gorgeous and full of detail in general, and the way the story is presented and the way characters are written makes it feel like a Disney movie. A good Disney movie like Tangled, I mean. (modern Disney just ain't it but that's besides the point) and a lot of that comes from Elizabeth who is just a fantastic character whenever she's on screen and works really well with Booker, the protagonist. I think Infinite definitely has the best characters in the series by far.

The gameplay is where Infinite gets a lot of flack these days. Not that it's bad but it's a far cry from the old Bioshock games. Levels are very linear, there's no hacking and a lot of the im-sim elements have been dumbed down. And yeah, that stuff is disappointing don't get me wrong. But I do think Bioshock Infinite has enough new stuff going on to make it stand out on its own. If I had to describe the gameplay it would be "scrappy". The way the game is designed makes it so you don't stay in one place for too long. There's a 2 weapon limit so you're kinda forced to run and find a new gun once you run out of ammo during a firefight, which you eventually will. There's also a shield that acts like a regular regenerating health bar which I'm mixed on. I feel like the old medkit system worked fine and would work better with the new gameplay style but it's alright. 

As far as bad stuff goes... I mean a lot of it's subjective stuff. Some love the story, some hate it. I feel like that's a universal thing with the multiuverse theme, and that'll be the biggest deciding factor as to whether you like the game or not. If you don't mind multiverse/time travel stories there's a LOT of good stuff here. I would go as far to say it's a masterpiece in terms of what it's going for, but your mileage may vary. Either way, I highly recommend trying it at the very least if you haven't.

In a medium where few titles can claim perfection, BioShock Infinite stands as an exception. It's a game that leaves no room for criticism, achieving a level of excellence that is rare. It's not merely a future classic; it may already be considered a classic in its own right.

On the other hand, I initially anticipated that BioShock Infinite would follow the trend of underwater cities, but once again, the developers showcased their pioneering spirit in the gaming industry. What a magnificent game it turned out to be! It had the power to both put a smile on my face and bring tears to my eyes. If you're a fan of the original BioShock, you absolutely must experience this gem. These creators need to conjure up another masterpiece because they have an uncanny knack for crafting the perfect formula to keep players enthralled for hours on end.

Pros:

- Graphics so good, your eyes will high-five each other.
- A plot that's more twisted than a pretzel on a rollercoaster.
- Combines old-school and new-school game mechanics like peanut butter and jelly (but with more explosions).

Cons:

- The story's more linear than a shopping cart with a wonky wheel.
- It dives into complex topics like a kid into a ball pit – only ankle-deep.
- Save points are rarer than a unicorn at a disco.
- Some late-game hiccups that make you wonder if the game needs a cough drop.
Bioshock 2 I think is the best.  But Infinite does a good job with resetting the series and making it stand out with it's own systems and style.

TLDR: Not recommended, 2K launcher sucks, game breaking bugs still in the game 10 years post release.

I only found the story mildly interesting and the combat was pretty good but gets old. I only stuck to using about three vigors for the whole game and did more with guns as the vigor upgrades are ridiculously expensive compared to the weapon upgrades. I completed the campaign on hard mode straight up which then unlocked a harder '1999' difficulty mode which I ignored and instead uninstalled the game.

The things that really turned me off the game were:
1. Losing my sprint all the time from hitting a pebble or invisible object
2. Getting stuck between objects requiring a checkpoint restart to fix (only happened once)
3. Elizabeth the friendly NPC ALWAYS getting in my way blocking doorways
4. Experiencing a game breaking bug where it spawned me under the elevator at the start of the hand of the prophet level. This required me to fiddle with the graphics settings and also replay the entire previous chapter to fix in order to be able to progress the game. This is a known bug yet 10 years after release it is STILL in the game causing problems.
5. In the late game you will be in situations (such as the ghost battle) where you run out of ammo and have to switch to random weapons you find. The problem is at that stage of the game you have the weapons you like that you have upgraded the damage for which do well so when you go to these other random weapons they perform very, very poorly. You go from having a challenge doing reasonable damage to every enemy being a massive bullet sponge because these other weapons have no upgrades and do pathetic damage.
6. The piece of crap 2K game launcher that was added in via a patch after the fact a long time after the game released. 

Things I liked:
1. The OP sniper rifle for popping heads
2. Shooting enemies off of skylines
3. The large number of secret rooms, boosts/upgrades and collectibles.

Not recommended. Play fallout 3/4 or something else instead.

My problem with the game was the depiction of the Vox. It just comes off very enlightened centrist. Still a pretty solid game.

One of my all time favorite video game series. When this was released in 2013 it was unlike any other game visually and in terms of lore it was a mindf*** as all the Bioshock games were. I've played through this game multiple times on console and once on PC and it was just as fun each time. I think it goes without saying that this game will go down in history as one of the most bizarre, fierce, and most out of this world campaigns in gaming.

I always come back to replaying this gem every couple of years, and even though I know how it ends it still trips me out every time I finish. I know it's not everyone's favorite Bioshock installment; it's not Rapture and it's not [i] technically [/i] a horror game, but I think it's become my favorite by far. The unsettling religious cult backing, the illusion of grandeur Columbia, the early 1900s atmosphere, and the history of post civil war fantasy all blended to make up some insane lore and story. This game makes you feel like you're in Disneyland for the first time, even when replaying it for the 10th time.

This game is an emotional roller coaster to say the least. Ever since this game's demo came out I've been dying to play it. I just never had the system to do so. And boy am I glad I have one now. If you're waiting to play this game, or if it's been sitting in your steam library for a while: play it! Do it! You literally have nothing to gain from not playing it. 
This game is a little outdated. I found myself stuck on an object, a simple checkpoint restart did the trick. But all the same this game is a must play. You have to listen to the voice recordings to really immerse in the world. There are little tidbits that explain things that were only mentioned briefly in the main dialog. 
In short: Play this game. No, really. Play it. This game is massive in size and even bigger in it's story. 
Trust me...Play it. I can't say that you'll regret it.

BioShock Infinite has taken my gaming experience to new heights. From the moment I stepped into the floating city of Columbia, I was captivated by its breathtaking beauty and intricate design. The blend of historical elements with science fiction creates a unique world that I couldn't help but immerse myself in.

The storyline, filled with twists and turns, had me on the edge of my seat throughout the entire journey. The characters, particularly Booker and Elizabeth, felt real and relatable, making me genuinely care about their fates. The game's ability to explore complex themes while delivering an action-packed adventure is truly remarkable.

The gameplay mechanics, including the use of Vigors and the Sky-Hook, added a layer of excitement that I hadn't experienced before. The combat scenarios were dynamic and engaging, and the ability to traverse Columbia's skyline added a whole new dimension to the gameplay.

The attention to detail in BioShock Infinite is outstanding. The world-building, the music, and the atmosphere all come together to create an unforgettable experience. Whether I was exploring the streets of Columbia or unraveling its mysteries, every moment felt meticulously crafted.

BioShock Infinite's Burial at Sea DLC expanded the story even further, offering a satisfying conclusion to the series. The care that the developers put into creating a cohesive and thought-provoking narrative truly shines through.

In a world where gaming experiences can vary greatly, BioShock Infinite stands as a shining example of storytelling and gameplay excellence. It's a journey that I'll never forget, and I wholeheartedly recommend it to anyone seeking a captivating and unforgettable adventure.

I wish that Steam had some kind of "Mixed" review option. I don't [i]hate[/i] this game -- there's a lot that it does well. The worldbuilding is excellent -- Columbia looks beautiful and is a lot of fun to explore; the interactions with Elizabeth, both in and out of combat, are well-designed and immersive; the music does a fantastic job of adapting modern music into pre-war styles (e.g: ragtime, big band, barbershop quartet, etc.); and the combat has some great moments. In addition, as much as the story bothers me, there are some well-written pieces of dialogue -- I particularly like the dialogue between the Lutece twins.

Unfortunately, there is much about this game that irks me. It feels like Bioshock Infinite has a lot of missed potential. I think [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=43lZUa69umw]this video[/url] summarizes my thoughts about the game pretty well.

With such a expertly crafted setting and many compelling characters, the game wastes itself on a nonsensical and frankly boring story. The intro and first (maybe second?) act of the game (up until the First Lady Airship) had me hooked, but as I continued playing, the story just kept dragging on and on and became less grounded and focused. In my opinion, the story could only have focused on [i]one[/i] of its main plot-points: [spoiler]The city of Columbia and its connections to white supremacy and American exceptionalism, or the many-worlds interpreation of quantum mechanics and parallel universes[/spoiler]. You can't have both and still maintain a coherent and meaningful story. While I appreciated the more character-driven nature of the second plot, the first could also have been as character-driven. In contrast, Bioshock's narrative had a much more grounded narrative with a twist that didn't throw the story into complete disarray; I see no reason why Infinite could not have done the same.

Perhaps the worst part about the story is that it tries to talk about so much, yet says so little. The original Bioshock had a masterful critique of libertarian capitalism, whereas Infinite only presents a shallow social commentary and shrouds its narrative in dubious science-fiction.

Furthermore, the health and salts system not allowing you to keep medkits and salt canisters proved to be frustrating at times and, even though the two weapon limit encouraged swapping weapons frequently which I liked, it became increasingly more restrictive in later sections of the game. As well, the game's hard mode brought with it a fair amount of bullshittery - especially with regard to enemies such as the Handyman and [spoiler]Lady Comstock's Ghost (whose inclusion doesn't make any fucking sense)[/spoiler]

If you enjoyed the first Bioshock game, it is worth experiencing because it does satisfy that Bioshock itch. But beyond the "Bioshock" label and judged solely on what the game offers, I would not recommend it.
Mechanically the worst Bioshock but the story is terrific.

This entry, in the franchise, took a whole different approach to what "Biohsock" is. And with that being said it succeeded. The main story line veers away from an underwater city and did the opposite... a city in the clouds. It has many great characters and places you visit. The "Infinite" part will make sense as you complete the game and I have to say It's a very impressive story. Now it doesn't stop there, the DLC "Burial at sea" episode's 1 and 2 take us back to Rapture and give us more insight on how the events of the first game came to be. It's very well done. I have to admit that I like Bioshock 1 and 2 more because of the setting but, at the same time, I do appreciate Infinite and what it does for the Bioshock timeline and I still think it's a must play.

You know… as much as I don’t like original Bioshocks, due to how drab and utterly depressing they are, this game is rather good. First paragraph after this is about my impression from the game, second is good points and third is bad and then I’ll tell you if I’d recommend the game for real.

Remember previous games in series? How depressive and weird they are, how Big Daddys are angry you’ve looked at them wrong way or how beautiful city turned to madness (and that’s putting it mildly), all because it was too small for two rich dudes (and one was an idiot)?  Yeah, here we have none of that and for the better. The world is still all kinds of messed up, characters have own, sometimes utterly stupid, motivations and main antagonist is genocidal maniac turned cult leader, but it feels a lot livelier and as if someone actually tried making functional “perfect” society for once… and kind of succeeded. Game feels, plays and looks as something more enjoyable and bigger than sum of its parts. Equally beautiful, depressing and bittersweet. It feels right.

Characters and their interactions (“Booker! Catch!” :) ), most of the story, but most of all this game lets you stop and think. It doesn’t force you to rush through, as fast as possible. Where other games would make you hurry because you have a world to save for some reason, Infinite says “yeah… you’ll get there eventually, for now have a break and explore the fair”. Elizabeth is, as odd as it sounds, one of the characters that you and not only Booker can, and likely, will, like, this is a rarity. Even more rare is that she isn’t deus ex machina nor needs saving at every turn, takes skill to do that.

Now the plot sometimes, or to be precise – half the time, doesn’t make sense. Lets look at you helping Resistance: you go to Fitzroy, get sent to an engineer, then jump realities, do plot-realted stuff, jump again to end up… somewhere that isn’t even your original reality. And that somehow is fine and dandy. Perfectly normal. Apart from minor graphical issues and extra launcher, this is perhaps all I can really say about unlikable parts of this game.

Would I recommend it? Yes, even with the launcher. Pretty nice game, even if it wasn't titled “Bioshock”.

TL;DR --- Worth playing once.

I've now completed 2 playthroughs of the base game, completed all CitC arenas, played through both dlc chapters, and completed all story content on 1999/1998 mode.

After all of this, I've come to the conclusion while Bioshock Infinite is a good game, I would not say that it is a great one. 

Combat is fun but linear, repetitive & always on a large scale. If you want to run around and blast things, this is a game for you. That said, if you come into this title expecting a stealthy experience akin to previous Bioshock games, you will be disappointed.

The narrative is captivating on a first playthrough, but under closer inspection loses much of its impact.
If you look past its spectacle and begin asking questions, really assessing the game design, you will most likely find it lacking. 

CitC is fun, but the blue ribbon achievement is a ridiculous time sink. 
If you find pleasure in it, all the more power to you.

The DLC chapters resemble previous Bioshock titles far better than the base game. Combat is smaller in scale, ammo is scarce, and stealth is viable. The major fault of the DLC rests with part 2, which despite having fun gameplay, is full of plot holes and leaves a bad taste in your mouth.

Rating --- 8/10 --- Play the base game once and try both CitC and BaS Ep1. Replays and BaS Ep2 really sour the narrative.

It's not perfect, arguably the worst of the trilogy, especially compared to the first two. Whether it be the inconsistent and confusing story telling about multiverses and the god forbid Burial at Sea DLC, or the severe amounts of downgrades in gameplay when compared to the first two BioShock entries, I still to this day enjoy my experience with the campaign. 

The beautiful and, in my opinion, unmatched art direction that they went for Columbia, and it's many paralleling technology to Rapture are some of my favorite things about infinite. Alongside that would be the world building and how they incorporate stuff from the distant futures into the idealized world of Columbia, an example being the musical tears that play 20th century music that subsequently reflect into covers that better reflect the 1912 period of infinite.

I've played this game through for the first time this year, and it's still a very enjoyable experience that holds up in a lot of ways.

The gameplay is fun, the action is satisfying, it looks great, and it's a game that also benefits from [u]not[/u] embracing a more open world approach to its design. The other big plus is the engaging narrative and characters that elevates it from other games in its genre.

That being said... This is also a game that doesn't do its due diligence when it comes to the full implications of some of its story elements and politics. Which is a bit concerning, considering the nature of those very elements. I'm being a bit vague here to avoid spoilers, but just to be clear, the game is definitely saying 'fascism bad', but its focus on its characters both helps and hinders it by sidestepping and brushing over the deeper conversations about how to actually combat fascism for instance.

In any case, I still think it's a memorable game that's worth experiencing even today, even if it's not quite as clever as it would like to think it is, and definitely doesn't stick the landing for me in terms of those pesky political implications.

(And yes, I know that there are famously certain Gamers™ who absolutely abhor any discussion of politics when it comes to video games, because it makes them uncomfortable to think about anything that challenges their status quo, but hey! You don't have to read this, boys. I give you permission to skip it. Here, have a KitKat! It's probably going over your heads anyway.)

I've loved this game for years now, used to play it on the PS3 back in the day and came to play it on PC years later, and it still is a damn good game, but has it's flaws. First... Visually, it's stunning- some of the most beautiful imagery is to behold during the first few sections of the game where you walk around and explore the world of Columbia. The floating buildings, the early 1900's atmosphere, the music, the lighting, it's all pleasant to the eye. The story leaves me asking questions, but mostly in a positive way, certain aspects not so. The ending is a bit inconclusive, but expected for a complex storyline that explores the concept of timelines. Gameplay? Maybe not the best, but very watered down compared to the first two Bioshock games I've played over and over again. Your'e limited to very few weapons, and the vigors/powerups feel a little less impactful, there's no upgrading either, besides your health pool, shield, and vigor points. Sure, there is gear you can equip, but it feels a bit lacking. Certain parts of the game feel like a pain in the ass, like a part where you battle a ghost woman that summons dead soldiers to fight for her, just feels like a typical damage sponge... and another where you are limited in ammo and have to fight these guys wearing masks. Enemy variety is to be desired, but improves later in the game, with the handymen being introduced and the various vigor/superpower users. There's more I could get into the story in it's issues, but I wouldn't want to spoil anything for readers. There's still certainly good things about this game, exploring each area feels lived in and always has something of note- there's of course the other main character, Elizabeth. She's a great character, feels fleshed out and not annoying really nor does it feel like a drag escorting her throughout the majority of the game. She helps out, can revive you, toss ammo, supplies, you name it- she's helpful. Just an overall super-likeable character, which makes the story have impact even more when you actually can care for a character. This doesn't really feel like a Bioshock game traditionally speaking, but still a nice play altogether. Can't get enough of this game.

Bioshock Infinite originally came out in 2013 and has aged ok in some parts and not so ok in others. It is really nice that this game still seems to get updates for fixes so props to 2K on that one. 

First off gameplay-wise this game plays alright, it's still a little clunky with certain button placements but it's way easier to hop in and play this than going back to older Bioshocks. The game however is pretty linear, it does open up a little later for one or two zones but really you're going from point A to point B to maybe a puzzle in between.

I do like when the sky hooks get introduced into the combat sections but I can count of my one-hand the amount of times you get to play the game like this. 

What this game does still have however is vibes, Columbia is a fantastic setting and great for just wondering around the empty streets sometimes and whilst maybe Rapture had some of the stronger designs like the Big Daddy just being miles better than the Handyman. Bioshock Infinite does its own thing. 

Guns are on a two weapon limit which is unfortunate and whilst you do technically have every Plasmid, you can only have two of these equipped at a time. 

This applies to the older games but it's a shame Bioshock never solved this issue for me of making it so the game doesn't pause every five seconds due to you having to switch stuff out. 

Then the story...

 The story has so many problems that I can't believe the city can float with this many plotholes. 

- The Booker / Comstock spoiler is silly because they look so different, yes I know there's an explanation but it's silly.

- That exact version of Booker from before the Baptism sacrificing himself seems silly too. This doesn't even stop every version of Comstock so Elizabeth is just incorrect. 

I'm sure there's more but these spring to mind off the bat.

Also the DLC's exist I guess, it's cool to go back to Rapture in Burial at Sea but these DLC's are honestly so bad story wise and damage the first Bioshock to the point that I think most people consider them non-canon.

 I'd love to do another playthrough of this game with the idea in mind that the there just aren't infinite multiverses and see if that fixes a lot of the plot holes. I think it's fair to say though that this game had something crazy like five full games worth of cut content so it's not a surprise the story is cobbled together like this. 

All in all I see why the game was celebrated in 2013, a decade later I can see why it's not.

For what it's worth though I still leave this review as recommended as it's really easy to get this game for under $10.

The best things about this game are the art style and the story. The art style, unique setting and worldbuilding have always been the strongest part and main selling point of the BioShock series, and this game is no exception.

The art direction of this game is absolutely amazing, the whole beaux-arts/art noveau aesthetics is so unique and beautiful, the mix of early 20th century america and Sci-Fi is so interesting and the fact that it's set in a city in the sky is just something I've never ever seen in other medias before. The art style absolutely carried the game, if this game looked like a realistic 1910s american city that just happens to be in the sky, I would've never cared about this game. 

The story itself had mixed receptions in recent years, but for me personally, I absolutely love it. What makes the story a bit problematic is entirely on the way the game potrayed the Vox Populi, which is a revolutionary and anarchist militant, the way they made the Vox Populi as an antagonist is just a shallow attempt of the typical centrist "both sides are bad" rhetoric. The game framed Vox Populi "as bad" as Comstock which is the leader of a theocratic, ultra-nationalist, white supremacist society that is Columbia, while the Vox Populi is just a group that rebelled against this said society that oppressed them, making them the second antagonist is just so obviously forced and makes no sense. Other than this portrayal which was done as a way to criticizes revolutionaries, the game also extensively criticizes, nationalism, religious fanaticism and capitalism. In a way Columbia is used as a satire of the US.

Well, despite the whole Vox Populi thing, I still think this game has an amazing story, arguably one of the best in video games history. I've always been a sucker for multiverse and time travel stories and this game had really done it right. The plot twists at the end was just so mind-blowing that I really have to take a minute to process it all.

And of course it's a game, so I have to talk about the gameplay too. This game is an FPS, while I'm not really a big fan of shooters, I don't really hate them either. This game has a unique spin by giving the player different powers called vigors alongside the guns, which all are very interesting, but for most of the game I've only used two of the vigors. all I can say is that the gameplay is decent, I've played better shooters and I've played worst.

I honestly really loved the art direction and story so much that I'm giving this game a 10/10. I've only played a little bit of BioShock 1, but after finishing this game I'm going to go back and finish both Bioshock 1 and 2.

What I didn't like in Bioshock Infinite? Simply put - story. It is nonsensical, touches concepts that writers clearly poorly understood, creating numerous plot holes and inconsistencies (even within same chapter!). The most glaring one were during so called Universe 3. Then there's the origin of Elizabeth's powers... by their own rules, anyone would have them.

All in all, they could do better with simple story. They didn't and now we have monster that is Bioshock Infinite.

The weakest of the three BioShock games. But still a lot of good stuff in here. Same old BioShock loop, shoot, loot, explore & story focused. Story gets muddled near the end, but its understandable any story with dimension & time travel will be muddled with unanswered questions and plot holes.

Some big negatives over the previous two BioShocks. Mostly game mechanics stripped away so Elizabeth has something to do.
No more hacking or door codes. Liz now handles all locked doors.
Only two guns at once. This is so Liz can hand you ammo.
No more health packs or eve syringes. This is so Liz can hand them to you in combat.
The game is still a fun shooter, but in many ways except having a Waifu, it is worse then the previous BioShocks in every way.

I wrote a review back when I first played BioShock Infinite, but am again so blown away by this game that I just have to write about it again. 

[b]BioShock Infinite gets a 9.8 / 10.[/b]

It's easier to tell you what detracts .2 points from this game for me:
• I feel there's a lack of combat early on (first 1/3rd) in favour of cinematic depth (adventure, voice lines, scenery, exploration) - I love this, but I [i]do[/i] feel like some extra transitional battles would have been helpful. This quickly resolves itself, of course, once you get into it, but I could see some combat-heavy players being turned off while waiting for fights. (0.1 points.)
• If anything, there is [i]too much[/i] chance to restock; adding into the below, I feel you could have less ammo, salts and health without issue in the world, as with so many options for restocking (finding things, Elizabeth, vending machines and Tears) you rarely need to worry about these.
• Animations are high-quality for the time but look a little clip-y and hand-imated compared to a quality mo-cap and touched-up anim like you might see in Apex or Overwatch. 
• Graphically, BioShock Inifite holds up great, but you can definitely see the lower-res in places. It still kicks ass.
• The Unreal Engine's 6-entity limitation makes it tricky for battles to feel intense, however, is enough to keep fights mostly high quality. If anything, they're usually too short. 
• There might be [i]too many[/i] ways to move and fight - so many guns, so many perks, so many vigors, so many places to go - I feel like I need a battlefield to use them all! This ties into the above point for me. (0.1 points for all above.)

BioShock Infinite is about as close to a perfect game for me as you can get. I cannot gush enough about it: the story is complex enough to be engaging yet explained enough to actually translate to a moron like me. The gameplay balances cinema with storytelling, character and world building with motion and fighting. Gunplay is fun and solid, and much more natural compared to the game's predecessors. Vigors are intriguing and useful and, while there may be a lot of options to play with, if you can decide what challenge you want to go for - "hmm, maybe I'll go for all explosives wherever I can!" or "non-auto guns only!" - I feel it aids that option, rather than force unwanted choice onto you. 

Audio is great. The music is nearly iconic, and the voice acting is stellar - my only qualm being that I feel Elisabeth sounds a little older than her character's actual age, but that said, I think it adds to her depth as you watch her play out across time. The enemies are solid, not tanky and not pathetically easy. I'd have liked to see more mini-bosses used, but don't think their scarcity detracts from the game. For an 'old-timer' setting, the wide variety of machinery, technology, vehicles and travel options are wonderful and look and sound incredible. 

The runtime is great, long enough to sink teeth into yet not so long as to make me want to just get it done with (I felt this way with H:ZD, for example.) What in other games would feel like the end-game climax, changing your location and really upping the stakes and scale of your gameplay, this game's only a third of the way in, and just keeps climbing. It performs like a flawlessly written three-act movie, and I adore it. 

Of course, the acclaim it received at it's release still applies: Elizabeth is intelligent, involved and alive, really heightening her companionship. Her lack of involvement in combat doesn't detract, especially as a pacifist for the majority of her storyline - but her assistance helps to explain everything from ammo to respawning and her attitude really increases this world's value and attraction. 

Columbia is gorgeous. The story is moving and delivers such a powerful punch as you learn the truth of this world. Your travel, when it could get so confusing, is surprisingly linear and smooth. The worlds and scenery are touching, horrifying, beautiful and marvellous. I even love the overlays; attention to detail is everything, and everything here has been carefully crafted to keep you in the greater world of this 10's-20's steampunk-esque space. 

The DLC, Burial at Sea (Parts 1 & 2) only builds on this. I loved returning to this world, seeing Rapture through Booker's eyes and linking the worlds together. Both stories are moving and intense. I'm not sure I've cried at the end of any other game in my life, but both BioShock Infinite and it's DLC moved me to tears. I adore them. 

BioShock Infinite, depending on the day, may come a close second or even usurp classics like Half-Life or Portal. It is [i]CERTAINLY[/i] alongside them, and if I had a showcase of all-time favourites on my wall, BioShock Infinite might well be in the centre, with pride. It is a 9.8/10 at it's poorest measurement, and I give it a standing ovation well beyond the disappearance of the final word of the credits. You will be hard-pressed to find a better game, and I dare you to try. 
Well done, BioShock Infinite. 

<<< My original review is below. >>>

The game starts off unbecoming and doesn't really give much of itself away, but by the end you realise you just sat through one of the most twisted, incredible, well written and well built games to come out this side of the millenia. It doesn't top the list; perhaps there could have been better attention paid to the fine details, ensuring the player didn't occasionally get stuck or a key wouldn't actually sit inside the lock, but none of these issues are either game breaking, ruining, or just bad craftsmanship. Instead, the visuals, the story, the animation and the audio - that sweet symphony of voices, cues, ambient auras and ship distress alarms - paint a perfectly concocted narrative around you. And while I did find myself somewhat lost, and some nights spending much more time walking about and searching every single visible location for goodies and hidden doors and spamming the F key like a man with Parkinsons', despite the fact that I failed to pick up on the true depth and theme of the story until much to late and left myself somewhat befuddled, and, despite dropping interest in the game early on through my first time playing to play other things with friends, none of that stands a candle to the inferno that this game turned out to be, and each and every one of these faults, if you could call them that, relate to anything other than user error, or simple preference on my part. 

The fact stands, after all has been said and done: this game carries ticks in all the boxes. It's a tight and seamless FPS game, with solid gunplay and challenging enemies, intriguing bad-ass weaponry and the opportunity for upgrades for your favourite ones. Vigors are fun, stunning, and even more bad-ass than the guns, and in combination turn you into a M'F'ing warrior dashing around and snapping necks faster than a team of Genjis. The story is fantstic, less linear and predictable than DOOM for me, a point that was one of my more meh points about that game, and it is held aloft by the audio and video the game provides, a veritable candy-store of beautiful models, shining worlds and crisp details. Elizabeth is beautiful - the Vox are animalistic - Comstock is fatherly, and eveyone else fits in to the cast like a brilliantly cast play. As I said above, and reitorate here; any faults this game has are far, far outshone by it's wildly successful strengths.

If you have not played this, I cannot more highly reccomend you do. It is well, well worth the price, and is, being older now, priced much better than other AAA titles you may be considering - perhaps DOOM, as an example - would be. 

So until you delve into the world of Booker DeWitt, I leave you with this;
Will you bring us the girl, and wipe away the debt? 
[i]And do you have a choice anyway?[/i]
ok

BioShock Infinite, developed by Irrational Games, is a thought-provoking and visually stunning first-person shooter that pushes the boundaries of storytelling in gaming. With its immersive world, complex narrative, and breathtaking gameplay, BioShock Infinite stands as a true masterpiece that captivates players from start to finish.

One of the standout features of BioShock Infinite is its meticulously crafted world of Columbia. Set in a floating city in the sky, Columbia is a visually stunning and meticulously detailed environment that immerses players in a world of wonder and intrigue. The city's vibrant architecture, picturesque landscapes, and attention to detail make it a breathtaking setting that feels alive and full of secrets waiting to be uncovered. The attention to detail in every corner of Columbia, from the architecture to the character designs, adds depth and authenticity to the game world.

The narrative of BioShock Infinite is a tour de force that explores complex themes and tackles thought-provoking concepts. Players assume the role of Booker DeWitt, a former Pinkerton agent, who is thrust into a mysterious quest to rescue Elizabeth, a young woman with extraordinary powers. The storyline delves into themes of nationalism, religion, and the consequences of unchecked power. The writing is masterful, blending historical references, mind-bending twists, and philosophical musings to create a captivating and emotionally charged narrative experience. The character development is exceptional, with Booker and Elizabeth forming a powerful bond that drives the player's investment in their journey.

Gameplay in BioShock Infinite is a seamless blend of first-person shooting, supernatural powers, and strategic decision-making. Players have access to a wide array of weapons and Vigors, allowing for varied and satisfying combat encounters. The ability to combine Vigors with conventional weapons adds depth and strategy to the gameplay, empowering players to experiment with different playstyles and approaches. The skyline system, which allows players to ride rails throughout the city, introduces a thrilling verticality to the combat and traversal mechanics, adding a layer of exhilaration to every encounter.

Visually, BioShock Infinite is a feast for the eyes. The game boasts stunning art direction, combining the beauty of a utopian city with dark and twisted undertones. The attention to detail in the character designs, environmental textures, and lighting effects creates an immersive and visually striking experience. The combination of breathtaking vistas and intense, tightly designed action sequences ensures that the visual spectacle never wavers.

The audio design in BioShock Infinite is equally exceptional. The voice acting is top-notch, with nuanced performances that bring the characters to life. The sound effects are meticulously crafted, further immersing players in the world of Columbia. The musical score, with its haunting melodies and evocative themes, adds depth and emotion to the narrative, enhancing the overall atmospheric experience.

In conclusion, BioShock Infinite is a mind-bending masterpiece that excels in its storytelling, immersive world-building, and thrilling gameplay. Its captivating narrative, stunning visuals, and exceptional audio design combine to deliver an unforgettable gaming experience. Whether you're a fan of first-person shooters, engrossing narratives, or simply seeking an intellectual and emotional journey, BioShock Infinite offers an immersive and thought-provoking adventure that will leave a lasting impact. Prepare to explore the depths of Columbia, unravel its mysteries, and be forever changed by the power of BioShock Infinite.

Bioshock Infinite is easily one of my most favourite single player shooters.

[u]What makes this game so great:[/u]
- the shooting is so smooth and satisfying 
- the fighting is so dynamic with the skylines
- a great story (especially with the DLCs "Burial at Sea 1&2")
- the game drops you so many hints towards the plottwists and secrets of the story that you almost feel stupid, when they are finally revealed to you
- the characters have such a great character developement

[u]What the game lacks:[/u]
- if you are expecting a horror shooter similiar to Bioshock 1 and 2 you will be disappointed, the game is very bright and only has a few "scary" elements
- the stupid fucking blue ribbons in the "clash in the clouds" DLC are so annoying to get that it's not even fun anymore

It is not required to play Bioshock 1 and 2 before Infinite, but i definitely recommend you to check them out as well.

This game is both amazing and very repetitive in its story. The aesthetic of the game and the atmosphere of nearly every area feels polished and generally amazing, The graphics still hold up today, often you are left not even realizing how old the game really is. Some textures are really poor, but from a distance everything in this game is absolutely beautiful. The gameplay however is a different story, there less than 5 actions that you perform during the game. Following a path which you've already been down multiple times, fighting enemies in open areas, flicking levers, and watching cutscenes. While this game is really awesome the gameplay is really quite stale in most parts. The story is amazing.

While visually Bioshock Infinite is amazing, and there are some aspects I really enjoy about the game, I cannot help but compare it to the first Bioshock game, which I feel did a much better job with the story pacing, combat and sense of isolation and making you feel like you were the main character.  Bioshock Infinite is still a good game on its own, but it will leave a lot to be desired if you play it thinking it will bring back that feeling you had playing through the first game, IMO.

I never understand how people enjoy this entry, it does not feel like bioshock in the slightest. The combat is not satisfying knowing that i have killed everyone with a sound cue alerting me, as opposed to the constant state of panic not knowing if more splicers are lurking. The atrocious gun play is another miss for me, if you were able to implement carrying all weapons in burial at sea why not in the main game? It was a waste of all the "unique" guns which is very generously giving a compliment considering the shotgun and heater are the same model as much as the repeater and machine gun just seemed very lazy & lackluster considering past iterations of the game with weapon design. Also having stealth be the almost all encompassing way of playing BAS is also not bioshock with specific tonics and play styles it was optional, but at least having a choice to combat enemies that way was why the originals are always miles above infinite in my opinion. Infinite is just another fps action shooter using the name of one the of most innovative and creative games ever made, "Close the Tear"  where this game came from and never open it again.

Bioshock Infinite... The word "Bioshock" is certainly in the title, and that alone should be enough to generate a certain expectation from the people who have played a Bioshock game before. This is not a franchise like Final Fantasy, where everyone understands that every game has its own different world, characters, and story while sharing many common elements among them all.

When I see the word "Bioshock" in the title, I think of Rapture, Andrew Ryan, Jack... even Subject Delta! But what I got with Infinite was something radically different: a city in the sky and a protagonist who can't walk 10 steps without making a comment about his surroundings. It was perfectly fine at first, to be honest, an exciting and mysterious new beginning for the franchise. But as the levels go by, the fact that this game has nothing to do with the world of Bioshock becomes painfully apparent.

The game introduces the player to many familiar gameplay elements, now with different terms such as "Vigors" and "Salts," and does not make any effort to properly introduce these new concepts like the original Bioshock did, banking on the fact that fans will recognize them as "Plasmids" and "Eve" right away. At no point in the story could one make any connection to the world of Rapture. So in the end, we ended up with a Final Fantasy game, where the story and the characters are their own, but many recognizable elements from the previous entry still remain.

Bioshock doesn't have to be solely about Rapture; it's fine, really. In fact, the first game ends in a way that leaves the door open for stories such as the one told in Infinite; going back to Rapture in Bioshock 2 feels forced in comparison. Ah, but then the Burial at Sea DLC comes along and says, "Actually, this is how everything connects back to Rapture, my friends! Alternate universes! See? Infinite was a part of the Bioshock world all along! The guys behind Plasmids, Vigors and Big Daddies were working together BETWEEN DIMENSIONS!!!" Well, I mean, sure, but you can't tell me this doesn't sound like some lazy fanfiction slapped together in 10 minutes. I enjoyed both the main game and the DLC stories for what they are, but man, this is such a mess.

The one thing that can't be overlooked is the art direction; the game looks breathtaking almost at all times. Gameplay is a solid 7/10 though. A regular FPS with some Bioshock sprinkled on top.

I'm a big fan of the bioshock series and this one doesn't disappoint! The story is very well done, as usual, the art style is nice, and it's fun! It's one of the few games that really pulls me in and makes me a bit emotional.

It is more linear like Bioshock 2 but some transitions allow you to go backwards to previous areas. Although, it's not always clear which transitions are a one way trip so you end up scavenging the whole area before progressing.

They do limit you to 2 weapons at a time. While it would be nice to have access to the whole arsenal when you like, the limit wasn't a huge problem to me. None of the weapons have alternate ammunition, so you're not losing access to trap ammo like in the previous games.

Most Vigors(Plasmids) are fairly similar to previous games but differ in function. There are a couple new ones as well as most having the ability to be placed as a proximity trap. There are also some combinations that can be performed. It does feel like the damage has been reduced and stuns have been added or increased, probably to encourage or at least allow the combinations to be performed, but this does push the game towards a more weapon heavy playstyle.

The only issues that I can think of are that there were some minor parts where the animations were a bit off and when you upgrade your guns, it doesn't add any sort of visual representation on the gun when it's in your hand like the previous games. Also, if you hug the walls and objects a lot, you'll get kinda stuck and you just have to reverse/backtrack out of it. Oh, and sometimes there are like invisible walls around things that make picking up cash and items difficult but also register shots on enemies in weird ways.
Great game, it still holds up despite the passage of time.

One of my favorite games of all time. It's politically relevant (especially in 2023), fun, and beautifully voice-acted. Unlike the previous Bioshock games, it is much more engaging, action-packed, and has a wider variety of characters/enemies.

Enjoyable gameplay with excellent atmosphere and world design. Great sound design especially with Songbird. However, the story (which can be decent if told correctly) is unnecessarily convoluted, full of plot holes, is too difficult to properly follow in the middle of gameplay, and was executed very poorly. In short, the story's execution is complicated for the sake of it, especially considering how shallow it is compared to Bioshock 1 and, to an extent, Bioshock 2's more linear but deeper stories. 5/10, only recommending it because the story doesn't weigh down the rest of the game to make it below average.

This game deserves its reputation for polish, gameplay and compelling narrative.  To be honest, it would take a fairly gripping concept to make me sit through 30 hours of FPS, but that complaint is with the genre and not the game.  As a work of science-fiction, the Bioshock franchise does alternative history on a grand scale.  The spectacle of this game is worth experiencing, even if gameplay in the 3rd act becomes more than a little repetitive.  As a meditation on revolutions, racism and religious fanaticism, the game has reasonably interesting things to say.  Not just an FPS, and certainly less of a horror title than the previous games in the series, Bioshock Infinite delivers a unique and visceral gaming experience worthy of it's universal acclaim.  Overall A gaming.

A Skyward Masterpiece of Narrative and Gameplay

Rating: ★★★★★

BioShock Infinite breaks free from the ocean's depths and ascends to the dizzying heights of the floating city of Columbia, delivering an experience that is nothing short of extraordinary. It stands as a shining example of the power of video games as a storytelling medium, masterfully blending a captivating narrative, dynamic gameplay, and an extraordinarily realized setting into a compelling whole.

In Columbia, we find a world that is as awe-inspiring as Rapture but bathed in the bright blues of the sky instead of the deep blues of the sea. This stunning setting is a character in itself, with its early 20th-century architecture and vibrant city life set against a backdrop of floating airships and whirling skylines. It's a testament to the game's art direction that Columbia manages to feel at once beautiful and deeply unsettling.

The story of BioShock Infinite is a complex, tightly woven narrative tapestry. The tale of Booker DeWitt and Elizabeth is full of twists and turns, political intrigue, philosophical dilemmas, and emotional beats that resonate deeply. The voice acting performances are top-notch, with particular praise deserved by Troy Baker and Courtnee Draper for their heartfelt portrayals of Booker and Elizabeth, respectively.

BioShock Infinite's gameplay also shines. It iterates on the series' existing mechanics while introducing several new elements. The skyline combat sequences add a unique vertical dimension to the gameplay, and the addition of Elizabeth as an AI companion enriches the combat without turning the game into an extended escort mission. Her ability to manipulate the environment, along with her character development, make her a welcome presence rather than a burden.

The range of weapons and vigors (this game's version of BioShock's plasmids) offers a plethora of tactical options, encouraging experimentation. Whether you're possessing a mechanical patriot, setting a group of enemies on fire, or pulling foes into a vortex, there's a myriad of ways to approach each encounter.

The game's sound design and music deserve special mention. The soundtrack, filled with period pieces and anachronistic covers of modern songs, adds layers of immersion to the game. The sound effects and ambient noises complete the illusion of a living, breathing city in the sky.

BioShock Infinite is a triumph in every sense of the word. It pushes the boundaries of interactive storytelling and presents a stunning, fully-realized world filled with rich detail and complex characters. It is a game that will linger in your thoughts long after the credits roll, a testament to its powerful narrative and the emotional journey it takes you on. A masterclass in game design, BioShock Infinite rightfully earns a perfect score.
