Bioshock Infinite is an action-shooter game set in the fictional city of Columbia and following Booker Dewitt, who’s come to this not-so-welcoming utopia to rescue a girl and pay the debts that haunt his life.

This is one of my all-time favourite games, so I’m clearly recommending it. But before doing that, let’s go through its weakest points.

First, this game is a bit short. Enough that I recommend playing it on hard if it is your first time, because if you play it on easy it will barely give you enough time to process it. And almost on the same point the game is also a bit… Small, so to say.

In retrospective, once you beat it, it will probably feel like you haven’t been to that many places nor you’ve taken that much time to travel the whole world. And even if it seems sometimes like scenarios are really opened and have lots of secrets to explore… Well, it’s a bit superficial and not always true. If you are going for a heads-on shooting experience you probably won’t pay that much mind to this… But if you are a person that enjoys looking around, exploring, looking for secrets… You may be a bit disappointed; Columbia is introduced as this behemoth of city, really interesting on its own, beautiful and eery, with both shiny and shady spots… But the game doesn’t let you go off-road that much.

This also puts in perspective the balance of the game. As I said, if you have any experience with shooters, you should play it on the max difficulty. Because easy is way too easy. And yet… Bigger difficulties aren’t that well balanced either.

For instance, I wanted to go through the first DLC a bit more chilled, so I tried to play it in normal. All of the sudden it felt more difficult than the main campaign on hard. It feels like they don’t know their balance too well. And the fact that the resources you get (money and ammo) are also reduced for the higher difficulties when not even on easy you get enough to buy all the upgrades feels a bit weird. I get that being able to upgrade -everything- kinda takes away the fun of making impactful sacrifices. But come on, I had what was probably close to the maximum amount of money you could get in a run and couldn’t even buy half of all the upgrades available for the weapons. I thought I was doing something wrong on hard the first time, but hell, not even easy lets you go a bit crazy.

Yet economics apart, what really bugs me about this game is the lack of proper boss fights. I kinda feel like this was missing from it. Yeah, you get to fight “hard-hitting” enemies from time to time, that have special powers and all, but besides one or two gimmicky attacks they are nothing but bullet-sponges. And the fact that they later appear within crowds of common enemies tells me that they are not designed to be proper bosses anyways.

The gunplay and action in this game are great, but it’s really missing that cherry on top. Some colossal mechanical machine that would have fit perfectly with the game’s aesthetic. Yet the closest thing to a boss fight is protecting certain item from being shot from hordes of enemies. Not the most inspired part of the game.

Yet I can’t even recall how many times have I beaten this game and enjoyed every bit of it from beginning to end.

The fighting, although it was never taken to the max with proper boss fights, feels awesome as it is. Guns feel so good, the protagonist is just agile enough and the girl that you are rescuing, who accompanies you, is basically the best side character of any game. She tags important enemies, she hands you ammo, mana and health... (without making you anything close to immortal, of course). All the pieces fit together to create fights that flow really well. This makes the fact that there aren’t any bosses forgivable, because it’s clear to the eye that they really polished these fights through the game.

Add to this the use of skylines, that -although a bit underused, due to the length of the game too- add a nice dimension to some of the sections. You can look for high vantage points, speed through the rails to take down your enemies while flying through a sea of bullets or jump on them for an aerial take-down. Usually, I tend to be a long-range player in shooters, but this game makes it so fun to go for close-quarters that I couldn’t avoid it.

This is also due to how powerful the weapons and Plasmids… err Vigors feel, paired to some extremely violent melee executions (that could have used a couple more different animations, but eh, good enough).

And also, Vigors. The Bioshock staple of paranormal powers returns with this entry, of course. There are slightly less than in the first games (11 vs 8), but it didn’t really feel like they were too few. Actually, there might be too much even. Some don’t feel that necessary, cause you kinda get used to using two or three of them and don’t bother with the rest later on.

These powers include possession of machines and -later- humans to gain temporary allies, creating fires, sparks or killing crows, locking enemies in the air or throwing them of your course. And even if I feel like you don’t need to exploit them all, they add a really nice dynamism to the fights. Specially possession, it’s really great to gain an edge before even engaging, or to create a breathing room for yourself. To this, add the fact that you can create traps with all of these powers, save one of them, that instead summons a tentacle to grab enemies and throw them around (I’ve seen enough hen-…).

What I’m trying to convey is that the fights are one of the most engaging experiences you can get in modern FPS. They play well, they feel well, they can be challenging (albeit keeping in mind the weird balance this game’s economy has). Something you must experience if you like non-tactical shooters.

And of course, one cannot talk about Bioshock Infinite without talking about its story. Now for returning Bioshock fans, this story is a bit different. And maybe play the DLCs with a bit of salt sprinkled.

I love the story of the main game and I enjoy the closure that the DLCs provide (the second part more than the first one, gotta say). But Infinite was my first Bioshock experience, so in a way that plays against my criteria. And taking a step back, there’s a certain idea that this game presents that overshadows the first game, and it becomes a bit far-fetched under a greater perspective. I can see some fans of the classic Bioshock being rightfully disappointed. And this even without playing DLCs, because the approach for this game’s main story is a bit different.

Now, as an isolated experience and if this is your first contact with the franchise… Prepare for a story that’s really gonna stick to you, even if some things might go over your head the first time. Although I see this as a positive, because it has a really nice story and subtle hints through its progression that make it really enjoyable to replay, both the story bits and, of course, the action-filled ones.

To sum up, a shooting experience that, if it gets to you, will probably have you wishing to return for a run every couple years. A classic worth every cent, that nowadays you can get really cheap on sales. A must have for any fan of either action-packed shooters or story-rich games.

BioShock Infinite is Majestic, another masterpiece from Ken Levine and Irrational Games (now Ghost Story Games).

Unlike the first and second BioShock games, BioShock Infinite World is now in the sky, there is no Rapture anymore, there is only Columbia.

BioShock Infinite plays differently than its predecessor; no more roaming in a maze-like city; in this game, you are gliding around on the skylines, no more saving or protecting Little Sister, now you are protecting only one person, one girl, Elizabeth. Yeah, this game is a big escort mission, BUT don't worry, she won't hinder you; in fact, she will be a big help, throwing you ammo and supplies.

also you won't have a tonnes of weapons like the first and second games, in Infinite you will only get 2, but don't worry because those weapons can be upgraded with money, yes in this game you can upgrade your weapons with money instead of finding hidden weapon upgrade stations

But what about the Rapture, you ask? Don't worry, you'll be back in the DLC "Burial at Sea."

Overall, BioShock Infinite is a breath of fresh air—refreshing but still fun.

10/10 - Love it. Long live Irrational Games.

Introduction

Bioshock Infinite stands as a shining example of the artistic and narrative potential of video games. Developed by Irrational Games and released in 2013, this critically acclaimed first-person shooter transcends the boundaries of traditional gaming experiences. With its immersive world-building, thought-provoking themes, and masterful storytelling, Bioshock Infinite delivers an unforgettable and intellectually stimulating adventure.

The Setting: Columbia, a Skyborne Utopia

Set in the early 20th century, Bioshock Infinite transports players to the floating city of Columbia, a marvel of human achievement suspended in the clouds. The meticulously designed cityscape, with its grand architecture, vibrant colors, and attention to historical detail, creates an immersive environment that captivates players from the moment they step foot into this extraordinary world. As players explore Columbia's streets, interiors, and skylines, they uncover the dark secrets lurking beneath its seemingly idyllic façade.

Themes that Resonate: American Exceptionalism, Racism, and Religion

Bioshock Infinite is not just a visually stunning game; it also grapples with complex and thought-provoking themes. The narrative explores notions of American exceptionalism, shedding light on the dark undercurrents of nationalism and blind patriotism. Racism is confronted head-on, as the game confronts the systemic oppression and segregation that pervades Columbia. Religion, too, is a central theme, with the game delving into the dangers of religious fanaticism and the manipulation of faith for personal gain.

The Protagonist: Booker DeWitt and the Mysteries of His Past

The player assumes the role of Booker DeWitt, a former Pinkerton agent burdened by a troubled past. As the story unfolds, players accompany Booker on a mission to rescue Elizabeth, a young woman with extraordinary abilities who becomes his enigmatic companion. Booker's journey becomes an introspective exploration of guilt, redemption, and the consequences of one's actions. The character development is exceptional, and the emotional depth with which Booker is portrayed adds a layer of complexity to the overall narrative.

Elizabeth: A Companion Who Transcends Expectations

Elizabeth, the game's central character, is a triumph of character design and development. Her presence and interactions with the player are seamlessly integrated into the gameplay, making her an invaluable and compelling companion. Elizabeth's multidimensional personality, her endearing innocence, and her evolving relationship with Booker create a genuine emotional connection, immersing players in their shared journey.

Gameplay: A Fusion of Action and Intellect

Bioshock Infinite's gameplay mechanics strike a balance between heart-pounding action and cerebral engagement. Armed with an arsenal of unique weapons and powers, players engage in intense gunfights while utilizing "tears," interdimensional rifts that alter the environment and offer strategic advantages. The exhilarating combat sequences are complemented by mind-bending puzzles and thought-provoking moral choices, forcing players to confront the consequences of their actions.

Visuals and Sound Design:
The visual design of Bioshock Infinite is nothing short of breathtaking. The city of Columbia is rendered with meticulous attention to detail, from its grand architecture to its vibrant landscapes. The art direction combines a nostalgic Americana aesthetic with steampunk elements, creating a unique and visually stunning world. The musical score, composed by Garry Schyman, perfectly complements the game's atmosphere, evoking a wide range of emotions, from awe-inspiring orchestral pieces to haunting melodies that enhance the game's most poignant moments.

Conclusion:
Bioshock Infinite is a masterpiece that transcends the boundaries of traditional storytelling and gaming. Its thought-provoking narrative, immersive gameplay mechanics, and stunning visuals create an unforgettable experience that challenges players intellectually and emotionally. The game's exploration of complex themes and its ability to weave together gameplay and storytelling make it a shining example of the artistic potential of the medium. Bioshock Infinite will undoubtedly continue to be celebrated and remembered as a landmark achievement in the world of video games.

BioShock Infinite completely changed the game for me. From the moment I entered the breathtaking floating city of Columbia, I embarked on a mind-blowing journey. The graphics blew me away, the story had me hooked, and the gameplay was exceptional.

The world-building in BioShock Infinite left me in awe. Columbia felt like a vibrant, fully realized place with meticulous attention to detail. Every architectural marvel and tiny object brought the environment to life.

The thought-provoking and expertly written story captivated me like no other game. It delved into deep themes of racism, religion, and politics, challenging my own beliefs by the end.

The gameplay seamlessly blended first-person shooter and RPG elements. With an arsenal of weapons and powers, combat was both fast-paced and strategic, requiring cunning tactics and precise execution.

In my opinion, BioShock Infinite is an absolute masterpiece. It's a game that will linger in my thoughts long after completion. A must-play for anyone who craves story-driven games or seeks an unforgettable, extraordinary experience.

Bioshock Infinite is an extraordinary game that swept me away from the moment I started playing, even amidst the release of Atomic Heart, which I personally refer to as "Atomic Fart." However, it would be unfair to dwell on that comparison, as Bioshock Infinite deserves undivided attention and praise for its own merits.

From its opening moments, Bioshock Infinite immerses players in a meticulously crafted world that seamlessly combines a gripping narrative, stunning visuals, and immersive gameplay. Set in the floating city of Columbia, the game transports you to a meticulously designed and beautifully realized environment that is both awe-inspiring and haunting. The attention to detail is impeccable, making every nook and cranny worth exploring and uncovering hidden secrets.

The storyline of Bioshock Infinite is a tour de force, expertly crafted with thought-provoking themes, complex characters, and mind-bending twists. As players assume the role of Booker DeWitt, a troubled protagonist with a mysterious past, they embark on a journey filled with political intrigue, philosophical musings, and profound commentary on themes such as American exceptionalism and the nature of choice. The narrative is masterfully executed, keeping players engaged and invested until the very end.

The gameplay mechanics in Bioshock Infinite are equally captivating. With a combination of fast-paced gunplay, inventive Vigor powers, and the ingenious Skyhook system for navigating the city, the game offers a unique and exhilarating gameplay experience. The combat encounters are dynamic and challenging, allowing for strategic choices and rewarding player skill.

Visually, Bioshock Infinite is a feast for the eyes. The art direction is breathtaking, with vibrant colors, detailed environments, and stunning architectural designs that bring the city of Columbia to life. The attention to detail is evident in every aspect, creating a visually stunning and immersive experience.

The game's soundtrack deserves special mention as well. The haunting melodies and powerful orchestral arrangements perfectly complement the game's atmosphere, heightening the emotional impact of key moments and adding an additional layer of immersion.

In conclusion, Bioshock Infinite is an exceptional game that deserves all the accolades it has received. It stands on its own as a masterpiece of storytelling, gameplay, and visual design, transcending any comparisons or distractions. If you haven't had the opportunity to experience the wonders of Bioshock Infinite, I highly recommend delving into its captivating world and discovering for yourself why it is hailed as a true gem in the realm of gaming.

Yeah Bioshock: Infinite is an excellent game but it's a pretty far cry from the quality of Bio 1. It's gameplay is this weird confused hybrid of linear shooter and immersive sim that leans too heavily on its linear setpieces to justify its immersive sim elements. Frequently the game will give you an optional objective that will require you to backtrack to unlock little item closets full of goodies, and encourage you to comb the environments for equipment and resources, but the breakneck pace of the story and gameplay and the linear setpiece based structure really discourages you from actually doing any of that. Also it seems all of the gameplay decisions you make are VERY temporary. Because of the lack of inventory and Elizabeth fetching supplies for you the only resource or item that carries over from encounter to encounter is money which is never in short supply. Contrast this to Bio 1&2 where ammo, Eve hypos, health kits, and hacked security bots all carry over from one encounter to the next in addition to money. Bioshock 2 even lets you repair security bots which when unlocked also gives your security bots names so you grow attached to them. Bioshock Infinite has no resource management or persistent rewards beyond weapon and vigor upgrades. Also the two weapon limit is BAFFLING in the context of a game that allows you to buy ammo. The two weapon limit is great for forcing you to constantly change up your arsenal as you adapt to using what your enemies are using, but since I could buy ammo for the guns I was most comfortable using (and when I couldn't Elizabeth would just toss me some) I never switched away from the carbine and repeater combo which severely limited my experience with the combat systems.

Narratively Infinite is also weaker. It's got some interesting ideas but it's not great at fully exploring them. For the whole first half of the game it seems to want to interrogate the role violence plays in both preserving and fighting injustice, and notably whether violence is justified in the pursuit of ending injustice. But it doesn't really resolve these themes before refocusing entirely on its convoluted multiverse plot. 
This multiverse plot has a pretty neat twist but I remember it being underwhelming when I played it the first time almost a decade ago. I remember comparing it to a Dr. Who plot at the time. My opinion has shifted only slightly toward the positive. I have a better understanding of what the game is trying to say about guilt and forgiveness now, and it does a good job of telling that story. When viewing the work as a whole, however, it feels like the second half of the game is so thematically disconnected from the first half. Like this was two game ideas jammed together. I would have preferred a story about the Vox Populi and Comstock's struggle for Columbia with Booker as an interloper that really digs into and explores the moral complications of an armed revolution OR a story about Booker and Elizabeth's struggle against Comstock's Columbia that really digs into [spoiler]Booker's transformation into Comstock, and how the acceptance of guilt is a necessity for growth.[/spoiler] Attempting to do both however spreads the game's focus too thin, and Bioshock Infinite really suffers as a whole. 

Bioshock Infinite is a mess. A perfectly fine game, but being pulled in so many different directions that it almost falls apart. It wants to be an immersive sim AND a linear shooter structured around setpieces. It wants to be a grand story about broad philosophies and sociological ideas about violence AND a personal story about the importance of guilt and forgiveness. It winds up doing a better job at the latter aspects than the former, but it should have committed to one or the other.

A "smart" game for "smart" gamers. 
I made the mistake of buying this game on release. Didn't like it then, didn't like it now. 

 In terms of gameplay, it is not very good. It takes BioShock 1 and 2, and throws all of it out the window. You are limited to two guns. the weapon upgrade system is simplified to have you buy upgrades at a station, but you can't "rush" a weapon you like, like you could in the previous game. No, you have to wait until you progress far enough in the story to spend your scavenged money on upgrades. Plasmids are not as satisfying as they were in the second game. Base shock jockey and murder of crows is really all you need.

There are spoilers below, so, don't read if you don't want them.

The game tries to come off as deeper than it is, by throwing alternate universes and time travel at you in an attempt to make you forget about the egregious errors in regards to existentialism, psychology, and what makes a man a man?

The game repeatedly shouts at you the differences of Comstock, and DeWitt. How Comstock pretended to be a soldier at the Boxer Rebellion and Wounded Knee, with another NPC confirming DeWitt was there, Comstock was not, and that Comstock is a revisionist lying in order to further sell his utopia and stoke the flames of fanaticism. Admittedly, the over the top racism and bigotry that would make HP Lovecraft blush aged like a fine wine, sadly. I'll admit the game was ahead of it's time there.

Back to the original point, the game tries to sell you Comstock and DeWitt are different, yet the same, because of time travel paradoxes and alternate universe BS that if you dumb it down to it's core parts, still doesnt make sense.

Take two genetically identical individuals. Have one live a life of prejudice, hate, sheltered. Have the other live a more humble life, join the military, fight for causes they don't believe in, go into crippling debt.

Are these two individuals, shaped by their life experiences, still the same? Basic existentialism and psychology would say "no."

So at the end of the day, the lovable partner in crime Elizabeth Comstock, turns out to be just as fucked up as Comstock because she straight up murders DeWitt. There are no alternate endings, because of this alternate universe BS they tried to implement but chickened out to make one ending, for one timeline/universe.

Save your money, play BioShock and BioShock 2 again, or maybe pick up the System Shock remake.

Commercial Heaven flying with fun, products, and shops seems to be a complete lesson about how to decorate public places in a city. People are controlled by Comstock the prophet figure also controls slavery to build the city. Mr Booker Dewitt entered the city Name Columbia baptized to pay off his gambling debts in New York. The mission is to rescue the abducted bastard daughter of prophet Comstock and hand her over in New York.  

The game starts with picking things from bins, shops, restaurants, and roadside benches by Mr Dewitt who might be wondering how happy people are in the flying city. The mission has a photo of a destination called monument island where the daughter Elizabeth is abducted and a key to free her from the Monument Tower. Trouble starts with a fight with police at the Raffle fair after the welcome centre of the city and since then Mr Dewitt keeps fighting against various kinds of characters including police, guards and the army of Comstock. Characters like fire man, patriot, crow man, giant robot the Handyman are stubborn in nature. As like as other two parts of BIOSHOCK, the mad machine guns are in every corner. A very common nature of this game is characters move very fast and randomly, the aim was barely visible to kill them. I would say some fights are designed to use your sixth sense to kill random enemies. Flying boats, flying balloons with machine guns, no end of catastrophe in this game.   

On your side, you have 8 kinds of vigour; you can use two at a time selecting from them also can update their effectiveness. I found the crows trap and electric shock most useful. In your right hand, you get plenty of variety of ammo. The thing is the game is printed in colour sketches, so guns are looking like toys until you start using them seriously. The job in BIOSHOCK is to slow the enemies down with left-hand vigour and then shoot them with right-hand guns. There is a button for melee attack when they come close and also a button to get directions arrow on the screen. Also, a magnetic device is given in this part to fly on skylines. 

As usual, after rescuing Elizabeth, it became difficult for Dewitt to take her out from Columbia to New York even though she wanted to be free. Once Dewitt told her about his mission in the First Lady Ship, Elizabeth simply ran away putting him into another gambling. The boat they need to travel to New York is now in the hands of slave leaders ( Vox & Daisy Fitzroy) who will only give it back if Dewitt can find the gunsmith Chan Ling who can supply guns to free the slaves. Elizabeth was really useful during fights because she was picking up supplies. The game has tear(s) in the screen which Elizabeth can open and bring supplies from other worlds. Finally gunsmith was found, slaves were freed and now Elizabeth had to leave with the Songbird to save Dewitt as the big metallic bird was about to kill him. Now Dewitt picked up a code from the ghost of Elizabeth’s dead mother which finally helped them to capture the big metallic Songbird which used to be the guardian of Elizabeth in the monument tower. Here I must say that the discovery of the ghost mother (Lady Comstock) of Elizabeth in the graveyard started a disturbing episode where dead things started coming alive. Until you can have some good aims in the source ghost it keeps growing in the scene. In three episodes Lady Comstock was killed.  

As like the first two parts, the game doesn’t end at the last scene of unprecedented fighting in the command deck of Comstock’s zeppelin. Finally, the prophet was killed in the deck of his zeppelin then the escape gets stuck and probably will let you finish the whole army of Comstock and Vox before you leave. Here to mention, “Vox Populi” the people freed from slavery become enemies as the game was entering different worlds through tears. Anyway, I have been playing chapter by chapter backward to upgrade everything up to the end to find out how to end the game.

Oh, boy, let me tell you about Bioshock Infinite! It's like diving headfirst into a swirling vortex of mind-bending awesomeness. This game has got it all, my friend. From the moment you step foot into the floating city of Columbia, you'll be hooked like a fish on a line.

The story? It's a mind trip, my dude. You play as Booker DeWitt, a badass former detective on a mission to rescue a girl named Elizabeth. But let me tell you, things are not as they seem. Prepare to have your mind blown wide open as you unravel the twisted secrets of this crazy alternate reality.

Now, let's talk visuals. Columbia is a freakin' masterpiece, my friend. The attention to detail is insane. You'll find yourself just standing there, jaw on the floor, taking in the breathtaking vistas and jaw-dropping architecture. It's like living in a steampunk dream.

But the real star of the show is the gameplay. Guns? Check. Powers? Double check. You'll be blasting enemies with a variety of badass weapons and unleashing some mind-bending abilities. And let's not forget about the skyline system. Picture this: you're zipping through the air on rails, raining down destruction on your foes. It's like being a superhero, man!

In conclusion, Bioshock Infinite is a wild ride that will keep you on the edge of your seat from start to finish. The story, the visuals, the gameplay - it's all top-notch. Get ready to have your mind blown and your gaming world turned upside down. This is one game you do not want to miss!

Step 1 Before even Launching the game:
- go to the gears icon
- browse local files
- go to 'XGame' folder
- go to 'Config' folder
- Click on the file 'DefaultUI' open in notepad
- Set the 'MaxResolutionUpscale' to = 1.0
- Now you can enjoy Bioshock Infinite on the widescreen and larger TVs properly.

Words cannot express how beautiful this game is. The contrast between harmony and disarray of violence throughout Columbia can already be seen upon launching the game. The peaceful nature of the main menu is very contradictory to the violence Booker DeWitt causes throughout the game. 

Even though, the concept of a utopia with a dark twist has already been used many times, this game can still be very atmospheric. Especially, because the world and the environment are one of the game's best features.

Due to the multiverse being a hard concept to explain I had some trouble understanding the plot on my first playthrough. It also doesn't help much that the game's timeline is occasionally all over the place.

The combat is fun and there is a big variety in weapons and open areas. It's also worth mentioning that one of the biggest positives of Bioshock Infinite is that it connects to the first two games, even if it doesn't seem like it at first. The game is also highly quotable and the Bioshock collection is affordable at an alluring price on sale. You can see that a lot of work went into crafting this masterpiece and the result of that is an absolute blast.

This game is an absolute masterpiece. Its immersive story, stunning visuals (at least for its time) and unique gameplay mechanics have captivated me from the first moment.

One of the game's strongest points is its story. It is a complex and thought-provoking tale that deals with heavy themes such as racism, nationalism, and the consequences of unchecked power. The game's narrative is masterfully crafted and kept me engaged throughout my entire playthrough. The ending is also one of the most memorable and impactful conclusions to a video game I have ever experienced.

The gameplay is equally impressive. Bioshock Infinite features a perfect balance of shooting, strategy, and supernatural powers, giving the player a lot of options for how to approach each encounter. The combat is fast-paced and exciting, with plenty of weapons and abilities to unlock and upgrade as you progress through the game.

It is a very accessible game, even for those with low-end computers. It runs smoothly even on modest hardware, which is a rare feat for such a visually stunning game.

Overall, Bioshock Infinite is a true masterpiece that deserves all the praise it has received. Its gripping story, engaging gameplay, unforgettable characters, and low specs needed to play make it a must-play game for anyone who loves first-person shooters, RPGs, or immersive storytelling.

A perfect game, a new word made up of familiar letters. A broad step not only for the BioShock series, but for the genre as a whole. And it seems like we've seen it all in other games, but never before in such masterful execution. Infinite hits all points at once - burns the eyes with beauty, occupies the spinal cord with gunfights, loads the intellect with the story and conquers the heart with the openness of Elizabeth.

Ahead of it's time. If it grabs you, you're history. If it doesn't, your life will continue.
There is no "one thing" to be said. It's story isn't finished when the credits roll, you're just getting started. Contrary to many's immediate deduction, the journey is overshadowed by the destination. 

Postcard from Columbia, come live with us in the sky.

BioShock Infinite is an absolute masterpiece in the world of video games. I can't even begin to express how captivated I was by the game's gripping storytelling and immersive gameplay. Developed by Irrational Games and released in 2013, this game takes you on an unforgettable journey through the floating city of Columbia, delivering an experience that is both thought-provoking and thrilling.

The story of BioShock Infinite is nothing short of extraordinary. Set in an alternate reality in 1912, you step into the shoes of Booker DeWitt, a former Pinkerton agent with a mission to find a young woman named Elizabeth and hand her over to a mysterious group known as the Vox Populi. But as you dive deeper into the story, you'll discover that Columbia is a city teeming with secrets, political strife, and a deeply entrenched racism that drives the conflicts within.

I have to say, the narrative in BioShock Infinite is absolutely mind-blowing. It's like unravelling a complex tapestry of American exceptionalism, religious zealotry, and the consequences of unchecked power. The characters are incredibly well-developed, and the relationship between Booker and Elizabeth forms the heart and soul of the game. Elizabeth, in particular, is an astonishing companion, with her own agency and unique abilities that greatly impact the gameplay dynamics.

Speaking of gameplay, BioShock Infinite seamlessly blends first-person shooter mechanics with a set of special abilities called Vigors. These Vigors give Booker extraordinary powers, such as telekinesis and the ability to control swarms of crows, adding a strategic twist to combat encounters. The gunplay is satisfying, with an impressive array of weapons that each offer a distinct feel. And let's not forget the level design, which strikes a perfect balance between expansive environments and carefully crafted spaces that invite exploration and experimentation.

But what truly blew me away about BioShock Infinite was its setting—the awe-inspiring city of Columbia. The level of detail is truly astonishing, with its vibrant art deco architecture, bustling streets, and sweeping skylines. It feels like a living, breathing city, with its inhabitants going about their daily lives, and it serves as a powerful commentary on the darker aspects of American history. The stark contrast between its picturesque facade and the underlying bigotry and oppression is both mesmerizing and deeply unsettling.

Visually, BioShock Infinite is an absolute feast for the eyes. From breathtaking vistas to meticulously designed environments, the game is a visual spectacle from start to finish. The audio design is equally impressive, with a phenomenal soundtrack that captures the essence of the time period. The voice acting is outstanding as well, especially Troy Baker's portrayal of Booker and Courtnee Draper's performance as Elizabeth. They infuse their characters with such depth and emotion that it's impossible not to be fully invested in their journey.

One of the most remarkable aspects of BioShock Infinite is its thought-provoking themes and social commentary. The game fearlessly tackles issues such as racism, xenophobia, and the dangers of religious fanaticism, forcing players to confront uncomfortable truths about society. It poses profound questions about the nature of choice, redemption, and the consequences of our actions.

Now, I won't deny that BioShock Infinite isn't flawless. Some players might find the combat encounters a tad repetitive, and there are moments when the difficulty spikes can be frustrating. And let's not forget the ending—it's an absolute mind-bender that leaves you with more questions than answers. While it's undoubtedly thought-provoking and thematically resonant, it may leave some players feeling a bit bewildered or even unsatisfied.

In conclusion, BioShock Infinite is an absolute triumph that seamlessly blends exceptional storytelling, compelling

I figure it's easy to talk about this game in the context of what I liked and didn't like starting with what I did like, which wasn't much.

The Good

- Though there are fewer of them in this game the plasmids, or vigors, as they're called now are overall much better in this game. They cut down on a lot of the bloat of redundant and useless plasmids in the first two games and every vigor that was in the main game and the DLC actually felt useful and powerful. I'd say almost too powerful once you start to upgrade them to become stronger and have chain effects.

-I want to have sex with Elizabeth. Not much more to say there.

-As far as video game escort quests go, Elizabeth is one of the better ones.

The Bad

-Columbia really feels like a step down in terms of a setting when compared to Rapture. Some areas were pretty cool, but overall nothing in Columbia was as interesting or unique as Rapture.

-Being able to only carry two guns at once sucks. I get that this was probably just trend chasing because at the time a two gun carry limit was the standard in FPS games. The gun upgrading also sucked compared the the prior two games because there were no visual changes to the weapons as a result of upgrading them (weird complaint I know, but I really liked the idea of gun upgrades being reflected on the gun model) and the fact the you have such a limited capacity for ammo means you'll frequently have to ditch your upgraded weapons in favor of whatever is available.

-The game is too linear and has no respect for player agency or intelligence. I wouldn't say that any of the Bioshock games were exactly non-linear, but one thing I noticed as I played through each game in the series is that the games got more linear with less optional side exploration as they went on. In this game the developers so desperately don't want you to miss any of the little set pieces or extras they put in that the amount of exploration you can do in areas outside of places you'd have to go anyway are almost now existent and usually confined to single rooms behind a door you have to lock-pick. This is in contrast to the first Bioshock which had entire sections of levels that were entirely optional.

-The story is incredibly stupid. I know it's Bioshock, not some literary classic, but the first two games at least had decent enough plots. In this game I pretty much tuned out as soon as the time travel/dimension hopping shit started. Those are concepts that even a good writer would struggle to make work well and sufficed to say a hack like Ken Levine was not up to the task. By the time I got the end I really didn't care anymore. They were clearly proud of the story and thought it was great too based on the cinematic presentation of the game and how often the rest control away from the player for the sake of cinematics, something the first two games didn't do that often.

The Ugly

-Basically the entirety of the the Burial At Sea DLC is awful. Very briefly I thought is was neat to see rapture pre-fall, but I quickly lost my enthusiasm when I saw the direction they were taking things. The desperation of Ken Levine to try and connect Infinite to the previous games via this DLC not only retroactively ruins the plot of the first two games, but also ruins some of the only good parts of the plot of Infinite. If you have to play Infinite, just skip the Burial At Sea DLC and pretend it doesn't exist.





On The Series As A Whole

If I had to rank the games it would be as follows:

BioShock 2 > Bioshock > Bioshock Infinite

Unlike Bioshock and Bioshock 2, Infinite lacks a lot of that "special something" the series has. The game play is fun, the fighting system is fluid and entertaining, but the story is highly predictable and stale. Rapture gave you a sense that the city could actually exist. Columbia feels forced and the NPCs feel very robotic and puppety. The abilities and weapons feel like the same old gameplay renamed to be catchy. Instead of having "incinerate" you get "Devil's Kiss" etc. The whole game just feels forced.

The part that probably irks me the most: This game was postponed YEARS so they would have time to perfect it. Instead, on Ultra PC settings, this game still has screen tearing. The water looks worse than it did in Bioshock 1. And we are left with a bad taste in our mouth at the end of the game because the story was not imaginative.

Overall, even with all of its flaws, it is still fun to play. Just not as fun as the first two.

I stayed away from this game for a long time because I kept hearing about how it was inferior to the other Bioshock games. This was a pretty huge mistake, as this is the Bioshock game that has so much replay value, a captivating story, and a world that just pulls you in so much you want to keep knowing more and more about it. Some of the achievements are absolutely ridiculous and I got some of the harder ones just due to dumb luck, but a feeling of elation once I did came all the same.

This game flips between extremes, it has some amazing qualities like character building for the 2 main protagonists, but in general the game feels empty. The more you look at it, the more things stop working and feel like empty allegories.

One of the main aspects in Bioshock 1 and 2 was the deep political discussions that were organic and "grounded", Rapture was a place built by humans that were to obsessed with progress, they had flawed perspectives and beliefs and they end up being destroyed by their radical progressive with no boundaries, capitalist ideology. Objectivism is heavily criticized in this game and the result of their demise was based on their choices.

In Bioshock Infinite all of this is scraped by some multiverse story where no political allegories are explored properly because they heavily focus on Booker and Elizabeth's story. They're quantum time travelers and they have influence over every universe, and for every consequence and decision they partake, it influences over every story, including Bioshock 1. 

Yes, it was Booker DeWitt and Elizabeth all along, they sparkled the entire first and second game plot, they're the magic beings that exist over every universe.

Another thing that bothers me a lot is that a lot of the story is just pointless, the revolution and Daisy Fitzroy, they're never really explored, they're just there and nothing really comes from it. They just change realities and she is suddenly evil and wants to kill a child. The songbird is pointless and it's just there in cutscenes, and in a stupid short battle, he's probably the most disappointing part of this game. 

And for the thing that bothers me the most, the gameplay... It's really... alright, I don't know what else to say. You can carry only two weapons, the weapons have no visual or significative mechanical changes, they're generally boring compared to the other games. When you upgrade them it's just stats, the enemies are not interesting or good as the splicers were, the daddies of this game are not interesting and they're planned encounters, I can only feel apathy for the combat of this game.

I would definitely say that time was not a good friend of Bioshock Infinite. As if it's worth it or not, if you never played this game it's still well made and enjoyable, like the start of the game and the presentation of Columbia, but the game falls flat the more you look into it. Specially the end gaming. And if you played the other games, I would say for you to only play this game for the sake of completion, since you played the other games. It's an okay game with high points and it's still better than most triple AAA games from now. But it's not a mandatory experience, that's why I'm giving a negative review.
I will never ever forget this story, amazing game :3

As a long-time Bioshock fan, it took a couple of hours for Bioshock Infinite's gameplay to really 'click' with me back when it was first released. That's because this most recent instalment of the series tones down the level of interactivity and player expression even more than the original [i]Bioshock[/i] already did compared to the series' spiritual granddaddy [i][url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/238210/System_Shock_2]System Shock 2[/url][/i]. [b]There are very few immersive sim elements left this time around, moving the third Bioshock game even further into pure shooter gameplay territory. But as you keep playing and you come to appreciate Bioshock Infinite on its own terms, it turns into one of the more interesting gaming experiences with one of the most interesting settings and narratives you've seen in video games[/b].

Much like Rapture in [i][url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/409710/BioShock_Remastered]Bioshock[/url][/i] and [i][url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/409720/BioShock_2_Remastered]Bioshock 2[/url][/i], the floating city of Columbia in Bioshock Infinite is built on a real-life ideological foundation turned to its logical extremes. This time around, we turn our eye on institutionalised racism, American exceptionalism and Evangelical zealotry in an alternate history 1910s USA. [b]Once again, this makes the setting of the game feel more grounded than a floating city would otherwise feel, and it lends the plot a lot of gravity[/b] (man, the jokes are just flying today), as the failings of these ideologies are quickly laid bare. Interestingly, the main plot of Bioshock Infinite isn't specifically about any of these topics, but rather interwoven with their associated themes. [b]The up-front ideological satire/tragedy takes a back seat as we explore the implications of multiverse theory and the game's central topic of redemption – whether it be religious or secular in nature[/b].

One of the defining features of Bioshock Infinite is Elizabeth, the main character's near-constant companion as they fight through Columbia. [b]Elizabeth is probably one of the best implementations of a non-intrusive companion I've seen since[/b] [i][url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/19980/Prince_of_Persia]Prince of Persia[/url][/i] (2008), as she points out interesting things in the environment, summons objects such as friendly turrets out of thin air and throws you resources when you need them. And she does all that without becoming a liability, since she's effectively invulnerable in gameplay terms. I know some people don't like that she can just waltz across the battlefield without anyone taking a shot at her, but I'd much rather have it this way than have the entire game turn into an extended escort mission.

Most importantly, Elizabeth is central to the plot and a great way of furthering the narrative through dialogue with the player character, Booker DeWitt. I don't want to go into more detail when it comes to the plot, as this is arguably the most important and most engaging aspect of the game. All I'll say is that, [b]while some scenes aren't interwoven with the gameplay in the best way they probably could have been (like holding seemingly time-sensitive scenes indefinitely until you press the interact button), the overall story will stick with you for a while[/b]. Not least because of its mind-bending existential horror undercurrent, its emotional impact and the chances it takes from time to time (such as Bioshock Infinite's honestly pretty courageous ending for a 'AAA' title).

If you've enjoyed the Bioshock series so far and you don't mind Bioshock Infinite being an arguably even more linear experience focused even more on straight-up shooting, this is a must-play. [b]Even if you don't like the new gameplay direction, I think its strong themes, characters and narrative more than make up for it[/b].


P.S.: Either buy [url=https://www.gog.com/game/bioshock_infinite]Bioshock Infinite[/url] DRM-free on GOG or use the launch options on Steam to get rid of the 2K launcher.

Bioshock Infinite has great gameplay, great atmosphere, and great characters. A game I do not regret buying at all. However, despite it's qualities, the story can be quite flawed towards the middle of the game. Infinite is ambitious and tries to include a lot of mature topics and themes, something the series has done with 1 and 2, but it stretches way too far and doesn't add any nuances and feels very, very surface level (and harmful). Especially in 2023, 10 years after the game has been released, there's some story elements that have not aged well and leaves a sour taste in my mouth. However, despite that major flaw that can ruin the middle part of the game for me, Infinite is great and redeems itself with a very impactful and jaw dropping ending.

8/10 - An amazing game that I really enjoyed, just wish some parts of the story were changed as it has aged badly in 2023

This game is so beautiful, I can't believe it was released 10 years ago. 
It is a huge improvement from the previous 2 games in terms of graphics, combat, weapons responsiveness, abilities management, AI behavior, looting system, upgrading system and so on, but it also has some let downs that I'm not sure why the devs didn't consider: a map, some tutorials -> I didn't know there is an inventory or how to open it, I didn't know you can ADS weapons before getting the sniper, I didn't know you can use any weapon at any time before getting into dlcs when I realized I don't have enough ammo with only 2 weapons and the default buttons does not help at all, it's very unintuitive.
If you played the predecessor games, you may find this one being completely different and you may wonder how is it related to the underwater universe, but only in the Burial at Sea you'll find out how well is the story connected to Raptor. The artstyle is amazing, the new mechanics, weapons and plasmids (named vigors here) were refreshing, the story was very confusing with an even more confusing ending, but everything was clear after finishing the dlc.
I totally recommend this game, grab it and have a blast!

Hooooh boy... I could talk for a long time about why i didnt like this game. Also, i wish i could give a Neutral rating instead of Recommend or not, i'll get into why later on.
So first of all, I only recently, like this week, played Bioshock for the first time. Bioshock 1 that is. I played through the first two games, and i freaking looooooved it. Original Bioshock has this really dark ambiance, this feeling of dread and gloom, this semi horror game feel. You, and your character, have no idea what is down there, and it was a true exploration of the place, discovering plots and insane technology at the bottom of the ocean. Combine that with it feeling like a metroidvania, with secrets and puzzles all over, with unlockable bonuses and lore that felt extremely rewarding to find and discover. Playing on the hardest difficulty, you really had to scrounge for resources, always sizing up the next big fight, wondering if i should find some more medpacks and wanting to find secrets to refill my stock. Wondering if its worth to go for the terrifying optional bosses early, and if i did go for it, planing out an escape route and putting up little traps on the way to chip away at their health. I, fu**ing, loved it. And then those two games were done. I had finished the story, i had found all the secrets. And so i installed Bioshock Infinite.

Bioshock infinite is about Nathan Fake (Booker Dewitt), generic rugged action hero, in what amounts so far (i only played for ca 4 hours), to a nonstop action sequence. Just the intro was such an extreme showcase of how different this game is from the originals. You have a long sequence of exploration, getting a feel for this cool and kinda tranquil place, and suddenly, as if someone flipped a switch, the game goes into overgear, showing that its in fact not tranquil, and in the first minute of getting a weapon you have killed about 20 enemies. The game then continues with about an hour long sequence of you killing hundreds of enemies, with this intense action music playing all the while, with every enemy always knowing where you are, until you finally get to the door that leads to the next area and the continuation of the story that takes 15 minutes, and then your back into the action sequence again. And look, i get that that is fun. I loooooved Doom when it came out, and Wolfenstein: new order was badass, I enjoy the S**t out of those kinds of games as well!
...when i havent just spent the last week playing a different genre of game and being super excited to play more of it.  

I think in the end, if Bioshock infinite had been a movie, then i would've been completely sold. alternatively, had the game not had the name Bioshock infront of it, had the game been called something on the line of "Aethershock" instead,  similar to Systemshock before Bioshock, then i could have completely understood that it is a story set in a similar world but with a different theme. Systemshock in space, bioshock under the sea, and Aethershock (name pending) in the sky. That would have made sense. As it stands, it just didn't fit into what i wanted it to be. And there is the crux of my dilemma of what rating to give. On its own, the game in itself is fine. Its good, its absolutely solid as an action shooter with a good story. But it isn't a successor to Bioshock 1 and 2. It is an action movie masquerading as one. 

TL:DR: If you want a good storydriven action shooter with actionpacked gameplay, then get this game. If you want another Bioshock after playing 1 and 2, then this isnt the right game for you.

with out a doubt one of the most overrated games ever made. A muddy narrative that shoots itself in the foot by trying to tie itself together with the other bioshocks using multiple timelines and universes. There's always a lighthouse, always a man, always plasmids, not as a common trait of a video game series but because of multiple universes. the first 7 minutes lets you press E to do a hate crime. enemies people bullet sponges half way through. the anti racist struggle against a fascist state becomes evil, not through good story tell, but through the leader shooting a random child infront of you. you then go through a time portal into the future where the fascist state has been replaced with a baby's understanding of Stalin. Oh yeah, you also fight a ghost in a graveyard for no real reason.
The game has very little to say while trying to say a lot, spread its story too thin to make a good narrative. Is it a condemnation of american exceptionalism? A meditation on the cyclical nature of violence and the folly of trying to overcome violence? Is it about how the ideals of a revolution can be lost (using time travel and alternative universes so you never actually see this unfold)? Is the songbird about an abusive boyfriend (no, seriously, thats what it is)? Is it a takedown on an ideology (you dont need to do a takedown on racist segregation FFS)? It tries to do all of these at once, failing to do any

The game is definitely a graphical step forward using Unreal Engine 3 instead of 2 like the previous installments. This game has some serious eye candy. It also has the best-feeling weapons mechanics of all Bioshock games, but the weapons system deviates from its predecessors in that you can only carry two weapons at a time (think Halo franchise). The story is pretty brave, but that made it very refreshing. My only complaints are the obligatory and sometimes unpredictable autosave system, and occasionally there were glitches like rag dolls taking up the same space, but nothing that was able to ruin the game for me.

Even after all these years this is one of the best games i have played, the asthetic is expeptional, the main side character (elisabeth) is the best side character i have seen so far.the gameplay is addicting enough to keep you going and the visuals are really holding up even after all those years.The game due to it's age is of course runnable on pretty much everything.the gameplay can get semi boring after playing half of the game+ but the story carries it pretty much throughout the end.

Note:This game can be played without you having to play the old bioshock games since it's a complete different story.

TLDR:  one of the best games in terms of story i have ever played with the best side character and amazing design overall,above average gameplay and estheticly exceptional

Edit 2: Hi I played the game again after 8 years and I don't really have many new thoughts other than I'm smart enough to understand the story now, because I actually understand history and am more familiar with ideas about quantum mechanics and space-time.
I think the biggest reason why I felt so overwhelmed back then is because the game does not have a satisfying ending. It has a set of HUGE twists toward the end and at the end of the game that can be hard to understand, but the problem is that it just doesn't resolve properly afterward, or at least it doesn't solve satisfactorily.
I JUST WANT A FATHER AND DAUGHTER TO BE HAPPY TOGETHER OK. I wanted a happy ending, and I get it blah blah bioshock something something but idk Bioshock 2 has a happy ending why can't this game, you spend all this time making us deeply invested in and care about Booker and Elizabeth and their relationship why not have them live happily ever after. 

Anyways, played it on 1999 mode. I actually enjoyed being forced into cover and getting shot down in like 2 shots, made me play very strategically. I want to say that the combat scenerios you're put in is pretty great and the AI for time of release is pretty great.
A few problems. The checkpoint system is absolute fucking garbage. You will never know how far back you'll get sent, and whenever I die I go back to checkpoint. "Oh why would you do that why not just pay for the revive", it's really simple, you need money for upgrades, and upgrades make you powerful and makes the super hard 1999 mode less impossible, plus I get to keep my ammo. Idk why they didn't have a checkpoint machine or at least some kind of HUD indicator for when a checkpoint was reached.
Gunplay is absolutely great, agree with my younger self there. Grinding on rails feels good (though is a lot less useful in 1999 mode other than evading handymen), and while being limited to 2 guns is VERY limiting it avoids clutter and encourages picking things up on the fly which feels awesome. HOWEVER. It's very easy to fall into using only two weapons and being ammo starved with them, because if you drop them you never know when you're going to be able to find them again. This playthrough I did sniper and hand cannon (sweet sweet headshots) which worked greats, and because of their low ammo pool I switched sometimes, but I switched right back after the battle was over. I get that Bioshock and ESPECIALLY Bioshock 2 had an issue of having waaaay too many weapons and ammo types, but fuck at least you had them available to you at all times, if you wanted to use something that suited the situations or set up a trap (which you often could successfully do in 2) then you simply could, no need to find the gun you want again.
The vigors were ok. I gotta say that plasmids and vigors never really impressed me much throughout the series. My main two was Possession (makes an enemy attack other enemies, divert their attention, and they may kill themselves afterward?? super OP), and shock jockey (free stuns). I used bronco for the firemen because they're annoying otherwise. More than what I did with plasmids honestly. 

Edit: Wow this is a super cringy review I made right after playing it. The story is interesting but it's really not that mind boggling or complicated, in fact the story in terms of making sense is kinda flawed. But whatever. Gameplay and aesthetic is still amazing.

Absolute garbage.
This should have been called Call of Duty Infinite.
Hand holding, railed campaign through linear maps that retcons the original games into ashes.
On top of that, the story has so many contradictions its a wonder my computer hasn't turned into a universe destroying singularity.
Plasmids and weapons are greatly streamlined and simplified, for the worse, making them incredibly boring and lackluster to use.

Enemies are a complete snoozefest too. Where Rapture's enemies are memorable and varied, like houdini, brute and leadhead splicers, Infinite's enemies are just plain guys with guns. The sole exception are the handymen enemies, who are clearly intended to be this games Big Daddy, but who are just bullet sponges that are neither memorable or a key part of the world like the Big Daddies are.

Infinite also somehow manages to make a literal floating city boring, which I didn't think possible. It completely lacks the charm or immersion of Rapture that caused it to be elevated to a character in its own right. Columbia is just a gimmicky set piece.

I would 100% recommend this game to anyone and everyone. While yes, you could say the combat and unique areas are not as strong as Bioshock 1 and 2, that is not where this game shines. The story and buildup of events are beautiful from the breathtaking intro to Columbia to the mind-bending timeline that you learn in the finale, not to mention the amazingly written character Elizabeth. The DLC Burial at Sea is also a must play, it does an amazing job at incorporating events and characters from the first two games and about how Atlas begun his takeover of Rapture.

The only thing I would change is that I played it sooner, honestly a masterpiece story wise that will forever be one of my favorites.

Bioshock Infinite is a masterpiece of storytelling and gameplay, taking players on a journey through a breathtaking world of floating cities, alternate universes, and political intrigue. As a first-person shooter, it offers a unique blend of action and narrative that sets it apart from other games in the genre.

From the opening scene, the game immerses you in the world of Columbia, a city in the clouds that seems too good to be true. As you explore the city and uncover its secrets, you'll encounter a cast of memorable characters, including the enigmatic Elizabeth, whose abilities will prove crucial to your success.

The gameplay is fast-paced and thrilling, with a variety of weapons and abilities at your disposal. The use of the Skyhook, a grappling hook that allows you to ride along the city's rails, adds a new dimension to the combat and allows for some truly impressive set pieces.

But where Bioshock Infinite truly shines is in its storytelling. The game tackles weighty themes such as racism, nationalism, and the dangers of blind faith, all while keeping the player engaged with a twisting and turning plot that will keep you guessing until the very end.

The voice acting is top-notch, with Troy Baker delivering a standout performance as the protagonist, Booker DeWitt. The game's soundtrack is also a standout, featuring haunting choral arrangements and period-appropriate songs that add to the atmosphere of the game.

Visually, Bioshock Infinite is a stunning achievement, with its vivid colors and art deco-inspired design creating a world that is both beautiful and unsettling. The attention to detail is impressive, with every corner of the city feeling like it has a story to tell.

Overall, Bioshock Infinite is a must-play for fans of first-person shooters and narrative-driven games. Its blend of action and storytelling is unmatched, and the world of Columbia is a place you'll want to get lost in again and again.

Bioshock Infinite is brilliant. Yes, it has many faults (like the ridiculous multiverse stuff around which the story revolves), but the environment and world it creates, along with still phenomenal gameplay. 

The game would have benefited from a 'simpler' story, but given the reportedly horrible development, it still managed to turn out pretty well.

[b]Summary:[/b] A somewhat predictable and too quick, yet incredibly fun, still thought-provoking, and engaging emotional rollercoaster.

[b]Long Review[/b]
Late to the party, the Bioshock series was my first real FPS experience. So while not the best judge of gameplay, in terms of the trilogy I consider Infinite to have executed it best. Many players found ability to carry only two firearms a hindrance, but I found it a strategic challenge bearing a certain level of realism—only now did I realise we would somehow haul an entire arsenal around with us in previous games—which actively demanded different strategies, as opposed to: I ran out of ammo... oh well, guess I'll shoot them with this other ammo then change over to one of my seven other guns, all of which require me to get up close and personal with my opponent anyway and go boom. The Plasmids/Vigors are also far more engaging and balanced. And, finally, no more dumb hacking minigames. Huzzah.

The graphics remain excellent a decade later, and nothing betrays the game's age in that department—with the exception of my device being easily capable of running the game at its highest settings without sounding like an aeroplane at takeoff. The change from Rapture to Columbia was a welcome one, as Rapture's post-catastrophic ambience was starting to get a little old, which was quite a drawback as environments are the primary means of Bioshock's storytelling. The soundtrack was great. Voice acting was also solid, with no background character cringe. Troy Baker (unsurprisingly) did well as Booker, and so did Courtnee Draper as Elizabeth.

Overall, Infinite easily leaves the original duo in the dust, in all but three aspects: the lowered difficulty, lack of player agency, and conclusion. 

(Minor Spoilers Ahoy)

Compared to the previous titles, Infinite felt a little too easy; my first death came in almost halfway into the game. I assumed the difficulty drop was due to the lack of vitachambers, and the game would send you back to your last checkpoi-you're revived three metres away from where you died? I don't normally prefer games on very high difficulties, but compared to the previous Bioshock games, this one felt like a walk in the park. That could be attributed to the far more streamlined gameplay, alongside the lack of the Big Daddy-esque bosses.

My biggest gripe with Infinite, however, was the only set of credits rolling in just over ten hours. Would it have been longer had I played it on a harder mode? Sure. But seeing as I had only played two FPS titles before it, I assumed Normal difficulty was the way to go as to not shoot myself in the foot. Constant death is an artificial way of narrative pacing anyway.

I didn't mind the lack of multiple endings, and it did make more sense plot-wise. That, however, [spoiler] alongside the conclusion's completely nihilistic nature, while I didn't mind it in terms of storytelling [/spoiler] makes replayability hugely redundant; there is hardly any story-related reason to return to this title. Maybe just to see how much more difficult the game can get, and get some achievements.

[b]Conclusion:[/b] Play this fucking game with its excellent storytelling and engaging (although done to death) social commentary. While not without fault, it's worth your time, and your money, and really highlights how lots of contemporary gaming has become very dull given that, plot predictability aside, had someone told me this game came out this year I would have believed them.

BioShock Infinite is a breathtaking first-person shooter game that takes players on a thrilling journey through the floating city of Columbia. Set in an alternate universe, players take on the role of Booker DeWitt, a former Pinkerton agent tasked with rescuing a young woman named Elizabeth from the city and the clutches of the mysterious Songbird.

The game's storyline is a standout feature, offering an intricate and compelling narrative that explores themes of American exceptionalism, racism, and quantum mechanics. The game's setting is brought to life through stunning visuals and rich environmental storytelling, creating a beautiful and immersive world that is both captivating and thought-provoking.

BioShock Infinite's gameplay is also top-notch, offering a range of powerful weapons and abilities to take on the game's various enemies. The game's innovative combat system allows players to use their environment and abilities in creative ways, resulting in a dynamic and thrilling combat experience.

In addition to its engaging single-player campaign, BioShock Infinite also features a fantastic multiplayer mode that allows players to engage in intense battles against each other using a range of weapons and abilities. The mode is well-balanced and highly addictive, providing hours of fun and challenge.

Overall, BioShock Infinite is an outstanding game that delivers on all fronts. Its stunning visuals, immersive storyline, and engaging gameplay make it one of the most memorable and thought-provoking games of all time. Whether you're a fan of the series or just appreciate a good story-driven game, BioShock Infinite is an absolute must-play.

Bioshock Infinite is a game that is truly deserving of all the praise it has received. It's a game that manages to perfectly balance incredible storytelling, immersive world-building, and captivating gameplay into one seamless experience.

From the moment you step into the city of Columbia, you are immediately drawn into its stunningly realized world. The attention to detail in every corner of the city is simply breathtaking, from the gorgeous architecture to the hauntingly beautiful soundtrack.

But what really sets Bioshock Infinite apart is its incredible storytelling. The game's plot is masterfully crafted, and the characters you encounter along the way are some of the most memorable and well-developed in all of gaming.

But it's not just the story that makes Bioshock Infinite so great. The gameplay is equally impressive, with a wide variety of weapons and abilities that make every encounter feel fresh and exciting. The game also features some of the most creative and inventive set pieces I've ever seen, with moments that will leave you on the edge of your seat.

And perhaps what I love most about Bioshock Infinite is its ability to tackle deep and thought-provoking themes, such as racism, religion, and the nature of reality itself. These themes are woven seamlessly into the game's narrative, and they serve to make the experience all the more impactful and unforgettable.

Overall, Bioshock Infinite is a game that truly deserves to be played and experienced by anyone who loves gaming. It's a game that manages to balance incredible storytelling with captivating gameplay in a way that few other games can match. It's a game that I will always hold dear, and one that I would recommend to anyone looking for an unforgettable gaming experience.

It's fashionable to poo-poo this game. And yeah, it's not exactly what I wanted. In a lot of ways I wish it were more like the original Bioshock, with combat encounters that aren't, well, kind of bad, and far more interactivity and player agency. But regardless, I've played this game more times than the original, for whatever reason. And I've never completed Bioshock 2 (which struck me as bad fan fiction from the jump). It might be the setting, it might be the story. It's probably a mix of both. But I'll be damned if this game isn't one of the more compelling experiences you can have in this medium.

Bioshock Infinite is a complicated affair for me, as a game it functions perfectly as intended. As a story, it functions fine for the most part. The game itself is fairly good but i do not think this will be remembered by the fans of the originals. Due to it's complete annexing of many elements that made the originals so special, it creates a more hollowed out dumbed down experience. 

That's not to say that Infinite does not have it's merits. The artistry and talent that has gone into this game is not to be understated.Combat feels good even in it's shallowness. The story is constantly having you guess what is happening and that's a great thing, Elizabeth as a character is a friendly welcome reprieve most of the time. However all of these elements are a far cry from the heights of the series and i'd argue even antithetical to the core of what Bioshock 1/2 was. The game is ultimately regressive which is a massive shame when you think of all of the empty elements that could have been filled. That could have been explored in the enemies and environments of columbia.

Bioshock Infinite is an apt name for the game an exploration of what is, what has been and what has been. It's essentially a game built on the exploration of the many world's theory. While that works for the story's narrative, thinking outside of the metaphorical schrodinger's box means that the story doesn't feel quites as palitable as it's previous entries. It's a fun adventure but at the end of the day, it does not execute on those elements what so ever in gameplay. It's a linear path, with linear corridors and ultimately your choices matter for nothing. Kill or Don't? Cage or Bird? Throw the Ball or Don't? It doesn't matter, the conclusion remains static. The beginning middle and end doesn't change or if it does, it's a trivial change. Titles like Prey and it's DLC Mooncrash do an excellent job of creating this sort of gameplay dynamic of playing against the player expectations when it comes to continuity, even deathloop does a better job of getting this across. Bioshock Infinite feels like a game that forgets it's a game at time, like a traintrack without a signaller to change it's direction.

Bioshock Infinite divorces itself from quite a few elements of the original and it's sequel. Plasmids/Vigors no longer serve as a narrative tool to build the world. Very little is done to explain how and why they function or why people have superpowers in this world. In addition, Columbia as a city is also a void of where that narrative storytelling was taken place. You never learn about the people who built columbia, you might see them but it's often a two line tale. Quantum Mechanics itself is a plot device that is given as an explanation but without much of a way in elaborating itself. Multiple times. Much of the strength of the narrative art told through posters and propaganda is cut short. Much shy of realising columbia as a place that can exist. In addition, the game itself does not function as an immersive sim. It's a FPS Shooter primarily. You might see RPG weapon numbers and the like but they can be for the most part ignored. There isn't as much depth as Bioshock 1 or 2 by a countrymile. Victory is handed to you on a plate, even more so than in the past. You are funneled so many resources practically served to you it means that combat has very little actual depth to it. Why bother choosing a sniper rifle over a shotgun for ammo economy when you have a mechanic that literally shoves it into your hands at the drop of a button?

Will you enjoy Bioshock Infinite, ultimately i can see people walking away from it being satisifed. If you enjoy Action FPS shooters, you're in for the ride. If you enjoy Immersive Sims, if you are a big fan of how the originals played. Then you're going to be very sorely disappointed. I like infinite but ultimately it could have been so much more and it just isn't. Get it on sale or bundled with the Bioshock Collection.
