I'm truly baffled and tired of seeing positive reviews for this stain on the Bioshock series so I'll give my two cents. I took the time recently to go through the Bioshock collection including Minerva's Den and was pleasantly surprised at the quality and care that was taken to ensure that the first two games in the series were as good as they could be. Then I got to this game and was unpleasantly let down HARD. I do not understand the amount of people who played the first two games including Minerva's Den in their entirety and then get to this game and think this game is as good or even BETTER than it's predecessors, it ASTOUNDS me beyond belief. Even if you try to view this game as a standalone it's subpar at best. I find it hard to believe anyone with a modicum of brain function can sit through this and genuinely say they enjoyed this snoozefest. I'll start with the gameplay first because trying to wrap my head around the story and put it into words right now on how absolutely horrendous and brain hemorrhaging it is after finishing it recently will strain my patience more so than it already was while playing this dumpster fire of a game.

Gameplay: For starters, This is LITERALLY a COD campaign, you are paying for a COD campaign with the Bioshock title slapped on it. Everything about the first two games is thrown right out the window, you no longer have your own guns that you can carry with you to change on the fly with unique ammo types meant to deal with different enemy types, instead you're forced to scavenge for other guns when you inevitably run out of ammo. Although, to be fair, I did carry the same carbine and sniper up until about the end of Comstock's house chapter. Did I mention there's a TWO weapon limit by the way? As opposed to the collection of weapons you carried in the first two and their versatility in combat. The weapon upgrades also work differently in this game and honestly for the worse. I don't mind not being to upgrade all the weapons but there are thirteen weapons in this game each having four upgrades to go through, a lot of them being completely useless as well because they either don't really make a difference because the gun was already fine without it or you will just never use that gun. I never once, aside from times where I just wanted to test them out, used the Vox weapons because they are downgrades of the weapons used by the Founders' soldiers. You find yourself going through the game buying ammo for the two weapons you have at every vending machine you see or swapping between the same four weapons because the other weapons are just that bad and not worth using. The vigors are this game's version of plasmids but honestly they're a downgrade as well, I found myself using the flame vigor the most because the counterparts for everything else was so completely garbage and useless in the middle of combat outside of a few situational moments or just used up too much of your salts to actually be effective. You also don't carry your own medkits or salts to recharge your vigor uses, instead you have to rely on drops scattered around an area or wait for Elizabeth to see that you're low and hopefully throw you the item you need the most. I almost forgot to mention the shield. I played on medium so I didn't really see a big problem with it. It's pretty insignificant without the infusion upgrades and it's really just a buffer between your health getting shredded instantly but I've heard on hard it's pretty much useless and just a way to take a single bullet while you poke out of cover to shoot at enemies and repeat the process until everything on the screen is dead. This game's equivalent to gene tonics was pretty underwhelming as well and it takes the form of "gear" which you can only equip four of at a time in certain slots for each. Your health, salt and shield upgrades take form in infusions which are scattered around the map and pretty hard to miss if you aren't exploring the already limited map or can't use your brain and you can fully max two out of three upgrades. Truthfully, salt upgrades are useless and you should be going for health and shield upgrades first. I haven't even talked about how redundant the gameplay loop is either. Every area you go through is just shoot bad man, progress a little bit forward, shoot more bad men, continue until the end of the chapter where you go through a "new" area that looks nearly identical to the last one where you shoot more bad men. I don't think I can recall any interesting side objectives or quests where you spent any longer than 5 minutes doing something for someone that amounts to something meaningful, probably because there are literally none from my memory. Again, this is literally just a prolonged COD campaign with Bioshock's skinned face on it.

Story: Honestly, I don't even want to get in depth with the story, just watch an unbiased review, my patience for this game has been expended. This story is full of plot holes and unanswered questions lined with pseudo-intellectualism, convoluted dimension hopping and time travel. It physically hurts my brain to even think about it's so obnoxious, it amazes me a group of people sat down and decided this was the best story they could come up with. It feels the need to beat you over the head with the story at every turn instead of letting the world tell the story itself like in the first two. There are  points in the game where Elizabeth has to lockpick a door with a lock that doesn't even need to have a lock on it and is literally only there so the game can dump exposition on you, I called them exposition doors. In fact, it isn't even always doors, the game will just randomly stop you from playing the game to dump some more of the story on you. You can think about the story and the events that happen for a few seconds and it falls apart at the seams.

While doing a bit of research and learning about this game and it's development, I have learned that Ken Levine, the creator of Bioshock and director of the 1st game and Infinite, possibly purposely sabotaged the series with this game because he didn't like the fact other people were using the series' name and characters without him. If you weren't aware, he had no hand in Bioshock 2 and I guess he was extremely bitter about that. Not even mentioning the incredible amount of concepts and ideas that were scrapped for no good reason out of the game other than the fact that he just didn't like them, even if it would have genuinely offered more to the game and fit into the world gameplay and narrative wise. The fact anyone could still support him or even justify this heaping mess of a game is pure insanity. Hope his next game flops.

As for the story DLC, it is absolutely a slog to push yourself through. The Burial at Sea EP 1 plays basically the same as the base game except you can carry more than 1 gun for whatever reason now, that being said it is still incredibly boring and almost feels like Bioshock 1 again but falls flat on it's face for almost every reason the base game did. EP 2 however is a STEALTH SECTION, the ENTIRE GAME is a STEALTH SECTION and it is as scuffed as it sounds. If it was refined more it probably could have been better, I honestly enjoyed it more than the base game and first DLC and it almost reminded me of Dishonored. This DLC also retcons the entire series, so if you enjoyed the world and story of these games, INCLUDING this game, this DLC is here to bring that crashing down for you.

This game and it's DLC are an absolute bastardization of Bioshock. I cannot express enough that this game is not even worth getting on sale, save your money for something else and just play the first two games or watch someone else play through this dog vomit. Please, don't touch this game with a 10 ft pole. The time I spent on this game genuinely felt like the biggest waste of time I've ever spent on anything. I wouldn't even wish this game on my worst enemy.

out of the entire series, Bioshock Infinite is the least secure in its identity. there is, at times, a sense of familiarity as you encounter some elements that seem like a logical evolution from the foundation established by its forefathers and harken back to what made them so successful. Burial at Sea excels at this, and i applaud it for showing us a glimpse of Rapture before it fell into decay. yet as much as i enjoyed Infinite, i can't deny feeling like it was a bit undeserving of its title. it's the least Bioshock game yet and lacks so many of the characteristics that gave Bioshock its distinct identity. compared to the first Bioshock, it's arguably less creative and undoubtedly less innovative. so many of Infinite's shortcomings come from the simple issue of trying to appeal to the market as opposed to remaining steadfast in the execution of an original vision.

that being said, i appreciate it for what it is. i appreciate it for how it expanded the lore and universe of Bioshock. i appreciate it for trying to stand out and act as a proper farewell to the series, even if it was neutered by the demands of its publisher. 

even if you love Bioshock, i can't promise you'll love Infinite. but for the sake of seeing the evolution of the dev team's creative vision for the series, it's absolutely worth it.

It could be that my taste in games has changed, but this game seemed like such a slog that I didn't bother going very far into it.  Graphics were good for the time period though.

This entire game could have just simply be a Netflix limited run or a movie. As a game, it's...playable, sometimes enjoyable. You shoot things, you move forward, you use abilities etc. But it's not a Bioshock game. I don't bemoan the lack of RPG aspects (Bioshock was terrible as an RPG) but there's something overly on-the-rails about Infinite that I feel suffocating. This in comparison to the slow exploration and dread within the original Bioshock and even the System Shock games that inspired it. There's a large dissonance between gameplay and plot, and I feel like half of the time I'm playing in service of the plot. The gameplay is not varied nor does it give me much options to approach. It literally plays like a run of the mill shooter. And then the story itself is not really that engaging as a videogame. You have no choices nor ability to impact the story. 

Games should really excel in one or the other - give me very good and tight gameplay that's enjoyable to go through and I could care less about plot (Sekiro, or Skyrim, or Resident Evil games), or give me a way to impact the plot and I'll slog through even the most dull gameplay (Witcher 3, Disco Elysium, etc). Infinite doesn't work because the gameplay is dull and the plot is linear. It feels like going through a Call-of-Duty campaign. I would commend the writing, which is interesting and engaging. It's just that all this could have been told through a movie or a TV series, where I would not have to slog through playing it. 

Obviously this is my personal opinion, and a lot of people have a lot of praise for 'games that are good movies' like the Last of Us. Honestly, I would give one caveat to this: I loved Uncharted as games. But that's because I always watched Indiana Jones and thought 'damn I wish I could play through that action set-piece'.  But Infinite just doesn't do it for me.

BioShock Infinite is a stunning game that delivers an exceptional storyline. The game's graphics, world-building, and characters come together to create an unforgettable experience that keeps players engaged from beginning to end. The game's exploration of themes such as redemption, forgiveness, and the consequences of one's actions is masterfully crafted, providing players with a deep and meaningful experience. The relationship between the protagonist Booker DeWitt and the enigmatic Elizabeth is one of the game's most powerful elements, and the game's ending is both poignant and impactful. Overall, BioShock Infinite is a must-play game that offers a profound and emotional experience that is sure to leave a lasting impression.

For its age Bioshock Infinite still looks like a AAA title that could easily have been released in the last 6 months. Graphics are stunning, and very well optimized for PC. The story integrates well with the previous Bioshock games as seen in the game, although I am yet to try Burial at Sea, which of course takes you back to the iconic Rapture environment. The floating city of Columbia and the character of Booker makes the game unique, although the variety of different collectables and challenges make 100% completion for a completionist like myself rather difficult and sometimes tedious. Rail riding is an interesting game mechanic, but like Doom's glory kill mechanic becomes less of a fun engaging tactic and more repetitive than I would like.

All in all a good game. 7/10

I will use this review to give my thoughts on the whole series after my whole bioshock series walkthrough. Personally, i really like the way those games tells the stories. Other than going through the main storyline, you also able to collect radio messages that reveals some part of the deep lore of the series. Bioshock 1 and 2 tells a really beautifully written story about the events and each characters. The gameplay also feels very fun and challenging. For bioshock inf, for me it feels like they trying to go deeper with the story but still managed to pull out an amazing story and a lot of unexpected plot twist (ngl i kinda expect some plot twist already before even starting the dlc lol) although the story can be confusing for me to understand [spoiler]due to the fact that it involves multiverse[/spoiler]. The gameplay also feels more challenging than previous games due to the limit usage of weapons and vigors but still manageable i guess. One of the best shooter + story rich game i have ever played.

Big fan of these games. Decided to restart the series since getting my PC, and all has been going pretty great so far, but the lack of good and proper subtitles in Infinite alone is very much upsetting. The subtitles we do get are so small they're almost useless, the art subtitles is equally as minuscule, but for some reason is also hidden in the top left corner of the screen, and the Voxophone dialogue just has no subtitles at all.
The keyboard remapping options are for some reason very limited. There's no way to cycle through Vigors the way you could Plasmids in previous games.
And my final point of critique for now is that screens are often super small for no reason. The pause menu is tiny, making the already barely legible text that much smaller with it, the video demos when you get a new vigor and those silent movies all around the game are equally as absurdly tiny for how much space my monitor has to use.
It's an amazing game and I am so excited to be playing it again, but the accessibility options are kinda puro garbage.

BioShock: After playing the whole series of the game, I can defenitly say its a great game. Everything you know or, at least think you knew about the world we're living at, is all lies. In each of the games you start as a "normal" character, with a casual personality, that during the game change and become a new character with a different personality. The game is about mental games with your brain. You gain new powers and new abilities the more you're progressing in the game. In each game, the story change alot on each move you make. The whole idea of BioShock game series is really cool in my opinon and so are the action scenes in it and the story of each game. I highly recommend on playing the game, but from the first to the last, one at a time to understand better the story of the games. Great game

Bioshock Infinite's story is my favorite of the three games. The gameplay is responsive, the addition of tears and the sky-line makes the combat more interesting, and all of the new vigors and gear are super fun (my favorite was the charge). Could really be its own stand alone game, but i'm glad its in the world of Bioshock. The sound design of Songbird was genuinely perfect. The high pitch mechanical screeching was terrifying. An almost polar opposite art style to the first two Bioshock games, but having Colombia so perfectly contrast with Rapture makes Bioshock Infinite feel like Bioshock, as it takes an entirely different approach at representing the same idea of dystopia. The Burial at Sea DLC does an amazing job at not only adding to the story but connecting the two opposite worlds of Rapture and Colombia. I only wish the base game was longer.

Bioshock Infinite is more than just a game, it's an emotional rollercoaster that had me on the edge of my seat from start to finish. It's an experience that transcends the boundaries of traditional gaming and leaves a lasting impression on the player. From the moment I started playing, I was captivated by the intricate storyline, the gorgeous visuals, and the immersive gameplay.

The world of Bioshock Infinite is breathtaking, with its floating city of Columbia and the stunning architecture that makes it feel like a real, lived-in place. The attention to detail is evident in every aspect of the game, from the music to the sound effects, which help to create an atmosphere that is both eerie and captivating.

The gameplay is equally impressive, with a satisfying mix of gunplay, exploration, and puzzle-solving. But what really sets Bioshock Infinite apart is its characters. The game's themes of redemption, forgiveness, and sacrifice are explored in depth, and the relationship between the two main characters, Booker and Elizabeth, is one of the most touching and memorable in gaming history. From the lovable Elizabeth to the enigmatic Comstock, each character is fleshed out and given a unique backstory that adds depth and complexity to the game's narrative.

In short, Bioshock Infinite is a masterpiece that should be experienced by every gamer. It's a game that will leave you breathless, in tears, and longing for more.

I am a 55 year old biker and trucker father, and probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my son many happy memories.

Thank you

An amazing, yet flawed, work of art that is a must play, atleast once. But in this special case, it is best played only once. This game does a lot perfectly. The presentation, the music, the characters, the visuals, the setpieces, the feel and the overall presentation is all done very very well. But the cracks will start to show on subsequent playthroughs. Despite how messy and flawed the story can be, I thoroughly enjoyed it. Left me genuinely spellbound at the ending. Try to not focus too much on the logic and science of it. I would love to play this for the first time again in the future if i could. Regardless, I do feel that I will find myself back in the game sooner or later. Columbia is a gorgeous place and the tale of Booker DeWitt is a great one. 

The DLC is well done, confuses the story a lot, but overall ties everything up very nicely. The new gameplay elements are especially good and just coming back to Rapture after Bioshock 1 is just a pure delight. Do play it after the game. But I have to say, TREAT IT LIKE AN ALTERNATE ENDING.

Overall, you'll walk out of this satisfied.

BioShock Infinite
The game was indeed not Infinite

BioShock Infinite is one of the most amazing story-driven games I've ever played. The game takes place in the city of Columbia, which is set in the clouds and has incredibly detailed and fantastic graphics. The main character of the game is Booker DeWitt, a former Pinkerton Agency agent who is hired to rescue a girl named Elizabeth from the tower where she has been held for her entire life. And it is this girl, Elizabeth, that makes BioShock Infinite a unique experience.

Elizabeth is one of the most iconic and touching characters in gaming history. She's smart, funny, and has incredible abilities that help the player throughout the game. Her relationship with Booker is very compelling and develops on multiple levels, giving the game depth and emotional gravity.

The story of the game itself is very complex and full of surprises. It covers various themes such as racism, religion, freedom and destiny. The game takes you to multiple dimensions and different timelines, making BioShock Infinite one of the most amazing gaming experiences.

The game's graphics are incredibly detailed and atmospheric, drawing you into the world of Columbia and making you feel like you are in the time when the city was founded. The gameplay is also very well designed, allowing players to use a variety of weapons and plasmids to survive in a hostile environment.

Overall, BioShock Infinite is one of the best story-driven games of all time. With memorable characters, a complex storyline and fantastic graphics, the game offers an experience that will completely immerse you. If you love story-driven games, you should definitely give this great game a try.

Once met a guy who worked in QA for 2k while I was doing photography for a car dealership. I asked him why the gameplay for Bioshock Infinite was so fun but the story was such a step down from the other two games. Then we ranted about the missed opportunity of the game for at least an hour. He gave me an original sketch from Bioshock 2 which was incredibly thoughtful. One of the nicest people I've ever met.  

That being said, the gameplay still holds up today, but damn the story is horrible. It's written so awkwardly and everytime I play it it gets worse. Elizabeth is mad one second and fine the other. One minute Booker doesn't know what he wants but then all of a sudden he's a good guy. There's a spot where Booker tells Elizabeth why he's there in the game, but when he repeats it in the cutscene now Elizabeth is mad. You might be thinking that this is nitpicking for a game that came out in 2013, but Bioshock 1 had better character building for a character that doesn't even talk. 

tldr: The gameplay is fun and interesting. The story is terrible. Play it for the gameplay because it still holds up 10 years later.

I played it from start to finish in 13 hours. I was an incoherent mess of a game. A lot of ideas fizzing around but they never quite come together. It's clear that this might have been a far bigger game, but in the end a lot was cut out for various reasons. Not a very worth successor to Bio Shock.

Look, if I'm going to be totally honest, I very much enjoy the gameplay of Bioshock Infinite, but if that's the only thing I can praise about a game that is very heavy on story, character, and world-building, it means something has gone horrifically wrong with the rest of the game.

While Bioshock 1 and 2 famously set up heavily political worlds and scenarios for you to march through, it was always very clear the game had an opinion on the extremely Ayn Randian politics of Rapture and what it has to say about unhinged capitalist-libertarianism, and it was additionally clear what message the player was supposed to take away from the experience, and even the moral choice system of the game fed into the experience of the morals of Bioshock 1 and 2: are you just as vile as the rest because you are allowed to be, or do you attempt to remain good even in a society where morality seems to have failed?

Bioshock Infinite, despite creating an almost obsessively detailed and accurate depiction of early 20th century racism as well as robber-baron cronyism, in addition to having a side narrative about a main character ashamed of his role in the Wounded Knee massacre and a people's liberation movement, somehow winds up with nothing to say about any of the world and characters it has so meticulously constructed other than the tired and extremely uninformed perspective of "the oppressed fighting back against their oppressors is just as bad as the oppression itself". On top of this, all of the potential in the world for the main character to tie his highly political backstory into the highly political themes of the game is never touched.

Overall, Bioshock Infinite fails miserably at having anything to say with its story, set-up, or characters, almost dumbfoundingly so, when compared to how much effort was clearly put into constructing those elements. You might as well play a Call of Duty game, which, much like Bioshock Infinite, has nothing to say other than "follow the dotted line and shoot the things that pop up along the way".

3/10.

BioShock is celebrating its 10-year anniversary today, March 26, 2023. Below, we reexamine the game with modern eyes, in the context of its place in the series as a whole.

If you're reading this, odds are that you have some opinion of BioShock Infinite, and it's likely to be a passionate one. When it released in March 2013, it generated enormous fanfare, inspiring strong stances from both excited series fans and those who felt let down by the final product. It continues to garner polarized reactions 10 years later, perhaps to an alarming extent. Once you go beyond the social media furor and the thwarted expectations, you have a game that ultimately failed to live up to the identity of its own series--and one that deserves neither the seemingly-bottomless stores of love and hate that some still heap on it.

The by-the-numbers nature of BioShock Infinite is perhaps most apparent in its moment-to-moment gameplay. Though ostensibly intended as the true successor to the original BioShock, Infinite simplifies the mechanics of the "immersive sim"-inspired series to the absolute minimum. The FPS part of this so-called "FPS RPG" series is tuned to max, and the RPG part is nearly cast away entirely.

Not only does it have fewer Vigors than both previous BioShock entries had Plasmids, it replaces the Gene Tonics system with a generic Gear system that allows for much less customization than in BioShock 1 and 2. Infinite also lacks the research camera system, a key non-combat mechanic of the original two games, and an important part of their identity. Infinite removes several other staples of the immersive sim genre, including the ability to hack objects--there's no Pipedream-inspired minigame here.

While there's nothing wrong with changing the mechanics of a series, Infinite doesn't add much to replace them. Sure, there's the Skyhook traversal system, which allows the game's gunfights more scale and verticality, but it's not used to its full potential. Elizabeth's tear powers are somewhat interesting at first glance, but they basically boil down to giving you either cover or resources, and it gets old fast. Similarly, the fact that Booker is limited to carrying two weapons at a time (one of the all-time worst design conceits in FPS history) means that you're usually stuck using the same guns over and over, even when you'd prefer to try something new.

Over the years, director Ken Levine and others have acknowledged that BioShock Infinite experienced significant design troubles during its lengthy development. For example, originally, the player would pick up individual Tonics by exploring the world, with each bottle being a single use. This was replaced with a more generic mana pool system in the final game. Other major changes included the reworking of Nostrums into Gear, which were set to be Infinite's version of Gene Tonics, as well as additional weapons, enemies, and levels left on the cutting room floor.

Perhaps the biggest casualty of the game's final stretch of development was Levine's ambitious plans for 1999 Mode. This would have transformed the game into something like System Shock 2, complete with the player choosing a class at its outset, and being unable to remove the Nostrums/Gear that they equipped, making every choice a major commitment. In the final game, 1999 Mode is a fairly standard ultra-hard difficulty that has very few of these aspects, retaining only a mild monetary cost for death.

It's easy to understand how these RPG elements were stripped from BioShock Infinite. In 2013, the immersive sim genre was at its lowest ebb, and it wasn't clear if there was much demand for these kinds of mechanics in FPS games. In the years since, games like 2017's Prey, Deathloop, and indie shooter Cruelty Squad have shown that there is indeed a market for more crunchy "imsim"-inspired fare. The System Shock reboot coming in May 2023 will be another test for the genre, which has always had question marks around its sales numbers.

This isn't to say that BioShock Infinite doesn't have its strong points, of course. Columbia is an extremely well-realized setting, all gilded streets and bright banners. The game also features some of the best-written characters of its era, from heroine Elizabeth to the delightful insanity of the Lutece twins. Spectacle is Infinite's strong suit--but nuance is its greatest weakness. The political themes that the series is perhaps best-known for are perhaps the most widely criticized aspect of its third entry, but that's for good reason.

One of BioShock Infinite's most telling scenes occurs less than 30 minutes into its runtime. Our intrepid hero, Booker DeWitt, wanders into a raffle in the floating marvel that is the city of Columbia, where he draws the winning ball, lucky number 77. When he steps forward to claim his prize, the curtain rises to reveal a bound interracial couple amidst clearly racist carnival imagery, such as monkeys carrying wedding rings. The ugly truth is revealed: This raffle is nothing but an excuse to punish those who refuse to bow to white supremacy. The game then prompts you to either throw the ball at the couple or at the announcer. Regardless of the choice you make, a nearby guard grabs Booker's arm, recognizing his tattoo as the sign of the "false shepherd," and the first-person shooting begins in earnest.

On paper, this scene is intended to serve as an early revelation as to the true nature of Columbia, similar to the famous twist at the end of Shirley Jackson's short story "The Lottery."

Like many other moments in BioShock Infinite, however, the scene is so one-note and over-the-top that it feels that it's the game hitting you over the head with the ball. The studio behind Infinite, Irrational Games, seems so committed to reminding you that racism is bad every five minutes--a statement so bland and uncontroversial that it's barely worth saying more than once--that it ends up drowning out almost anything else that the game has to say.

This scene reveals one of the fundamental problems with BioShock Infinite: It has very little to offer about racism or America beyond this obvious truth. Sure, the seminal BioShock 1 is not exactly subtle in its critique of libertarianism and writer Ayn Rand's greater worldview, but there are many people in the world who sincerely believe in that ideology and would like to see it enacted. Though there is no doubt that we still live in a racist society, the faces and parties that promote those policies are those that oppose open, more overt racism--for now, at least.

Though there's plenty of room for video games that explore the particulars of structural racism, BioShock Infinite is not one of them--instead, it's blaring a klaxon that's so uncontroversial that its political edge is hopelessly blunted in the process. And when the game descends into "both-sides" pandering when the Vox Populi plot becomes a wrong-footed critique of revolutionary politics near its conclusion--an aspect of the game that has been mocked and dissected and retconned so thoroughly that it hardly seems worth discussing--you can't help but wonder if the game had anything to say in the first place.

When played today, more than anything, BioShock Infinite feels like the product of its era. A well-made but ultimately compromised AAA series entry that tried to appeal to everyone, it could be convincingly argued that Infinite succeeded in its aims: It sold millions of copies and garnered rave reviews on release. That said, the passing of a decade has not been kind to Infinite, and I doubt the next will be any nicer. The industry has changed a lot since 2013, and I suspect that a BioShock 4 that leans more into the series' core identity would do better today than revisiting the half-hearted Infinite approach.

This game is a brilliant shooter like its predecessors.  And after the expectations set by those predecessors, it carried the legacy of the franchise perfectly with a stunning world of retro-sci-fi technology, gorgeous scenery, and a cast of fully fleshed-out memorable characters. The story is great, though despite having some plot holes, is captivating and interesting. The gameplay is good; it's a bit repetitive, but that's standard shooter fair. The gunplay is nice and smooth, with a wide enough variation but the enemies lack the variation in types and skills. Bioshock: Infinite is a game that has delivered a bigger story and more polished experience. Definitely a rare shooter, a rare gem.

bioshock: infinite is a fps adventure game developed by irrational games and published by 2k in march of 2013. you play as booker dewitt, voiced by troy baker, as he heads to an colorful airborne steampunk city called columbia to retrieve a girl named elizabeth. after bioshock (2007), ken levine (creative director of irrational games) wanted to make a game like infinite, however, they eventually made a deal with 2k where a new studio would be created under 2k and they would develop bioshock 2, irrational games then started working on infinite around the same time the new studio at 2k was working on bioshock 2.

it was february 2008 when they had started concept work on infinite, and 2k had given irrational game a large amount of creative freedom. ken levine had a notoriously infamous creative process which has been described as "brilliant but time-consuming." he focused on very small details and would change his mind on the fly after spending hours (or days or weeks) on a singular aspect of the game. they finally announced infinite two and a half years after they started working on it in august of 2010, and in the next two and a half years leading up to the 2013 release, irrational went through a period of sustained crunch while a ton of stuff was cut from the final product. the game ultimately took about 5 years total to make, and would be the last game irrational games made before they rebranded as ghost story games (still led by ken levine).

infinite takes place in 1912 and is set in a floating steampunk city called "columbia" which was founded by a self-proclaimed prophet. the city was funded by the american government as a floating display of american exceptionalism. columbia eventually would secede from the united states and become a theocratic police state where the founding fathers are religious icons. racism and elitism run rampant throughout the city, as the lower class is almost entirely comprised of minorities who are extremely marginalized in columbia. right around the events of the game where you go to columbia, a civil war is on the verge of braking out between the elite and a resistance group that fights for the rights of the marginalized.

infinite is a fps but does incorporate rpg elements, as it adapts the gameplay loop of bioshock (2007) with similar guns/weapons and powers. also featured is a voiced protagonist, as the first two bioshock games had silent protagonists. in my opinion, infinite has the best story and art style of all three bioshock games, and infinite has been praised as having one of the better stories in video game history. one common thought is infinite didn't lose momentum after a certain plot point like the first bioshock did after the big twist reveal. the setting of columbia has also been widely praised and has similarly been considered one of the best settings in gaming history. rapture was great in it's own right, but columbia had the color and vibrance that rapture lacked. everything you encounter in columbia contributes to your understanding of the world and society in columbia, whether it's a horrifying event happening to you or someone around you, listening to an audio log, or just looking at propaganda that is all over the city.

overall, bioshock infinite is a spectacular title from the early-to-mid 2010s that has strong themes that are open to interpretation and speculation. it tackles topics such as religion and does so admirably. the fact you can get it for $7.49 on sale regularly is insane and an absolute steal for a masterpiece of a video game and the pinnacle of the bioshock franchise.

While I can't NOT recommend this game, I'd have to say that I was disappointed in it and feel that it is the weakest of the series.  Not to say that it is a bad game, I DID enjoy it, it just didn't have the same appeal as the other two games in the series.  Elizabeth did make the game interesting, and the story was decent, weapons were awesome.  Besides that, the things I didn't care for:

First: Columbia is NOT Rapture (obviously), but I just couldn't get into the whole atmosphere of this "City in the Sky" thing.  Take me back to the sea!

Second:  The whole travel by grabbing a skyhook thing sucked (MY opinion) and whirled you around so fast that you often don't know just where to jump off or whether it was just the same platform that you started on.

Third: NO MANUAL SAVE!!  That is a big one for me because the automatic save points seemed to be stretched too far apart sometimes and you have to go back and play half a level if you die.

I'd still recommend the game, but if you are new to the series, definitely play the others (at least Bioshock 1) beforehand.

Bioshock makes me a gamer for life. It is the series that makes me fall in love with video game. Infinite is the perfect ending to this great series. Part 3 of the Shock trilogy, BioShock Infinite, BioShock, and System Shock2.

[b]PLOT SUMMARY, BIOSHOCK INFINITE[/b]

A gruff male with the pleasantly old-timey name of Booker DeWitt travels by rocket chair to Columbia, a flying city where people make 20 second recordings of their deepest secrets and leave them lying around in cupboards. He has been sent to retrieve a woman named Elizabeth, who has the magical ability to summon a box full of first aid kits from an alternate dimension.

Booker wanders around in awe, observing the racist population as they throw machine gun ammunition in the trash and stare silently at nothing. But his sightseeing is cut short when a policeman tries to grab him and he's forced to explode 1000 heads with a giant rotating hook in self-defence.

After exploding enough heads, Booker is taken to an alternate reality where the underclass of Columbia has risen up in rebellion. "These revolutionaries are as bad as their racist oppressors," says the deadliest serial killer in the history of human civilization, "because they are violent." Fortunately, the entire setting is erased from existence and nothing of consequence ever happens. Metacritic rating 95 (94 on Xbox).

—[i]Brendan Patrick Hennessy, 8 April 2013[/i]

The final entry in the Bioshock series. Beautiful Columbia... Another great game. They tried some different things and it worked out in a awesome way.  I have such a blast playing this game, and there is just something about this game that puts me into a good mood when i play it. You play as Booker DeWitt who is a private investigator and to repay a debt you are sent to a lighthouse that then takes you to the beautiful floating city of Columbia. You have to find this mystery girl named Elizabeth and are supposed to bring her back to this certain person and they will "wipe away the debt". And the rest is history, i'm not one to think video game characters are hot but man Elizabeth is smoking lol xD. But this game is awesome! Great story, great and beautiful atmosphere, memorable characters, great gameplay, and great soundtrack this game absolutely check all the boxes of what a great game needs to be successful. The dlc in this game are pretty cool burial at sea episode 1 and 2, they will definitely throw you for a loop that's all i'm gonna say about that. And i had to save the best for last "CITC" Clash In The Clouds its a pretty fun wave based mode with 4 different maps, the more waves you go the harder it gets. But overall i like it and its pretty fun! However if you find yourself wanting to 100% this game there is one achievement that is time consuming and rage inducing. I'm talking about "Blue Ribbon Champ" Man this achievement took me sooo many hours to get. Constant restarting from Wave 14 or 15. Very rage inducing and annoying if you ask me but hey i did it lol. Basically every map has 15 waves, in those 15 waves every wave has a certain challenge you need to complete to get the blue ribbon as they call it. But say you've gotten up to wave 15 the last wave and your fail the challenge you have to start allllll over again from wave 1. Its a pretty infuriating achievement to get its definitely a grind but its worth it to say "Im the blue ribbom champ" lol. However don't let this discourage your from playing Bioshock Infinite, its a awesome game and its absolutely worth a play in 2023!!! Now we wait for Bioshock 4.......
Only get this game if it's in a bundle. If you liked the two previous entries you won't like this one, It's basically call of duty with a bloom filter/sci-fi setting

I played a lot before writing a review, and I still have mixed feelings about BioShock Infinite.

I dislike nearly every character in the game. The game's story is incoherent, which is fine, but it wants me to feel deeply sympathetic to some truly awful people, which is not. Aesthetically, the environments and animations are breathtakingly beautiful; mechanically, the shooting [i]feels[/i] great: it's so clear that everyone tried [i]so[/i] hard to make this a great game. It is not.

I do not regret my time playing. I just wish that it had been a better game, with more to say as a whole work of art, rather than leaving me to appreciate all the composite pieces and wonder what might have been.

In an alternate universe, this game is "Columbia Infinite" and is mostly loved, and likewise I'd probably just let most of these criticisms slide. By making Infinite a BioShock game, then not executing on the core BioShock-isms that made BioShock distinct art, it makes me frustrated that it could have and should have been a lot more than it was.

Or at least it could have made good sense, instead of making goofy profundities like "constants and variables" stand in for a real functioning plotline. Allusions are not plot. Easter eggs are not plot. I think this game will be immortalized for having killed off the series. [spoiler]Now that I've finished Burial at Sea, I can confirm, this was definitely the point of Infinite. It almost feels mean-spirited, like someone in management really tried hard to kill off BioShock as a franchise on purpose by cleaving all possible reentry points into the series one by one.[/spoiler]

The difficulty is quite unusual, spiking quite abruptly at times, but usually [b]too[/b] easy (especially if you, like me, are looting every tucked-away secret the whole game through).

Don't care for Clash in the Clouds, it's basically just PvE with arbitrary extra challenges. The museum is kind of nice, but I'd rather just have had access to the museum rather than having to grind for a few hours to eyeball some paintings and statues. The music was really fun to listen to, though.

Haven't yet played Burial at Sea, but I imagine it will be at least alright. Update: Wow. I have now played Burial at Sea. I have opinions, and they are [b]even more deeply mixed[/b]. On the other hand, this is how I always imagined Rapture with people in it. Just, beautiful, but painfully clear that the people who inhabit it are fundamentally broken and unable to be happy. [spoiler]Plus they clearly dusted off their hands and declared job done on the whole series. Except instead of being internally consistent with the first two games, they used Infinite as a framework into which the main games fit. So it really, really ruins all three games without either completely ignoring Infinite and Burial at Sea altogether or rebooting the whole franchise and hoping [i]that[/i] goes well.[/spoiler]

I did not purchase Columbia's Finest. The base game is so easy that you won't need it at all. Maybe the gear helps for 1999 mode or speedruns.

I'm saying a lot of bad-sounding things, but they really did try their damnedest to make this a great game, and I appreciate that their presentation was so well done that I actually thought actively about the game, it's setting, it's connection to our timeline and the Rapture timelines, the nature of redemption, and so many other things. I don't know how they did all this, and still managed to make the bigotry plot elements so clunky. To make one of the main bad guys be literally named "Fink". To bring up labor issues [i]in a game with cyborgs and vigors[/i] and not really do anything with it except put up posters and have some NPC convos you can eavesdrop upon.

I am saddened that this is probably how BioShock ends, but I am hopeful that other IPs will be inspired to do better.

While I had heeded the reviews, recommendations and liked what I had seen of Bioshock games I had never played one, but I had bought them on sale hoping to eventually play them.  When I heard Bioshock Infinite was approaching its 10th year anniversary I felt sheepish at how long I had managed to put things off.  I was in a bit of a lull period on a weekend so I loaded it up, after checking Infinite was a standalone game.

The first thing I felt was the presentation even at the level of the game menus was the best I had ever seen in a game, maybe only Syberia had approached it in my experience.  The music was amazing too, and the game didn't try to wow me with flash or action to start.  No, it had a quiet understated confidence and integrity that was compelling and nailed the mood and setting.

Like most good books or scripts it starts with a good opening hook too.
Elizabeth: "Booker, are you afraid of God?"
Booker: "No, but I'm afraid of you."

The voice acting is spot on from the start and I have nothing but praise to share about that too.

The graphics despite being 10 years old now, hold up well.  The look of the characters can take some getting used to, but upon reading up on it, it was very intentional.  At first a realistic Elizabeth was used, with motion capture.  Player feedback on it though said people ignored her a lot during gameplay so they entirely scrapped all that work and redid it with exaggerated facial features you could tell their expressions at longer distances and keyframed all the animations by hand.

If that sounds excessive, that is par for the course for director Kevin Levine commonly said to be an auteur (from filmaking someone so involved of every aspect of the creation of a movie they are said to be the author) of the video game world.  Orson Welles and Alfred Hitchcock are examples.  He reported that about 2 games worth of things were scrapped during production and he's well known to be a perfectionist and stubborn in sticking to his vision.  On the negative side, he has a high employee burnout rate due to demoralization in part from having so many things scrapped.  His games also take a very long time to make.  (Judas coming out was in development for over 7 years). 

The music draws from a lot of existing songs, but all are renditions that fit the theme and tone of the game or the moment they appear.  There's also dynamic battle music, that has things that insert themselves dramatically when there's headshots and other events.  Elizabeth also aids you in battle, and the world comes alive in part through your interaction with her and her interactions with the world. 

I can't say much more for it without giving away too much, but I think Bioshock Infinite is a game you need to experience to understand.  For me it's one of my favorite games now and I'm going to play the expansion soon.  A lot of people commented that Bioshock games proved to them video games can be art, I don't think personally that was ever up for question, but if someone doubts it then perhaps have them play this game.

It's honestly amazing this game has higher reviews than Bioshock 1 or 2 (Remastered versions). It's not a bad game at all, but incredibly mediocre compared to its predecessors, especially compared to the critic reviews i'm seeing.

Pros: 
* Great environment / graphics. Game looks very nice, especially for a 2013-era game. Columbia is a great setting, bright and grandiose with great visuals.
* Uh.....

Cons: 
* Linear gameplay. Compared to 1 and 2, this game is much more linear. Events are scripted, the areas are always a straight path with the occasional open area (1 entrance, 1 exit), for combat purposes. Bioshock 1 and 2 had goals you had to accomplish, but much more open level plans where you could meander and explore before accomplishing said objectives.

* Below-average gunplay/gameplay loop: Gunplay was severely mediocre in this game. A lot of guns were very samey, with very simplistic upgrades of +damage or +reload speed. There was a melee weapon which really wasn't that interesting. Not much to say here. Very underwhelming compared to the drill / various upgrades from 1+2. For some god-forsaken reason, you can only have 2 guns at a time, swapping whenever and enemy drops them. Perhaps you're into that, but for me it was incredibly restricting and didn't even make sense. You bought an upgrade for a certain gun, then threw it away? You get to keep it the next time you pick one off an enemy! I guess those enemies coincidentally had the same upgrades you bought 3 stages ago?

* Tying into above, the "plasmid" (vigor) systems. In bioshock 1+2, plasmids/ADAM/Eve were all cohesively part of the story and made sense. They tied into eachother and were all relevant throughout the game, relating to the plot in a significant way. In Infinite, Vigors are there because...... it's a bioshock game I guess? They could have removed vigors and the game would be almost exactly the same. They don't tie into the plot in the slightest, and are a completely "modular" part to the game.

In addition, plasmids (vigors) were incredibly less useful and samey. Every single power fell into "Press right click to do primary projectile! Hold right click to set trap!" (Except ram/charge I guess?). They were much less useful in Infinite, in addition to not having any connection story/lore-wise. 

* Story: The overall story seemed incredibly contrived and a tad bit pretentious. It alternated between being about slavery/race relations, time travel/alternate dimensions, and making fun of religious/libertarian types, and did none of these topic/satires justice. They touched on these topics on a very shallow level, but there really aren't any lessons to take from these. None of these topics are explored in significant depth, and the game really tries to pretend it's some artistic masterpiece with a deep, moral lesson to be learned. It's *incredibly* shallow and a bit insulting.

* Voice acting / dialogue / character development: There's something about Booker / Elizabeth's acting/development that just doesn't *work*. Their dialogue is usually cringy and out of place. Hard to say without spoiling exactly, but (usually) elizabeth will make some sort of cringe-worthy comment emotional/developmental comment, then immediately go back to being an emotionless robot. It's very weird to describe, but the dialogue and character development feels *extremely* inorganic, as nobody in these 2 peoples shoes would react in the way that Booker and Elizabeth did. It's difficult to describe.

* Elizabeth in a gameplay sense. Props to the developers for not making her an escort mission and keeping her out of fights - honestly, good work. But she really only exists to toss you money / ammo / health / EVE at a constant rate. It's kind of jarring how her only gameplay purpose is just a glorified item dispensary. Dunno how to describe this well, but it was weird.

There are a few more things I could go into, but Infinite was incredibly mediocre - 5/10. I would not recommend it over 1 or 2 remastered, It's a decent *game*, but a fairly bad *bioshock* game.

From the moment you step into the game's stunningly beautiful environment, it's clear that BioShock Infinite is a masterpiece of game design. The world of Columbia is a vibrant, living place, filled with characters that are both interesting and compelling. The game's visuals are absolutely breathtaking, with detailed textures and stunning lighting effects that create a sense of immersion unlike any other.

But it's not just the visuals that make BioShock Infinite such a standout game. The story is expertly crafted, with plenty of twists and turns that keep you on the edge of your seat. The relationship between Booker and Elizabeth is particularly well done, as they bond over their shared experiences and help each other navigate the complexities of Columbia.

The gameplay itself is fast-paced and engaging, with a variety of weapons and abilities that allow you to approach combat in different ways. The ability to use Elizabeth's powers to summon objects and manipulate the environment adds a whole new layer of depth to the gameplay, and creates some truly memorable moments.

Overall, BioShock Infinite is an absolute must-play for any fan of first-person shooters or immersive storytelling. Its stunning visuals, compelling story, and engaging gameplay combine to create an experience that is truly unforgettable.

A mixed bag, but enjoyable 

First off for a bias, I am really not a fan of longer games without the option for manual saves (I like to be able to call it a night without having to slog to an autosave point, plus in my last play through the cat jumped on the keyboard and locked me into proceeding to the endgame section). Additionally the game crashed (only twice, thankfully), which was very frustrating to then slog back through a section. When your game is on the longer side without a great narrative reason (ex: some horror games) to not have manual saves it irritates me. 

Gameplay and story-wise, it is a expansion of the lore set up by the previous Bioshock titles (of course Burial at Sea really does this more). It may be overly pretentious at points, but hey-it's still a fun time. It does make some changes from previous titles such as a 2 weapon limit which did take some getting used to, but I eventually got over it. This game still holds up pretty well.

Here are some reasons to play Bioshock Infinite:

Who doesn't love shooting crows out of their hands? Seriously, that's some next-level superhero stuff.

The floating city of Columbia is like nothing you've seen before. Sure, it's a dystopian society rife with violence and oppression, but it's pretty to look at!

You get to team up with Elizabeth, a companion with a personality and backstory that puts most other video game characters to shame. Plus, she can open up tears in space-time, which is pretty handy.

The storyline is a mind-bending trip that will have you questioning everything you thought you knew about reality. Who needs drugs when you have Bioshock Infinite?

The game's soundtrack is pretty darn good. You might even find yourself humming "Will the Circle Be Unbroken" long after you've finished playing.

The final battle is one of the most epic and visually stunning moments in gaming history. Seriously, you'll feel like a total badass taking on the forces of evil.

And finally, who can resist the appeal of a game that lets you shoot fire from your fingertips? Burn, baby, burn!
Must play classic for everyone

This game is a masterpiece. It skillfully explores complex themes such as social dynamics and metaphysics in a unique way that sets it apart from other games. In the original game, the dystopian conflict between communism and capitalism was presented symbolically through the underwater city of Rapture.

The game depicts a multiverse in which an infinite number of universes exist, each with their own unique attributes resulting from different events. In this case, the pivotal event is the protagonist's baptism at a specific point in time. The universe where the protagonist is baptized becomes the universe of Comstock and Columbia, while the universe where he is not baptized becomes the universe of Booker and Ana.

Comstock, who exists in the universe where the protagonist is baptized, is unable to have children and ultimately travels to the universe where he is not baptized to take Ana from Booker. Booker, on the other hand, returns to the universe where he is not baptized to rescue his daughter and kill Comstock. However, he discovers that this universe is also one of countless others that have diverged due to the baptism event, which is split into universe A and B.

The game tells a tragic story in which the protagonist ultimately chooses to sacrifice himself, allowing his daughter to end the cycle of violence and undo the consequences of the baptism event.
What a piece of art! that's it.

For the steam version:
Don't buy it. The publisher 2K is doing their best to make future digital purchases of their games a bad idea.
You are forced to install the 2K-games launcher and create an accout on their platform.
So far, you can  add:
"BioShockInfinite" -run %command% 
to the launch options of the game to circumvent this, 
but who knows how long it takes for 2K to patch this out?
At that point, you are no longer purchashing the game, but only the permission to play it. 
And what gurantee do you have with this new license agreement that they will not make further changes to the title?

If you are interested in the game: Look for a (used) physical  copy; if possible with the expansions included.
That way, you will have a save copy.
The developers were already payed for the game. Only the greedy publisher is still profiting from this title nowadays. If you want to support the makers of the game, support the indivuals that made it, and whatever projects they are working on nowadays.
If you already have the game, back up the files so 2K can't screw with the game any further.

For Bioshock Infinite itself: It's good. Solid 8/10, despite it's flaws.
It's still a well made, enjoyable game. The setting is fleshed out, the maps offer incredible detail. The gameplay is fun. The story is engaging. You will be engrossed in the story and it's charactes, and it's messages are mostly conveyed well.
It only starts showing it's cracks when you look at it in depth, which the game's ending asks you to do.

[spoiler]
While Bioshock Infinite is nowehere near is genre defining as it's predecessors,
it's still memorable in it's own right. The setpieces and presentation are exceptional.
And while it's still old, the game's extreme amount of detail still rivals modern releases, whith art design helping a lot to keep the game timeless despite it havng aged graphically.

The game ditched many of the light RPG features of prior games and focused more on being a First Person Action Shooter.

But, like those prior Bioshock games, the game is incredible ambitious - something modern games lack.
Irrational games wanted not to just make another action game. They wanted to elevate great gameplay with a thought provoking story. A triple-A game with genuine political themes and critiques about certain apsects of society and history.

And like the critique about Objectivism previous titles had, Infinite, too, wants to emerge the player in it's details.
This time, it's about American Exceptionalism, Religous Fanaticism, R-cism and fighting personal trauma.

This does not always work, especially due to game's industry influences of the time. For example: 
RPGs work best with a silent protagonist, as it allows the player to fill in the blanks the best.
With the light-RPG elements gone, so goes the risk of clashing player intent with the narrative too much.
Irrational games had the opportunity to make the protagonist an intersting part of the narrative.
Instead, Booker DeWit is the epitome of early 2010s game protagonist writing: The "tragic, rough, tough guy with a heart of gold" trope in it's extreme. A shallow trope created to make the violent gameplay not clash with the story too much.
Having an uninteresting protagonist is going to make any story suffer.
Next, the game is about as subtle as a jackhammer with it's messaging. As mentioned above, Infinite has a lot of ideas.
But with the messaging being hammered in your face, it lacks any of the thought provoking qualities prior titles had.
There is still intrigue to be had, but it stems more from the mystery elements of the story, and less it's hamfisted messaging.
And lastly: Bioshock 1+2, part of the story heavily revolved arround gameplay mechanics, such as the implications of an easy-to-access magic system in a world without morales.
But in Bioshock Infinite, gameplay mechanics feel completly dissonant from the story.
Ironically, the game has more themes and ideas than it's prequels, but it fails to actually implement them in the gameplay itself.  And furthermore, the story telling is also not done within gameplay itself. The gameplay switches between two modes: 1) slow story moments, which are essentially interactive cutscenes, and 2) - bombastic action movie scenes.
Speaking off: Those combat sequences are exceptional. Even if the survival horror elements are gone and the challenge being far lower than prior titles, it's still top notch action fps gameplay; even 10 years later.

In the end, despite it's flaws, the game is still absolutly good,
and an easy recommendation to anyone who enjoys a good story-driven FPS.

[/spoiler]

My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you're watching this tape, I'm probably dead, murdered by my brother-in-law Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a Virtual Youtuber empire for over a year now and using me as his recruiter. Shortly after my 50th birthday, Hank came to me with a rather, shocking proposition. He asked that I use my Live2D knowledge to recruit talents, which he would then hire using his connections in the Japanese utaite world. Connections that he made through his career with Niconico. I was... astounded, I... I always thought that Hank was a very moral man and I was... thrown, confused, but I was also particularly vulnerable at the time, something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me on a ride along, and showed me just how much money even a small indie channel could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin so I agreed. Every day, I think back at that moment with regret. I quickly realized that I was in way over my head, and Hank had a partner, a man named Motoaki "Yagoo" Tanigo, a businessman. Hank essentially sold me into servitude to this man, and when I tried to quit, Yagoo threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn. Eventually, Hank and Yagoo had a falling out. From what I can gather, Hank was always pushing for a greater share of the business, to which Yagoo flatly refused to give him, and things escalated. Yagoo was able to arrange, uh I guess I guess you call it a "hit" on my brother-in-law, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured, and I wound up paying his medical bills which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge, working with a man named Riku Tazumi , he plotted to kill Yagoo, and did so. In fact, the bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen in the ranks to become the head of the Cover Corp, and about that time, to keep me in line, he took my children from me. For 3 months he kept them. My wife, who up until that point, had no idea of my vtubing activities, was horrified to learn what I had done, why Hank had taken our children. We were scared. I was in Hell, I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, to end this nightmare, and in response, he gave me this. I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me, or worse, hurt my family. I... All I could think to do was to make this video in hope that the world will finally see this man, for what he really is.

Ah, Bioshock Infinite. A game that had a lot to live up to, given the pedigree of its predecessor. So, does it succeed in surpassing the original Bioshock, or does it fall short? Let's find out.

Firstly, let's talk about the story. Bioshock Infinite's narrative is ambitious, to say the least. It deals with complex themes like racism, nationalism, and the nature of reality itself. And for the most part, it handles these themes with a deft touch. The game's setting, the floating city of Columbia, is a sight to behold. The attention to detail is remarkable, and the city's inhabitants are an interesting bunch.

But, as with any ambitious story, there are a few missteps. The game's ending, in particular, is divisive. Some love it, some hate it. Personally, I'm in the latter camp. The ending feels like a bit of a cop-out, and the game's attempts to tie up all the loose ends feel rushed and unsatisfying.

Moving on to gameplay, Bioshock Infinite is a mixed bag. The shooting mechanics are solid, and the vigors (the game's equivalent of plasmids) are fun to use. But the game's biggest flaw is its repetitiveness. The game falls into a pattern of "go to location A, kill everyone, move on to location B, kill everyone," and it gets old fast. The game's attempts to mix things up with "tear" abilities (which allow you to manipulate the environment) and the skylines (which allow you to travel quickly around the city) are admirable, but they don't do enough to alleviate the monotony.

And finally, let's talk about the characters. Bioshock Infinite's cast is one of its strongest assets. Elizabeth, in particular, is a standout. She's a well-written, well-acted character, and her relationship with Booker is the heart of the game. Booker himself is a bit of a cipher, but his interactions with Elizabeth make him more interesting than he would be otherwise. The villains, on the other hand, are a mixed bag. Comstock is a compelling antagonist, but the other villains feel like they're just there to be killed.

In conclusion, Bioshock Infinite is a flawed but ambitious game. Its story and characters are strong, but its gameplay can feel repetitive, and its ending is divisive. If you're a fan of the original Bioshock, it's worth checking out. But if you're looking for a game that's a step above its predecessor, you might be disappointed.

An overall decent entry into the franchise. I do feel like it is definitely the worst of the 3 BioShock games. The gameplay was a little too linear to me, it took too much inspiration from other FPS games at the time as well. The plot really has too much going on for it to land everything properly in my opinion. The plot-lines of political struggle, racism, multiple dimensions + time travel all feel underdeveloped and lack focus. The DLC Burial At Sea does make some major improvements (especially regarding weapon limit), and the story feels much more focused. However, I really dislike the amount of retconning of events in the main story and the "Star Wars prequelizing" of BioShock 1. I actually think Burial At Sea actively damages and ruins a lot of the plot in the original BioShock by over-explaining and re-contextualising things in that game. I also personally experienced severe crashing issues, just like BioShock 1 and 2 Remastered. On the positive side, I think Columbia is still a beautiful location, the voice acting is still great, and the gameplay is still very enjoyable especially compared to other FPS games at the time. Even though it is definitely my least favourite BioShock game, I still think it is worth playing.

My reason for a negative review is that this is "Not" a BioShock Game.
Its really only appearing to be one.
It does it really well, but it is at the end of the day not a BioShock Game.

The main reasons it fails to be a quote end quote "BioShock" Game boils down to a few simple things.

Reason 1: Choice
In the previous games, Choice has lasting impact at the end of the game and gave the player to "choose" how they wanted to play/end their game.
They could have the feeling, even if surface level, abiltiy to play/role-play the "villian/anti-hero"
The choices changed charger behaviours, story beats, and events. Mainly the endings in which would allow the player to "make" their own cannon, while the devs could create the " actual cannon".
BioShock 2 I believe did this the best, if to a fault by having alot of endings at the cost of not feeling as impactful or different form each, with not enough choices in the game to allow for them to work.
Think it would have been better with just the flat 3.

Reason 2. Tone & Atmosphere.
This one is up for argument, as the tone of the new setting does feel like the alt-timeline that Bio-Shock, Fallout, and many other are well known for.
However, given the past games, the more darker feeling is completly replaced for a more "cheery/sadistic"
nature, gives everything almost a manaquine cold smile feel.
While works, just doesnt have the same energy as the previous Bio-Shocks.

Reason 3 The Art Style
This has nothing in of itself to deal with Ole-American, full send, Patriotism that is has going on, but more of that actual art of the characters, the way they are modeled, and the shading they have.
They all match extreamly well with the new setting, and are faily well detailed, lot of great well done animated writing and characters that you only see once.
However, as previously mentioned, this tone is not Bio-Shock.

Reason 4 Characters/Enemies
Bio-Shocks have been well known for the great cast of characters, very well known for their persoanlity and unqiue quirks.
The different enemy types and the vast list of lore that each enemy created and had. From eliets, Big-Daddys, Big-Sisters, Splicers, Sander, Alas/Fontain, Lamb, Ryan, etc.
You first found the spider splicers in the markets area in neptunes bounty, they wore clothes that match they had sea wear, hooks, and fit the athestetic.  
In Infinite, you get rarely and of these enemies, and types. Most are just humans, either reskined guards or thugs, then your only other break up are the firemen, and the handymen who you see very too and far between.
The lack their unqiue writing from past games, where you could come across a splicer that was lost ranting, looting, or in a firefight with a Big-Daddy breathing life into the world.
Infinite throws most of that out, as its far more  liniar in its gameplay and writing. Which works really well for this game, but its not Bio-Shock nearly as much as previous games.

Reason 5 The Gear System
This is a very interesting System the could work really well, however many of the gear is vastly stronger than the others and are not well designed. It feels very surface level and the way to change them all feel like an imcomplete system that never really took off, but most of it was done, so it was kept in.
In previous games, we had the tonics system as well as the slot which worked great as it forced the player to make "choices" in their playthrough, and go about their way of playing, and in infinite, just like the ending, there is really only 1 way to play.
Replacing Adam in general, is a very strange design choice, even if fitting for lore, but at the cost of gameplay, The need to almost complelty reply on money to get everything feels very forced, In previous games if you took your time looking everywhere you could fill your wallet and never need to really worry about ammo, hp etc and you explored and were wealthy rewarded, here it forces you almost to look every nook and cranny just to get by.

Burial at sea completes the Story and is the best part about this game, however as the form of a DLC and seperate from the Main Game I can not help but feel cheated that we could not have gotten this story back in rapture but instead you need to pay extra to get what you really wanted and that is Bio-Shock, not Interdimentional rift making, fary tale, sunflower, rainbows and sunshine glitter that is the 3rd game in the series.

These are my main reasons as well as tons of very small ones that stack to form my opinion.
It is a great, solid game, just does not feel like Bio-Shock.
I hope in the future games if any, will keep the same tones, and atmosphere while telling its new story.
The characters here are great, well written, have great awesome VA, and animations etc.
Its just not Bio-Shock.
I think dispite the need for Bio-Shock to be in the name as part of the story, I think it would have been better off being a new idea, rather than keep the Bio-Shock name.

2K bundled their new store launcher into a fake QOL update, which at the time of writing, breaks Linux support. For the first update this game has seen in over 6 years, it’s a slap in the face. Personally I have nothing wrong with developers having their own launchers or store fronts. Except when it makes the game unplayable for people who already own a copy of the game or who wish to buy it.

For those on Linux who wish to play this masterpiece, I recommended picking up a DRM free copy of it on GOG. Otherwise you should probably wait until they fix it or the community finds a workaround.

EDIT:
As of 1/8/23, they've released a patch fixing Linux support.

Lame.  I'm not sure what everyone sees in this game.  It pales in comparison to Bioshock 1 and 2.

From a technical standpoint, it is linear, repetitive, and a typical console port, which means checkpoint saves.  Checkpoint saves are awful, and should be outlawed in PC games.  It's like the developers don't recognize that we actually have a life outside their precious game, and don't appreciate replaying the same scenario over and over and over.  Good grief.  It wouldn't be so bad if it was like Halo, were the saves come every 3-5 minutes.  But here, you can go sometimes be 60-90 minutes between saves!  Ridiculous.  One time my player got stuck on a mesh and had no choice but to reload the save, losing nearly an hours worth of progress.  Did I mention ridiculous?

From a story standpoint, I was not convinced.  [Spoilers ahead]

I simply can't stand games with wormholes, alternative realities, and time travel. Not only does it introduce plot holes, but it's a pathetic plot device that only serves one purpose - get out of a jam.  And that happens numerous times here.  I couldn't roll my eyes enough at the ending cut scene.

Save your time.
I really enjoyed playing it! The graphic is amazing, the combat is enjoyable and the story line kept me intrigued thought the whole game.  Would totally recommend it!

BioShock Infinite is a truly outstanding game that is a must-play for fans of the franchise and newcomers alike. The game takes place in the floating city of Columbia, a breathtakingly beautiful and unique environment that is unlike anything you've seen before. The attention to detail, world-building, and notes of historical accuracy create a truly immersive experience.

The story is a masterclass in narrative design, with a well-written script that keeps you engaged from start to finish. You play as Booker DeWitt, a former Pinkerton agent tasked with rescuing Elizabeth, a mysterious young woman with extraordinary abilities. The relationship between Booker and Elizabeth is one of the highlights of the game, and their journey together is full of twists and turns that will keep you on the edge of your seat.

The gameplay mechanics are top-notch, with a focus on fluid and intuitive combat, and a wide range of powers and abilities that allow players to tailor their playstyle. The new vigor system, which replaces the plasmids of the previous games, adds a new level of depth and strategy to the game.

The game mechanics are well-balanced, providing a satisfying challenge without becoming too difficult. The DLC, Burial at Sea, is also a standout, offering a new perspective on the world of BioShock and adding even more depth to the story.

BioShock Infinite is an outstanding game that is a must-play for fans of the franchise and newcomers alike. The time period, story, gameplay, mechanics, and DLC all come together to create a truly unforgettable experience. If you're looking for a game that will challenge your mind and transport you to another world, I highly recommend you give BioShock Infinite a try!

I am reviewing every game in my library and this is the 25th game. Bioshock Infinite is the first Bioshock game I played and I got it around release. I played the game at several different occasions but only beat it once. 

I generally enjoyed this game and I think it is the best in the franchise. The world building, the atmosphere and the gameplay all work well together. Plus the abilities were very satisfying to use. This game was difficulty at times and the story in general was a good time. There is little to say that was bad about this game in my opinion.

Though one qualm I share with this game like I do with the other Bioshock games is that the gunplay feels a bit weak. The guns dont feel as impactful and instead feel more like toy guns. Thankfully other parts of the game make this bearable and the whole world with its colourful art redeems it. 

I recommend to play this game, even play this over the other Bioshock games. It's a game I will remember for a while and the ending was interesting to say the least.
