Bioshock Infinite is a critically acclaimed first-person shooter video game released in 2013. Set in the floating city of Columbia, the game follows the story of Booker DeWitt as he searches for a mysterious girl named Elizabeth. The game's unique setting, captivating story, and thought-provoking themes make it one of the best games of its generation.

One of the standout elements of Bioshock Infinite is its world-building. The city of Columbia is a marvel to behold, filled with intricate details and a rich history that players can uncover as they explore. The game's art style, with its bright and vivid colors, also sets it apart from other shooters and creates a truly immersive experience.

The game's story is equally impressive, expertly weaving together themes of American exceptionalism, racism, and religion. The relationship between Booker and Elizabeth is also a standout, with the two characters growing and evolving over the course of the game. The game's ending, which ties together the game's themes and plot elements in a surprising and satisfying way, has become the stuff of legend.

All these elements come together to make Bioshock Infinite not only the best game in the Bioshock series, but one of the best games of all time. Its combination of stunning visuals, thought-provoking storytelling, and thrilling gameplay make it a must-play for any fan of the genre.

A masterpiece of storytelling that blends sci-fi, fantasy, and political intrigue in one spectacular package. If a well-written story-driven game with a linear narrative is what you're after, Bioshock Infinite is one of the best games out there for you.

The plot is filled with tiny details scattered throughout, which forces you to pay attention to the game, or you risk not understanding the story. The plot is quite complex, and the characters extraordinarily compelling, and there's just so much rich world-building that makes the world of Columbia a delight to explore.

When you play this game, however, I also highly recommend you play the 2 story DLCs, Burial at Sea Episodes 1 and 2, because they tie back to the original Bioshock game. This is a connected universe, and the DLC stories are absolutely incredible (particularly Episode 2).

I will say this, though: I started off not enjoying this game a whole lot. The combat was okay, the story seemed to be too subtle and felt like it was going nowhere. But the experience eventually did find its way and I started to really enjoy myself after the first 2-3 hours.
As much of a masterpiece as I remember it all those years ago. I'm very happy I could go back and play this again.

8/10 game

Visuals: Extremely beautiful world with a perfectly executed theme. The sets are exactly what a dystopian steampunk world should look like. The items in game are also within the steampunk universe. The speech is done in a steampunk way too. The visual and auditory immersion is here.

Story: I didn't entirely pay attention the story, but I thought it was kinda confusing. This might differ depending on how actively you see out optional collectibles that contextualize some plot points. After Googling a bit, I found it quite interesting. But if you're looking for a story that just lays itself out for you, I don't think it's here. This story is for imaginative people.

Gameplay: It's very fun at first. The weapons are pretty standard but it's fun. The Vigors or powerups are fun to experiment with but I found myself using the same one over and over. The gameplay loop is somewhat bland and there's not much variety in enemies past the halfway mark. I wish there were more big spectacle playable moments. The majority of the fun comes in the first half, when you don't have many upgrades and you play more strategically.

Misc: Elizabeth, your AI companion, is absolutely amazing. She feels like a real person and actively helps you in combat, passing health potions or ammo, etc. The voice acting is also amazing. Beautiful performance by Elizabeth's voice actress. The game itself isn't very difficult. On a super super casual playthrough, you won't struggle at all. The death penalty is almost nonexistent and with decent aim, you can easily get through the normal difficulty.

8/10 game. Great visual and auditory presentation. Story is a little confusing to follow. Gameplay gets a little stale at the end.

(THIS IS A REVIEW ABOUT THE MAIN GAME NOT THE DLCs)
To start it out the bat, this game is kinda mid. Look, I like the polish, the story and SOME parts of the gameplay. But coming from Bioshock 1 & 2, it's not good compared to them, which is a shame, cause the 1st 2 games are legitimately the most fun I've ever had in a game. But, the aspects of Bioshock Infinite drags it down by a lot so I'll go over some of the stuff I do not like.
- Weapons: I do not like the fact you can only hold 2 weapons, it reeks of copying modern shooters and not finding a work around for holding many weapons, I'd understand if they limited the weapons you got to 4 or 5 cause swapping weapons in B1 or 2 was a real pain but holding only 2 is really cringe and should've been executed differently.

- Exploration: I really hate the exploration, because ADAM, weapon upgrade stations and hacking tools have been removed all you get is a stat increase bottle, money or lock picks. Which gets really tiring after a bit cause it doesn't feel very rewarding for getting money that doesn't let you get a new upgrade, you have to get a BUNCH of money to upgrade, speaking of..

- Upgrading: It is really stupid how they made upgrading money only so you have to juggle towards upgrading a weapon that you barely run into or for your plasmid which you never have salt for.

- Plasmids: The plasmids are just underwhelming, I played on hard and the only plasmids I ever used were electricity and possession. The other plasmids feel useless or do no damage whatsoever, man if only I could upgrade them with a different source that wasn't used for weapons.

-Handyman: Fuck this enemy, they are just a boring big daddy that are not fun to fight ever, it takes 5 minutes to take 1 down while you're trying to juggle enemies with them, I do not like them at all and when they showed up I played like a weasel.

- Depth: After the 1st 2 games I feel as if the depth was just destroyed from removing different ammo types, slowing the animations, forcing the player to choose only 2 weapons at a time and making exploration feel shallow and pointless. 

That being said, is the game good? YYYYYYeeeeesss? I don't know, maybe it is and I'm just bitter on how much they changed to reboot the series. We needed change so rapture wouldn't be overdone and so people wouldn't get tired of the formula but this was WAY too much. To me, this game is just mid, it's not super offensive but it just feels annoying to play sometimes. I plan to try out the DLC sooner or later when I have the funds but from what I hear it's B1/2 level design with B:Infinite combat which doesn't seem that appealing.

Final verdict: 6/10

This is now one of the best singleplayer campaign I've ever played. Every second of it was enjoyable, every character interesting. Even the similar aspects from the previous ones were perfect.

That's not all, the combat is almost perfect, the combination of guns, vigors and tears makes you want to stay fighting a while.
The story is just magnificent, the entire city is so well created that it'll feel like an actually functional one.

First off, let me start by saying that this is a great game. Okay, I got that out of the way. Now, on to why I'm giving this game a negative review. 

Without notice, 2K has implemented their useless DRM launcher into many of their titles on Steam, including some of the older ones. They're masquerading it as a "Quality Of Life Update," but all they're doing is adding another DRM layer to your games to track and collect data on you, while peddling their worthless online storefront. So, you've got to have both the Steam and 2K launchers open at the same time, at all times, in order to play these 2K games on Steam. 2 DRM launchers for one game is one of the reasons why I buy the majority of my games on GOG.

[h1]Rushed, wasted potential[/h1]

I want to like this game, but it feels like a largely mistepped advancement in the Bioshock franchise, with its saving grace hidden behind two separate DLC packages that literally double the cost of the game. The starting "puzzle" is a sign of things to come. I have mixed feelings, but I want to focus on the very lack of focus that this game seems to have. And because of the huge paywall for the Burial at Sea DLC, I'm not reviewing those.

[b] The Good: [/b]
[list]
    [*]Booker is a great character, with great voice acting and is very satisfying to play as, and experience his story. It's a big change coming from the largely silent protaganist of Bioshock 1, and very much changes the style of story telling, breaking the silent protagonist rule and lacking some of that immersion, but all of the cutscenes are firstperson, and the world is seemless, keeping players invested in Booker's story.
    [*]Similar to Rapture, Columbia is a storied, detailed, beautifully crafted setting, and is a world of many opposites to Rapture. I prefer Rapture's dark, seedy, and immediately violent and troubled setting, but I will not defy the acheievements to the world of relgiion to the setting of Columbia, and it still looks great even today with a very strong art direction.
    [*]The firearms and Vigors feel very satisfying to use, as is a hallmark of the Bioshock series and it holds true to that.
    [*]The ideas that went into this game have a lot of potential, and were very popular in the time of this game's release, with this game contributing to their popularity.
[/list]

There is certainly a lot to like, but this review is negative so the real meat of the review isn't in the positive aspects, but I want to show the game some love, not just hate.

[b] The Bad: [/b]
[list]
    [*]Perhaps my biggest single and very addressable complaint is the sheer lack of ammo reserves/ammunition availability, and the remedy to this matter is that Elizabeth pulls ammo out of her @$$ at numerous moments.
    [*]Extremely hamfisted with the themes of American values and American exceptionalism. It feels odd, considering the very premise of the founding of Columbia. I do think it's very intentional, but it comes off as extremely surface level commentary, with little depth behind it beyond THIS THING BAD.
    [*]Time traveling, multi-dimensional non-sense. The more you think about it, the more it falls apart. Rick and Morty has a million times more depth to it with regard to abandoning your current universe for another, and alternate timelines, and while that might seem incredulous, it's because it explores those aspects in depth, while Elizabeth will use it to pull resources out of thin air and get you guys out of a shitshow. For being the "emotional center of the game", her inclusion feels like a Deus ex machina in every way, she is the reason the story even exists, and she is the reason you will survive, get revived, tranport into a new dimension, magically transporting you to Rapture, or [spoiler] having a bunch of them showup at the end and drown you, to somehow prevent Comstock from existing, which creates a time paradox solved by infinity?[/spoiler] It feels rushed, a bit edgy for the sake of edgy, and like it has no constraints.
    [*]The story feels like it writes itself into a corner, providing some kind of meta commentary of the choices of games or the way it comes across as complex when it doesn't feel richly complex like a tiramisu, but complex like a "I mixed all of my leftovers into a single dish to use up all the food that was going bad" way.[spoiler] Making Elizabeth the daughter of Comstock feels forced, and the other universes shouldn't have been something you could go into but rather grab things from.[/spoiler] The world of Columbia feels like it gets pushed aside as Elizabeth's powers become much more of a keystone holding the story together. I think it has the focus and setting that is unique but feels like a major step back, not knowing what to say with the subject matter compared to its predecessors. It's offset by the great world building, but not enough to draw me in personally. It feels like a frankenstien of ideas. 
    [*]2k DRM, which has single handedly ruined many's experience with simply playing the game.
[/list]

After playing through the game for a second time I felt like I had to completely redo this review. On my first playthrough I was so annoyed that this game is barely a Bioshock game and I still stand by that. I was hugely disappointing with the direction of the story because I wanted a continuation of the Bioshock story and I still stand by that. I think this game would operate much better as a game set in the Bioshock universe without having the Bioshock name attached (which would make a certain location visited at the end of the game much more impactful) HOWEVER: looking at this game not considering it as part of the series then the story is incredible and the gameplay is almost always fun (With the exception of the stealth portion near the end of the game which is total bs lmao) The graphics still hold up amazingly well and I think the themes explored are very interesting and engaging. Whilst the story is incredible I think there were a lot of uncooked elements though with the main two being the Vox Populi and Lady Comstock. Still, I heavily underrated the game on my first review and it didn't feel right to not redo it because I would 100% recommend this game.

tldr; Mechanically very well designed and fun first person shooter. Thematically a complete and total mess, when it isn't being actively malicious in its messaging.

The central theme of this game for 3/4 of its run time is:
Armed rebellion against a racist, totalitarian, jingoistic society for the abuses and inequality it represents is barbaric and morally just as bad if not worse than engaging in those racist, jingoistic societal systems as a willing participant.

The central theme for the last 1/4 of the game is:
We skimmed the wikipedia entries for Multiverse Theory and Quantum Mechanics and we thought they were pretty cool.

I really wish the game was just the latter, because I got pretty sick to my stomach when one of the main characters literally espoused the former idea in dialogue.

Oh the plot of Burial at Sea is:
We decided to make our female lead worse in every conceivable way, give her less agency in her own story, and drop the whole multiverse/quantum mechanics thing because we apparently couldn't keep it straight within our own narrative.

Honestly wish they had just made a new Thief game instead, that's clearly what Burial at Sea 2 wanted to be in the first place.

I found BioShock Infinite to be a game-changer. As soon as I stepped into the floating city of Columbia, I was taken on a journey that blew my mind. The graphics were stunning, the story was gripping, and the gameplay was top-notch.

I was impressed by the world-building in this game. Columbia felt like a fully realized, living and breathing place that could actually exist. The attention to detail was staggering, from the grandiose architecture to the smallest of objects scattered throughout the environment.

I found the story to be one of the most thought-provoking and well-written in any video game I have played. It touched on themes of racism, religion, and politics, and had me questioning my own beliefs by the time the credits rolled.

I found the gameplay to be a perfect blend of first-person shooter and RPG elements. I had a wide variety of weapons and powers at my disposal, and the combat was fast-paced and intense. But it was also strategic, as I needed to use cover and plan my approach to take out enemies.

Overall, I believe BioShock Infinite is a masterpiece. It's a game that will stick with me long after I finish it. It's a must-play for anyone who loves story-driven games or just wants to experience something truly special.

Like all Bioshock games, Bioshock Infinite’s overall presentation is far grander than what you are given to work with.  

I like the environments in all the Bioshock games for their originality and overall design, and Infinite is no exception.  This game has beautiful graphics for sure. The sound, music, and voice acting are all excellent with special praises deserved for the main actors, who were just superb.  

The combat plays out better than previous Bioshock games, but you’re limited to two plasmids and two weapons at a time.  There were only two of the plasmids that I really liked and used them 99% of the way through the game. The combat still gets very chaotic at times, though not quite nearly to the clusterf*ck level of the first two games.  

The overall story is kind of blah and really starts to drag about ¾ of the way through and it was hard for me to stay interested.  After a while, I felt like all I was doing was listening to the characters talk, listening to Elizabeth’s heels clip-clop everywhere, shooting at something, searching through things (many of which you couldn’t use or pickup because you had too many of that item already), and listening to voice logs which added little to the overall story.  By the time I reached the end, I honestly didn’t care what happened.

I definitely had fun with it, but somehow expected more.  The Burial At Sea add-ons are just OK but nothing special.  

I will give the game a thumbs up for the voice acting and environments, but the rest…meh.

Thumbs way DOWN for adding the totally unnecessary 2K launcher also.  What a stupid idea that was.

Bioshock: Infinite is the third and (so far) final entry in the Bioshock series. The story follows Booker Dewitt and his escapades as a hired gun in the hyper-American airpunk city of Colombia. While the political messages in this game are confusing at times, the story itself is compelling and enjoyable.

Bioshock: Infinite -- The city of Colombia & meeting Elizabeth
GAMEPLAY 6/10 -- A decent shooter with lots of routes and options to adopt for combat. Rather than having scarce ammunition like in the former entries, Bioshock: Infinite allows the player to only hold two weapons at a time. This posits a lot of variety for gun use. The same cannot be said about the vigors, of which many are just clearly better than others.
STORY 7/10 -- I actually like the story, sort of. I think that the "both sides are bad" mentality holds the game from truly being minted as definitely good story-wise. That being said, the collectibles and whatnot (including the voxophones) paint a really interesting and unique story.
BEAUTY 8/10 -- Conceptually and visually, the Bioshock: Infinite world is fascinating and beautiful. The style is decent, though could have been executed better.
[OVERALL] 7/10 -- The game is good.
~15 HOURS TO 100% (1998 MODE WITH VOXOPHONES IS HARD)


[DLC] City in the Sky -- Arcade
GAMEPLAY 7/10 -- There are four different maps with numerous variables and 15 rounds of combat each. Each map is very unique and interesting, differentiating each other effectively, Each round of combat is designed intently. While achieving all the special conditions is rather time-consuming, I enjoyed doing it.
STORY N/A -- This is an arcade mode.
BEAUTY 5/10 -- It's an arcade mode. However, some of the scenery is unique and I like that this mode has its own special maps.
[OVERALL 5/10] -- It's fun, but I wouldn't recommend it if you didn't like the initial game's gunplay.
~12 HOURS TO 100%


[DLCs] Burial at Sea (part 1 & 2)
GAMEPLAY 8/10 -- Rapture is generally a more interesting map and I really enjoyed the different methods of approach, mostly due to the focus on stealth in part 2.
STORY 8/10 -- Caps off the story of Bioshock: Infinite and grants some insight into how the three games are all interlinked. It's also fun to be in Rapture before chaos strikes.
BEAUTY 9/10 -- Rapture is a beautiful city conceptually. The map you traverse is drastically different from Colombia, which was genuinely a little baffling to me.
[OVERALL 9/10] -- This is one of the best DLCs for a game I've ever played. The DLCs in combination is about 3/4th the size of the main campaign. Less maps & areas generally, but each map is much more elaborately designed, allowing for lots of sightseeing.
~4 HOURS TO 100%

OVERALL RATING FOR BIOSHOCK: INFINITE: 7/10

Man, I wish I could recommend this game. Granted, I've only ever played the main game and none of the dlcs. It had such a strong start--I really thought they were going to make some strong statements about capitalism being inherently racist, and they were almost there when suddenly the game does a sharp 180 and [spoiler] you end up killing the black leader of the rebellion against the white, confederate, fascist state. [/spoiler] The game really doesn't get any better from there--[spoiler] the dimension/parallel universe hopping seems thrown in there just for the sake of making the game feel more science-fictiony, the appearance of Rapture feels like the devs were going "Look! Remember Rapture? It's a BioShock game, remember?" But you literally don't do anything in Rapture--you're there for maybe 2 minutes before you're jumping into another dimension, and another, and another, until finally you discover you're Zachary Comstock and you kill yourself to prevent the game from ever happening. It's a rushed ending that retcons everything you did in the game to begin with, making the replay value quite low compared to the first two BioShock games. [/spoiler] I'm also not sure why they chose to only allow you to use two weapons at a time. My guess is they wanted to give Elizabeth something to do during combat, and if you're lugging around ~10 weapons, you'd just be able to switch to the next one when you run out of ammo rather than Elizabeth providing you with reloads. But from what I understand, they returned to allowing you to carry all of the weapons in the dlcs, so again...odd choice. The plasmids (or vigors in this game) are pretty uninteresting compared to the first two games, too. I used Devil's Kiss and Shock Jockey the most simply because while Possession and Return to Sender are useful, they cost way too many Salts even with the upgrades to make them cost less, and even with Elizabeth constantly throwing me Salts.

I just wish so much that they had stuck to one theme with this game. If they wanted to do a dimension-hopping game that spends some time in Rapture, they should have done that. If they wanted to do a completely new story that [i] maybe [/i] takes place in the same universe, but focuses on racism/the many faults of capitalism, they should have done that. As it is, it feels like they were trying to tell two different stories here that got jumbled in the middle.

All of this being said, it would be nice to see another BioShock game eventually, even if it retcons some stuff that happened in 2 and Infinite.

I paid release price for this game and it's the last time I have ever done so. Even if the game dropped to $15 dollars, I still couldn't recommend it to anyone. Even with Steam's generous refund policy, DO NOT play this game, as the only good portions are before the first 2 hours. The rest is a slog.

GAMEPLAY:
-I bought into the epic feeling of flying around on the sky-rails, not knowing the rest of the game was as linear as the tracks.

-The environments are beautiful, but they also drag you along on a very narrow path with poor obstacles to replace invisible walls, and the interactivity you have with the environment is almost non-existent. Level design is lacking and doesn't support the narrative at all.

-Elisabeth is useless except to interrupt the flow of combat in an already incredibly easy, mediocre linear shooter. The things she throws you interrupt whatever it is you're doing, and her powers are worthless.

-Enemy damage is pitiful and your health shield is very powerful.

-You have two weapon slots. You will never run out of ammo for either of them unless you use a grenade launcher at all times.

-By the time you find your first explosive weapon, the game is over. One shot can kill almost everything in a room, outside of a few elite enemies. Ammunition isn't that rare for it, and one shot trivializes entire encounters.

-The hard mode is not harder. Resources are a bit more scarce, but not enough for it to count. You may have to drop one gun for another.

-Your character's powers are extremely underwhelming and always inferior to un-upgraded firearms, and in some cases, melee strikes. They have destroyed one of the defining parts of the IP.

-"Boss battles" are recurring enemies later, with no real power spikes for the player to help defeat them easier. The worst part is, they're genuinely non-threatening the first time you encounter them. You're teased with several epic battles that never happen, because they're resolved in cut-scenes.

STORY:

-Elisabeth is a really bad example of likable companions. She was nothing but an annoyance for the entire game, delay the resolution of the plot, pad out the game-time with poorly written, shallow moments that are supposed to define her.  Her every action felt like an interruption to the narrative flow, and as cute as they tried to make it, she's too much of a selfish, unlikable, arrogant child for that to work in the game's favor. All of her powers were huge examples of wasted potential narrative and in gameplay.

-CADbortion levels of shifting tones throughout the story make it really difficult to keep up with the ham-handed bludgeoning of the half-assed social commentary everywhere in the story.

-The antagonist is fought in a cut scene that, thankfully, doesn't have QTEs, but I think this might be the sole exception for where they'd be acceptable so you might feel some involvement in the story being resolved rather than feeling like you're in an out of body experience.
 
-Imagine an six year old trying to make up a ghost story on the spot. The game is like that. It's meandering, thoughtless, uninspired, and can't keep a single train of thought.  The thing they expected to be a plot was so full of holes it couldn't even pass for a functioning screen door, let alone a $50 game.

-Elizabeth was a two dimensional plot device in a complicated, disjointed, rambling, thinly veiled, aggressively Americanized Dr. Who fan-fiction. The ending to the game cements that fact. There's no satisfaction, or resolution to the story, only disappointment. Booker's time was a waste, everything he did was for nothing, and the reason why is so stupid you're left staring at the credit screen feeling the exact same way: Feeling you just wasted an entire day of your life for nothing.

This is one of, if not the best and brilliant story telling that I've ever see on video games. 

    This game's kind of story is like putting a piece of puzzle. You done it one-by-one. Most of the thing that you see seems doesn't make sense at first, but once you put all the missing pieces together, you can finally see the bigger picture on what the story is about. 
    It's surprising that perhaps, nothing on this game that doesn't make sense, I mean it. Even the scene where you are died and coming back to life (respawning) has some kind of logic put into it.
    The other thing about this game that amazes me the most is the world/level design, it's so unique, this comes from someone who have played tons of games in the past.
    The gameplay itself is also fun and engaging.

That said, this game is a 10/10 for me, surely a Masterpiece.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2022 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

As you can tell by my play time, I've replayed the game quite a few times over the past 10 years. As good as Bioshock was, Infinite is to me the pinnacle of the series. The gunplay is fun, and heightened by Elizabeth's special abilities and the fast movement and repositioning of the skyrails. Exploration of the wider levels is well rewarded with extra context and conversation fleshing out the world and the main conflict. The story is great, and the performances by the main cast remain some of the best ever achieved. The original score and soundtrack is top shelf and the City of Columbia is visually breathtaking.
Not as good as the 1st and 2nd Games, but overall Infinite has it's charm! wait for a sale if you're interested in the Bioshock Series.

[h1]BioShock infinite [/h1]
This is a wonderful shooter game with an intriguing story. Having played Bioshock 1 and 2, I really love the change in Bioshock infinite, it's truly a different game then the first two made. The first 2 games where dark and gloomy, horror/thriller in genre, and most notable; underwater. And had a dark Steampunk-ish feel to it. Bioshock Infinite is bright, and looks cheerful, it has "Steampunk" type elements and is set in 1912, in a time where for example racism is still alive. Instead of underwater, Bioshock Infinite is played in the sky, and allows a whole different type of gameplay. Like the first 2 games, you can make choices in the game, although the choices in Infinite, don't really matter as there is only one ending, I still like that I get to make a choice. It gives me a feeling of importance in how the playable character (Booker DeWitt) is. It also changes small dialog in how the NPC buddy (Elizabeth) will act towards you.

[b] Buddy System:[/b]
The NPC buddy is made really well, I can't shoot her, she collects things for me, I don't have to protect her, and most of all; she is not blocking me or standing in the way. Which happens a lot with games that have a buddy NPC character, It's frustrating to be running somewhere and the NPC that is supposed to help you, blocks you're path instead. Shes a very likeable character, fascinating an has a fascinating story.

I really don't have anything bad to say about this game, It's well made, well though about. For someone that doesn't enjoy most shooter games, I absolutely loved this game. And would go as far as to call this one of my favorite games. You don't have to play the first 2 games, to understand this one, as this game is so different then the first 2 made. If you want to get into shooter game, with a good story, I would most definitely recommend this game.

[The Greatest Game I Have Played]

If you love steampunk, play this game. If you like an amazing story, play this game. If you are ready for insane plot twists, play this game! 

This game is absolutely amazing in the story, the lore of how certain things work in Colombia, and when you explore the levels, you could find Voxophones which hold even more details about the story! 

While I was playing the game, I noticed the song "Girls Just Want to Have Fun" by Cyndi Lauper was playing during the festival. It threw me off because the song was made in 1983 while the game is set in 1912 (71 year difference). I was confused until I picked up a Voxophone in a part of the game that gives more details about certain things (I don't want to spoil anything) and then I was shocked and amazed by it all!! 
Any detail in this game has a reason and I love that about this game.

I highly recommend this game because of the amazing story, the characters are memorable, and overall it's a masterpiece of a game!

extremely different from the first 2 games in the bioshock series. personally, i loved the first two games and only liked infinite. 

PROS: fun gunplay, story was interesting with a cool twist (that gets tiresome/overdone in the DLC), main characters (booker and elizabeth) were overall likeable, and columbia was gorgeous. main game was very fun and didn't overstay its welcome. lastly, this game has one of, if not the best, companions in any game. elizabeth is not only endearing and interesting in the main game, but is helpful during and outside of combat without being annoying/intrusive!

CONS: extremely repetitive character models, some guns feel like peashooters, little to no choices in the game and what choices you do have make 0 impact, imo lacks a lot of the bioshock staples (art deco, big daddies, little sisters, ADAM, splicers, commentary on society that is actually nuanced/not just one-dimensional). also, the burial at sea DLC sucked in my opinion and created a lot of plotholes/forced narratives for bioshock as a whole that i'm just choosing to ignore.

overall, bioshock: infinte is fun for the 10 hours it takes to beat, but it feels like a standalone bioshock-adjacent game as opposed to the third bioshock game. the DLC i can live without, but i know some people really love it.

overall 7/10 for base game, 6/10 when taking the DLC into account

Irrational studios has done it again: epic game.

After Bioshock 2, I was kind of done with the Rapture theme. Although I can play the first two Bioshock games over and over again without it ever boring me, if there was ever to be a new game, I wanted some fresh new ideas. My wish had been granted when Bioshock Infinite hit the shelves. 

Instead of playing on the bottom of the world, you are now playing high in the sky, almost touching space. Bioshock Infinite takes places in a new city Columbia. It floats high in the air by massive fans and, just like Rapture, keeps hidden from existence. You play as Booker DeWitt, a new character and a good one I might add. Just like Jack from the first Bioshock, you immediately feel some sort of connection with him because of his excellent dialogue, expression and overall interaction. 

Irrational studios has done it again. They produced another excellent game with another excellent story. It is what the Bioshock games are known for and they did not disappoint with this game. Because of this reason, I will not review any part of the story in this review, this is something that you need to experience for yourself, especially in combination with the two DLC episodes “Burial at Sea”.

The mechanics of the game work very similar to the first games. You got a selection of new different weapons and instead of using Plasmids, like the previous games, you use Vigors and Salts. The Vigors have the same idea as the Plasmids but are still completely unique. You can shoot a horde of murderous crows at your enemies, posses them so they attack other enemies and then shoot a bullet trough their brains or splash them away with water and tentacles. 

For money, you collect the national currency of Columbia, the Silver Dollar.

The new enemies in the game are also very well created and a lot of thought did go into them. You got your standard police officers and other human enemies, but then, out of the blue, you got attacked by a big, mechanical patriot doll, complete in the style of George Washington. And if that is not enough, you got the Handymans, humans in a big exoskeletons with their hearts outside of their bodies, encased in the middle of their suits. The only thing they do is Hulk Smash so they are predictable, but when they hit you, you just bought yourself a one way ticket back to earth.

I like the combat, besides shooting and bewitch enemies, you can also knock them off Columbia. If there is a ledge and you have your trusty Broncho Vigor selected, let them fly! 

Speaking of flying, the new rail mechanic, in which you can use kilometers of metal railing to quickly travel to other places, or giving you the advantage in a fight, is really cool. You collect some sort of grappling hook early in the game and can attach it to the railing whenever you want. You even got a nice attack when disengaging from the rail and jumping towards an enemy. 

The controls in the game work flawless and the new mechanics, Vigors and rail sliding is easy to understand and master. You just feel like you are in control.
The graphics in Bioshock Infinite are beautiful and the environments and attention to detail is just stunning. The lighting is also very well done and gives objects, enemies and scenery a nice finishing touch.

I must say that the ambient music and fight tracks when sh!t hits the fan, are a little disappointing from what I was used to from the previous games. They are just generic and “all right” .However, this did impact my positive experience with the game. 

I really don’t have any complaints or minor issues with Bioshock Infinite, it is just another game in the series that impressed me just as much as the previous installments.

As of September 2022 malicious spyware has been added to this game. I don't know how this is something steam can allow as a product I bought previously and was able to use has now effectively been stolen from me as I can no longer run the game due to the malware.

[h1] Cannot Recommend [/h1]

[h2] Gameplay [/h2] 
I believe the gameplay core was there. There were interesting elements, new mechanics and lots of fun times. But I feel like there should have been more. For the purpose of keeping this review short, I'll group a few categories together. In terms of gunplay too, I never felt the need to upgrade any of my weapons at all. I could scavenge enough ammo or swap weapons often enough to not have any difficulties. One of the coolest things I think about the gameplay was the skyhooks you could travel around the levels on. This was something done really well. The guns didn't handle badly, but I also think they weren't very strong. 

Finally, I think the powerups you received throughout the game honestly weren't that good. Some of them were, but I found myself only one or two, or none at all. It was an after thought while in combat, and I didn't care much to use them. In the original two bioshock games, I feel like they were natural and belonged in the world. In Infinite, they felt more like they were only added to keep continuity between the games. 

[h2] Story and Characters [/h2]
For the story, I was not invested in what was going on at all. I didn't care who Booker DeWitt was or who Comstock was. I was just a mindless character trudging along in the gameworld doing what I wanted. Elizabeth was more interesting than the others, but she seemed under utilized. Someone who was finally able to escape from a cage, and yet she didn't care very much. For some of the other characters, they seemed believable with the themes they carried, but I never got attached. The story was interesting at first, and the setting was very cool. But I just lost interest about half way through and it never caught be again. 

[h2] Score [/h2]
Overall, I would give this game a 6.5/10. Definitely not as good as the previous two installments, but I don't think that is to the devs' miscredit. They had some truly great ideas but maybe because of their highers rushing them or budget cuts, they couldn't realize their true dream. I would recommend you pick this game up for about $10 on sale, and you'll be happy.

BioShock Infinite is nothing like the first two games. No Rapture, no Plasmids, no Little Sisters or Big Daddies and certainly the city is not under water. It brings a new look set in a new world with things familiar yet foreign enough to not be connected to what we know from first two games. Although Vigors act in the same way as Plasmids did they're less varied in elements with enemies less varied in their own elemental properties, that the majority of the game is simplified and most likely played with weapons only, even on 1999 difficulty. Story itself doesn't really get you personally involved with the female companion, making her just someone who's part of the job you're on a mission to do, until the very last part of the game where your own involvement to her is revealed, too little, too late. Songbird on the other hand is the one with the most personality yet it is a bird with no dialogue and its ending the most heartbreaking.
The new addition to the franchise that is a lot of fun to use is the Sky-Hook which is used to traverse certain parts of the city the current mission keeps you in, as well as a melee weapon which ends up being a bit redundant since the open parts of the city keep enemies far away from you, sniping you from the distance rather than engaging in close combat since the game is focused more on combat rather than stealth. Unfortunately with no way to go back to parts of the city explored previously Sky-Hook ends up being very limited in how and when it's used which is a real shame. The game would've benefited with having parts of the map connected by Sky-Hook travel system, allowing both returning to areas and more fun time spent on the rails. Overall it's a good game in the franchise, but it stands out so much with new things not used as much as they could've been that it makes it feel and play like a completely new franchise more focused on action than stealthy horror elements.

Burial At Sea DLC sees us return to Rapture, as well as give us back Plasmids, limited in number and only ones with elemental properties, with Sky-Hook making a comeback too, although once again limited though for good reason. The stealth-horror is back, especially in Episode 2, and the open sky replaced once again with water and enclosed space, a welcomed change from the main game, and seeing the return of both Little Sisters and Big Daddies hitting right in the feels. The story makes a full circle back to the original game, tying everything up nicely with a fulfilling ending.
The only shaky part is Elizabeth's story which the game would've worked beautifully without, but it doesn't ruin it (much) to be counted as a negative. 
Clash of the Clouds DLC however is a different beast altogether. As much fun as it is trying to get through the waves and get ribbons it's soon apparent it punishes more than it rewards. It's one thing to be challenging, but another to completely remove the entertaining aspect of doing the waves when there's no repeat option for a single wave to try and get the missing ribbon, making the achievement connected to them tedious and grinding too much that it ends up being a negative.

Overall BioShock Infinite and its DLCs are a nice ending to the franchise which serve as its beginning as well, with such a unique story, characters and world one can't help but replay them all, all over again.

Bioshock Infinite is a first-person shooter game developed by Irrational Games and published by 2K Games. The game was released in 2013 for the PlayStation 3, Xbox 360, and PC. It is the third game in the Bioshock series, and is set in an alternate reality in 1912.

The game's story follows the protagonist, Booker DeWitt, as he is sent to the floating city of Columbia to rescue a young woman named Elizabeth. Booker quickly discovers that Columbia is a city with a dark past, and that Elizabeth is being held captive by the city's tyrannical ruler, Zachary Comstock. As the game progresses, Booker and Elizabeth must navigate the dangerous streets of Columbia and uncover the city's secrets.

Bioshock Infinite introduces several new gameplay elements to the series. The game features a new "vigors" system, which allows the player to use various supernatural powers, such as telekinesis and fire blasts. The game also introduces a new "skyhook" mechanic, which allows the player to travel around Columbia by riding on rails and grappling hooks.

One of the key features of Bioshock Infinite is its complex and engaging story. The game's narrative is told through a combination of cutscenes, in-game dialogue, and environmental storytelling. The game's characters are well-written and well-acted, and the game's setting is richly detailed and immersive.

The game's graphics are impressive, with detailed character models and environments. The game's soundtrack is also noteworthy, featuring a mix of original compositions and period music.

Overall, Bioshock Infinite is a fantastic game. The game's vigors and skyhook mechanics add a new layer of depth to the gameplay, and the game's story is engaging and thought-provoking. The game's graphics and soundtrack are also top-notch, making for a truly immersive experience.

I really don't get this game...

Pros:

+ Varied gameplay. Bioshock's combat is a solid mix of gunplay, melee and "superpowers" (vigors/tears). You will also have to pay attention to the environment, hide behind covers, look for bottlenecks and use crowd control on your enemies.

+ Setting and art design. The overall art direction is unique, captivating and consistent throughout the entire game.

Cons:

- Terrible characters. Probably the game's main problem, you spend most of your time with the protagonist and his female companion, unfortunately this duo is really hard to like. Their motivations are very weak, they make dumb decisions and their chemistry is forced. You are supposed to care about them because the game tells you to, nothing more.

- Cringy dialogues. The artificial banter between the main duo is pretentious at best and torture at worst. Nothing is stated clearly, everything is veiled and ambiguous. On top of that the characters often talk over each other or the audiologs. There are some good, honest moments but they make only a small portion of the game.

- World execution. Bioshock Infinite's dystopian world offers some interesting social commentary, unfortunately our characters never address it in any meaningful way.

- Convoluted story. Fan fiction-level writing with odd pacing, no satisfying resolutions and a shock value ending. Characters are not able to sell the story, vital details are hidden in the audiologs instead of being presented throughout your actions.

- Linear. It's fine to have a linear shooter, but this game really teases you about making a couple of seemingly story changing choices that don't affect the final outcome at all.

In conclusion: An okay shooter with interesting mechanics, weak characters and a really disappointing story.

A huge downgrade on the first Bioshock. I was excited to try it out after seeing positive reviews, but after an hour of trudging through one identikit corridor after another spamming the shoot button, I was thoroughly bored and uninstalled it. The devs have inexplicably removed all the fun from the core gameplay loop: powers are pared back and simplified to the point of absurdity, there's zero horror and the world, though pretty, lacks the immersive (pun intended) character of Rapture.

I don't care how good the story gets (though having now read about the ending I sincerely doubt I'd have been impressed seeing it for myself) - if the gameplay is dull, I'm out. And it is dull.

Pros:  Nailed that early 1900's aesthetic in a truly top notch, immersive way.  Sidekick character mechanic done at a superlative level not often (never?) seen in FPS's.

Cons:  Disappointingly short campaign.  What I expected was a fun miniboss sequence to be half way through the campaign was later discovered as the final boss of the entire game.  Jarring and unpredictable how quickly the game ended.  I understand there is DLC to extend this experience but I just can't be bothered.

This is one of the greatest FPS games I've ever played. It's a perfect example of being able to craft a believable, living world in a linear game. I have absolutely no idea what the hell this game was about, and watching videos has not helped. The other Bioshock games were confusing too, but the story here is absolutely mental; nothing made sense, even when the ending tried to explain it all. I literally got this whole game spoiled out of curiosity seeing a let's play several years back, yet that took nothing away from the experience, and I was still left stunned; it's that bizarre. 

The game is really fun though, and still looks great. Columbia is really pretty to look at, and I feel it's just as good as Rapture, plus the world building, especially in the intro, is really well done. The horror elements in this are really cool too, and surprisingly, you get an escort companion that isn't completely useless and actually helps you defeat enemies and get supplies. Great game; check it out, but prepare for a mind f-ck.

Oh, and 2k? F--- off with your launcher. The games were perfectly fine before. If you truly want to help with the "quality of life", then don't pull a Rockstar and force us to install even more software just to play a nearly ten year old game. If you can give me five ways this launcher in any way amplified the gaming experience, you're talking out of your a--.
Shooting is clunky, but story is so good that it blowed my mind

First of all, fuck you 2K, first you add the stupid ass launcher, that strait up breaks the native linux version, and then you make a post saying you're sorry and that you know that the launcher is breaking the game but you STILL LEAVE IT IN, if you know the launcher is broken, then roll back the update. Anyway the game is still playable on linux via proton, but still asshole move 2K. 

As for the actual game it's kinda meh, compared to the previous Bioshock's a lot of gameplay stuff is removed, or simplified for no reason. The weapon wheel is gone, you can now only have two weapons at once. The weapon upgrades are now just purchases in the vending machines, same for the powers upgrades. The amount of gear is lowered to only four. You can no longer carry mana and health packs. Which all seems a bit necessary as those were simple things that made combat and exploration more fun. Now they do appear in the DLC in some for which makes it even weirder that they are not in the main game. The new tear mechanic is very simple and after it is introduced it does not change much, just press x to chose if you want some cover, health, weapons, or ally. There are also the new skyhooks that allow you to quickly move around and take out enemies which is pretty fun. If you get all the DLC you get some gear and upgrades at the start, which is pretty good so you might not care for the gear you find in game later. The Burial at Sea DLC changes gameplay quite a bit, Episode 1 is much closer to the gameplay of the first two games, and Episode 2 is a stealth game. Makes you really wish that the entire games has such variety.

The story is OK.
The companion, Elizabeth, is awesome, she doesn't feel like a drag you have to carry thru the game, and the interactions between Booker and her are quite fun. 
The story is pretty good but it relies a bit too much on long cutscenes or "gameplay" that is just you holding forward without being able to do much. There are only three choices and unlike in the previous Bioshock's, they do not matter at all, everyone gets the same ending no matter what. From what i can tell two of the choices only affect physical appearance. 
There are some inconsistencies in the gameplay sections and the cutscenes, a couple of times in my play thru the characters would talk about something and the completely forget they talked it in the cutscene.
The main game's story is not connected to the previous games, there are a couple of mentions here and there but for the most part it is not necessary to play the first two games, the Burial at Sea DLC however ties this game into the the previous games, and is a must if you want the full story.

Overall if you liked the first two Bioshock games, while this one might be a bit disappointing, it is still a good time.

[h3]Hocus-Pocus Mumbo-Jumbo[/h3]
Perceiving this game with abundant seriousness as some fans and haters do is like taking Verhoeven's movies at face value. From my perspective, in terms of its setting and narrative, Infinite falls under the pulp category, akin to adventure movies from the middle of the 20th century. It sure contains the same exceeding amount of racism, reproduced to be deconstructed in the spirit of our era and, of course, presented from a completely different angle, mocking and poetic in equal measures.

The first and last puzzle, which insulted everyone's intelligence, is an irrelevant meme at this point. But looks like it still stings, causing a divide in the masses. Although, I'd be a huge snob if I actually held it against the game and not its fanboys. Who resort to praising it for showing portals as well as a bunch of flying buildings and then having quantum physics mentioned briefly. Instead of magic, it's particles! Referencing ideas isn't the same as implementing or exploring them. The claim lacks a follow-through.

The science of it all remains a hocus-pocus mumbo-jumbo. It's fine, but the predicament reflects on the world we live in today, where merely stating that physics is good because it lets us see the world beyond our observational capabilities wows people with boldness. Yet, despite being used as a carte blanche for pseudo-intellectual swagger, it's a good message, considering all the anti-vaxxers and flat-earthers skulking around. Alas, it isn't profound or delivered in any kind of mind-blowing way by a long mile.

[h3]Artistry[/h3]
Let's describe something that describes itself. Stylistically, compared to older instalments, it's Baroque vs. Christian cheese all the way. Everything's baked-in, petrified, from lighting to geometry. The levels might as well have been pre-rendered, which is a fair price to pay for polish and gorgeous sights. The architecture is monumental! The city is blooming with striking colours, industrial hellscapes have their factory pipes smoking like guns, and the juxtaposition of luxury and poverty jumps you.

[h3]Zack Comstock and the Fate of sᴉʇuɐʅʇⱯ[/h3]
[quote]"Just because this city flies doesn't mean it doesn't have its share of fools."[/quote]
Bioshock games always revolved around cults. They've shown the world that droves of gullible people don't even need tangible cult leaders and easily fall for mere virtual gobbledygook. Yet, reaching that height was an achievement on the writers' part. However multi-dimensional in his bigoted megalomania, Cumsock didn't come close to the meme status of his precursor. This is what you get when your idol is a racist coffin-dodger who grosses an entire nation out by endlessly preaching about his seed. Ew, gramps, shut it!

One of the biggest gripes I thought I'd have with the game was its heavy-handed anti-racist moral. I'm still not sure if they expected me to take it seriously or to burst into laughter due to the level of mustache-twirling overkill involved. Even the Irish aren't white enough for these brats! To top it, they jumpscare you with racist Chinese and Indian faces, which is just farcical. Yes, racist jumpscares are apparently a thing that exists. And... I loved this campy parody of religiously patriotic nonsense!

They ask you whether you want to help the freedom fighters while holding you by your suspenders over a concentration camp where prisoners wear cartoonishly striped uniforms. They don't hesitate to throw a child amputee your way. I dig the old reductio ad absurdum device, it's a plausible absurdity since real-world racism is grotesque by nature. And above all, Infinite draws a comprehensive picture of good intentions getting inevitably corrupted by allowing the bloodthirst of an overthrown dictatorship to persist in the new era.

[h3]False Shepherd and the Lamb[/h3]
[quote]"Lets not call each other that."[/quote]
Before playing, I was a bit annoyed with all the Elizabeth-worshiping fans and their "she said "multiverse", she's my waifu now", but at the end of the day, she isn't a vehicle for some virtue signaling but a well-written and exceptionally well-animated person - lively, hopeful, and her facial expressions are priceless. Dewitt and Liza share the best story beats and engage in enjoyable banter during which he doesn't act like he's Liza's daddy and she ain't no sissy herself. For one, you don't have to protect her and she's actually indispensable in and out of combat.

He's an ex-military man, a slayer of the working class in an infinite amount of worlds, and its hero in another infinity. It isn't a question of whether he is a murderer, because of course he is! The past tortures him, and not because he killed people, but because he killed the wrong people. The game doesn't make a wet blanket out of Liza either, touching these subjects in a brief, yet meaningful way. Until it seizes to be an option, she throws to the side her own PTSD and the heavy burden of responsibility her powers infer for the greater good. Respectable.

[h3]"There's survival... and there's finding pleasure in the act."[/h3]
A Bioshocker in me squirmed at first since it doesn't play like a Bioshock game. Wouldn't even call it a streamlined version. The maps are linear, the variety is lacking, and the 2-weapon carrying limit is stupid. Hell, even the audio logs are shorter than ever! It's barely a looter-shooter, more like a shooter with light elements of limited, yet rewarding loot-incentivized exploration. But I quickly forgave it for not being an immersive sim and a true successor.

Because what remains is a tight, high-feedback arena shooter. Although you now have a regenerating energy shield, on Hard, the game baptized me in Kool-Aid more often than its predecessors did. No stimpack on a hotkey to keep you going forever, just Liza's inconsistent handouts and what you find on the battlefield. Enemies aren't bullet sponges, but they produce copious amounts of damage, so getting distracted often means certain death. Their roster isn't that diverse, but where else could you witness a mecha Washington from a parallel dimension spinning a hurdy-gurdy minigun, huh?

The game could use extended environmental interactivity, and although sliding on rails and hanging on hooks was kinda fun for a while, the feature is underused. It all comes to abusing corners and the high ground, especially since the most Bioshock trait of them all, extremely sluggish movement, was carefully preserved for some reason. Killing egomaniacs is another distinctive, and this time more positive, property of the series. As always, you'll have to wade through their theme parks to have the gratification of putting them down for good. One of them even tried to give me a job. The audacity!!!

All weapons are fantastic and the meaty gunplay makes said killing fun. The game incentivizes weapon juggling by curbing your ammo capacity, but I didn't have to switch often anyway, it isn't exactly Halo. I liked blasting so much that I even enjoyed the shooting gallery mini-games at the beginning! Not as much when I had to repeat them after closing the game in a hurry. The checkpoints are weird and redoing exploration sucks. Finally, there are upgrades and equipment, but they're nothing special. When it came to Plasmids, or Vigors, I almost never used anything but the lovely head-popping lightning.

[h3]End[/h3]
I enjoyed Infinite as a creative action flick, which narrative doesn't provide any kind of subtlety, replacing it with heartfelt violence and camp. Although, good writing doesn't have to be subtle or sophisticated. To devise something over the top, emotional, and so transparent that not even the densest of dimwits could possibly miss the point is a feat of its own. The story is beautiful and touching, yet even if it was crap, disregarding the gratifying action would be silly.

I've never once replayed a story-based game, BioShock Infinite gets to be my first. The fact that I caught myself reminiscing about the game 5 years after my first playthrough just shows how much of an impact this game still has on me. That being said, this is definitely a long overdue review.

BioShock Infinite has a storyline that isn't like any other. The plot twist turned out to be so wild that there is absolutely no way one would see it coming. I remember the chills up my spine watching the final moments unfold for the first time. The best thing about the insane plot twist is that the game manages to make it make perfect sense. It's no secret that the BioShock series is known for its unexpected plot twists, but Infinite was the one that rendered me the most speechless.

Moving on to Elizabeth, she is hands down the best deuteragonist/side character I've seen in any of the games that I've played. She doesn't feel like a hassle or an AI but an actual sidekick and companion. She reacts and interacts with the environment, mostly stays out of the way during combat and knows how to take care of herself so you don't have to be putting up a fight with enemies while stressing about protecting her. She shows up exactly when she needs to in order to provide you with health and ammo and without spoiling, she also helps out with combat via different means, all despite her distance from you. Aside from her outstanding mechanics, Elizabeth just strikes me as an overall charismatic and easily likeable character from the get-go.

Other than that, I do feel that Booker's movements need improvement. The lowered sensitivity when switched to running and ADS was something that annoyed me so much and had almost gotten me killed numerous times.

In light of all that praise, it's pretty obvious that BioShock Infinite (or the series as a whole really) is one of my favourite games ever. Even though sadly, I've heard Ken Levine won't be involved in the next BioShock game, I'm still excited to see what more the series has to offer and I hope it somehow ties in and lives up to its legendary predecessors.

[b][i]Please note: Since the recent "Quality of Life" update that adds a 2K launcher to the game, the SteamOS/Linux native version no longer launches. There is a blog post on [url=https://www.gamingonlinux.com/2022/09/various-bioshock-games-get-a-2k-launcher-calling-it-a-quality-of-life-update/]Gaming on Linux[/url] that notes the steps needed for using Proton as a workaround[/i][/b]

I just finished this game 10 minutes ago as of writing this review and like... what the f*ck?

Ironically, restricting the weapon carrying capacity to two of them means that I default to the same two weapons and my mid to long range focus makes vigors relatively useless and the constant reminders to use them quite annoying. The gameplay is more reminiscent of Halo than Bioshock. An element that is exacerbated by the fact that the dynamic between Booker and Elizabeth is reminiscent of the relationship between Cortana and Master Chief despite this being inconsistent with Elizabeth's established backstory. The first person perspective is wasted on a Booker who talks far too much in first person to effectively serve as a self-insert character, which is the benefit of the first person perspective. The game could have improved this aspect by having Booker do most of his talking in third person cutscenes, much like Halo, or by simply making the game an over the shoulder third person shooter reminiscent of The Last of Us. The moral choice mechanic is completely squandered as the player has had no input in any of the decisions that are designed to shape the player's perception of Booker, e.g. his role in Wounded Knee and the choices the character makes have neither immediate in-game benefits nor long term impact on the story. If you're going to opt for this course making the game third person would make Booker more sympathetic. If the point is that you're not supposed to sympathize with the character then he shouldn't be the player character. The philosophy of Columbia is considerably shallower and less compelling than that of Rapture. Criticizing American exceptionalism is hardly an original stance in comparison with Rapture's critique of Randian philosophy. The impression this game gives is that more thought went into the multi-verse aspect of the game, which is still poorly thought out and opens quite a few plot holes. Exploration is considerably less rewarding in this game than it was in previous entries and resource management is considerably less important in this game than it was in the aforementioned previous entries, especially considering Elizabeth's constant provision of ammo whenever the player begins to run short. This is also compounded by the removal of health kits as a manageable resource in this title. Even on the highest difficulty I have yet to be at a loss for any resource, a challenge I encountered regularly in previous titles.

The characters of Booker and Elizabeth are excellent and the way their dynamic evolves across the game is sublime. Bioshock 1 on the other hand, I'll happily throw down with some Big Daddies with no assistance.

More or less everything I liked about the first two Bioshock games is gone. Every step forward demands two steps back. I also feel that the game itself has been ground down to pander to the lowest of our denominators. Reduce and simplify everything, and then dress it up with a pretentious wet fart of a story to grant the illusion of depth. Press F to interact and watch the game play itself for you. Now everyone can partake in the video gamings! 

Biochock 1 and 2 gave us a large arsenal of varied and unique weapons, Infinite takes all that away in place of a more generic- or "modern" loadout with what feels like a half dozen reskins of an assault rifle. The developers must have thought 10 or so weapons was simply too much fun, so now you can only carry two at once. Only having two weapons at any given time makes a nightmare for balancing and upgrading, when all upgrading is specific to each individual weapon.

Plasmids, particularly telekenesis, scout, and security command, are replaced with Vigors. The vast majority of said Vigors are variations of a stun spell, with its only variables being damage, cost, and visual flair. 
I simply can not understand why you would take something that worked so well in the previous game, and then reduce it to "press mouse button 2 to drain blue bar and stun enemy for an arbitrary amount of time". No longer can I warp behind enemy lines, or use telekenesis to build small forts and cover. Instead, if I press F to interact when the game occasionally lets me, I might be given the option of an ammo crate or some med kits. 

Speaking of, the developers must have thought that having to manage med kits and mana kits on the fly was too demanding of a process for the average gamer, so now you are simply given a ridiculous amount of health and mana, and have to scout the map for kits. Oh, and occasionally the vapid companion, Elizabeth, will randomly toss you health and ammo, which you again have to "press F to interact" to receive. 

Lastly, the story and world of Bioshock was, at least to me, completely ruined. Bioshock 1 and 2 presented the dystopia of Rapture. It drew some analogies to real life anarcho capitalism and what effects, positive or negative, that it might have on a society. Aside from the opening of Bioshock 1, it was never really in your face either, just an interesting back drop to the ongoing plot. I should also note that the world of Bioshock 1 and 2 never really deviated that far from science fiction, disregarding the origin of ADAM. Bioshock Infinite, on the other hand, becomes full blown, goofy fantasy. Columbia is a city far up in the sky that is made possible with QUANTUM SUSPENSION. In other words, the world is justified through Quantum Woo, and prays the player pays no more mind to it. It is patently ridiculous and is made even more so when the game is supposed to take place in an alternate-history 1912 America. 
Because it is a Bioshock sequel, it must obviously have some social commentary to boot, right? What social issue/system/structure would plausibly be relevant in a bland first person shooter set in a superscience utopia of a floating sky city? Why, Racism, of course! 
And to make it more unfortunate, it never goes any deeper than: Evil christian whitey did the oppression on the colored peoples!
It does not make much sense and it gets increasingly more silly as you play. The developers must have noticed this too, as the RACISM undertone gets dropped completely about halfway through the story, replaced with "ideological dogma bad". At the end of the day, none of your choices mattered, either, because Bioshock Infinite ends up being about the "Many Worlds Theory". Yes, it is indeed one of those games. At no point does the game deeply explore neither racism, corruption, many worlds, quantum science or even physics on its own, as these concepts only exist to veil a nonsensical and bland plot, and a profoundly inept story. 

If you like to press F to interact with video game, press mouse 1 to do the shootie, and press mouse 2 to do the magic gaming, Bioshock Infinite is the right choice for you (not that the combat itself ever gets good). And do not worry, for if you ever get distracted from juggling more than 1 thought at once in your head, game will do the key jangle with hot damsel in distress cutie, or EPIC combat music that plays every time you enter a fight. And if you ever start thinking that this game is not what its hyped up to be, we will provide you with mind-boggling, nigh-hypnotizing phrases like QUANTUM, PERPETUAL, INFINITE. 
What a fucking tragic joke of a game to end the franchise on.

Ah, don't you just love games that have overt political messaging? Gameplay is good, but the game couldn't just shut up and stop insulting and mocking american history and tradition. I'm tired of entertainment pulling me out of immersion just to slap me around and call me a bigot.

To even make the game playable, you have to extensively edit your .ini files, then reboot the game and struggle past its slow as molasses main menu repeatedly to see if your changes worked.

The following things are broken by default;

1. Mouse sensitivity. There is absolutely no way to get a value that both feels good and is fundamentally stable with the slider provided. You must set a numerical value in your configuration files, as well as lock both the minimum and maximum values to that same value in order for it not to fuck up when you change other settings, or when you sprint, or when you aim down sights. Oh, by the way, no matter what you do, your sensitivity is drastically lowered when sprinting, and does not scale accordingly to your FOV change when zoomed with any weapon. Not only is it broken, but it's designed to feel terrible.
2. Field of View. The max field of view you can set is about 80 by default. 80 FOV, for a first person shooter from 2013. Wow. Thankfully you can bump this up by using the same exact method you used to fix you mouse. Oh yeah, it also doesn't scale for widescreen properly, so you have to alter yet another thingamabob in the .ini files. A 2013 game without native widescreen support. Wow.
3. There is aim assistance... for mouse users. Which, you guessed it, cannot be disabled without editing the game's files and setting them to read-only. Holy. ♥♥♥♥.
4. There are 5-6 logo screens when you open the game that you can only sometimes skip with rampant button mashing. With the power of .ini, you can thankfully delete all but one of these, the AMD logo. The AMD logo is unaffected by your game volume and will deafen you. Really just insult to injury when you're trying to configure this mess.

Anyway, after an hour and a half, I finally made it to the game! Without further ado, let's list what went right and what what wrong.

[h1]The Good[/h1]
• Columbia is a very pretty environment.
• Setpieces and scenery change just enough to keep you distracted with shock and awe throughout so you don't pay attention to the game's downfalls.
• Some of the special enemies' functionalities are interesting. Crow guys are cool. Handymen being able to shock the rails you're swinging from is cool. I don't know what firemen do but they talk funny so I like when they pop up.
• The rails you can swing around from are pretty fun and prevent complete combat stagnation, despite their clunkiness.
• The guns themselves feel decent enough to shoot.

[h2]The Bad[/h2]
• You only get two guns. It isn't even a proper gameplay limitation since arenas are littered with extra ones, and you get effectively infinite ammo for anything you desire since it's so cheap. It just makes things dissatisfying because of how long it takes to switch to a weapon on the floor if you /happen/ to need it for a particular bossfight or scripted encounter that exhausts your resources. You typically won't need to switch throughout the brunt of the game, though. None of the weapons have a specialized role, and it doesn't matter what you pick for general use since the DPS is more or less homogenized across the board. The gameplay would be exponentially better if you could hold more guns and each gun served a specialized purpose, but resources were rationed out in a handcrafted way. You know, like the other games in the series.
• You have regenerating heal- I mean shield. Combat encounters boil down to ducking behind cover until it regenerates. Maybe if the inputs weren't so awful you could run and gun, but I don't think that's how it's designed. This fundamentally isn't a retro shooter where your raw reaction and aim matter, nor is it an im-sim where you have to think ahead about how to approach encounters. The way everything is structured and the behaviors of the enemies do not allow for anything remotely approaching those. This is Call of Duty with a different coat of paint.
• Unlike Plasmids, Vigors play a very minor role in the combat. It's nice to have them, sure, but most encounters are easily resolved by popping heads, and since you can't manually refill your salts (unless Elizabeth tossing you some during larger fights  counts), you aren't incentivized to experiment. On a regular basis, I saw no reason to do anything except hack machines, spam crows, and charge toward folks to stun them. There's a single sniper section, and a single defense section where the bullet absorbing one helps.
• Instead of any manner of ammo/health/mana/money/resource management, you are literally handed everything you need constantly. Took a few too many hits? Here you go buddy, health kit. Didn't buff your salt pool or ration out your salts for this fight? Doesn't matter, here's a potion. Blew all your money on an upgrade for a weapon you haven't found in 20 minutes? Doesn't matter, Elizabeth just pulled 400 coins from her ass. Need lockpicks to open this door? Nah don't scavenge around for them, they're right in front of your face.
• If the extremely dull combat wasn't already insulting enough, there is no fail state. That's right, you get INFINITE lives! And you can't disable this feature like in other Bioshock games! Yay!

Final verdict? 7/10 walking simulator, 4/10 FPS, 0/10 Bioshock. Literally no point in playing it yourself, there isn't even the illusion of player agency. Watch a glitchless speedrun or something, same difference if you just wanted to absorb the "story", since that's all there really is to do. I guess that fits its deterministic outlook? Who cares.

Bioshock Infinite is very different compared to the earlier games in the franchise due to a more story rich experience. 
The claustrophobic and horrifying realization of being stuck in a deeper and darker atmosphere deep under the sea "Rapture" truly makes the player feel uneasy and is now replaced by fear of hights due to the game taking place in a bright floating city in the clouds "Columbia".
(There are DLC for the game that puts you back in the nostalgic city of Rapture which I highly recommend).
Infinite clearly focuses on the action rather than survival-horror and it clearly shows, but it's not a bad thing. This fits the games narrative as this is a story (no spoilers) of a man named Booker DeWitt trying to reach and rescue a woman from the floating city to clear his debt, but for them to leave the city, they have to fight their way through many obsticles along the way such as full on civil war if they ever wish to get back to the surface, back to freedom.

Side Note: If you are looking to 100% this game (DLC included) you're gonna have a bad time. All the campaigns are quite easy to finish even on 1999 Mode for an experienced Bioshock player, but when it comes to the Blue Ribbon Challenges (Survive waves of enemies and successfully complete all of the ribbons on every mission, oh man... This is where the game becomes you new full time job. 

Personal Rating: 7.2/10

All the mechanics and the new messy launcher scandal aside, Do you know what I find interesting (and like) about this game?

Despite its extremely obvious political nature and being set in a literal Confederate-loving White Supremacist Sky Kingdom, this game never felt preachy about a particular agenda and instead decided to tell its own story set in a fictional setting rather than being a hit piece on marginal political groups that the devs didn’t like.

Instead, the game manages to create a setting that is dynamic and genuine, where people get tossed around depending on the political climate like dolls, and you are to witness it firsthand in a tremendously compelling and in-depth narrative that only a few games managed to pull off (but that is given that you have the time to collect all the in-game collectible story pieces which, to be honest, kinda sucks for most people but I didn’t mind it that much).

I also love that there is no “good faction” to align yourself within the game, the first half was showing you how terrible and oppressive the regime in Columbia was and how it needed to be overthrown by the rebels. And then the game proceeds to spend the other half of the game showing how rebels’ concept of justice is simply mindless genocide under the pretext of retaliation, which draws uncomfortable parallels to real-life events and cleverly deconstructs the notions surrounding the romantic idea of a popular revolution against an oppressive system (although the DLC kind of ruined this part with a plot twist, but I won't spoil it for you.)

To me, Bioshock Infinite, like Bioshock 1 &2, is a political game done right and truly improves on the original, and although I would love to see more Bioshock titles, I am too afraid to ask for it, because of the possibility of some writer turning it into a political murder fantasy rather than meaningful commentary unlike all original Bioshock games.
