[h1] BioShock Infinite [/h1]

As an adolescent growing up in 2013, BioShock Infinite made a remarkable impression on me as a young boy. At release, the game was met with glowing responses from both critics and fans alike praising the game for its awe-inspiring depiction of Columbia, and its ability to tell a beautiful and emotionally gripping story of Booker and Elizabeth, the likes of which we had never seen before in a First Person Shooter game. To put it simply, BioShock Infinite was unprecedented. But fast forward almost ten years later, and the conversations surrounding this game couldn't be any more opposite. Criticized by fans in hindsight for its regressions in gameplay and convoluted story elements that introduced unnecessary plot holes into an otherwise beautiful narrative. time had not been kind to this once adoring gem. As for me, somebody who has recently played and finished the game almost ten years later, BioShock Infinite, despite its numerous shortcomings and imperfections, is still a game I hold very dearly in my heart. For all of its flaws, I utterly cannot bring myself to dislike it or even see it in an unfavorable light. Since this game deserves nothing less than my full attention, this is going to be a lengthy review. 

[b] The Positives [/b] ▼

[b] 1. Columbia Is Breathtaking [/b]
Seeing the flying city of Columbia for the first time is the closest anyone will ever come to having a religious experience playing a video game. And I mean it. Columbia might be the complete antithesis of Rapture but it is every bit as beautiful and creative as one could imagine. Roaming its patriotic halls and experiencing the history and culture was one of the great joys I had exploring this incredible world. 

[b] 2. Elizabeth [/b]
Amidst the breathtaking grandeur of Columbia, her beauty stood unparallel. Bring us the girl and wipe away the debt, this is Elizabeth's story as much as it is about Booker's. Her emotional journey in search of freedom along with Booker's arc for redemption is the glue that holds the entire experience together, and Irrational Games couldn't have done a more fantastic job with their lead characters. As if I haven't made it abundantly clear enough, I love Elizabeth. She's gorgeous, intelligent, capable, and compassionate, and the technical accomplishments that were required to bring her to life were nothing short of a miracle. Aside from being the emotional crux of the narrative, Elizabeth also proves to be an invaluable ally to Booker; She can open tears and bring in helps to aid during combat, decipher codes and open lock doors, and throw important consumables when the player is running low. Her presence in the game simply cannot be overstated, and she is without a doubt the most important element of the game and BioShock Infinite's greatest achievement. 

[b] 3. Incredible Acting Performances [/b]
When you're up against the likes of Troy Baker, Jennifer Hale, and Oliver Vaquer, it's going to take a great deal of talent to be the stand-out star who steals the show, but Courtnee Draper did it flawlessly. It's not an exaggeration to say that the success of BioShock Infinite rested heavily upon her shoulders. If she failed, the game failed. It's as simple as that. Now don't get me wrong, every vocal performance in this game is easily worth its weight in gold, but what Courtnee, who is the voice actress of Elizabeth, was able to do in terms of bringing her character to life is something that was simply extraordinary. Elizabeth is the very heart and soul of the game, and Courtnee was able to capture every aspect and nuance of her personality perfectly and did the character justice in subtle ways I don't think many actresses could with all due respect. In the end, I had nothing but praise for the entire cast of BioShock Infinite, and it was their incredible commitment to their roles that breathed life into the story. 

[b] 4. The Music Is Amazing [/b] 
I might catch flack for saying this, but BioShock Infinite might be my favorite score of the entire series. I mean, there's a reason why it won the best soundtrack of the year at the BAFTA. I didn't fall in love with every score that was written, but when I do, I fall hard. Frankly, it's some of the most unique and moving pieces of music that I've ever come across, and when looked through the emotional context of the story, it only gets better. 

[b] 5. Combat Feels Fun To Play [/b] 
It's not perfect, but it's a far cry from the "Call of Duty knockoff" that so many disgruntled fans love to accuse it of being. It's not as slow-paced and methodical as the previous two games were but in my opinion, that definitely doesn't make it automatically inferior or bad by default. The combat is high octane due to the introduction of the skyline, there are more enemies to populate the more spacious maps, and the flow of combat is fast-paced. Combine that with the multitudes of weapons and vigors that you come across as well as tears that you could use from Elizabeth, and the experience couldn't be any more distinctive than your average first-person shooter. 

[b] The Negatives [/b] ▼

• Level designs are too linear and narrowed when compared to their predecessor
• Time traveling, trans-dimensional travel, and the multi-world theory were handled poorly leading to many plot holes, time paradoxes, and unresolved questions within the story
• A lack of meaningful choices that lead to different outcomes
• Burial At Sea Episode 1 & Episode 2 are suicides in the forms of narratives and characters for Bioshock and Bioshock Infinite 
• The Vox Populi and Daisy Fitzroy didn't have enough screen time to fully flesh out their side of the story
• The visual differences when upgrading weapons are no longer present
• Carrying weapons is now limited to only two
• Tears aren't quite as strategic and impactful as they were intended to be
• Most of the gears you get are mediocre, boring, and sometimes even pointless
• Various other subtle storytelling tools and gameplay elements have regressed such as vigors not being interwoven into the world as seamlessly as plasmids, and enemies not being as interesting as splicers in terms of personality. 
• Vigors play much less of a role in how you explore the world than before
• Some vigors feel too similar to one another in terms of what they do such as Murder of Crows, Bucking Bronco, and Shock Jokey.

Before I move on to my final thoughts, I'd like to take this opportunity to recommend some very useful mods which not only improve how the game performs and feels but also how it looks as well. In my eyes, these mods are indispensable and essential in optimizing your experience, and I'd strongly suggest that you download them before playing the game. Furthermore, BioShock Infinite is an incredibly complex game to talk about, and one where no Steam review could ever do justice to the brilliance and flaws that it possesses. As a result, I'd like to also recommend some high-quality reviews (spoiler alert) for those who are interested in more in-depth discussions and analysis.

[b] In Summary [/b] ⚠

There is still so much I want to share, and my mind is overrun with thoughts. Ultimately, if I have to choose a message to end this review on, it's this: I love BioShock Infinite. Regardless of how much I may criticize it for not living up to its true potential, it's undeniable just how much I adore this game. Columbia, Booker, and finally Elizabeth - I won't ever forget you.

This was my first time playing the Bioshock games. I'm not usually a person who plays first person shooters, but I wanted to give this game a chance after hearing about it for years.

Coming from Bioshock 1 & 2, I was shocked over how different this game was, and it was a welcome change. The gloomy, foreboding feeling of the underwater city of Rapture was replaced with beautiful, hopeful city of the sky, Columbia, and exploring the different areas was euphoric to me, especially when I had a chance to look around and not get shot at.

I can't believe this game is almost 10 years old - it's so stunning. The game play is incredibly fun, and the lore - oh, the lore! - is just brilliant and intricate.

I loved Columbia so much more than I loved Rapture, even when it was at its worst. And I appreciated them including all the race issues (including how Irish and Chinese people were treated), although there were definite times when being able to shoot a racist t*** in the face would have been appreciated.

My only big issues with the game were a lack of a manual save, like the first 2 games had, and only being able to carry 2 weapons at once. They rectified the gun issue with the DLC, but I would like to have been able to do that in the actual main game. The manual save issue was the biggest for me - at one point, I explored an entire area for 45 min, only to have to close my game to go somewhere and I had to start all over. That was incredibly frustrating for me.

Overall, this is now one of my favorite games. I can't believe I'm saying that about an FPS. But it's an incredible game and I highly recommend it to all gamers.

The title Bioshock certainly invokes, for me, thoughts about the first game as the spiritual successor to the excellent System Shock 2. Now, so that I don't come across as being extremely unfair here, I never really thought about this game within the context of System shock 2, nor even the first bio shock. However, I did have expectations.

And those expectations were sadly not met. What we have here is a game that, for whatever reason, has a lot of narrative focus that doesn't translate into an actually interesting game to play. Sure, it's worth exploring some of the environments since they are pretty well realized. Hard to argue against the level of graphical and sound design on display here.

But none of it translated into a fun game to play. The combat loop in this game feels exceedingly generic and the gimmicks are lifted straight out of the better preceding entries in the series. Gone are the open environments that allow you to get immersed into the setting and gone is the feeling that the game really cares about immersion at all. It has a story to tell gosh darn it and you better do as it says so it can move the plot(?) along.

I do have a good example that can cut through all of this though, to illustrate just what kind of game this is. When you rummage through trash cans, they always only have 3 slots for whatever items. When you inspect a fallen foe, they also only have 3 slots for anything they're carrying, and so on. Now, some may call this streamlining, but I just call it a half-assed carry over from when the series gave incentives to actually check every object rather than it becoming a final-fight-like turkey in the trashcan for health nonsense.

And this is coming from a huge final fight fan, I love me some yummy trash turkey, but in a *shock game it feels really jarring.

The other aspect that is apparent is that the design of the gameplay is centered on arena set pieces (which are easily identifiable by the railings that you can use to move around in what can only be described as half-baked idea done as quickly as possible so as to be basically meaningless.) This works great in games that have a solid combat loop, but this game does not. The combat isn't eye-gouging bad by any means, but it's simply not good enough to justify basically ditching what made the *shock series what it was. It does work in favor of pushing you along from set piece to set piece so the game can show you its damn plot.

And oh boy what a plot. It certainly has some characters, and events happen. They really do. And then, there's also an ending, which is strange, but since the plot kind of prides itself in being strange from the get-go, it doesn't get any bonus points for being this predictable.

Watch the damn game on youtube, it's cheaper and it accomplishes what the developers wanted since there's very little actually playing the game will bring you compared to watching someone else play it, or even a montage of the first person cutscenes.

This game was so much fun to play through, Columbia is a very bright and beautiful setting. The game play is fun and exciting, riding on rails and pouncing on my enemies was awesome, and the most of the vigors were very useful and the game did a good job at making you balance out what you used. As for the gun play, you can only hold two weapons at a time so it's best to pick what best suits your play style. I went with the sniper rifle and shotgun most of the time because I liked to pick off enemies from a distance while having a powerful close range weapon to take down anyone who got too close to me. Elizabeth, the girl who you spend most of the game with is very helpful with getting you ammo, salts(ammo for vigors), health, and money. Plus she can spawn in items or allies to help you in a battle. The main story has an excellent plot that does take some thinking to understand what is happening, but it is really interesting to learn about.

For the dlc, in my opinion it's still good but not as good as the main story, episode 1 of Burial at Sea feels not as fun as the main story since there isn't many rails for you to ride on. Episode 2 changes up the game play with making you focus on stealth first and only using combat as a last resort. I wasn't overly fancy about going all stealthy instead of fighting my enemies head on, but it paid off to have patience and not take serious amounts of damage. The story of episode 2 is better than what episode 1 starts with as it connects with the first bioshock in a satisfying way. 

Performance with the game ran pretty good for the most part. The game had it's moments where the frame rate would drop when looking at certain actions from Elizabeth or a fireplace burning, or whenever I booted up the game and started from my last save. To be fair I do not have the greatest hardware and the frame rate never dropped during important moments of game play.

Overall the game is fantastic and in my opinion is better than the original Bioshock. If your a fan of the original games then I highly recommend you give this game a try.
Beautiful story & world environment. Seeing Columbia for the first time always puts a tear in my eye. If you do buy this game PLEASE do not spoil it for yourself.

Bioshock Infinite has made a lot of mistakes. The creative choices that were made for this game scream "compromise" and the gameplay of this game compared to the games that take place in Rapture, scream "watered-down shooter."

Although Bioshock is a shooter, the first 2 entries didn't seem to be trying to feel like "combat-shooters." They felt like adventure games, explorations games, that just happened to have a first person shooter as their basis for gameplay. 

Infinite throws out what made the first 2 games special in my opinion, and it's a shame because Columbia had potential. 

The Setting- Columbia is an insane paradox, because it manages to look objectively pretty and interesting, yet is an incredibly boring, bloom-filled blur. I think part of the problem (and this is linked to gameplay) is that you are moving through the city so fast while utilizing the skyhook. In addition, each stage of the city, is spaced out and there's quite a bit of emptiness. 

What propelled BS1 and 2, was the setting of Rapture and the stories it created just by it's existence alone. Rapture was a gateway that led into the introduction of genuinely interesting characters shaped by it. 

Columbia feels like a setting. And that's it. It doesn't feel like the setting has shaped any of the actual characters, it feels like the plot and the setting are both weak, and could've only been worthwhile if they worked off each other. 

Gameplay/Combat- Infinite's combat is weak and unsatisfying- though I will admit the first time I smashed open an officer's head with the skyhook, was disturbingly delightful. The problem is, any satisfaction from the combat is fleeting and will not last you longer than halfway through the game. BS1 & 2 had a great balance of plasmids feeling good to use, and an environment that worked off them. Additionally, plasmids could be upgraded and combined in unique ways. It felt very classic among traditional FPS mechanics. 

I don't like going on tangents so I'm just going to say- Bioshock Infinite won't satisfy COD fans, and it sure as hell won't satisfy Bioshock fans. But something that needs to be understood is that Infinite is not a bad game, nothing about it is overtly offensive. It's just boring. It really is. 

6/10- Buy if you're craving a shooter that you don't have to think about while playing.

I personally think this game is probably one of my all time favorites. The story is way different than almost any other game but it is still done well. The characters feel like people who in this context could actually exist realistically. The game play doesn't feel unbalanced with one weapon shining above that you must need to play the game. My only complaint is the ending. One common one you'll hear is how it only has one despite it's theme. Though for me it was the fact that I didn't get it until after I searched it up but that could just be a me problem. The game's DLCs: Burial at Sea Episode 1 and 2 have also got to be some of the best DLCs in a lot of games that if it was somehow as long as the original could compete with how good it is. It does really require you to play the first one which you really should've done if you are playing this game but it fills in a lot of the story and even has a very great ending. I would say that Episode 2 is better than Episode 1 but that is my opinion. In conclusion, I think it is a great game that is worth its weight in gold and combined with Burial At Sea could also become one of your favorite games.

This is the first Bioshock game I’ve played and every minute of it had me captivated in its world. The art direction for this game is incredible it looks fantastic and runs well on low end tech. the 1912 aesthetic with the mix of steampunk and WW1, I really like it helps the game separate itself from the 1960s Bioshock 1 & 2 games. Sure it’s more of an arcade shooter than survival horror which some people might not like compared to 1 & 2. I don’t mind it tbh. One of few complaints is you need to own the dlc if you want to change your gear in the menu, otherwise if you want to play the game by maximizing your stats you have to keep track of what you have equipped and what you want and hope you don’t equip gear you don’t want.  Other than that good game. The game is about 7ish hours but depends if you look for the secrete areas or explore the optional environments which can reward you with cash, guns, and upgrades to health, vigor, and shield.

The game is beautiful and the story is great. I really loved the world building and conversations npcs had when you walked by them, and the architecture and map layout. The gameplay was a lot better than the first two as well, less clunky and honestly, dare I say, I liked the vigors better than the plasmids. The only thing that was annoying in combat was that you only could hold two weapons, but in the end it didn't really bother me because I mainly just used the shotgun anyway. 

It can be played without having played the other two, but you should play the other two Bioshocks BEFORE you play the DLC. 

Why don't I recommend? The game became unplayable to me because of an error of the 2k launcher. I tried every fix by scouring the internet, and it wasn't any hardware or software issue on my end. I ended up seeing a review here to launch the game in the steamapps folder (Steamapps-->common-->bioshock infinite-->binaries-->win32-->Bioshock infinite application) was the ONLY way to launch the game. This was AFTER I made it through the middle of the game (finktown) with ZERO issues launching through Steam until it decided it wouldn't launch anymore because of a dx error. 

I was able to finish the game and I really did enjoy it. The DLC is super buggy and unplayable though, like getting stuck in airlocks, elizabeth getting stuck and not triggering events, etc. 

I recommend playing this game if you get it really on super sale with like the bundle of all games + DLC.

Its not a very bad game but its by far the weakest one of the 3 Bioshock. If you expect the same scary nice looking underwater city of Rapture and the same kind of battle you will be deceive. They simply change EVERYTHING, from scary hell to sweet paradise. The only thing they keep the same is the story plot, very lazy decision and they found a very lazy way to explain it at the end. I was expecting the same impressive underwater city ambience (not already over use flying city), level up with adam (not money) and some new lore about character of the Bioshock 1 and 2 games. I wish they have done the opposite, keep what people love (scary underwater city, little sister hard decision, plasmid, adam, character and found a new interesting story. ) There is also no save, just overwrite checkpoint and they are sometime impressively far. 

DlC are not well design.
Very far checkpoint in these 2 DLC  and no save again. I did get a lot of bug. getting stuck, enable to move or get out. Door bug on opening animation ON BOTH SIDE and stay shut forever. Keep in mind, there is no save... or even reload XD, so you need to quit the game and reload 2k account Bulls***, reload the dlc content, reload your last checkpoint and loot again every single place you have done in the last hour or fight 15 round of enemy again. Also, Elisabeth is very annoying in these 2 DLC. She always block your path, stay in doorway, block your hiding spot, you cannot loop around an enemy and melee him without having Elisabeth get in your path in Burrial of the Sea, and she save at least a dozen enemy from free falling in clitc...

Pros

+ Decent enough graphics
+ Occasional vertical mobility through skylines makes combat more interesting
+ Elizabeth as one of the most engaging videogame companions
+ A wide enough selection of Vigors (most of which you will never use)

Cons

- Shooting elements are pretty average overall, not really standing out even by standards of its time
- being forced to have a 2K launcher for an already purchased game
- Nonsensical and depressing end-game plot twists that do not provide any satisfying conclusion (the whole story is not that interesting either)
- Not very fond of the historical revisionism (yes, it is a work of fiction, but the highly exaggerated tropes and heavy emphasis on only one side of the presented conflict is quite noteworthy)
- the true ending (one that is both unnecessary and worse than the normal one) is hidden behind several DLCs

Conclusion: A fairly average (and rather overhyped) game with a few noteworthy features, dragged down by its own story that provides very little nuance, forced third party launcher and forcing you to buy several DLCs just to get the true (and even worse) ending. Would not recommend, especially when there are better shooters and better story-drive games on the market.

This is not a review about the launcher or whatever.  There's plenty of that.

A poorly written story (albeit an interesting concept) coupled with a repetitive run and gun style of game play makes for a boring experience.  No puzzles, no engaging combat, Vigors (this game's Plasmids) are mostly pointless, YOU ARE DEPRIVED OF KILLING 3 out of 4 BOSSES, Elizabeth's annoying fetch mechanic and  Elizabeth does all the cool stuff.  The combat is extremely poorly paced, not only is it boring (as stated) but then you engage in a walking simulator for about 15 minutes.  An action game doesn't need to be all action but I felt as though it was jarring.  It's nothing like the first two games and that's not always bad but in this case, it's not good.  Go play the first two instead.

Oh, the DLC:  I only played Burial at Sea.  The first episode wasn't to bad, the second episode (which is nothing but a stealth simulator) I would be better off having not done.

The only issue I have with this game is that there is a bug with keybinds in the DLC that has existed since 2013 and was never resolved, keybinds that work in the main game are bugged in the DLC and this can cause issues for some players, so beware of this. Again, main game not affected, only DLC.

(To be more specific: the "interact" button works as intended, but the "loot all" button, automatically tied to the same key, does not, as the "loot all" screen seems to reset to default keybinds every time you loot, i.e. it's bugged. Thusly, IF you have one of the default keys bound to another action, that action will be performed while in the loot screen whenever you try to "loot all" with your "interact" button. I'm fine with getting used to the default keys just for the DLC playthroughs, but this may not be the case for everyone. Buyer, beware! 

To be even more specific: here is a sample thread on steam, that also links to the 2K forums thread from 2013: https://steamcommunity.com/app/8870/discussions/0/666826251029777181/ )

I've been so conflicted to review this game here. I have hundreds of hours on it from my old Xbox 360 and truly love this title. The story, the characters, the world graphics and ambiance are all the height of video game design to me. I do a fresh playthrough, start to finish on 1999 difficulty, every year for my birthday as nostalgic tradition.

So why would I ever be conflicted to review this game? Should be one of the easiest thumbs up on steam, and it kind of is. But I truly truly TRULY loath the Mouse/Keyboard controls.

Specifically, I can't handle toggle to aim iron-sights. I hard quit CS:GO at GNM because it's apparently 'griefing' to mentioned I unbound ADS. I ONLY give FPS games a chance after learning it's a bind-able option (as it should be in every FPS). It is, in my incredibly subjective and relatively unpopular opinion, the largest of first-person sins to FORCE either Hold or Toggle sights. It MUST be adjustable.

So this gets a very bare thumbs up; and ONLY because the Voice acting, Art Design, Writing, World Building, and Gameplay (on controller) are some of the industry's best.

I was genuinely excited to run through the story mode again possibly in a night because I have the next few days off, but after the launcher and new "quality of life" updates I can't play Bioshock Infinite after having beat it on multiple accounts and consoles and completing both Clash in the Clouds and Burial at Sea. I don't need to play this game, but I loved being able to revisit it here and I'm pissed off for everyone who can't get that experience because of needless launcher and I'm assuming DRM additions. Fix this game so people can enjoy it again, this is an embarrassment to the legacy of Irrational Games as well as 2K, let alone the Bioshock franchise and it's questionable at best to sell in this barely playable state.

Ken Levine and his team, who took us on an amazing journey under the ocean in the first Bioshock, invite us to an amazing adventure above the clouds this time. We manage a character named Booker Dewitt in the game. Booker is a man in debt and asks creditors: "Bring the girl, clear the debt." With that promise, we set off for Columbia, a utopian city built on the clouds. That's enough about the story. Play the rest and see for yourself.

Graphically, bioshock did an endlessly great job. Ok, it doesn't have very realistic graphics, but it has graphics that reflect the world it is in very well. From time to time, it is impossible not to admire the landscapes that come your way.

Bioshock Infinite is a game that can be considered long enough for its type in terms of gameplay time. If you go straight, it takes around 8-10 hours, if you walk around and search for hidden things, it takes 15-20 hours. The vending machines in the first bioshocks are also in infinite. These tools are one of our biggest helpers in the game. Thanks to Vending Machines, we can improve our vigor, fill our lives, get the salt necessary for vigor and the bullets necessary for our weapons. Speaking of weapons, there are many weapons in the game.

I recommend you to play the additional packs. It was very good that Bioshock 1 was connected to the 1st game by explaining the prequel.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2867534661

To be honest, I don't really consider this a Bioshock game. It is under the franchise name though, so I was obligated to get a perfect game. That took a hellish 41.2 hours.

This game felt like a weird case of deja vu for the series: the setting, the characters, the mechanics and the story. It was nice to have a protagonist with a backstory such as Booker DeWitt. He felt like the opposite of Jack from the first game, instead of rescuing all the little girls, Booker loses his own and drinks himself to death. That is until the Lutece twins come along and set the plot in motion. The Lutece twins feel a lot like Half Life's Gman, a human with powers beyond human comprehension and the architects of fate itself.

Elizabeth is one of the best companions in a video game, period. She's insanely helpful, giving you ammo, health, salts, and the ability to open tears that have so many goodies in them. The best part is that she takes care of herself, meaning that you can just enjoy your time killing everything. Speaking of Half Life, I enjoy Elizabeth more than Alyx Vance.

Unlike Halo Infinite, Bioshock is ACTUALLY Infinite. Elizabeth and Booker have been trying to escape this time loop that keeps this series' plot replaying. Confused? Yeah me too. And remember when I said that the game felt like deja vu? That's because it is. Columbia exists in a world without Rapture, and Rapture exists in a world without Columbia. With the addition of Burial at Sea, you get to see an alternate timeline where Comstock is in Rapture and Elizabeth kills him. Shit I forgot to mention Comstock was Booker! Well in the end, everyone played their part to start the events of the first Bioshock, which leads to Bioshock 2, which had to be started when Booker got reborn as Comstock after the events at Wounded Knee and then worked with Lutece to open up parallel universes, and so on.

I know my explanation isn't the best with this series, but one of the best things about Bioshock Infinite is exploring all of the possible scenarios of how this plot unfolds, and the possibility that there is one scenario that finally breaks this cycle. This game is worth it along with the other 2 games if you want an amazing story-driven shooter.

Je vais commencer par une ligne empruntée à l'éval d'Eddy sur ce jeu, que je trouve parfaitement adaptée à l'expérience que j'ai vécu sur Bioshock Infinite : "Ce jeu contient le twist le plus célèbre de l'industrie puisqu'on croit jouer à un bon jeu jusqu'aux dernières 2-3h où on se rend compte que c'est bien nul. Bravo Ken Levine."

J'arrive sur ce jeu en ayant fraîchement terminé, et beaucoup apprécié, Bioshock 1 et 2. Arrivé sur ce Infinite, j'ai évidemment tout de suite constaté le changement de ton dans la palette graphique, car on passe d'une cité sombre et déliquescente au fond des océans à une cité steampunk dans les nuages, forcément l'ambiance s'en est ressentie en passant d'un jeu d'exploration semi-horrifique à un shooter bourrin et forcené. Pourquoi pas, mais si ça n'a pas le style d'un Bioshock, le gameplay d'un Bioshock, ou l'univers d'un Bioshock, pourquoi appeler cela Bioshock ? 

Qu'on se le dise, c'est un très, très beau jeu graphiquement, qui a je trouve plutôt bien vieilli et qui tient la dragée haute à Borderlands. Les décors sont splendides, la ville flottante est superbe, les PNJs sont parfois un peu bizarres mais en plissant les yeux, ça passe. Le gameplay remplit bien son rôle de shooter bourrin même si je trouve étrange de ne pas pouvoir porter plus de deux armes simultanément pour un jeu où on va passer 95% de son temps à flinguer tout ce qui bouge vu qu'il y a des ennemis partout, qu'on a un bouclier, et que les pouvoirs sont à peu près inutiles. Elizabeth, le compagnon féminin qui va vous accompagner pendant la quasi-totalité de l'aventure, est un personnage profondément attachant, dont l'évolution des relations avec Booker DeWitt, votre personnage principal, tout au long du jeu, est traitée avec beaucoup de délicatesse ; et l'aide qu'elle apporte en terme de gameplay est précieuse.

Et puis il y a le reste. 

Le gameplay est long et pénible. On sort, on absorbe les balles avec le boubou, pew pew, on tue le vilain, on se cache le temps que le bouclier recharge, on recommence. De temps en temps on utilise un pouvoir de stun de groupe. Puis vient la phase d'exploration où on fouille dans chaque recoin pour trouver 3 pauvres Silver Eagles, qui combinés aux 1497 autres nous permettront d'acheter l'amélioration suivante. Plus de mini-jeu, plus de hacking. On rince et on répète. Et au bout du compte, l'ennui total. Le tout renforcé par l'impossibilité de sauvegarder manuellement la partie en cours, ce qui est une gêne inutile. La philosophie est une critique de l'Exceptionalisme Américain, tout comme le 1 était une critique de l'Objectivisme et le 2 une critique du Collectivisme. Cependant, là où ces critiques dans les deux premiers opus sont faits de façon subtile, en montrant la glissade progressive opérée par, respectivement, Andrew Ryan et Sophia Lamb, jusqu'au moment où la nature humaine reprend inéluctablement le dessus et les deux leaders susmentionnés trahissent leurs propres idéaux lorsqu'ils sont confrontés à la réalité, conduisant au monde de cauchemar qu'est la version post-apo de Rapture, ici cette critique nous est enfoncée dans le crâne à grands coups de marteau et d'images de pauvres noirs caillassés, maintenus en esclavage et ségrégués. "la religion cé mal, le nassionalism cé mal, le racisme cé mal oci, mon jeu est tellement edgy" Le scénario, basé sur un multivers et des voyages dans l'espace-temps, finit, comme tous les scénarii qui utilisent ces ficelles, par s'emmêler les pinceaux, au point que le dernier quart du scénar a visiblement été écrit par un scénariste débutant en plein trip à l'acide pour arriver à une fin qui n'a aucun sens, ni moralement ni scénaristiquement. (Spoiler mineur : A la question "Suis-je responsable des actions et atrocités commises par les variantes de moi-même provenant d'autres univers ?", ce jeu a visiblement décidé de répondre résolument "Oui" ; je vous laisse juger de la stupidité de cette assertion, à moins qu'il s'agisse d'une allégorie du white-shaming post-colonial, auquel cas on a juste affaire à une infecte propagande wokiste). Vos choix n'auront, évidemment, aucune incidence sur le déroulement du jeu. Pas question d'influencer le développement moral d'Elizabeth, pas question de contrôler votre personnage et de faire des choix pour lui dans les moments-clés du jeu, bref pas question d'avoir le moindre contrôle sur l'histoire, contrairement au 1 et 2 qui avaient des justifications pour fonctionner en couloir scénaristique mais laissaient pourtant plus de liberté au joueur pour en influencer le déroulement. Et tout cela nous conduira à une fin qui est absurde, qui aurait pu être facilement évitée, et dont le joueur ne veut pas, puisqu'elle est basée sur des prémisses philosophiques fausses et des incohérences scénaristiques gigantesques. Et bien évidemment le récent launcher 2K est une daube absolue. Je ne comprends pas comment ce jeu a pu avoir autant d'avis dithyrambiques.

En conclusion, voici mon conseil : si vous voulez vraiment y jouer, achetez ce jeu en solde, et arrêtez-vous juste avant d'enfin rencontrer Comstock. Ne vous infligez pas inutilement cette fin incompréhensible et insensée.

For fans of the Bioshock series and who are curious about how it stacks up compared to other entries in the title, here's my comparisons. Mild spoilers? Idk, nothing major or that you won't find out pretty early on. 

Graphics: better than ever before. Not exactly groundbreaking or impressive, but it was made in 2013 so I'll give it some leeway. 
Art style: eh, I mean it's pretty cool, I guess? Not quite my cup of tea. Rapture was better imo. 
Genre: not really horror, more adventure/action than anything else. A shame. 
Escort missions: used to be radically difficult, now your escortee gives you ammo and you don't have to worry about protecting her. Win win. 
Story: incomprehensible, with a side of incredulity. Decent at the start, middling at the middle, and dissolved into lunacy by the end. Twist endings are typical of the series, and this game is no exception. But at least the other two's twists were easily understood and clearly defined. This one, I shut down the game after the end, stared at my steam page for a solid minute, and then feverishly researched theories and explanations because I had no earthly idea what had just transpired.
Combat: great weapons and combat mechanics! Skyhook is your best friend! But you can only have two weapons at a time, which just discourages experimentation and fosters a false sense of desperation as you scrounge and desperately hope Elizabeth will bail you out. 
Plasmids: there's plasmids. That's about all I can say. 
Absolute no-doubt-about-it-plusses: the twins. The gear/clothing system. The fact that you now have shields. 

All in all, I respect what the devs tried to do. They kept the heart of what Bioshock games are at their core -- themes of family, themes of identity, a setting of an impossible city in a place where humans shouldn't be -- and they took a major step away from the franchise and tried to breathe something new into the series. And a part of me respects that. But the rest of me just dislikes how they went about doing that. I feel like the game would have been better received by fans of the series if it hadn't been attached to the Bioshock name. It's not a great Bioshock game, but it's a pretty decent game just by itself. It's only when you try to compare it to its predecessors that it falls short. So, the best way to play and still appreciate the game is to try to view it as its own game as much as possible.

Leaving aside all the 2K issues others have already mentioned, I am going to focus solely on the game for my review. After having played both bioshock 1 and 2, I felt quite disappointed with this one. BS Ultimate feels dull both in characters and dynamics. The only thing I really liked was the final plot twist and the burial at sea DLCs story. The gameplay was significantly worse than any of the other 2. The fact that you can only carry 2 weapons at a time is a bad decision that I really don’t understand (this changed in the DLCs). At some points you find yourself in a situation with 2 empty weapons and nothing to do, as you cannot change it for anything else unless some enemy drops another one off. Also, using vigor is extremely restricted. If in BS 1 and 2 you had 9 levels to “reload”, in infinite you basically use the vigor a few times and that’s it until you find more salts. There is no map so although it is pretty linear, for exploration purposes, it is a pain as you don’t know where you are, especially in big areas, leaving many things behind. The menu is small and pretty bad visually speaking in my opinion. The auto save system is terrible, you cannot save anytime as in BS1 and BS2 and only change locations or basically have a major event happening if you want to save your progress. Finally, there is an alarming lack of puzzles, in BS1and 2 you at least had the hacking thing, here the vending machines are extremely poor and simple. In general, I felt it was a downgraded version of the original games, except for the graphics everything was worse. The DLCs are the only part of the game that is really worth it.

Since the inclusion of the 2k launcher I am no longer able to start and play this game.

Let's start with everything bad, first of all, for most of the game the Lutece twins feel like a plot tool, they are there just to drive the plot forward and even tho it is explained why and how they just appear out of nowhere and do what they do it still isn't great. The enemies and the areas are far less memorable, the only thing that will make you remember an area will be some event you either really liked or hated. For a decent chunk of the game you are just going back and forth from one area to another and even three times in the exact same place just to get to your goal, this ended up being boring and even tho some very interesting things happened with the plot in this time it did not save it. The enemies lost their unique character and the game doesn't have the hard ethical question that made the previous two games what they are. The Handymen are a cheap replacement for the big daddies but they are far far worse. If they hit you your whole screen is usually taken over by their body so you don't even know what is going on. The few choices that you have in the game don't actually make any difference and there also a God awful boss fight against the First Lady, she is a bullet spunge and one of the most unfun bosses I've ever fought. The ending of the game is somewhat familiar to BioShock 2 in the way that is a repetitive fight against lots of enemies with the difference being that in BioShock 2 it was actually interesting cause of Eleanor and Sinclair. The death of the songbird also felt cheap cause: 1. Elizabeth did not need to take it with us through the tear, 2. I felt nothing about the bird, 3. The fact that it got angry just cause the thing we used to "control" fell out of our hand feels stupid. Very minor thing that could be better: I would have liked it if Elizabeth had slightly different dialogue as the way she sees Booker changes through the story and it would also be nice if she reacted when you upgraded your Vigors and weapons like the Little Sisters in BioShock 2. Also it would be nice IF I COULD HAVE MORE THAN TWO GODDAMN WEAPONS. (it's technically one cause let's be honest the shotgun will take one of those slots).
I liked the game quite a bit... Elizabeth was a really good character and the story, even if it was too convoluted for its own good, was good even tho the worldbuilding and combat did let me down and there were no interesting side characters. Even tho I would suggest it if you just wanna try it out and really like shooters (not the DLC, please for the love of God don't buy that) I wouldn't give it more than 6.5-7/10

Loved the game until the end. I didn't have Return to Sender which would have helped greatly. So I was not able to win the game. You are blocked from going back into the ship so that maybe you could get the Return to Sender. Ah well. Just play from the beginning, eh?

That final battle is just basically wave after wave after wave after wave while protecting (well, trying to protect--you are not going to win in the end) a device that is important but strangely just out there in the open with no installed protection to speak of (and on the Prophet's gunship---you'd think it better protected). Seriously, that was just a head-scratcher. Even if you have the Return to Sender. It's ridiculous the waves after waves after waves. The ending seemed like a lazy way to create a boss fight. Ah well, the rest of the game was interesting. And I did play it before and won, just didn't this second time because I forgot to make sure I had Return to Sender. When you do slog through this tiresome final boss fight you do to get to the finale where you learn more about the story, an interesting reveal, conclusion.

UPDATE (or "why I no longer can recommend this game"): 
yeah, not going to replay the game. They back-added a launcher on top of the game. The 2K launcher adds another layer of glitches to the game. And DRM. And you have  to create yet another account (because we don't have enough of those--I've reached saturation I guess or maybe it's that while I have an interest to play the game again, it is not great enough of an interest to overcome the 2K launcher being added after the fact. Quality of Life update--not my definition of quality of life.

I tried some workarounds to bypass the launcher but they didn't work for me (going to the game exe directly and launching, -ihatelaunchers %command% after the exe). Ah well, I do need to work on my game backlog! So, moving on to other games.

However, I feel, like others have stated, that adding the launcher, forcing us to create an account to use a game we [b]ALREADY[/b] purchased years ago should be [b]ILLEGAL[/b].

The launcher should be optional at most for previously purchased games. For new purchases, I guess it is the publisher's right to add in the launcher requirement, but revising previous orders, no.

If you don't mind yet another launcher, and, thus, yet another program to take its time to run before you can get to your game, and another way your game can have issues, then go ahead, especially if you have never played the game. I mean, I actually do find a certain enjoyment to troubleshooting computer hardware and software issues, but not quite as much as I used to. Maybe less energy in my old age :-). And this launcher just adds issues when, well, why? I'm not going to go out of my way to add problems to troubleshoot. 

I wish there was an ambivalent choice for recommending. I love the first two games and would otherwise recommend playing them, but I do not recommend the 2K launcher. if you have not "updated" your game yet, don't do it! But if you never have purchased the games before, sadly you will be forced to use the buggy 2K launcher and create a 2K account, so keep that in mind. Do a search for 2K launcher issues and make up your mind after that. So, in my present frame of mind, I am choosing not recommending this game. I make that choice reluctantly.

2K saw the release of the steam deck and said "We don't want none of that! Lets add a launcher that makes it unplayable for them, laggy for everyone else, and throw in microtransactions." Then they skipped back to their boardroom to vigorously pat themselves on the back for improving everyone's "quality of life."

The Gameplay: 
A larger focus on movement, traversal and fluid use of plasmids(ahem vigors) over being a walking arsenal. Having only two guns feels fine, if not makes each gun and gun upgrade a more meaningful choice.

The Story:
Stronger than it's level design, the story that holds everything together and takes you along this wild ride is... wild. It has so much subtle foreshadowing that can just be taken as video game logic but it is expertly crafted in there. The other two stories were more settings than a story told.

The Visuals:
Absolutely great. The level design and atmosphere are  the best in the industry as it is so powerful to how it affects the rest of the game. The characters are also very pleasant to look at and well of course better looking than their predecessors.

The Sound:
The voice acting is done superbly and very easily demonstrates what our protagonists are going through in a believable immersive story. The music is great and in a lot of ways more memorable, especially the song that plays once you finally see Columbia, it is much more pronounced.


The Experience:
This game was a true masterpiece. While I loved the previous games this was the one that generated a true response of wonder and awe. I actually cared about the protagonists AND the world they lived in. The previous two felt like you were just along for the ride with mostly the antagonist egging you on and talking to themselves at you. The setting was was also a beautiful touch that makes it a counter balance to Rapture which some could see as Hell.  However the big meat of the story was done incredibly well and honestly left me speechless, the other games were neat, but they did not hit the same. This was their magnus opus.

It is a huge shame that 2K decided to put their launcher on all their previous games making startup awkward and giving me another window. One of the best games I've ever played. It took me a very long time to get into it - I played 2 hours of it roughly 4 years ago and then stopped - but its slow start gameplay wise fades away if you continue through. There are a few weaknesses in gameplay, and very occasionally the game shows its age in certain ways. Despite this, the game is probably the most beautiful I've ever seen, and the story is top notch - the entire final section had me sitting there thinking about it for a long time after playing. On top of this, Elizabeth is one of the best characters in gaming - compelling, actually useful, and above all else, human. The new launcher is a pain if you're on linux, and it is a shitty thing to do by 2K, but that doesn't take anything away from the fantastic experience of playing this. I will be replaying it soon.

I would recommend the game with the following caveats:

1) BioShock Infinite lacks the quality of the original game. It falls short of the overall philosophy built into the original game. It does strive to achieve a sense of atmosphere within the game but, lacking that overarching philosophy, it doesn't reach the heights of the original.

2) It is a short game. I finished the game in 15 hours. I've paid less for games that provided double the hours of satisfying game play. So, watch for a sale if interested?

Caveats out of the way, BioShock Infinite is a fun FPS with some challenging fights. Those into Steampunk will likely enjoy the game's setting and design. Characters and plot are interesting enough - certainly more interesting than many FPS games I've played. I played with keyboard and mouse, and the controls were smooth and - once learned - instinctive within game play.

While it doesn't reach the heights of the original BioShock, if approached as its own entity, it can be a satisfying - if short - diversion. (I did like the murder of crows ability.)

ORIGINAL REVIEW:

The gameplay is the usual mix of conventional weapons and creative use of your Plas- excuse me, your Vigors and the environment. The skylines make it a lot easier to get around the battle stages, and the tears add even more potential for crazy chaos, although they sometimes feel like they're there just so Elizabeth has something to do. I'm not a big fan of the carry limit on guns though; like a lot of modern shooters, Bioshock Infinite allows you to only carry 2 guns with you at any time. In a game series that's all about creative combat, this feels like an odd choice (although the number of different guns in the game is huge), and fortunately the devs chose to go back to letting you carry all weapons at once for Burial At Sea.

The game is less about scavenging than the first one. You still get some freedom about the way you explore an area (and going straight for the objective will mean you miss out on a lot), but it lacks the sense of desolation that you get in Bioshock 1 and 2, simply because in those two games, you walk around in Rapture after the civil war, while Infinite takes place before/during the civil war in Columbia. It makes sense but I still miss it.

The graphics are stunning. Columbia looks absolutely gorgeous, the first time you see the city is very reminiscent of the first time you see Rapture in the original Bioshock (and also an obvious call-back to that famous scene, only the bathysphere is a rocket this time). Rapture also looks incredible in the Burial At Sea DLC.

Unfortunately, the game holds itself up considerably less well in terms of storyline and characters. Frankly, Father Comstock just isn't nearly as interesting a villain as Andrew Ryan, and the struggle between him and the Vox almost boring compared to the battle between Ryan and Atlas. In that regard, Fink feels like he would have made for a much better big bad. This becomes even more painfully obvious in Burial At Sea, when old characters make their returns.
The Luteces, on the other hand, are absolutely brilliantly voiced by Courtnee Draper and Troy Baker as two bickering siblings, and the moments in the game where you encounter them are among my favourite.

I'm not going to say much about the ending to the main story. Yes, it sucks. As for the ending to Burial At Sea, well... That made a lot more sense, actually.

Altogether Bioshock Infinite is not a perfect game, but I had a LOT of fun playing it, and I fully recommend it and the Burial At Sea DLC.

Recently, this game has been getting review bombed thanks to the needless inclusion of the 2K launcher across all BioShock games on the platform. For some, this alleged “quality of life update” has made the game unplayable, yet I still don’t believe the questionable practices of the company a decade on from release should reflect on the game the way it does at the moment. For a while, I’ve been toying with the idea of reviewing my favourite game, BioShock Infinite, and now seems like a perfect time to convince any newcomers to the series to give it a shot, despite the negativity surrounding it at the moment. I wish this review to be as spoiler free as possible, but I will be discussing certain aspects of the games like characters and the setting, so if you prefer to go into games blind, please take my sincerest recommendation and enjoy. I’ll refrain from talking about the main points of the story, however, I would like to just add that this game (like its predecessors) has an amazing narrative, which can only be achieved through the medium of video games, and would be lost in other forms of media.

So, let’s begin with the characters, shall we? You inhabit the character of Booker DeWitt, a private investigator and former Pinkerton agent. For those who are familiar with the Pinkertons history in real life, you’ll understand that to be kicked out of such a group implies that he’s done a lot of bad in the world, and he feels like he owes penance to society. He is presented an opportunity to do so in the beginning of the game, which he at first views as nothing but a normal job. This leads him to a person of equal importance in the story, Elizabeth, who is more of a deuteragonist rather than just another side character. The evolving relationship between the two throughout the story is incredibly well done, and will have you feeling for both characters during their struggles. What’s great about Elizabeth’s character is that she’s by your side throughout the majority of the story. And already, I know what you may be thinking. A game based around an escort quest? Lame, no thanks. But you’d be wrong, because for once, Irrational Games (rip) made an escort quest enjoyable, and I’ll touch a bit more on that in the next paragraph. Other than our two protagonists, there are a number of various side characters, all with intricately important roles in the story. However, discussing them here would be spoiler-ish, so once again I shall refrain. If you are interested in knowing how these side characters were received, one of them was awarded “Character of the Year” at the 2013 Spike video game awards.

Now, I’ll discuss the gameplay. The gunplay handles well, and the range of different weapons you can use is vast, all with their own unique feel. You are also given a melee weapon in the form of a “skyhook,” which allows you to travel these cargo rails found high-up across the city, which grants a level of verticality not often found in other first person shooters. Alongside your weapons, you are granted an arsenal of “vigors” which are a series of varying powers you can dual wield with in your other hand. The addition of these vigors separates the game from other formulaic shooters which oversaturate the market, and gives the gameplay a unique feel and playstyle. You can zap enemies to stun them before closing in, or send them floating off the map to their demise. One vigor called “charge” allows you to fly at your enemy like a whirlwind, meaning you can close the gap between you and your foe in a quick dash and finish them with a shotgun, for what I like to call the Mass Effect vanguard experience. In combat, Elizabeth isn’t a distraction for you to be worried about, but rather a noticeable asset. She supplies ammunition, when you’re running low, and also makes sure to keep you patched up when your health starts to dip. Once you become accustomed to having her at your side in a fight, you’ll find yourself fearing for your life if she isn’t there to help. Putting my rose-tinted glasses aside for a moment, there are some valid criticisms against the gameplay that you may find an annoyance. For example, in previous titles, once you unlocked a weapon you had it in your inventory for the rest of the game (think something similar to Half Life). In Infinite, you can only hold two weapons at a time. Personally for me, this was a non-issue as I dislike having to scroll through my entire list of weapons to select one with ammo whilst I’m being attacked, but for some players this was a major concern. Another issue is that combat in the middle of the game I found can feel like a bit of a slog, particularly when replaying the game. Technically you can actually run from a lot of fights, but I’d advise against that even though you wouldn’t miss anything like experience points for example, since such a system does not exist in the game. A lot of joy in the game can be found by simply exploring and taking in the world around you, which brings me to my next discussion point.

The setting of BioShock Infinite is by far the most enjoyable part of the game. In the original, we explored Rapture, an underwater city which was once the pride of objectivist values, now reduced to a run down city crawling with lunatics. Unlike previous titles, Infinite decided to shake things up and looked upward, literally. The game is set in the flying city of Columbia, which was originally constructed as a floating world’s fair, based on the World’s Columbian Exposition in Chicago (1893). Despite the game being nearly a decade old, its gorgeous art style still holds up by today's standards, and proves that a visually distinct game will always age better than attempts at photorealism. I challenge you to try and not wear out the screenshot button. In the rare moments of peace from the fighting, make sure you take in the scenery and enjoy the short lived bliss, before the next hectic shootout consumes your focus. Columbia is not just the setting of the game, but it’s essentially a character within itself. The world is fleshed out creatively through the use of “voxophones,” which are voiced recordings used to relay short stories or worldbuilding snippets for the player’s enjoyment. If you find reading large text walls of information to be tedious (like this review!), then don’t fret, because voxophones will give you your lore fix in an easy to digest format, all whilst you carry on and play the game!

Anyway, I’ve rambled on too long. I think I’ve made my point clearly that I think BioShock Infinite is a worthwhile game, despite current circumstances regarding the increasingly infamous update. If you find the game unable to launch via Steam, I’ve read that booting it up via the .exe file directly is a temporary workaround. My main point is don’t let the current reviews regarding the launcher deter you, the game is worth the effort. 

For some, it’s not Christmas until Hans Gruber falls from Nakatomi Plaza. For me, it’s when I boot up this game and “After You’ve Gone” kicks in.

This is the best combat in Bioshock has felt, but the removal of visual upgrades to your weapons and limit to carrying 2 at once is a step back from previous games. Enemies are also quiet samey, and the new boogeymen you encounter, the Handymen, lack the ominous presence of the Big Daddies. You also never get to fight Songbird which is totally bizarre for such a unique villain. 

The skylines are a great addition and add a necessary sense of verticality to the flying city setting. The new plasmids ("vigors" now) are interesting but the concept has no reason to exist in Columbia. Hacking has, mercifully, been removed entirely. 

Elizabeth isn't an escort NPC but a fully-fledged party member, requiring no coddling or protection, ending up as a net gain to your capabilities by finding resources for you and modifying the environment in- sadly- limited ways. Her voice actor does a great job and she has an interesting relationship with Booker, Bioshocks first protagonist with his own honest-to-god personality. He sounds like Troy Baker because that's what Troy Baker sounds like.

The story is pretty barebones on anything but a surface level and the ending makes no sense at all if you think about it for longer than 5 seconds. But if you can overlook that and just enjoy the emotional beats it's fine.

The DLC is more of a love letter to the original Bioshock than a logical continuation of Infinite, but it does a nice job tying up loose ends and I got to hear ME WEE BABY Atlas again, so. 

Oh, and they literally just added the 2K launcher as a necessity to launch this 9 year old game which is bullshit. Fuck that,

Update: Good game, but now you have to play it through an additional launcher as of the 9/2/2022 update; you can still buy this on GOG, so you don't have to deal with that, but I don't like the game enough to go through with it.

I went back and forth a lot on this one.  The shooting is a lot better than its predecessors, but you can only carry 2 guns at a time.  You get all of the magic automatically, but I found it even less useful than before.  The game is even more linear then BioShock 2, because there is next to no exploration for 90% of the game.  The setting of a city in the sky was a great idea, but it turned out to be a lot less visually interesting than I'd thought it would be.  1912 is also an interesting setting, but you didn't get as immersed in the culture as you might've been, especially with the main characters talking just like people from 2012, instead.

The story starts off pretty rough, too; you're not in Columbia (the sky city; not South America) long before you realize what's going on.  The racism going on is so blatant that it actually goes does more harm than good toward the anti-racist movement of today; when you paint racism as the over-the-top caricature of white hoods goose-stepping while clubbing minorities and spewing slurs, it makes today's more subtle racism seem like not such a big deal.  "Oh boy," I thought, "this is even less subtle than the first game's message.  Well, at least I know what it is that's been bothering me about BioShock's writing for the last few games."  From there, you have a "twist" that's very poorly explored, the characters reach a conclusion before you do without any real evidence, and it's "proven" by actions so out-of-character they might as well have been ripped from Legend of Kyrandia 3.  Uhh... kids, ask your parents.  The writing is worse than ever, and my cynicism has built an entire labyrinth of walls between myself and immersion, and lit them on fire.

And then, the story goes all WHAAAAAAAAAAAAT, and all of a sudden, I'm interested again.  It wasn't exactly deep, but it was [b]weird[/b], and I was SO invested in what was going on.  It brushed it off like nothing, and we were back to boring again.  AND THEN, IT CAME BACK WITH A VENGEANCE!  I was prepared to write this off as another pedantic installment that elicited a number of unearned gasps, and the ending still blew me away.  Plot twists are so often a lazy writing device used to attempt to inject some intrigue into a story that's nothing special to begin with, but Bioshock Infinite understands the one thing that really matters: it [i]does something[/i] with it.  It isn't perfect, and I hate to be [i]that[/i] person, but stay with it until the very end; you'll likely find a worthwhile payoff for it all.

Update: Recent updates to this game have made it difficult to recommend. I don't condone adding random launchers and data collection systems. No matter how good a game is, that doesn't give publishers to right to screw around with content that people have previously purchased. (The fact that when you buy on steam you're not purchasing, just licensing, is a symptom of the same problem and also does not excuse this behaviour).

For posterity, and should the publisher reverse this decision, or if you choose to buy and bypass the new launcher, here is my original review:

Infinite is a great third game to the Bioshock Series. I initially had my reservations with it, at it seemed to take the game in a completely different direction, both in terms of gameplay and storytelling. But it completely won me over very soon into the game.

Gameplay: This game has some pretty major differences to the previous games in the series. Most of these are pretty good. 
- You're restricted to only two weapons at a time, which I think gives you a more realistic FPs than one where you can lug around an entire armoury on your shoulders.
- New vigours or plasmids. These mix up the special powers into something much more imaginative and magical.
- No more fiddling around with gene splicing. This game makes the process of upgrading yourself a bit simpler. You can have as many upgrades as you want active, provided you have enough coin to buy them. There are some 'magic gears' that you can get and wear. I'm not entirely sure I like them, as they randomly generate and are hidden around levels, but they provide extra abilities if you want them.
- Sky Hooks. One of the great things in this game is the sky hook. This, with the lines you can zip around on and jump everywhere give a sense of freedom to the environment that takes advantage of the fact that this game feels very 'open', even though it's played fairly linearly. It reminds me a lot of what I felt playing mirrors edge.
- Much larger levels. This game has much larger levels and gives you more freedom of movement between them. It also makes good use of 'tears', which allow you to modify the combat field in imaginative ways.
- Elizabeth. The game introduces what I think is one of the best 'companions' in an FPS I've ever played. She provides you help in combat that goes beyond just shooting back at enemies, but actively scouts for loot so you don't have to. The game also makes use of some pretty good AI which, even though Elizabeth is just following you around, makes it seem as if she is actively makign choices on her own, and actually feels 'alive'.
Given all of these changes, I feel as if the game play in this game is a great improvement on the previous bioshock games.

Story: 
This game takes a big departure from the previous bioshock storytelling. Rather than following someone on a radio, you are more directly involved with the events that are playing out before you.
This game has a pretty deep story, that I won't go too much into because of plot spoily reasons, but it involves a lot of great themes like [spoiler]parallel universes, family relationships, and hard choices.[/spoiler]
Plus, the characters in the game all seem to be very real, and rather than having your standard villain that you need to beat, everyone is on a spectrum of good to evil.
The game also helps to add depth to the story by the use of tape\record\video collecting to tell the stories of some background characters, if you want to seek them out, like in previous games.

Graphics: The graphics in this game are amazing.
The environments of all of the structures are beautifully crafted, with buildings that give a real atmosphere of everything from a lived-in 1900s american city, to a civil-war style battleground, all surrounded by steampunk floaty island-ness.
The main characters have some great design to them, both from a perspective of their general appearance, and the design of the costumes\clothes\armour they are wearing.
I did see a fair bit of copy\paste in the background civilians, but the game did include a few stand-out background characters even though they appear only briefly [like the barbershop quartet].
The post processing was a bit much at times for my tastes, but that can be fine tunes if you want.

The worst part of this game: Checkpoints.
Checkpoints are awful.
The previous games allowed you to save anywhere you wanted, but this game restricts you to only saving at given checkpoints. This provides a problem as if, like me, you like to explore every nook and cranny of a level, you can spend a long time between checkpoints. And if, for life reasons, you need to take a break, your options are all awful. Quit and lose all progress; pause the game and leave it running, hoping your computer doesn't crash or suffer a power loss; run ahead to the next available checkpoint and miss out on all combat, as when you reload your save next time, the enemies will not respawn.
It would be great if someone at 2K games were able to implement this, but unfortunately, you're just going to have to deal with it.

That aside, overall this game is great. One of the best I've played in a long time. Great if you like FPS games, and can be played independently of any previous bioshock games.

''G:\Games\SteamLibrary\steamapps\common\BioShock Infinite\Binaries\Win32 BioShockInfinite'' %command%

Here's a review that isn't crying about the third-party launcher (which is ass):
Bioshock Infinite is maybe the most soulless game I've ever played.

The gunplay is clunky garbage. Movement is, often quite literally, on rails. Enemies are all damage sponges. The powers are bizarre and somehow never feel very effective, interesting or congruent with the rest of the setting, almost like you're playing a Chinese knock off of Bioshock. It feels like a different game shoehorned into a template of what someone who never played Bioshock thinks Bioshock is. My working assumption is that Ken Levine ate a tombstone piledriver onto solid concrete in the late 2000s and never recovered mentally. This isn't the revamp anyone wanted. I rate this gameplay a zzz/10 for being a sleep aid.

The plot doesn't fare any better either, despite being the biggest source of bloviating approval. It doesn't really make any sense and even if it did, it wouldn't be very compelling because there are no real stakes and characterization is flat-to-nonexistent. The protagonist is bland which means the antagonist is also bland, because they're secretly the same character. Furthermore, imagine being so high on your own farts you write a side antagonist called 'Mr. Fink' who is a moustache twirling factory owner virtually plagiarized from Dickens. Unless you're some sort of incel neckbeard fishing for material to construct a headcanon 'waifu' you can daydream about, this game contains zero characters of interest. (Un)surprising, since there's only about 4 in the game to begin with: Booker, Elizabeth, Fink and the lady scientist who's supposed to be important but I forgot her name to make room for more important trivia. Did you know Baku is the capital of Azerbaijan?

Now if you thought writing a story with zero characters was impressive, you haven't even begun to grasp the levels of incompetence involved in the construction of the setting itself. Most obviously it's an intentional pastiche of classic Americana, but undercuts any kind of depth or structure by presenting its world as a Disney theme park. On purpose. It's supposed to look like a series of lifeless amusement ride facades by design, grappling hook rollercoasters and all, because the same fart-huffer who wrote Fink thought "World's Fair as presentational metacommentary for the superficiality of American exceptionalism" was VERY smart. Oh, and the nefariousness lurking behind those facades? It's just racism. Tell me when you start caring about either of these stale political takes. Also, we already have a racist version of Disney: it's literally Disney. The game disappears so far up its own ass it accidentally becomes the thing it's satirizing, a far cry from the objectivist dystopia of Bioshock which skewered Ayn Rand in a way that didn't age like milk. Ironically, Bioshock Infinite is a game that presents a multiverse but manages to be one-dimensional in every respect.

Play literally anything else.

Played this game after getting the bundle and finishing 1 and 2. I went in without expectations but man this game is conflicting. First, the gameplay does feel fun, the different vigors you get feel smooth with the gunplay. The guns feel okay I guess, not super memorable compared to previous games. The game looks so visually pleasing at parts, loved the colors and scenes that made you want to screenshot (bloom and lighting can be a little much).  The economy feels kinds odd, you have to choose if you want to upgrade your gun or abilities, while you hardly ever need supplies. The setting is cool for sure and immersive, however the feeling of isolation rapture gives you is unmatched imo. The enemies feel so bland and gimmicky compared to the insanity that was splicers. The big mechs (I cant even remember their names off the top) were lifeless compared to big daddies. Another nitpick is I miss hacking. The story...really was not for me.  Booker is pushed so hard to be badass and Elizabeth this Rapunzelish character that can feel awkward at times. The dialogue between the two really took away from some scenes. The ending was the cherry on top, felt like it was trying so hard to be deep and the shock value of things being revealed. The inclusion of a certain setting felt like fan service. The shock value of religion and politics was also not my favorite. Overall, if this game is on sale or in a bundle and you played the first two, go for it. However, this game feels like it was inspired by bioshock, not a mainline game. The dlc being set in rapture was such a tease, the story could have been interesting if made into a whole game. I was not the biggest fan of the wave based mode compared to protector trails and the first games side mode. I do feel like if this game did not have the Bioshock title, I would have gone easier on it. I am also not purely hating to jump on the bandwagon, these are legitimate concerns I had while playing.

"2K is proud to announce an upgrade to Bioshock Inifinite that focuses on providing value for purchase. Bioshock Infinite has been praised by dozens of industry publications as a triumph of the medium, and has been experienced in full by tens of millions of the gaming public around the world. As the years have passed, the gaming public has experienced what our game has to offer, and have been stuck in limbo searching for the next great experience that is going to fill the void that such a powerful story as that featured in Bioshock Infinite has left behind. Is this game good? Is it bad? Is it so-so? Is it meh? I have no idea. 2K has forced an update download that completely fucks your installation of any of their games (I tried it with "Mafia", and the same thing happened). Apparently, it's some sort of online thing that I don't understand. Basically, it goes like this:

Play a game once; the launcher doesn't recognize what's going on. Thus, you can play the game perfectly as normal and not notice anything wrong. Close the game and then try to play it again, and it won't even open. Honest to goodness, you can't even launch Bioshock Infinite (or any of their other games) after that from the 2nd attempt onwards. The game literally won't even turn on.

At first, I thought this must have been some sort of a hardware issue, so I tried restarting my computer. Didn't work. So then, I looked up "bioshock infinite steam not launching" on Google to see if anybody else has had this issue. There were posts from 2018 and also from 2020 about having to reinstall Windows. So, I tried wiping the `$PATH/compatdata/<pfxid>/` records (as I'm on Linux and not Windows) to start with a clean prefix. Also didn't work. Then I went to this very game page on Steam and scrolled down to the reviews. There are lots of negative reviews from just the past few days (I'm writing this review on Sept. 2nd, 2022) cursing the game development company about their new shitty launcher.

I'm very terribly sad and angry about this. Bioshock is a beautiful game. I'd just barely started playing the first half-hour or so of "Bioshock Infinite", and I couldn't wait to see how the story unfolded. It obviously has something to do with religion somehow. That much at least is super, super clear even just from the first half-hour or so. The aesthetic of a floating city with semi-jointed suburbs is just beautiful. Again, I didn't really get to see anything regarding the story, so I can't comment. 

It was getting late and i had to go to bed, so I turned the game off, thinking, "Wow, this game is beautiful. I can't wait to play it again tomorrow!" Cue the narrator's voice in the background: "As our hero would soon discover, there was no tomorrow."

Anyway, it looks like a great game. I just wish I'd been able to play it. So, as much as I actually do love the beautiful aesthetic of Bioshock Infinite, and as much as I was really excited to experience the story, I have to give this negative review because game companies need to learn that they can't fuck their customers like this. We need to get the message to them somehow.

In summary, fuck 2K, and especially fuck whoever signed off on this new bullshit launcher that doesn't even allow you to play the game.

I've started replacing my Steam library with games from GOG (and other places) because they don't do this. Your games bought on Steam will never be safe, you never know when this will happen or to what game. And if you've loved the game for years? Tough break, no refund because it's past the two-weeks-since-purchase refund period for Steam. This will be the third game that I paid for, downloaded, enjoyed for years, and then lost to unreliable 3rd party software forced on me through Steam. Thanks Steam, that's really uncool. None of my games library feels safe now. What are you going to take from me next? 

Get this game from somewhere other than Steam if you want to play it. Steam will sell you one thing, then turn around and add a bunch of garbage without asking or even informing you first. How long will it take them to mess up your save files with something that wasn't part of the original purchase, added without your permission? One week? One Month? One year? If it's longer than two weeks, no refund for you. But there's no two-week cap on how long developers can use their game as an excuse to force proprietary software onto your computer. Software that may die when it's no longer profitable to support, cutting off your access to the game entirely. Software that may track your behavior, like how long you play, when you play, your IP address and where you're located geographically, who else you play with, and anything else they can get. Software that was never essential to play the game until the parent company decided they could squeeze a few more bucks out of you. This has been going on for years. Shame on Steam for being a part of it.

Good game.

The world and gameplay were very good. Unfortunately, the big issue with this game lies in the story. The story made sense 1/2 of the way through, but in the second half turned into convoluted garbage. They threw too many things in there, such as ghosts, infinite worlds, class warfare, double identities, that it is all too much to keep track of. The dramatic voice acting didn't even hit any emotional notes for me because I had no clue why the current story point was important. Why is Elizabeth's mother a ghost but also a representation of herself? Why does Elizabeth keep creating new worlds? Why is the main villain of Comstock so quickly brushed over? [h1] 💎         COMPARE TO OTHER SIMILAR GENRE:[/h1]
