* Variety combat option

[h1]  🔊         BUYER MUST KNOW:[/h1]
* Game world timeline: 1912, flying city of Columbia

* Uninspired combat system: limited to carry only 2 weapons and it doesn't fit with melee execution, regenerating shield, collecting lockpick pin ➜ Those look fine!

I played this game completely blind and with no prior experience with the Bioshock franchise. What can I say... Well, it's a tepid thumbs up. Several times through the story, I had to ask myself: is the game just ok, or is it just old? I don't really know because I completely missed my childhood, but at least I am not blinded by nostalgia. Honestly, I am dragging my feet to write this review.

The gameplay holds up, I guess, to 2010's standards, but as another review commented, some of the boss fights really halt your momentum to progress through the story. At the last one, after many many attempts, I just said f*** it, and went from Hard to Easy to continue the story. The game is generous with supplies until it isn't, and that was one such case for me. Sorry, but I'm not going to beat multiple waves of George Washington mechs on Hard with 4 pistol ammo and an RPG. You're going to have to throw me a bone.

The main attachment point for the player is the story and your companion Elizabeth. I'm a big fan of Many Worlds / Everett's Quantum Theory BS as a plot line, and I'd say it was executed alright here, but my disappointment is it's really only hinted at throughout the story. Although the ending is good, and does do a good job to make you think, I wish there had been more investment in this MW concept throughout the game instead of just slapping you across the face with the ending.

I'd say I see how the game is a classic, but I'd personally suggest just buying it on sale and running through it quickly on Normal difficulty or below. I don't think playing Hard was worth it, and neither was finding audio logs or getting achievements. If you do that, you can get the story experience in maybe 10-12 hours.

[h1]At-A-Glance:[/h1]
[b]Game type:[/b] First-person Shooter
[b]Genre(s):[/b] Sci-fi
[b]Art:[/b] Bright and sunny 7th generation 3D graphics
[b]Length:[/b] 8-10 hours for a first run-through
[b]Pace:[/b] Fast-paced
[b]Tags:[/b] Emergent gameplay, action-adventure
[b]Computer requirements:[/b] Medium-end


[h1]Notes:[/h1]
[olist]
[*] As time passes, I find [i]Bioshock: Infinite[/i] to be steadily disappointing. From the nonsense storyline to the streamlined mechanics to completely screwed-the-pooch boss fights, this is a game whose goodwill got by entirely on presentation.
[*] ... and this game's presentation is certainly incredible. The initial view of Columbia is magnificent, and the little anachronisms at first hit you as a "huh, that's weird" sort of deal before the story unfolds. It's beautiful - really. However, [i]Bioshock[/i] felt like each plasmid and bit of dialogue or design had a place in the world... and for [i]Bioshock: Infinite[/i], it becomes quickly clear that most of the world design is a fresh coat of paint rather than an actual fleshed-out world. What, you're telling me there's a tonic being sold whose purpose is to just... hack vending machines? Or possess people? The narrative explanation in the first game stated that your normal splicer [i]couldn't[/i] use plasmids that way (which is why houdini splicers were so scary - they could!), whereas in [i]Bioshock: Infinite[/i], we've just completely thrown out caring about that I guess. The Fraternal Order of the Raven is the most egregious example. Sure, one could say "just turn off your mind and play the FPS", but isn't this game supposed to have a great, grand narrative?
[*] The "normal enemy" mechanics feel pretty solid. Handymen and firemen are both fun to fight and sad to behold, and the general mook is far smarter (though still occasionally janky for 2013 games) than the other two series entries.
[*] Boss fights are atrocious bullet sponges. This starts slow with the Motorized Patriots being easy to fight but long to kill, and gets really [i]really[/i] bad with a certain Siren boss fight whom you have to kill three times. Boss fights in this game are a complete annoyance that frequently stop the game's momentum. Again, the "turn off your mind" people might quickly see that this game isn't actually that mechanically deep on the FPS side.
[*] The first [i]Bioshock[/i] game got flack for taking out some of the 0451 characteristics of predecessors and sisters like [i]System Shock 2[/i] and [i]Deus Ex[/i]. In the third installment, we're just a straight-up FPS. There really isn't any different or exciting way to play this, and the clothing options are a bit of a joke.
[*] Elizabeth is a legitimately good companion who should be the typecast for escort missions everywhere. Could you imagine playing this game and actually worrying about her safety as a damsel in distress? No, she's a perfectly capable woman on her own... even if that's kind of strange considering she's supposed to have been locked up all her life yet immediately acclimates upon release. But hey, that's expecting a consistent story.
[*] The story is.... well, again, presentation is the ringer here. But if you were to read this game's script without the flash, you would quickly see how plot hole-ridden and frankly idiotic it is. It's kind of hard to talk about this particular twist in a post-2016 American political landscape, but the certain line "the only difference between Comstock and <character> is how you spell their names" is just so ivory-tower nonsense that I'm surprised Troy Baker didn't refuse to say it on principle. It reflects this general shallow approach that [i]Bioshock: Infinite[/i] has despite expecting you to be wowed at every turn and twist, or getting by on the pathos of playing "Let the Circle Be Unbroken" ten times. And sure, maybe I'm overthinking philosophy in an FPS... but wasn't that the point of [i]Bioshock[/i] games?
[*] When I first beat [i]Bioshock: Infinite[/i], I thought it was one of the greatest experiences in gaming I've ever had. I was genuinely moved by the ending in particular, with the chemistry between Troy Baker and Courtnee Draper being phenomenal. But since then, with just a little bit of thought applied to the game as a whole - it utterly falls apart for the mechanically and narratively shallow experience it is.
[/olist]

Upon replaying Bioshock Infinite almost 4 years after first beating it, I have a new found perspective of this game and have a little more I would like to add beyond my initial review. This game is without a doubt, one of the most beautiful games I’ve ever played. Aesthetically, it works wonderfully for me. While not every level is filled with amazing detail or visual storytelling like in other games such as Fallout or even Bioshock 1, spending time in the world of Columbia is a treat. The colors, saturation, and world building it engages in are really well done. The game is clearly a relic of early 1900s America and it clearly still struggles with class divide and racial segregation. In fact, this country prides itself on white power and capitalism to the point where it plays a central role in the story. NPC dialogue, propaganda posters, and other elements throughout the world all help flesh out the world and are fun to stop and engage with. 
	One of the main subplots of the game plays into this class divide with a proletariat uprising. This violent uprising uproots the white elite of Columbia and through the combined effort of minority groups and the exploited worker class. This conflict places you on the side of the proletariat, mostly out of necessity, as you attempt to find a ride off of Columbia. Initially, the game takes a very anti capitalist approach, using 1900’s imagery of overworked and underpaid workers being exploited by self indulgent and larger than life bosses. Upon the proletariat victory, the game takes a much different approach, showing the communist leader, Daisy Fitzroy becoming the same violent and power hungry leader she sought to destroy. It definitely aims to show these two “extremes” as equal which is ultimately disappointing as one is white nationalist religious zealots and the other is working class uprising. Although many deem a violent uprising necessary for systemic economic change, it’s unfortunate how Daisy Fitzroy are merely pushed to the side, becoming enemies that are no greater than their oppressors.
	About halfway through the game, the revolution aspect of the game is completely abandoned, without any real meaningful conclusion. Elizabeth, of all people, kills Daisy Fitzroy, which essentially sends the revolution into a frenzy since it no longer has its face. Although it was kill or be killed with Daisy at that point, I thought Elizabeth would have resonated with their struggle a little more. The second half of the game deviates into a rather interesting many worlds theory type of story. It is here where the true nature of our main characters are revealed. Having played the game twice and watching videos on the subject, I am able to piece everything together a little bit better, but it is certainly the type of ending that will have you looking up explanations. It is a very high concept and some may view it as “pretentious”, but I for one have come to enjoy the ending. It does a fantastic job at concluding the story regarding Booker Dewitt, Comstock, and Elizabeth. Beyond the communist revolution and aesthetic of Columbia, it seems like this was the story they were truly trying to tell.
	One of my favorite aspects of the game was the relationship between Booker and Elizabeth. They start out as complete strangers and over the course of the game, they slowly learn how to trust each other. There are plenty of times throughout the game where Booker’s selfishness or Elizabeth’s headstrong attitude conflict with each other, but it always leads to growth in their relationship. By the end of the game, they truly do have a father-daughter relationship, where Booker would do anything to save Elizabeth. I don’t think their relationship is as natural as Atreus and Kratos in God of War, but I did find that Elizabeth and Booker had more chemistry.. Their interactions throughout the game are perfectly acted and add a lot to the atmosphere of the game. Having a character by your side, who is naive to the outside world, slowly discovering her purpose in life is a treat to watch unfold. The end of the game has an off putting tonal shift in which Elizabeth becomes this all knowing, and almost godlike that goes on to explain the ending of the game to Booker. Within the context of the ending I suppose it makes sense, but it is still weird nonetheless.. Comstock plays a compelling villain to Booker and Elizabeth. I love how clearly vulnerable they make him despite how worshiped he is in Colombia. He is clearly scarred by his past involvement in wounded knee and attempts to cover up his sins with religion, which is quite the opposite of how Booker handled that situation. 
The pacing of this game is incredible. The plot is constantly moving forward, with the only exception being the Lady Comstock fight, which slows the pacing down to a halt. This section isn’t that long, but on harder difficulties, it can definitely be frustrating . Besides this slight mishap in pacing, these is little to no backtracking or filler in the game. Naturally, that leads to a shorter game of about 12-15 hours, but it is 12-15 hours of riveting story that is never dull. Upon a second playthrough, on the 1999 mode (hardest difficulty), I found the shooting and fighting set pieces to be exciting. The rail system allows for a great amount of verticality to the game. You can approach fights in countless different ways, using height to your advantage. The vigors were also useful and I found myself relying on them more on the harder difficulty. At some points, I found the hitboxes of certain benches, staircases, etc to be unforgiving. Booker would often be stopped in his tracks and I’d be forced to move around the smallest obstacle. I also found that trying to jump on and off of the rails quickly would often be unresponsive or glitchy, making it difficult to exit and enter the railing. Despite these problems I found the game to be exciting and rewarding, especially on harder difficulties 
Despite some jarring 180 degree  story changes, spotty social messaging, and infuriating boss fights, there is something magical about playing Bioshock Infinite. The beautiful coloring of the world coupled with the mystery and mythos of Columbia, create one of my fondest gaming memories. The ending is really well done and each main character gets closure to their story (especially Elizabeth in the DLC). There’s a reason why people still make videos on this game almost 10 years after it came out. 9/10

The first two games are "Infinitely" (get it?) better, with the first one still being the champion. The story here was ridiculous. The call of duty gunplay, while fun and snappy most of the time, doesn't mesh well with the bioshock health-sponge enemies it occasionally throws at you. Handymen are particularly egregious in that the amount of screen shake applied to their mere presence turns the game into an unplayable mess until you manage to kill them. Luckily there are only a few of them that I encountered. 

Again, ridiculous story, the end actually made me laugh out loud, and I gave up on trying to enjoy it about halfway through, I think, when you start dimension hopping and that pretty much indicates to me the writers just gave up. I should have seen this coming when the start of the game has to make you not like the villain by just making him a big racist, and throwing around a bunch of white power propaganda for shock value. Maybe one day I'll learn to trust my gut on this kind of laziness, but clearly not today.

For a while it's a frantic shooter game, then it's a touching confession, afterwards it is a parable about the ideological turmoil in America. The others would break it into pieces, but quantum physics and its creators that are hell-bent on going further than other big productions hold it firmly together. Irrational has delivered a bigger story, more polished experience. Bioshock Infinite is a visionary piece of entertainment where the gameplay, characters, art style and story all come together to make what undoubtedly is one of the greatest games ever made.

Note: This review is done on a Bioshock fan standpoint, I don't recommed it for the series old player, but to the new player, its no doubt an excellent introduction and totally worth a shot.

[b]Review layout: [/b] STEAM

[b]Review format: [/b] Normal, lazy
[h1]PROs: [/h1]
✅	Pleasant artstyle
✅	Very enjoyable world (nice looking, fancy) (Never liked aquatic themed things like first games had)
✅	As usual great narrative presentation, did enjoy the story itself as well this time
✅	Elizabeth sidekick is cute and how she interacts with stuff/idle animations are cute
✅	No more switching between 100 weapons constantly because of running out of ammo 
✅	With Elizabeth combat is more dynamic and interesting (give free stuff, opens rifts that give you combat assistance
✅	Gore is nice
✅	Abilities have projectile and trap mode
✅	Love the mystery eccentric duo
✅	Skylines are fun
✅	Executions
[h1]CONs:[/h1]
❌	Some missing graphic settings that you are force to tweak in config (i.e motion blur, DoF, UI scaling)
❌	Don’t like the Charlie Chaplin styled lore reels
❌	Wish “enter” could be rebinded… literally only key I have to travel across the keyboard to do things..
❌	Mouse sensitivity is lowered a lot when sprinting
❌	Story’wise Elizabeth can be quite obnoxious (but overall she was great)
❌	No manual saving
❌	Whats with ammo quantity at the later part of the game…
❌	Ability based key interaction were minimal / introductionary 
[h1]Comments:[/h1]
Pretty comical how Elizabeth warps around the moment you turn around camera. I somehow managed to get myself stuck as well in the first 30min of gameplay (jumped on stuff then got eventually stuck)
One thing that I found annoying but were at start like “hmm that’s nice”. Is the ammo management. First half of the game or even more, you get ammo everywhere and Elizabeth also gives you free ammo… but after certain threshold in game ammo becomes suddenly so scarce, which was really annoying. I mostly were forced to melee around as I hate collecting random guns on the ground from enemies as not only I haven’t upgraded em, but also that ruins my meta gameplay. I usually end up choosing guns I like the most, upgrading them and using the whole game, which was really nice at first half of the game as I got 0 ammo issues.
With weapon upgrades you have to be picky. As throughout the game I could upgrade only 2 weapons fully.
If compared to previous installations…. I enjoyed this the most. Artstyle was more pleasant, enjoyable sidekick, more entertaining characters and world was much much more fun and pleasant to explore. Sky islands with skylines was tons of fun. Also gunplay wasn’t so obnoxious. As you essentially could pick between plenty of weapons that you like the most and upgrade them. Plus boost your choice of gunplay with gear and abilities. By the end I rolled with rifle and RPG with projectile shield and crows as ability. Damn crows were OP, they essentially disabled the whole arena, especially once you get upgrades for it. Another thing that made gunplay more fun is that you didn’t have to constantly switch between weapons as you got plenty of ammo and with gear could get even more. Previous bioshock stories were maybe more “realistic” in a sense… had sense of mystery.. but this was simply purer form of entertainment. There were fun twists, eccentric elements and more straightforward premise.
As for DLCs there is challenge mode I couldn’t be bothered and story DLC of different parallel world. In story DLC we back to aquatic world sadly…. And ammo became cancer again. I ran out of ammo so often that were forced to melee shit… Also think I liked this Elizabeth the most, she hot.
Part 2 intro was, interesting for sure I guess for lelz? Lockpicking minigames, going through vents, sneak killing enemies, using enemies against each other is essentially part 2.
Part 1 of DLC focuses on action/gunplay, part 2 focuses on stealth

Bioshock Infinite is a worthy successor to the original Bioshock. It has many of the same mechanics but is a completely new experience with its on unique characters, story/plot, setting etc. The graphics even today in 2022 are beautiful, it spots a lot of high resolution textures and unique models in the world which make it feel unique and believable. The gunplay is satisfying and the freedom to move across rails and leap from great heights gives the combat a fluid and dynamic feel. What steals the show is the first ever competent NPC I think we've ever seen in a FPS, Elizabeth. They've managed to make sure she doesn't block your movement, she intuitively stays near you either ahead or behind but never blocks your path, she alerts you to items in your area and in combat will even seek out things you need and throw them to you, they truly set a new standard for NPC design in this game. The story is intruiging, it keeps you constantly interested with a cast of eccentric characters and balances the pacing of story and combat extremely well.

Even if you just want a dumb FPS shooter to blast people and don't care about any of the above, you'll still not be disappointed, this game is solid in every way and you should definitely buy it.
Yes

I am torn on this game. I have limited expeirence with these games as I only played Bioshock 1 on ps3 YEARS ago, and only a few hours of System Shock 2. It could've been something far better, judging by what we got in those older trailers. While I did enjoy playing it, it fell flat in certain areas. Not just that, but it was hyped to infinity back in 2012-2013. could not even go one commercial break on TV without that "beast of America" ad playing.

_________________________________________________________________________________

Here's what I liked;

The atmosphere.

Columbia is a fabulous world with such amazing architecture and soul. The whole turn of the century look is one of my favorite things out there so to see it so realized in video game form is quite amusing.

The main characters

I absolutely loved Booker and Liz's dynamic. Specifically at Battleship Bay and the rescue in Monument island

The Music

All those song remakes were fun to listen to, and a personal favorite of mine is the OST that plays when songbird first pursues you.

The animations

I liked the weird animations that would play whenever you'd drink a plasmid and it starts messing up your body.
_________________________________________________________________________________

Here's what I disliked;

Many plot elements.

Multiverse as always is a finicky concept as best to work with in a plot, but it's just all the more odd here.

Combat

It literally feels like a COD game where you can only use 2 firearms at any one time. The game feels like it's trying to appeal to a greater audience and while I don't dislike COD, it doesn't work in this series. Along with that, the hook being confined to a button instead of being it's own individual weapon slot is annoying too.

Lady comstock boss fights

Need I say more? It was more annoying than most other bosses I've fought before and went on too long.

Too Linear

Compare it from System Shock 1 all the way to Bioshock 2, the overworld in this game feels more like connected paths you follow and not as open ended, so despite taking place in the endless sky, it manages to feel more confining than the halls of rapture or the citadel.

180's

From columbia being seen as a nice gorgeous and wondrous spectacle of a city with citizens being kind to each other, to then be shown right AFTER the raffle as a corrupt xenophobic culture chock full of unsubtle propaganda and many citizens making rude comments towards everything came off as weird, especially since there were pretty much 0 signs of it prior to the raffle.
along with that, Daisy becoming a child killer out of nowhere and the Vox turning on you was just dumb. "both sides are bad" never works in these types of situations, the plot was just asking for more melodrama at that point. It's even dumber because no more than 1 map earlier, you and the Vox were allied with each other.

The ending.

Perhaps it was "2deep4me" or I just didn't get it but that was one of the strangest endings I've ever seen.

_________________________________________________________________________________

I am a 58 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing Bioshock Infinite. I am a single father to my Son. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 25 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching some tiktok videos. So i decided to get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me so many happy memories.

So, i played Bioshock 1, 2, and Infinite all within the span of like a week, working on all of the achievements for each game so i could experience everything this series has to offer.

++ Bioshock: Infinite as a standalone was a really fun game, the change of scenery, as well as the changes to how the combat works and plasmids are dished out, called "Vigors" in this installation of the series. This series always provides such an interesting look into different time periods and putting them into such fantastic scenarios. However considering the game by itself, i still believe that the first two games offered more in exploration, combat, and general action. I LOVED using the rails around Columbia to get around and gain an advantage over my enemies, but i was a little disappointed in they ways they used the rails, they were super cool, and i loved them, but i think they probably could've utilized them a little better.

++ Bioshock: Infinite alongside its DLC, Burial at Sea, was the best experience I've had. It wrapped up most, if not all of the loose ends of the series, and provided tons of interesting ways that the series could continue. With all of the scenery changes, game play changes, in tandem with all of the new content that Infinite already offered, was seriously cool and i loved every second of it. Including the DLC, Infinite takes the cake as my favorite Bioshock game. It was emotional, it was beautiful, and it was fun.

++ The game was gorgeous, the visuals were breathtaking, playing this game on an ultra wide monitor was an incredibly cinematic experience, it was like i was playing a part in an action film.

++ The Clash in the Clouds, blue ribbon challenges were one of the hardest, but most exciting challenges i had to complete.
they were hard, they were time consuming, they really could've benefited from a checkpoint system, but i learned so much in unique ways to utilize the weapons and powers in Bioshock: Infinite, that i couldn't help but come out of the experience super pumped and with a great sense of accomplishment.

++ Bioshock is always very honest in its telling of different eras in our time, sometimes this leads to some uncomfortable topics being brought up in the story of Bioshock. To me, these moments are welcome, they help add realism to the incredible storytelling of this series, and i respect the developers refusal to shy away from harsh facts of American history.

-- The crashing issue that i noticed in the past 2 Bioshock remasters, is still prevalent in Bioshock: Infinite. However, i will say that i crashed the least in this game, i also lost the least amount of progress from crashes in this game compared to the other two. This is still my biggest complaint of the series, these crashes were the only real issue i had when playing them all.

-- I was really disappointed in how the hacking system has fallen apart through the series, in Bioshock 1, the hacking was challenging, but fun. In Bioshock 2, the hacking system was made so much simpler and easier, to the point that it was almost too easy, but i was happy that i could still hack things to my advantage. In Bioshock: Infinite however, the hacking system was reduced down to just a vigor that's much harder to predict and control than hacking. I think this would've been an awesome change if they included the hacking and possession abilities together, kind of like they did in the past, but with hacking pretty much gone i was sad to see it.

OVERALL ++ Playing through the Bioshock series from start to finish, including all of the DLC and challenge maps, completing all of the achievements along the way, was INCREDIBLE. The storytelling between the games was all mostly linear, and i finished the series with very little questions, and a lot of answers. Despite the crashing issues across all of the games, i still, loved every second. Bioshock is an awesome example of a fun, classic feeling game, there was never a point where i felt overly bored or frustrated. I recommend this series 100% to anyone that enjoys a good ole fashioned beat em up shooter.

[h1]BioShock Infinite[/h1]
[b]BioShock Infinite[/b] is the third title in the successful franchise from [b]2K Games[/b]. Bringing a proposal to change the setting of the series and evolution of the gaming experience, Infinite features a complex and intelligent plot, incredible graphics and renewed gameplay.

[h1]From the bottom of the sea to the top of the clouds[/h1]
BioShock Infinite's first scene pretty much sums up the game's stance towards its two predecessors. The new protagonist, agent [b]Booker DeWitt[/b], appears in a small boat in the middle of the sea and heads towards a kind of launch capsule, which projects him to the heights, taking him to Columbia, a floating city. The metaphor of leaving the ocean and heading for the sky is quite clear and shows both a willingness to change and respect for what has already been done in [b]BioShock[/b] and [b]BioShock 2[/b].

Throughout the game it is possible to notice that the heavy atmosphere of the claustrophobic corridors of Rapture has been left behind, giving way to the bright and bright Columbia. Gradually the curious city reveals its secrets to us through the eyes of the character DeWitt, who represented another change in the series. Booker breaks the silence of the former protagonists and actively participates in the game's dialogue, showing his strong personality.

[h1]Exciting and refined gameplay[/h1]
Initially the impression is that the gameplay is practically unchanged in [b]BioShock Infinite[/b]. The firearms, the powers, the items scattered all over the place, the radio messages, the health and energy bars, everything is present. However, with the arrival of Elizabeth in the plot, the real changes present themselves, and please.

Just before finding [b]Elizabeth[/b], [b]DeWitt[/b] gets into a mess and soon we realize he can only carry two guns at a time. The change may seem punitive, but it actually ends up contributing to the dynamics of the game. It will no longer be possible to choose your three or four favorite weapons and play from start to finish with them. You'll have to adapt to the game's various challenges and make smart choices about which weapons to carry with you. For example, in a part of the story with distance shooting, it doesn't make sense to have a shotgun, but a grenade launcher or a rifle for long distances. The novelty forces the player to 'make do' with weapons that he doesn't master so well, needing to improvise to keep Booker alive.

The great innovations are presented with the arrival of [b]Elizabeth[/b] in the plot. Fortunately, the character doesn't do the 'helpless damsel in distress' type and doesn't need to be saved every fight. In fact, it's Elizabeth who helps us in times of need, whether it's looking for extra ammo, warning of the arrival of enemies or using her special ability. Elizabeth is able to open portals that warp time and space and can bring entire objects from other realities into the battlefield, like an automated balloon that shoots her enemies.

[h1]Improved death/rebirth system.[/h1]
Unlike the other BioShocks, in which the player was respawned with what was left of ammo and energy (Eve), in Infinite you return (again with the help of Elizabeth) with the resources you had before the last fight started. In this way, it is possible to rethink your strategy and start practically from scratch, instead of simply fighting with what's left of the last beating you took in the game.

A factor that also deserves to be mentioned is the rail system. Using a hand hook (which also serves as a weapon) it is possible to travel at high speed along the Columbia rails, reaching higher places and surprising enemies from above. The mechanism adds a lot of agility to the game's combat and serves as a different way to explore the scenario, avoiding the long walks of [b]BioShock[/b] and [b]BioShock 2[/b].

[b]The skills are very interesting, such as the powerful crows and the fun power of levitating enemies, and the equipment works automatically, you just have to choose the effects that you like the most. In addition, the Big Daddy and Big Sister leave the scene, and the Handymen, the Patriots, the Incendiaries, the gigantic Songbird and others enter. To make it a little more difficult, most of them are immune to some ability (Igniters are not affected by Devil's Kiss bombs, for example).[/b]

The increase in the variety of mini-bosses forces you to prioritize your targets better during combat, taking down the ones that pose the most danger first, since throughout the game they tend to appear in packs.

[h1]Parallel worlds and many questions to be answered[/h1]
The story of BioShock Infinite takes place before the events of the first BioShock. The plot brings some well-known elements of the franchise, such as the protagonist initially without a past and the theme of dystopia, represented by the decay of a society full of fanatical followers led by a tyrant. In Infinite the story revolves around three axes, the pasts of DeWitt and Elizabeth and the history of the mysterious city, Columbia. Add to that the maiden's power to alter reality and the result is a complex web that links parallel universes that converge on a main plot.

[b]Patriarch Comstock represents the authoritarian leader of Columbia and fights the rebel group Vox Populi, led by activist Fitzroy. Both sides have their share of followers who fight each other, turning Columbia into a floating battleground. However, when traveling between the different realities through Elizabeth's power, it is possible to see different versions of the story, in which the roles are reversed. Therefore, there is not a villain and a good guy, but there is meaning in the plot, which is gradually revealed with the twists and discoveries of the characters.[/b]

Being one of BioShock Infinite's strongest points, the story is dense and well-crafted, with revelations well distributed throughout the campaign, which keeps the
 our high interest during game hours. In this way, Infinite will appeal to you who are looking for more than just shooting in a game.

[h1]Columbia delights in every detail[/h1]
BioShock Infinite's graphics and sound are simply impeccable. The city of Columbia is stunning in every detail, be it the lighting, the richness of objects in the scene or the fluid movement of the characters. It all demonstrates great dedication and care from the game's development team. In addition, the city seems to have a life of its own. In a square, for example, people walk and talk aloud, and not just when you approach and click on characters. DeWitt and Elizabeth are also communicative and initiate conversations with others spontaneously, without our intervention. All this helps in the immersion experience provided by the game.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
[b]BioShock Infinite[/b] brings the innovations we wanted to see in [b]BioShock 2[/b] and surprises us by taking the franchise to a new and higher level of quality. The presence of the character Elizabeth is one of the great successes of the game, allowing a fluid interaction with the protagonist both in the complex and intelligent story, as in the frantic combats. The graphics are another asset of Infinite, with impeccable lighting, detail levels and movement.

Bioshock series is well known for its amazing visuals, its great game direction, voice acting and atmosphere.
I have played all 3 and I consider the 3rd to be the worse. They all had their problems but I could not enjoy the 3rd instalment. 

Overall the game is too easy, it won't let you choose the hardest difficulty from the start and the hard setting can be cleared even by a monkey. Hard is supposed to be hard, period.
Ammo is literally unlimited, never had to buy any at all. The shield is busted, all you have to do is take cover until it regenerates and carry on killing enemies by said tactic from afar. In very few instances you get forced to play close and if so you have some overpowered builds with charge and so on. It reminds me of Tomb raider where I had to drop since it literally was holding my hand. If you like Uncharted/Tomb Raider holding hand difficulty Bioshock Infinite is the same. Not my cup of tea. 

At least you don't have to solve these annoying puzzles like BS1 and the turrets are way less (DLC included).
Also, I find it frustrating that you have to keep spamming interact to collect the overabundant items hidden all over the place. This game style hasn't been fixed since the BS1 and I mean fixed because I find hard to believe that anyone enjoys collecting 5 different items repeatedly on small area spaces.

On the dlc Elizabeth tends to bodyblock you a lot. On an instance she bodyblocked me while I was crouching waiting to ambush 2 enemies. Had to jump to get out revealing myself and dying...

I hope if BS4 is a thing, that the overall gameplay is improved.

I am a huge fan of the Bioshock series, so when this game was announced I watched every single update, trailer, sneak peek, demo and leak. The beta game footage in the trailers was incredible, so i preordered the game and waited anxiously for the game to come out.
but, little did I know that most of the interesting mechanics and cool setpieces that I saw in the trailers had been stripped out of the game. not only that but [spoiler] the story starts to get really bad halfway through, when Booker and Elizabeth travel to a parallel universe, and the ending sucks, seriously it makes no sense, the games writer does NOT understand quantum physics [/spoiler] those problems with the story were probably caused by the numerous rewrites and redesigns that the game had.
but, beyond my disappointment, the gameplay we were left with is all right. it was good enough that i played it a couple times even before it got the DLC. the visuals are really good for the time it came out, and they hold up  well because of the stylized character designs.
The first DLC was Really good. it actually fixed most of the problems I had with the main games gameplay and some of the problems I had with the story. but the second DLC wasn't as good. it ruined a lot of the story improvements from the first DLC and it spoiled and retconed the first game in the series. still, it was cool seeing the characters from the first Bioshock in HD, but the way they disregard the lore from the second game in the DLCs was also really disappointing.
I'd recommend you get the game only if its on sale, and only if you've already played the first game, because of the spoilers in the DLC.

Not as good as the first two games, but still pretty good.

Developers made a few steps back from Bioshock 2, end even the first one.
The biggest one is a 2 weapons limit. This forces players to unnecessarily choose between weapons while in the previous games we could have sizeable arsenals at all time. At one point it really hurts the experience. Without spoilers, there is this one enemy that is a major bullet sponge. A few extra guns would really make a world of difference.
The ending is pretty out there, even for Bioshock standards. I wasn't fully satisfied with how the game ended. It, and the final boss fight felt rushed. All of those things drag the game down a notch or two below B1 and B2 (yes, I'm saying it: Bioshock 2 is better than Inifinite, in both story and game play :D).

All the above aside, this is still a great game, well worth playing. While the ending may not fully deliver, it's not out right bad. And for the most part the story is quite fun to follow. I also like the characters, especially Elizabeth. She is very well written and portrayed during the game. Also, as AI managed companions go, she is quite useful in fights :). Her mid-to-late game ability is really fun to use. Too bad it's limited to scripted locations.

I also very much like the setting. Rapture is awesome, iconic underwater city, but to me personally Columbia, a city in the sky, beats it hands down. It's an outlandish idea (what isn't in Bioshock games). But it also looks so damn epic. Great place to have an out there story like this one.

On the technical side everything was fine. It's an older game now, so don't expect visual fireworks. Still, the graphics holds down quite well. I don't remember any technical issues, nothing of the sort bothered me during my playthrough.

I don't think Bioshock Infinite is a bad game and if Steam had a middle of the road option for its reviews, I would pick that, but here we go:

The gameplay changes a LOT from Bioshock 1 and 2, and not for the better. While the shooting itself feels a more crisp, the aspect of resource management from the first two games is completely gone. Instead of having a health bar with medkits, you just have one massive health bar and restorative items are used immediately upon picking them up. The game showers you with ammo, meaning you don't really need to think about how you're using it. This also means that money is pointless except for buying the major upgrades for your guns and vigors. There's also a new shield mechanic that works the same as Halo, except it's pretty pointless as it barely blocks anything. The vigors (which are the replacement for plasmids from the first two games) just aren't as fun or creative as the plasmids from the first two games, as I don't feel like I need to use them creatively. Additionally, the basic enemies are just a huge downgrade from what we had previously. Splicers in the older titles were aggressive and had good AI, while the soldiers in Bioshock Infinite feel more like braindead mooks from a Call of Duty campaign. Honestly, a whole squad of soldiers in this game is less threatening than a single splicer from Bioshock 1 and 2. As such, the game really isn't challenging until nearly the end of the game (and I was playing on Hard BTW). Level design is also a lot more linear with not much opportunity to explore off the beaten path.

It's not all bad though. While the basic soldiers are boring, when the game throws special enemies at you, they are fun to fight. The automatons, patriots, handymen, and firemen are all fun to fight. The combat also flows fairly well. I also enjoy the sky hook mechanic, which adds a cool dynamic to fights. The tear mechanic adds a hint of strategy to the game, allowing youu to make choices such as sky hook points for faster traversal, extra weapons and restorative items, friendly machines to fight alongside you, etc.

Then there's the story. There are some things I love about it. The city of Columbia is a really interesting setting that I absolutely adore. Another high point are the characters, who are interesting and well written, and I especially love the dynamic between Booker Dewitt and Elizabeth. However, the actual plot is a complete mess. it pulls in way too many directions at once, trying to focus on many things but succeeding at virtually none of them, and it only gets more confusing the longer it goes on. After beating it, I had to look up explanations on the internet just to [strike]enjoy[/strike] understand what was going on, and even then I'm still having trouble wrapping my head around it, mostly because about halfway through the game, they decided to bring in multiple universes into the plot for some reason. Also, besides one throwaway scene of absolutely no significance, this game does not connect to the other games in a meaningful way.

TL;DR: Bioshock Infinite takes many steps back from its predecessors in terms of gameplay and story, but it's not entirely bad, as I enjoyed it enough to actually beat the game. I'd say get it on sale if you're interested, but don't expect it to be as good as the first two games.

I just want to precede this by saying that I went into this game completely blind, knowing nothing aside the "city in the clouds" bit, and I suggest you do too. Don't read this review. Go play it. I'm not going to directly compare it to either of the previous games because it's so different, but if I had to make a bold statement, I think it's the best of the series, I have almost as many hours in it as in the first two combined, and the fact that I replayed it at all, when I had little inclination to replay either of the first two, should speak volumes. Bioshock Infinite is fucking awesome. 



Note: I beat the game once on Hard, went through and played through the DLCs on Hard, then went back and beat the main story again in 1999 Mode -- the only major achievement I didn't do was to revisit Burial at Sea: Episode 2 in 1998 Mode.

The beginning is probably the best opening sequence I've ever played. The first few minutes are weird and mysterious, with a very similar style to the first game, as you arrive at a lighthouse with ominous religious phrases inside. You land in what seems to be a church, and soon enough, from there you enter the city of Columbia.

At this point I saw that this is the most visually impressive game I've ever played. The graphics and art style fit perfectly together, and your entrance into Columbia is magical. There's a fair bustling around you, full of exhibits to see and minigames to play. Since Infinite starts as a walking simulator, I was practically spamming Alt so that I could walk through it as slowly as possible. (Though, "spamming" partly because Walk doesn't like to stick for some reason.) I easily spent an hour just taking it all in. The citizens are having all their side conversations, and there are references to things that seem important ⁠— "Vox Populi", and "False Shepherd", for example ⁠— but they're just mentioned, not exposited upon, leaving you to wonder. These are just subtle hints that there is something more than meets the eye to this place. Once the sinister underbelly truly reveals itself, the real game begins hitting the ground running: you are the prophesized False Shepherd, and the (racist) society of Columbia wants you dead. (Well, the police do. Most of the civilians just poof into thin air, which is a bit odd.)

Before I continue talking about the story, let's talk gameplay. Infinite takes quite a turn from the previous games in that it's mostly linear. You could argue that this is a downgrade from the more sprawling, exploratory gameplay of the first games, but let's be real, the main difference is whether the linearity is hidden or not. Personally, I didn't mind Infinite's approach, and it's refreshing in a way — this game dares to stray from the "BioShock formula."

Instead of plasmids, you're now equipped with vigors, and the weapon control scheme is much like BioShock 2, with the one caveat that you can only hold two guns at a time now. Personally, I actually think this an improvement. When you have seven weapons available at once, it feels like bad game design if you're using one almost exclusively. Infinite accepts that weapons are not created equal, and if you don't want a weapon, you don't have to ever use it, allowing you to tune your loadout to your playstyle. Yet, at the same time, when ammo is scarce, it forces you to take risks, to switch weapons mid-battle and adapt on the fly. (Also, I do think gunplay overall is better than the first two games.) On the other hand, you still have access to all vigors all the time (though I didn't notice this for a few hours). I didn't end up using Devil's Kiss or Murder of Crows frequently, but most everything else I found distinct uses for. Although fundamentally some of them are reskins of familiar plasmids, things like Undertow and Return to Sender add new, fairly deep mechanics. When I played through in 1999 Mode, I gained a real appreciation for Bucking Bronco, Undertow, and Return to Sender, and figuring out how to use these vigors properly gave me a huge edge in combat. 

Zooming out a bit, I would say combat is overall the most polished of the series. Yes, I do miss Big Daddy and Big Sister fights in a way, there's no longer any element of a terrifying, roaming mini-boss, and no, Motorized Patriots and Handymen are nowhere near as interesting, neither as enemies nor lore-wise. Yes, most of the human enemies are kind of same-y, though Infinite's enemies are generally an improvement over splicers in that they use the full spectrum of weapons. What makes Infinite unique is that it has frantic, high-octane combat, which it leans into mechanically, and to that end it has Tears and the Sky-Hook. Elizabeth's Tears make the battlefield dynamic, and require on-the-fly thinking to harness to their full potential. You can have a freight hook, [b]or[/b] you can have a turret to help, [b]or[/b] you can have health and ammo supplies: pick one. But then a few seconds later, you can pick another, and so on. It forces you to constantly assess your position and the positions of the enemies. With the Sky-Hook you can use freight hooks and the Sky-Line, which really add to the verticality and mobility to combat, respectively. But, you're vulnerable when using them, so there's added strategy there.

Some miscellaneous criticisms:
- There's not many civilian player models, and sometimes you can see a whole group of people with the same model in one place. It's uncanny.
- When you grab onto a hook or Skyline, the camera has to settle in a certain direction before you're allowed to move it again. It's kind of annoying.
- Enemy visibility can be a bit tricky sometimes, soldiers' colors don't always stand out.
- Some dialogue is bugged and two characters will talk at once during important scenes.
- [spoiler]The Boys of Silence are just cameras and have nothing to do with silence. I realize this is due to development hell, but still, silence-based stealth would have made more sense.[/spoiler]

It's about time that I mention that [b]Elizabeth is absolutely the pinnacle achievement of this game. This is how to do a companion[/b]. With a Disney princess-like "girl in the tower" backstory, she has exactly the personality to fit. Her voice acting and mo-cap are fantastic; she walks around the environment looking at things like newspapers; she makes small talk; she points out items for you; she opens Tears; she picks locks; she throws you ammo, salts, and health kits during combat, apologizing if she can't find anything... I could go on, but she actually seems like [b]a person[/b]. Most importantly, [i]Elizabeth will actually copy your movement speed[/i]! Hallelujah. Also, the [spoiler]"Will the Circle Be Unbroken" scene in Shantytown[/spoiler] is a highlight for me.

My second favorite character(s) would have to be the Luteces. With sarcastic, absurdist dialogue straight out of "Rosencrantz and Guildenstern Are Dead," accompanied by their distinct accordion tune, they're both comic relief, yet genuinely important characters, [spoiler]seeing as how they're the masterminds behind basically the entire game[/spoiler].

I'm almost out of space and there's many things I haven't talked about, but the last thing I really want to mention is the ending. I think it's awesome and it actually works. Major spoilers. [spoiler]The first time I beat it, seeing everything fall into place, I was basically frozen in my seat with my mouth hanging open. That final piano note gave me chills. It's a ton to process, but it ties up nearly all of the plot holes. I defer to this video that I think explains it mostly well: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MhjKW1S1xvk.[/spoiler]

I'm not sure what sold critics on this game when it came out, or my teenage self playing this for the first time. Or perhaps its troubled and controversial development that made people love this game, because I truly do not. There is no system or alternative play styles that you can employ, like in Bioshock 1 or 2. Whether it be the lack of weapons you can use, the basic vigors, or the infamous 2 weapons at a time system, this game went from a visually impressive splendor, to a mind numbing chore. In terms of its story, it has interesting characters and dialogue but its plot twist hinders it from having meaningful closure with the story apart from trying to shock you. I just wish this game did its setting, aesthetic and characters justice. I would give it perhaps a 5.8/10.

Bioshock Infinite a bad game. Alright, pack it up, we did it. Its the final entry of the Bioshock franchise, which i honestly think is one of the WAAY better immersive sims to come out back then. But uh.. you saw the thumb. This will be split into 5 sections instead of a really cluttered essay.


1. THE GAMEPLAY

The gameplay is really bad. It also feels way more streamlined than bioshock. Many mechanics were added in with no rhyme or reason besides "They were in the last two", or "They were in the popular games" and if thats the choice they wanted, why change the gameplay so much? Lets address the call of duty sized elephant- There is a fucking sprint button. Now, do i think this is inherently a bad change? No, a sprint can still work. But do i think its a good change for the bioshock  franchise? No, because the last two bioshock games were designed to make you feel disempowered to some extent. You had to creep around, using your most disposable weapons no matter what so you didnt face an encounter with your worst gun. It makes the game less of a careful immersive simulator, and more like a "get shot, shoot more back" game. 


2. THE GAMEPLAY (PART 2)

My main problem with it is the lack of weapons. Since this released in the same year as COD: Ghosts, you have only two weapons on your person. Yet for some reason, they KEPT the upgrade system. That doesnt work since your wasting hard earned money (yes, no more adam and regular cash, you get your vigors, upgrades, everything with money.) on something that will be unuseable by the next level. This gets worse during the vox period where you get reskinned versions of the same weapons you upgraded, but they dont HAVE those upgrades. Why make a upgrade system if you arent gonna give it a weapon wheel of sorts where you hold all your weapons? In Bioshock, you  would upgrade your gear so you could use your best weapons when you needed them. You bought different types of ammo for your proximity mine launcher to take on a big daddy for adam easier. In Bioshock 2, you would upgrade your gear to become a weapon of mass destruction. In Bioshock Infinite, you would upgrade your gear just to be told off when you wanted to keep using the weapon you paid to be stronger.


3. THE GAMEPLAY (PART 3)

Now then, since this is a streamlined call of duty clone- i mean bioshock game, they had to make it so they wouldnt be sued for the game being so difficult a 7 year old would toss there xbox controller at the wall and it bounces back and breaks there skull. So, they introduced Elizabeth, a plot important character as she can open "tears" into different realities or points in time. But the intresting thing is that this is a game mechanic, and not JUST a plot point. Meaning that she can make tears for cover, ammo, weapons, health, freight hooks, turrets, even patriots! She can also "scavenge" (stand behind a piece of cover and do nothing)  for guns, weapons, and money, and even health if your low on it! She is quite litterally, just a glorified assist mode.


4. THE STORY (light tread on it)

The story has two sides, one side of the coin is this timeline altering, marvel style quantum physics, and other random stuff. The other side is so miniscule and worthless that if you flip a coin and it lands on this, you transform into a white writer instantly. The side i wanna talk about is the racism side. It doesnt have anything deep about it because they do NOTHING WITH IT. Only thing they do with it is shove imagery down your throat and OH LOOK OH MY GOD ITS A BLACK GUY ON HIS KNEES SHINING SHOES OR CLEANING SOMETHING! WOOOOAH! Now, im not going to say that racism isnt something to cover in media, but its just distasteful to do THIS with it. Also, a large portion of the story can be described with the grandfather paradox. Basically, if you went into the past to kill your grandfather, you would be unable to exist since in the future, you killed your grandfather, but since you dont exist, how could  you kill your grandfather in the first place? Its very weird.


5. CONCLUSION 

Overall, Bioshock infinite is a mediocre video game, and a terrible bioshock game. Everything about it feels copied from a different game  without any thought about what it would do to the other parts of the game. Its story is weak and forgettable (had to read the wiki to remember it), It has shallow undertones of racism, and its gameplay is thoughtless and feels less like a bioshock game, and feels like it'd fit better as a replacement to call of duty ghosts.

Like the original Bioshock, this game has an incredibly imaginative story and richly detailed environment, but this time it all takes place in the airborne city of Columbia in 1912. The action is significantly better than the original Bioshock, but once again I felt like the biggest motivation for playing this game was to further explore the city and uncover the next plot point in the amazing story. And just as it was with the first Bioshock, the climax and finale are exceptional. As for the optional DLC, the first Burial at Sea episode is good and the second is excellent.

This is my second review after finishing my 2nd walkthrough with 1999 Mode.

This time around I took my leisure to explore around gathering lockpicks and loots because I know each time you die in 1999 mode you'll lose 100$ so I stacked my greens as much as I can, upgrade only the weapons that I'll be using most of the time, and it helps a lot. My tips for you, if you're going to play in 1999 mode, be conservative on your spending and don't afraid to invest upgrade in only 2-3 weapons, since Ammo cost is cheap anyway so you just need to find circus of values to restock all the ammo.

Is it hard? damn right it is (not really), often times it feels unfair and you are always fighting against the odds, enemies are a lot stronger, when you die, enemy health return to full (yes, the boss health will return to normal when you re-spawn), so I depended a lot to a shotgun in close combat and sniping enemies from afar (since if you try to melee and get melee-d by enemy instead, your shield is instantly broke)--the final fight is the greatest pain in the ass because you literally have to become one man army to defeat wave after wave after wave of enemies with often without salt stock and wondering are your weapon even do damage the enemies at all (despite shooting right in their faces), I'm losing my mind because one time, when I got out a the room setting up my defenses and like entire country shooting at me from every direction. 

You have to find your play style and adapt to fight certain enemies that will not be affected by your current play style and look into their weaknesses to beat them. I strongly advise to use and upgrade sniper, and if you good at landing head-shots it will helps a lot to lessen the enemies count before you're facing them head to head (especially those annoying fireman and the likes of them, they can be killed with one head-shot but took forever to kill if you shoot them in the body).

In the end, I come to appreciate even more the work that developer has worked on the game, I explored the nooks and cranny of Columbia each level, enjoyed every single details that I found in the game. Thank you, Irrational Games and 2K, this is a lifetime experience, and I feel bad because I can't just erase my memory and play this game again without knowing anything like the first time.

This was my very first Bioshock game that I've ever played. I had gotten the game for free back in the day when the Xbox 360 was still relevant. When I first played it, I really didn't have any expectations going into my play through on the Xbox 360. I had only known about Bioshock 1 & 2 through internet reviews and media outlets at the time but had never came around to play neither of them until recently. When I finished Infinite for the first time the story had mind fucked me so hard as a 14 year old kid in 8th Grade that I was mentally affected for two days. The one thing that I still remembered after 7 years since my last play through (besides the ending) was that the outside world of Columbia was so damn mesmerizing and beautiful for its time of release. I'm always surprised to see that it wasn't received as well as I would have expected back then but I guess I was just so enthralled in the story and world that what many consider to be average gameplay didn't deter me at all- I just so deeply yearned for answers at the time. After playing through the remasters and finishing them completely, I only had infinite left to play. I was so excited to play infinite because even though I had only completed it once on the 360, I felt like since I had gotten older and had now played Bioshock 1 & 2 that I would finally get the full picture. After all those years the game really gave me that same feeling It did when I had first played it back when I was middle school. The atmosphere, the story telling, and the graphics is still great and it felt like I was 14 all over again. After finishing infinite and the Burial At Sea DLC, I can now say that infinite (In My Opinion) is the best in the trilogy. Infinite will always have a special place in my heart and is one of the few games to ever make me cry like a baby after finishing the Burial At Sea DLC. I highly recommend this game to anyone and I also recommend Playing thru Bioshock 1 & 2 if you plan on getting the Burial At Sea DLC(that it makes sense to you).

The third and most recent game in the BioShock series. I recommend playing the other two first, though it seems a commonality for a lot of players of this game was that this was their first game of the series. It's a good game however there are some features in the game that make it more difficult than it needs to be (only operating on autosaves, only being able to have two out of the ten weapon choices in the game at any one time). However, this game has the best graphics in the series, and the characters are very lively. The gameplay is fun and the combat, despite it's occasional limits, feels fresh and refined. The fundamentals are still there and as the first two games did, this game has a lot to say about society. Though it might be my least favourite in the series (until where I am, anyway), that's not saying much, as it's still an amazing game. 9/10, with potential to increase by the time I'm actually done the game.

BIOSHOCK: INFINITE

Bioshock, one of the greatest series EVER, unrivaled in unique First person horror Shooter with an excellent story narrative and progression / Atmosphere.

You, Booker DeWitt, the false Shepard.. the Tin Man.. play this incredible story out from start to finish, I can't tell you a single goddamn thing.. it will ruin this for you.

10/10 - the very best trilogy in gaming history in my opinion, I beat these game multiple times each, tons of Replayability.

UPDATE

Burial at Sea 1 & 2 playthrough review

Ok, I completed both expansions for infinite and I honestly have to say.. it felt very different from the base game without being different if you can catch what I'm saying...

B@S 1 - very short, maybe 2 hours long so all the  cool vigor upgrades are useless because you will have beaten it before you even get to figure out a play style you like.. ammo is slashed big time and you can be killed in 2 or 3 shots on normal difficulty.. very weird feeling but still unique and fresh, you find a new weapon called the radar which can cook and explode enemies from a far, pretty fun actually. The ending very a bit surprising but left me completely confused till I started the second expansion.

B@S 2 - so you just got the feel for the first expansion which changes things around quite a bit eh.. well, unfortunately part 2 changes the game play style up again, right click no longer iron sights but shoots your vigor, you get completely new vigors and thie biggest addition has you play as elizabeth.. she has to use stealth or will die very easily, you can now use small vents.. its very different put it that way.

All three games feel different which.. is an off thing to do, they should have just made a stand alone spin-off for Elizabeth instead of DLC that does not feel like the base game.

I liked several aspects of this game, but I think if we're looking at the BioShock trilogy as a whole, this is the weakest entry.  The reason I say that is all due to story which is probably the most important aspect of a BioShock game.  Let me start with the positives first though.  Graphically I think this game still looks really good, even though it's nearly a decade old at this point.  The setting is unique and a historical time period that's barely ever touched upon in gaming.  Playing on Linux I can say that it and BioShock 2 were far more stable than the first game.  I can't even remember ever once having the game crash on me.  Having said that, I did have to disable the opening logo movies to get it to launch.  Other than that, no major technical hurdles to overcome.  I raised the UI font since it was a bit small to read on a 1080p display, but that's more personal preference really.  I think the characters in this game were well developed and not all despicable like in BioShock 2.  Though the ones that were bad were REALLY bad.  Hehe.

Gameplay wise this game is a bit of a mixed bag.  It feels like a step back compared to the two other entries especially being limited to two weapons at a time only.  Even the developers thought this was the case as they changed that in the Buried at Sea DLCs.  The vigors are pretty decent, but I don't think they have the same impact as the plasmids.  BioShock 2 had the best plasmid system by far.  I'm not a big fan of the whole needing money to resurrect aspect either.  I know there were the vita-chambers in the previous games which were similar, but I played through both of the games with those disabled.  This game?  It's designed where you ARE going to die, but the guys you killed don't come back.

And this may be the more controversial aspect of my review, but the story falls apart about halfway through the game.  Maybe they could have made the whole multiverse idea work somehow, but then they decided to mix that with time travel and I HATE time travel.  Having said that, you can't really mix both of those concepts and have the idea work.  In fact, the whole twist of the game happens at the very end and it just falls flat on its face.  I understand they wanted to give a shock to the player like in the first game, but it just doesn't work.  The first two games didn't use either of those concepts and they're stronger from a narrative perspective for it.  Even the DLC contradicts the time travel stuff.  It's just a mess.  Honestly, I could have looked over all of the other things I mentioned before if the story was strong, but it's not.  It's a shame too because this game had massive potential that just got squandered by a nonsensical plot twist.  Both of the Burial at Sea DLC's had depressing endings too.  It's still a good game and worth your time, but the story severely hurts it.

It's a great game, and it has a great story. I only have minor issues with some mechanics. The Clash in The Clouds DLC sucks if you're trying to get every achievement. It's a set of challenges to kill enemies a certain way, which sounds fun, but if you fail you have to start from the very beginning of the wave if you want a blue ribbon for the achievement. So if you need one of the blue ribbons from wave 14, you have to start from wave 1 and work your way up to wave 14. This makes the process tedious and really annoying. 

My other problem with the game is with Elizabeth in combat. 9 times out 10 she won't give me the item I need, like if I'm low on salts she'll throw me a weapon even if the weapon I am using has a ton of ammo. I found her as a support character quite useless, because if she's not giving me an item I don't need, she's giving me nothing at all. (Thanks Elizabeth, I guess I'll just die!)

Also using the Possession Vigor on more than just a base enemy type is quite useless. Using it on turrets is hit or miss, but in most cases the turrets have the accuracy of a Storm Trooper and enemies take them out in a blink of an eye. Using Possession on a Motorised Patriot makes them look every where but where the action is, and they somehow forget to fire their weapons. It's not very helpful to use Possession on them anyways as you can only utilize them for ten seconds.

Despite my nitpicking (I have other rants like limited buffs in the form of gear. The previous games did buffs a lot better and offered more than four), Bioshock Infinite is game worth playing, and makes me excited for a possible sequel.

It still boggles my mind that this game was so poorly received on release. I can KINDA understand some fans being disappointed that this game is very much an action adventure, in contrast to the franchises horror survival roots, but the fans insistence that this meant that the game was fundamentally BAD or BORING is ridiculous. Infinite is insanely fun, and in my humble opinion, is more fun than the first installment. Oh I enjoy Bio-shock 1 well enough, it's certainly revolutionary for the time, but I have had almost no inclination to pick it up again since finishing it the first time. Infinite on the other hand is incredibly addictive

The gun-play is satisfying, the build variety is surprisingly large for an FPS from 10 years ago (or even today) the vigors are honestly more creative and fun than the original plasmids, and the use of the sky-hook and tears adds a whole new dimension to combat. How this game was ever called TOO HARD also confuses me. Now I'm far from the type of person to say "git gud" or "skill issue" (I rarely play games on difficulties harder than normal) But this game is only actually hard when, well, you play it on the Hard and above difficulty! "the Handy Mans were too difficult!" WHAT?!?!? on normal mode they die in like 5-10 shots depending on your build! yes the game is harder than Bio-Shock 1, but that game is honestly TOO easy. 

But the combat is just one facet of the experience. the steampunk/Art-Nouveau/Neo-Classical/turn-o-the-century aesthetics and architecture are to die for. I know that I'm supposed to hate this place but, like Rapture, I can't help but want to live in the flying towers of Columbia, and the game takes full advantage of the technology of the time to showcase the city in mesmerizing colors and lightnings. Booker and Elizabeth's characters and chemistry also make for a superior game experience over the mute and lonely Jack. Their relationship grows heartwarming and their dialogue witty , without any of the eye roll worthy garbage you hear in many modern movies and games when the writers want to sound "smart" or "relatable" 

Bio-shock Infinite is quite possibly my favorite game, or at least my favorite story driven shooter and I definitely think it will be worth your time, though obviously you should play it AFTER having played at least Bio-shock 1 which usually comes with it in the "collection which always has amazing sales here on steam

This game is really good! I remember a lot of people who played the first two were bitching and moaning about this game, but honestly it's not bad. Elizabeth is an amazing companion and the story is well written, with that Bioshock twist in the end that blew my mind the first time I saw it. The only thing that the other games did better was the gunplay and exploration. Bioshock 2 did that way better. But it's definitely a worthy installment to this series.

The story takes place in the floating city of Columbia, where religious and political influences are at play. You play as Booker Dewitt, a private investigator who also happens to have impressive combat abilities due to the fact he was a soldier prior. He is tasked with retrieving a girl named Elizabeth so that his debts would be wiped away.

This game was definitely a fun experience. There are a variety of skills (called Vigors in the game) that you could unlock by playing through the game. You won't be able to miss any, and all of them have their own distinct uses. Another noteworthy thing is that you could combine the usage of two vigors to create fun and deadly combos. One example would be using Bucking Bronco to make enemies levitate then using Undertow to grab an enemy mid-air to throw them off the edge of the floating city.

The base game's atmosphere is totally different from the previous Bioshock games. The connection between this game and its predecessors doesn't seem to be clear at first, but playing through the DLCs will explain it. Though, I think this game should be a separate game unrelated to the previous games as it takes place in a completely different setting with a new set of characters.

I would recommend playing this game for those interested in a fun shooter game with a decent story. The voice acting and dialogue between characters are top notch as well. Note that playing the first two games isn't really necessary as the main campaign doesn't really reference it much or at all.
this game is a timeless art piece 10/10

Bioshock Infinite is the worst Bioshock game to exist, aside from a few things. I sincerely advise any and all potential buyers of Bioshock Infinite to play the campaigns of the first two games as those actually have reasonable lore and are the definitive games that set the mood for the franchise anyway.
TL;DR: The devs basically said "Let's take our previous two very successful games... And do NONE OF THAT".

Consistent Themes shared by all the games:
1. Play style choice - In all the games, the player is free to make a playstyle for themselves practically on the fly.
2. Entrapment - The first two games involve being underwater, while Infinite involves being high in the sky away from the "sodom" below.
3. Religion - All the games have some religious/anti-religious messaging, portraying things like Christianity as rather cult-like (which I like about the game because I used to be a Christian).
4. Men with too much power - Not much to say here. The protagonist is pretty much tasked with taking down these men.

Offset Themes taken by Bioshock Infinite:
1. Quantum theory - This plays heavily into the game by the end and not only becomes confusing, but (frankly) stupid as it completely differs from the previous two games.
I'd put more here, but I'd be spoiling too much.

All I can say now is that the first two games were more sensible and had dimension, depth and tangibility unlike this one.

If I had to recommend based off of the gameplay alone, I'd still say that the previous two games are better. Bioshock Infinite may have a few neat features that the others didn't have, but they're lazier than the previous two.

Pros:
+ Beautiful aesthetic & setting (Columbia)
+ Elizabeth keeps up & helps in a pinch
+ Tears were enjoyable to experience, whether helpful or entertaining

Cons:
- The settings felt hollow. This extended from the NPCs (not being able to interact with most people) to the level design (many levels felt like a hallway of buildings and not an actual place). It would have been nice for Elizabeth, or anyone, to make small talk not directly related to the plot and to create a more believable world.
- Did you know pressing "O" opens the gameplay menu, allowing you to see your objectives, equip gear, and more? Google told me. If it's mentioned at the beginning of the game, it's mentioned once and never again. Not helpful lol
- The pacing got sluggish near the end. Hoping the game would be finished after the third Siren fight (about 80% complete) was not great.
- The two gun limit. Elizabeth can't hold an extra gun for me?
- Infinite timelines mean an infinite number of potential plot holes / paradoxes.

I'm nearly ten years late to the party, but this game felt like it tried to be too many things at once and absolutely failed. I liked Elizabeth, the gameplay was decent and the graphics were beautiful, but that was it. It isn't a bad game but it felt mediocre, and the story just felt convoluted towards the end.

The biggest problem I had was with how the Vox Populi and Daisy Fitzroy were treated - they were really not handled well, and came across as a case of bad centrism. America is literally a country that had to go through an entire civil war to decide that yes, slavery should be illegal - please don't slap on a "it goes both ways" message on it. The fact that the stark depictions of racism in the beginning went absolutely unresolved makes it seem more of a shock factor than genuine criticism too; I feel like it genuinely would have been better if they just focused on Booker and Elizabeth's story, since the whole thing with the Vox Populi disappears from the second half of the game and they just replace Columbia's police/military as generic baddies. If you can't handle it well, please don't put it in your game.

The main thing that distinguishes BioShock Infinite against the background of most high-profile novelties of recent times is the amazing wholeness and unity of all elements of the game. There is nothing superfluous here - neither the "pasted" RPG-component, nor the far-fetched plot turns. Gameplay, script, graphics, music in synchronic sound create a truly stunning Steampunk atmosphere.

[i]The level designers have done a great job.[/i] [b]The external appearance of Colombia will make the hearts of even the most demanding graphics enthusiasts tremble.[/b] 
[i]Locations are diverse, the scenery throughout the passage constantly changing, each square meter of the city is full of some small details. I want to walk around this world, peering into every corner, listening to all the dialogues of random passers-by, looking through sets of funny pictures in each kinetoscope.[/i]

[h1]My opinion:[/h1] 
Pros: Stunning design; An exciting atmosphere; Interesting story; Images of characters; Dynamic skirmishes; Beautiful Elizabeth.

Cons: Aren't you ashamed to look here!?

Massive fan of the Bioshock franchise and Columbia is one of the most beautiful worlds I have ever explored in gaming. I would absolutely die for a new game exploring this fantastic location. 

I know a lot of people will compare Infinite to Bioshock 1 and 2 however honestly I dont think they deserve comparison at all. The game shares enough of the base mechanics to be a Bioshock game yet is very clearly its own entity at the same time.
The attention to story building and lore is fantastic, the way it slowly transitions from a beautiful metropolis to a ruined creepy city in the sky. The characters and their voice actors are immersive and interesting enough to want to explore more.

In all other games I am someone who skips cut scenes and dialogue but here I was actively seeking out all the additional recordings and interactions.
Its one of very few games where I have watched countless videos of peoples interpretations of the detail of the game within the engaging story line which reveals itself over time. 

It fits a genre that appeals to me, a fast pace action adventure game which has an immersive storyline. This factor alienated the original Bioshock fans as the element of horror and real threat is essentially removed for around 90% of the game. I would encourage everyone to play it.

Bioshock Infinite is a good game but I have mixed feelings about it so I'll just explain my point of view a bit.

When it comes to visuals the game is beautiful and colourful, the city of Columbia is an interesting setting with some creative ideas and it can be mesmerising to simply look at the scenery from time to time. The problem lied in the level design, the exploration wasn't really interesting while it had some decent parts the lack of interactions with the environment rendered the experience a bit bland.

The writing is good, it's story-driven so it's a change of pace from its predecessors but it was well executed even with how convoluted it was. The characters were interesting with the chemistry between Booker and Elizabeth as the best part but the Lucetes were quite entertaining as well. The only problem I have here is the lack of player agency, it feels like a drawback for a Bioshock game. 

Now this is the crux of my problems with Infinite, the gameplay is streamlined in many ways. There is no more bullet types (instead of 3 per gun) , the gun variety is lacking, there is a carrying capacity of 2 guns (instead of no limit), the upgrades felt mostly insignificant, the amount of customization with upgrades is severely limited, the vigors(plasmids) felt tacked on, the more interesting vigors are found way too late into the game and vigor upgrades felt mostly insignificant. The gunplay was alright but because of there are no more bullet types and a lack of gun variety the enemies are also handled the same way every time so there is no more strategy to maximise bullet efficiency or how to approach tougher enemies. Another issue is how it's basically going from one arena to the other, most of the combat is the player entering an area which gets locked up until everything is dead with as little exploration or down time as possible in-between. There is also no more hacking and there is a lack of interactions with vigors and the environment. It's not too unbearable and I can still find some enjoyment out of it but it's certainly a letdown. 

Some positives for gameplay are the tears that can sort of summon allies, supplies or an environmental element to help in combat and the sky-lines were fun to make fights more fast paced in large areas.

Overall, I think it's worth playing and can recommend it but be aware that it's noticeably different from Bioshock 1 and 2 if you had a lot of love for them you might get a little homesick but if you can overcome that there is a fun experience to be had.
